parking.directions: From Fertile 1 mile S on MN Hwy 32, then 0.5 mile W on Sand Hill Rd (450th St SW). Park in lot on S.

name: Agassiz Dunes SNA

wildflower.cname: New England and heath aster hybrid

description:
At its maximum, the Glacial Lake Agassiz was larger in surface area than all the present-day Great Lakes combined. Glacial Lake Agassiz began draining roughly 8,500 years ago, leaving a scattering of relic lakes and distinctive landforms. The story of this vast lake continues to unfold at Agassiz Dunes SNA.

The site's hallmark feature is its dunefield, comprised of sediments that originally accumulated here as a delta where the Sand River entered Lake Agassiz. Sculpted by wind over centuries, the landscape remains a work in progress, with fossil dunes, younger secondary dunes and modern blowouts.

An interesting mix of vegetation reflects the local conditions of this dune environment as well as the larger context of the site's location on the state's prairie/forest border. Bur oaks feature in two dominant plant communities: dry barrens oak savanna and bur oak aspen forest. Short grass prairie covers low dunes, and prescribed burns are restoring tallgrass prairie in open areas. Rare plants include Indian ricegrass (MN endangered), annual skeletonweed and beach heather (both MN threatened). The site is also a refuge for rare wildlife, including Western (plains) hognose and gopher (bull) snakes, both MN special concern species.

Through the rustling grasses, visitors can listen for vesper sparrows, rare upland sandpipers and lark sparrows. Late summer brings blooming blazing stars, purple coneflowers, sunflowers. Any season, keep watch for a white-tailed jackrabbit in brown or winter white, a bounding blur through the dunes.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Dogs (only when used for hunting, must be under control).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Canby 2  miles SE on MN 68, then 6.7 miles E on County Road 29 (becomes D6/200th Ave), then 0.8 miles S on County Road D7 (270th St) Park in pull-off on W.

name: Antelope Valley SNA
description:
An especially unique feature of Antelope Valley is the occurrence of wet saline prairie, found in low areas where mineral salts accumulate at the soil surface. As described in the Minnesota Biological Survey (MBS) report, Native Plant Communities and Rare Species of the Minnesota River Valley, remnants of wet saline prairies are extremely rare in the Minnesota River valley region. They were documented by MBS only within broad, shallow drainages in the nearly level, rolling till plain of western Yellow Medicine County.

Areas of wet saline prairie here are characterized by grasses such as little bluestem, switchgrass and prairie cordgrass, and flowering plants such as heath aster, western ragweed and Canada goldenrod. Two saline prairie plant species very rarely seen in southern Minnesota have also been documented: Hall's sedge and plains bluegrass (Poa arida). Both are Great Plains species that reach the eastern end of their distribution in western Minnesota.

While most of this site is ranked as having high biodiversity significance, the 40-acre former hay meadow in the southeastern corner of the site contains the highest quality prairie. Management of this SNA will focus on control of invasive Russian olive, restoration of degraded areas with native prairie seed, and reintroduction of prescribed fire.

This SNA is part of a string of public conservation lands that include the Upper, Middle, and Lower Antelope Valley WMAs. A low-lying area dominated by wetlands, the valley has its origins in the retreat of the last continental ice sheet from the third (so-called Antelope) moraine, one of a series of 12 mapped in Minnesota. The name recalls a time when the range of pronghorn extended as far east as the Mississippi River.

While an errant antelope could conceivably wander across the border from the Dakotas, visitors are better advised to keep an ear tuned for the "wolf whistle" song of Upland Sandpipers, who have been observed here during their breeding season. In a profile of the species, MBS ornithologist Steve Stucker describes the Upland Sandpiper as one of the "quintessential birds of the prairie." It's one of only a few sandpiper species that nest in the state, and (unlike most sandpipers, which are associated with aquatic habitats) is terrestrial. Listen while you can, between April and August, since by September they'll be gone—headed back to their South American wintering grounds. Fortunately, Antelope Valley SNA will be here for their return.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Lake Wobegon Trail).
Deer hunting only allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Avon 1.4 miles W on Co Hwy 54, then 1.8 miles N on Tower Rd, then 0.5 mile W on Quaker Rd. Park on S road shoulder. Hike S into woods of site.
From Avon 1.5 miles SW on Co Rd 9, then 1 mile S on Kalla Lake Rd, then 0.5 mile E on Schuman Lake Rd. Park in pull-off (field) on N. No parking along Schuman Lake Rd.

name: Avon Hills Forest SNA
description:
This 350-acre SNA lies in the heart of central Minnesota's 65,000-acre Avon Hills region. The region is known for its constellation of high value natural and cultural features within the rolling terrain of the St. Croix Moraine.

The two units of the SNA are characterized by classic kettle and kame topography which supports extensive hardwood forest. The landscape dotted with wet depressions, pot holes and lakes. Uplands are dominated by mesic oak forest, while lowland plant communities feature tamarack swamp and black ash seepage swamp.

In a 2009 study of 41 SNAs, Avon Hills Forest SNA ranked highest in state-designated species in greatest conservation need: many of which rely on the SNA's interior forest conditions (large, intact tracts). Notable birds include cerulean warbler, red-shouldered hawk, veery and blue-winged warbler. Wide-ranging mammals-timber wolves, black bear, fisher-are reported in the vicinity and may utilize habitat here as well.

Any season merits a visit: early spring for neo-tropical migrant songbirds establishing nesting territories or refueling for journeys farther north; fall for seasonal color in the oaks, maples, birch and tamarack; or, as local resident Kenzie Cotty (age 12) writes , "If you want to believe that anything is possible, you should go take a walk in the Avon Hills in winter as the snow falls."

Selective acquisitions for SNAs and other public lands, citizen advocacy, voluntary conservation easements on private lands, and a conservation district established with Stearns County zoning are all contributing to a positive outlook for the natural features of Avon Hills in this rapidly urbanizing region.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From the Badoura State Forest Nursery office at the junction of MN Hwys 64 and 87, 1.5 miles E on 140th St. Park at gate on N.

name: Badoura Jack Pine Woodland SNA
description:
Badoura Jack Pine Woodland is one of the largest examples of a mature jack pine woodland community represented on an SNA. The only other site, LaSalle Lake SNA, suffered the loss of most of its mature jack pine in a 2012 windstorm. These woodlands are considered critically imperiled in Minnesota, and globally rare.

This native jack pine woodland is rooted in the flat terrain of a sandy outwash plain. It's an even-aged stand, originating when the heat of a major wildfire in 1959 caused the cones of mature jack pines to open and release a profusion of seeds. Carried by wind or simple gravity, many of these seeds then germinated in the fire-exposed sand.

Jack pines have a close and positive relationship with fire. The cones of the jack pines are serotinous (coated in resin) and need sufficient heat to fully open. Fire also is part of the natural disturbance regime for these forests, maintaining conditions that favor the jack pine over other species. Accordingly, periodic prescribed burns will likely be among the management tools used here.

Impressive as it now is, this 390-acre native jack pine woodland was twice its current size in the recent past. Shortly before SNA designation in 2014, trees from roughly half of the site were removed in a clear-cut harvest. Part of the cleared area (166 acres) was planted in jack pine seedlings and the remainder left unplanted. In the years ahead, management will focus on promoting natural regeneration of the jack pine forest throughout the cleared area.

Visitors here will appreciate the relatively open aspect of the jack pine woodland with its beautiful understory of blueberries, bearberry and snowberry, along with prairie species such as hoary puccoon and heart-leaved alexander. This is also an important location for native Hill's thistle with its fist-sized violet blooms.

Birders hoping for a glimpse of the federally endangered Kirtland's Warbler may some day spot one here. Once known to nest only in jack pine forests of Michigan, in recent years they have been reported nesting in Wisconsin and Canada. Here at Badoura, when and if they should ever appear, it would likely be among the younger, up and coming jack pines, since the Kirtland’s favor so-called "dog's hair" stands of even-aged trees between 6 and 22 years of old.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is adjacent to Badoura State Forest.

parking.directions: From Read's Landing 1 mile NW on US Hwy 61. Park in pull-off on N. Hike about 400 feet W, then across Hwy 61 S and into site.

name: Bald Eagle Bluff SNA
description:
Bald Eagle Bluff protects key roosting habitat for eagles over-wintering near the mouth of Lake Pepin, where the in-flowing Chippewa River keeps the water open year-round.

By day, the birds utilize adjacent trees to perch on and harvest fish from the open water, supplemented by carrion foraged from surrounding uplands. During the long winter nights, the mature, oak-dominated forest on the slopes of the SNA offer a sheltered roost site.

The general area represents one of only four winter roost sites along Minnesota's Upper Mississippi River Valley for eagles that remain in the area rather than migrate farther south. While numbers vary with the severity of the winter, monitoring over the past 15 years on the SNA has documented single-day counts of between 20 and 70 wintering birds.

Birds may be seen throughout the winter months, with greatest concentrations in late February and early March when over-wintering eagles are joined by returning migrants. Travelers along U.S. 61 who stop at pull-outs will see eagles soaring above the river, on the ice at the water's edge, and perched in tall, "super-canopy" trees in the SNA and on the far shore. Wait long enough, and see one snag a fish in its talons, repeating a ritual that has happened along this river long before there were people to watch it.

Although populations have bounced back from serious declines in the 1970s, the bald eagle remains a special concern species in Minnesota.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.The Mississippi River Water Trail is adjacent to this site. This site is an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: Waterfowl hunting only allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: In Orr, from US Hwy 53 150 feet W on Johnson Pkwy. Park in water access on N. Site is about 5 miles W in Pelican Lake. Accessible by boat.

From Orr 1.5 miles S on US Hwy 53, then 13 miles W on Co Hwy 23 (Nett Lake Rd), then 1.75  miles E on Co Rd 514 (E Nett Lake Rd), then continue 0.5 mile E to water access and park. Site is 2 miles E in Pelican Lake. Accessible by boat.

name: Big Island SNA
description:
At Big Island SNA you can see what nature can accomplish given enough time to invest. The island, located within Pelican Lake, has escaped significant disturbance by fire or humans for over 150 years. It hosts a variety of old-growth communities , including hardwood-conifer forest and aspen-birch forest, both of which are seldom known to attain old-growth status. Individual trees display splendid forms: imagine gnarled, 190 year-old paper birch with broad trunks and a thick mass of scrolling bark very different from their more familiar, younger counterparts seen elsewhere in the state.

In many ways, the forest composition is similar to what one might expect on the shore of Lake Michigan. Basswood, bur oak, and old-growth white spruce make up a large portion of the canopy. Balsam fir thrives in recent blow-downs, and a band of lowland conifer swamp with black spruce, tamarack, and white cedar extends across the island's mid-section. Uplands feature dry, rocky outcrops and areas of mesic (moderately moist) soil carpeted in ferns, bishop's cap, sarsaparilla, buttercup, sweet cicely, and violets. Standing dead trees (snags) and downed logs in various stages of decay enhance habitat for wildlife.

Pileated woodpeckers drum and call as they work the snags. Ruffed grouse winter here and at least 40 bird species are summer residents. Active osprey nests occupy birch snags and 100' tall white spruce in the island's interior; bald eagles favor the large white pine along the western shore. Over three miles of undeveloped shoreline, an increasingly rare feature on this popular recreational lake, provides spawning habitat for black crappie, bluegill and smallmouth bass.

Invaluable, irreplaceable: with its old-growth communities, Big Island SNA is a present-day refuge for wildlife, a living archive for research into the past, and a reservoir of genetic diversity for the future.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Holyoke 2 miles S and E on Co Rd 145, then E (left) and 5 miles S on Harlis Rd, then 4.3 miles S (right) on Gandy Dancer Trail - watch for ATV traffic. Park on E (left) shoulder near old railroad buildings.

name: Black Lake Bog SNA
description:
Black Lake Bog is one of the nation's few interstate natural areas with 1,414 acres in the Nemadji State Forest of Pine County, MN and 2,009 acres in adjacent Douglas County, WI. In his essay “Luminaries of the Bog,” Paul Gruchow wrote of this place: “On the late September day I spent there, a deeper silence reigned that I can remember hearing in any remote wilderness.”

A dozen native plant communities have been documented on the Minnesota side of this vast and relatively undisturbed wetland complex, which occurs at the southern extent of peatlands in the state. Roughly half the site is occupied by a subtype of northern open bog, a plant community characterized by high hummocks of Sphagnum moss and ericaceous shrubs such as leatherleaf, Labrador tea, bog laurel and bog rosemary. Tree cover is sparse here, with tamarack and stunted black spruce. Also well-represented is northern poor fen, which —unlike the raised bog—has access to some mineral-rich runoff and groundwater, and is therefore able to support species such as bog birch and white beak rush. Communities present in lesser amounts include, black ash swamp, willow-dogwood shrub swamp, and aspen-ash forest, the last of which occurs on islands and the site's limited upland acreage.

At its heart is 84-acre Black Lake, which straddles the MN/WI border. This shallow, acidic lake and surrounding wetlands are the source of the Black River, a tributary to the Nemadji River, which flows north to Lake Superior.

Large expanses of the SNA are virtually inaccessible for practical purposes, with wet, irregular terrain and alder thicket, making for slow going by foot in any season. For the most part, native plants and wildlife go about their lives unseen. Over the years, site managers and researchers across the 3,426-acre natural area have spotted timber wolves and moose, pine marten and lynx, rare LeConte's sparrows, yellow-bellied flycatchers, and the ground-nesting short-eared owl with its moth-like flight. Seventeen species of dragonflies have been documented, among them the white-faced Meadowhawk, Beaverpond Baskettail and Harlequin Darner.

Those who venture here in fall will find a uniquely peatland palette: the tamaracks turned briefly gold before their needles drop, bright red cranberries and winterberries, even sphagnum moss going from summer green to shades of burgundy and rose. Along the Gandy Dancer Trail, one may more easily see wood thrushes and other migrants as the trees lose their leaves, or, with luck, the occasional Northern harrier winging low and slow over the wetlands.

But whether or not one ever sees this SNA in person, it is rewarding to know that we, as citizens, have together protected this natural area as a fine expression of peatlands at the southern extent of their range in the state, habitat for rare plant and animal species along with pitcher plants, sundews, and other “familiar faces” of native bog vegetation.

* Access in Minnesota is along the eastern edge of the SNA via the old Soo Line railroad grade, which is now part of the state Gandy Dancer Trail. A GPS is useful for navigation as one approaches the general area, which is sparsely populated and crisscrossed by unmarked, minimum-maintenance roads of the Nemadji State Forest. Note that this northern section of the Gandy Dancer is open to ATVs, off-highway motorcycles and off-road vehicles. Periodic flooding can make sections of the route range from adventuresome to impassible (even in fall). Cell signal is unreliable to nonexistent, and (with the exception of deer hunting season when blaze orange is wise), passerby can be few. In other words, in the best of conditions, a visit here is not to be approached lightly.
notes:
Harlis Road is impassible due to washouts. See the Nemadji State Forest for updates. The site can be accessed from the south by following these directions: from Cloverton, 5.4 miles N on CR 31 (Kingsdale Rd) to Belden Road (stay right at T, road will curve E then N again). Turn W (left) at second T, and follow 0.1 where road curves N. Follow as road crosses over to the left and continue 7.7 miles to old shelter along trail next to SNA sign. The road does merge with the Gandy Dancer State Trail. Note: this area has numerous forest trails and other access roads. When in doubt, follow the maintained gravel road.
A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Gandy Dancer State Trail and Nemadji State Forest are adjacent to this site

parking.directions: In Blaine, from I-35W exit at 95th Ave (Co Rd 52), then 0.25 mile W on 95th/Raddison Rd, then 0.25 mile N on Naples St NE. Park on E in park and ride lot. Hike 500 feet N, crossing Naples St, to site on W. This site is open by research permit only.

name: Blaine Airport Rich Fen SNA
description:
What happens when a site of high biodiversity significance with endangered species is discovered at an airport with 76,000 takeoffs and landings annually? In the case of this SNA, a perpetual conservation easement dedicated by the Metropolitan Airports Commission creates opportunity for co-existence. This SNA was created in 2007 as part of a mitigation agreement to account for loss of rare species impacted by airport expansion.

Three state-listed species have been documented on the 47.9-acre site: tubercled rein-orchid and marginated rush (both endangered) and lance-leaved violet (threatened). These occur in the context of an interconnected complex of wetland communities, with characteristics of wet prairie, sedge meadow, rich fen and marsh. The fen for which the site is named is a sedge-dominated open wetland community characterized by a shallow peat layer, hosting such species as wiregrass sedge, bog birch and sundew. The remainder (and majority) of the SNA is vegetated in oak woodland with a mix of pin oak and quaking aspen, which continues onto adjacent airport-owned land along the southern border of the site.

Management here is focused on limiting encroachment by woody species such as buckthorn and aspen, regenerating native plant communities through controlled burns, and maintaining natural buffer areas to protect the integrity of the site from the impacts of surrounding development. In particular, it is important to limit alterations to the site's sensitive hydrology caused by concentrated stormwater run-off and/or inputs from dewatering of adjacent land. Invasion of wetlands by reed canary grass is also an ongoing concern, requiring regular monitoring and selective controls as needed to protect the SNA's rare native species.

This remains private land, and for reasons of airport security is not open to the public. Under the conditions of the easement, limited access for research and educational purposes is allowed by permit.

One such permit was issued for an Army Corps of Engineers study in which the wetland complex here was used as a classic example of its type, enabling researchers to field test and fine tune a model designed to assess the condition and functions of “organic flats” wetlands in Minnesota and Wisconsin. Steve Eggers participated in the research and co-authored the resulting guidebook. He notes: “SNAs are vitally important, serving as ‘reference standards’ for the least-disturbed examples of particular plant community/habitat types in the least-disturbed landscapes.” It's a key value of SNAs: providing a baseline for comparison, understanding and management of other sites.

Most of us will not have the opportunity to visit this site in person. But those with an interest may wish to explore nearby Blaine Preserve SNA, which is part of the same wetland complex and displays a similar mosaic of native plant communities.
notes: Sanctuary (open by research permit only).

parking.directions: In Blaine, from I-35W exit at 95th Ave (Co Rd 52), then 0.5 mile E on 95th/Lovell Rd, then 0.25 mile S on Hamline Ave. Then 0.1 mile W into Lexington Memorial Park. Park and hike N into site.

name: Blaine Preserve SNA
description:
The journey that led to this site's 2013 dedication as an SNA began in 1997 when Jason Husveth took his dogs for a walk in a Blaine city park and spotted a plant that hadn't been documented in the state for 30 years. An ecologist by training and trade, it's not surprising that he recognized the rare twisted yellow-eyed grass, but even Husveth could not have foreseen what would follow.

Spurred by this initial finding, subsequent comprehensive inventories of surrounding areas by Husveth, DNR botanists and a host of others over the next 15 years eventually led to discovery of the site along I-35W destined to become the Blaine Preserve SNA.

This 63-acre preserve contains the best remaining example of a vast complex of wet prairies and rich fens that existed in association with the Anoka Sand Plain at the time of Minnesota's original land survey (circa 1850). Its biodiversity value is astounding: the site contains 13 species of rare plants (7 of which are state-endangered, 4 MN-threatened and 2 MN-special concern) and fully 12% of the species that comprise Minnesota's native flora, some of which have not been documented in the state in 100 years. The predominant native plant community containing most of the site's rarest plants is a Graminoid Rich Fen, represented here by a low-lying wetland characterized by sedges growing in peat.

"This is a truly special place, even when considered in the context and with the high standards of Scientific and Natural Areas," notes Husveth. "It's near and dear to my heart, a place I have spent many hundreds of hours researching, studying, restoring, and just simply enjoying." The best time to visit? "Given the floristic diversity, there is always something in peak flower from mid-April to mid-September. Nonetheless, most would agree that the Prairie Blazing Star (Liatris pycnostachya) provide the most spectacular display within the wet prairie transitions that are interspersed throughout the SNA, especially in the years following a prescribed burn. This profusion of purple flowers typically begins in late July and peaks in the first week of August, and this display is accented by the many late season asters and flowering meadowsweets (Spirea alba and S. tomentosa) as well."

Spoken like a true botanist. Just go.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Barnesville 8 miles E on MN Hwy 34, then 1 mile N on MN Hwy 32, then 1 mile E on 147th Ave, then 0.75 mile N on 280th St. Park in lot on E.

name: Blanket Flower Prairie SNA
description:
Blanket Flower Prairie straddles the ecotone between the prairies to the west and the eastern deciduous forest. Hill's thistle (Minnesota special concern) and sky-blue aster are found here at the western edge of their range, while Hooker's oat-grass and blanket flower (both listed as Minnesota special concerns) are at their eastern most distribution. Dry prairie dominates the upper slopes of the rolling hills with mesic prairie in low areas interspersed with small groves of aspen.

Spring through fall, watch for horned larks flying low over the grasses, the air filled with their high, ringing songs. Find the SNA's namesake native wildflower blooming in June and July with showy yellow petals and deep red/purple centers, listed as a state special concern species due in part to habitat loss related to gravel mining. As the growing season unfolds, the slopes host pasqueflowers, purple prairie clover, dotted blazing star and silky aster blooming among the native grasses with their own distinctive, delicate forms: prairie dropseed, blue grama grass, porcupine grass.

The research and educational purposes of SNAs are well represented by the Minnesota Dragonfly Society, which has used this site to engage citizen scientists in surveys of Minnesota's dragonfly and damselfly populations; and also by the students from the Natural Resources Management Club at North Dakota State University, who volunteer their time as site stewards. Ongoing management focuses on reconstruction of old fields to prairie vegetation with native seed collected from within the site.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site is designated as the Ole Huseby Homestead Unit. Ole was an early settler of this land. In 2011, four additional parcels of land were acquired to expand this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Granite Falls, 0.2 mile S on MN Hwy 23, then 0.15 mile W on Co Hwy 39 (540th St). Park in pull-off on N near wood-routed sign.

name: Blue Devil Valley SNA
description:
The namesake "blue devil" of this site is fully grown at 5-8 inches, has a bright blue tail as a juvenile, an identifying "Y" pattern on its head and back, and is inclined to do a quick set of push-ups when disturbed. At the edge of its range in Minnesota, the five-lined skink is the rarest of our three lizard species, this site hosting one of the state's largest known populations. The granite outcrop here that the skinks favor for basking-a key habitat element used to regulate body temperature-is itself an increasingly rare natural feature.

Many such outcroppings in the Minnesota River Valley exposed by torrents of Glacial River Warren have been lost to mining and are truly irreplaceable, their value not only in the raw material of the 3.6 billion year-old rock, but in the living community arising in association with it. In what seems a harsh environment-with rock radiating heat from summer sun, and a scarcity of soil limiting the ability to hold moisture-xeric prairie species such as the brittle prickly pear cacti thrive. Visitors will find harebell, little bluestem, pasque flowers in early spring, and cacti blooming in summer. Listen for the rustle of leaves at the base of the outcroppings, which may reveal a skink foraging for insects.

A relatively small site flanked by busy roads, this SNA speaks to the exquisite vulnerability of native species like the five-lined skink-whose existence is now prescribed within such isolated areas-and the challenges of maintaining a measure of Minnesota's biological diversity in a changing world.

Stewardship focuses largely on removing buckthorn. A little time is also devoted to other invasive species such as birds-foot trefoil, crown vetch, leafy spurge, dame's rocket, black locust and Siberian elm.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

Rock climbing for sport, including bouldering, is not allowed on Scientific and Natural Areas. Bouldering promoted at Blue Devil Valley and Swedes Forest Scientific and Natural Areas on various websites and guidebooks is in violation of state law, please do not boulder at these sites.

parking.directions: From Moorhead 11 miles E on US Hwy 10, then 3 miles S on MN Hwy 9, then 3.5 miles E and N on Co Hwy 12. Park in lot on N as road turns E.
From Moorhead 11 miles E on US Hwy 10, then 1 mile S on MN Hwy 9, then 1.5 miles E on 17th Ave S. Park in lot on N.

name: Bluestem Prairie SNA
description:
The sound of spring at Bluestem Prairie SNA is a low, thrumming boom resonating across the flatlands and shoreline ridges left by Glacial Lake Agassiz. Visitors willing to rise before dawn can reserve their spot in a blind to see its source: male greater prairie chickens vying for the chance to pass along their genes to the next generation.

This is one of the most significant northern tallgrass prairie sites in the nation. Like a set of nested cups, the 1,310-acre SNA lies within the 6,568+ acre Bluestem Preserve owned by The Nature Conservancy, itself within a 23,600+ acre critical core area identified in the state's Prairie Conservation Plan.

In 1842, Charles Dickens famously dismissed the tallgrass prairie landscape as "the great blank;" but those who (unlike Dickens) leave their coaches to explore this prairie will find it brimming with life. Uplands host mesic tallgrass prairie, and low swales contain wet black-soil prairie with sedge meadow and calcareous fen. Rare species include the small white lady's-slipper, regal frittilary butterfly, prairie vole, and plains pocket mouse. Among more than 115 bird species are Wilson's Phalarope, Henslow's sparrow, marbled godwit and loggerhead shrike.

Find Bluestem Prairie is in bloom from the first pasqueflower of April to the last gentian of September. Any season, students and fans of the earth sciences will also appreciate the subtle escarpments of the Norcross and Campbell Strandlines, marking historic levels of Glacial Lake Agassiz and offering insight into the region's past.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site is owned by The Nature Conservancy and is partially within Buffalo River State Park.
notes: This site has no maintained trails. Recreational facilities available in Buffalo River State Park. Blinds for viewing the prairie chickens' courtship behavior in April are available by reservation through The Nature Conservancy Bluestem Prairie office (218) 498-2679. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Grand Rapids 2 miles NW on US Hwy 2, then 3.5 miles W on Co Rd 63, then 3.5 miles SW on Co Rd 17, then 1.5 miles S on Co Rd 459, then 0.25 mile W on Co Rd 458 (N Sugar Lake Rd). Park in water access on S. Site is 1.25 miles SW in Siseebakwet Lake.

name: Boltuck-Rice Forever Wild SNA
description:
This SNA protects the only large, undeveloped parcel of land with frontage on Itasca County's Siseebakwet* ("Sugar") Lake. Uplands are dominated by northern hardwood forest, with mature sugar maple, basswood and yellow birch. Near the lake and in lowlands are smaller areas of northern wet cedar forest, black ash swamp and tamarack swamp. A 1-mile stretch of shoreline hosts the only significant wetland vegetation remaining on the lake shore.

Protection of this natural area, like many land conservation efforts in the state, has been long in the making. Together, sisters Mary Boltuck and Jeanne Rice entered into a conservation easement with the state on the property more than 20 years ago, donating the majority of the easement's value. In 2011, they and their families donated the remaining interest in the land to the DNR for designation as an SNA, with the intention that it would remain forever wild.

A story by Margaret Haapoja in the Sept/Oct 1995 issue of the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer captured Mary Boltuck's perspective at the time the easement was established: "Each time we walk in the woods we're absolutely convinced that this is the right thing to do. The idea that when we're gone—and 150 years from now— this place will still be the same way is a fantastic thing to think about." Jeanne's husband, Howard Rice, added: "Unless we take steps to protect shoreline… we won't have the loons, ospreys, eagles, and fish we have now." The site also protects landforms of geologic interest. Between the lake and a large cedar swamp is a series of narrow, steep-sided ridges and intervening swales (depressions) running parallel to the shore. Covered in vegetation, these ridges are approximately 6' high and as wide as 26 feet. According to Dr. Howard Mooers, Professor of Earth and Environmental Sciences at the University of Minnesota Duluth, these are examples of "ice-push ridges" which—while not uncommon in Minnesota—are often disturbed by lakeshore development. As Mooers explains, these ridges typically form in late winter, when lake ice expands due to solar radiation or a rise in temperature, pushing off-shore and near-shore sediment inland. They can also be formed by wind-driven ice.

Here, the series of ridges is closely nested. Those nearest the shore formed more recently, while more inland ridges reflect earlier periods of higher lake level. "Together," notes Mooers, "they provide an excellent example of the morphology of these features and provide a record of lake level lowering throughout the Holocene."

With their steep slopes and sandy soils, the ridges and their wetter swales now support an interesting mix of native vegetation that adds to the diversity of the site. Please take care when visiting to avoid disturbing this vegetation, which may lead to erosion.

The Boltuck and Rice families have done what they could to preserve this remarkable place. Now it's our turn.

*The name Siseebakwet is derived from the Ojibwe ziinzibaakwad (sugar), and is a reference to a small maple sugar camp inhabited by the tribe here in the 1800s. Today, local residents and establishments refer to lake variously as Sugar Lake and Siseebakwet Lake.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from the Boltuck and Rice families.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Ortonville 19 miles NW on MN Hwy 7, then 1.4 miles W and N on 320th St into Big Stone Lake State Park (Bonanza Unit). Park at Education Center and hike E to site.

name: Bonanza Prairie SNA
description:
For visitors to Big Stone Lake State Park, the off-trail climb to the top of the hill on Bonanza Prairie SNA is rewarded by spectacular views across Big Stone Lake and the South Dakota plains beyond. There is a timeless quality to this blufftop vista: the sight of the broad valley carved by the outflow of Glacial Lake Agassiz, the lake below—source of the Minnesota River—and the understanding that this was home to Native Americans long before the arrival of Europeans.

Traveling with the Stephen H. Long Expedition in 1823, artist Samuel Seymour depicted this landscape in a watercolor titled “Native American encampment at Big Stone Lake.” According to Long’s account,* the expedition met up here with the Wahkpatoan tribe of the Dacota nation, people whose descendants would be among the present day Sisseton Wahpeton Oyate tribe. Long describes being hosted by the tribe as they journeyed northward along the lake's shore, sharing meals of buffalo and mashed prairie turnip, a plant still found here at Bonanza Prairie SNA.

Today, the steep slopes with their droughty, gravelly soils support a high-quality remnant of dry hill prairie, along with lesser amounts of dry-mesic prairie and bur oak savanna communities. Dry hill prairie offers important habitat to a number of increasingly rare, “prairie obligate” butterflies with very specific requirements for reproduction. Bonanza Prairie has been among roughly a dozen sites in the state monitored by the Minnesota Biological Survey for the presence of these species, which have experienced an alarming decline across the state. In the 1980s, MBS surveyor Robert Dana observed Poweshiek skipperling, Dakota skipper, and Ottoe skipper here. But surveys of the SNA in 2013-2015 looking for 13 target species documented only the Regal fritillary as present.

Throughout the growing season, visitors will enjoy the forbs and grasses of this fine prairie, with big and little bluestem, grama grasses, prairie thistle, purple coneflower, silverleaf scurfpea, as well as rare prairie moonwort, Missouri milk-vetch and slender milk-vetch. In summer, birders can scan the prairie slopes for bluebirds and bobolinks, and watch American white pelicans soar above the lake with their 9- foot wingspans. One of the state's two critical breeding colonies of this species is located on nearby Marsh Lake. Late autumn will bring an occasional Harris sparrow passing through en route from its Canadian breeding grounds to wintering grounds in the central Great Plains.

Stewardship work here has focused on removal of boxelder and ash, along with prescribed burning on a rotating basis. Future plans include restoration of former crop fields on the hilltop.

Note that Big Stone Lake State Park has three separate units, the SNA found in the most northerly of the three.

* Long's narrative runs the gamut. Of the “Dacota,” (though not speaking their language) he presumes to write, “Their faces are faithful indices to the equanimity of their souls,” while he characterizes Big Stone Lake as “an expansion of the river improperly called a lake.”
notes: This site has no maintained trails. Recreational facilities available in Big Stone Lake State Park. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From MN Hwy 65 in Bethel 6.5 miles E and N on Co Hwy 22, then 1.2 miles E on Co Rd 17 and N on Jodrell St NE. Park on in pull-off on W.

name: Boot Lake SNA
description:
Designated in 1980, this site became an SNA in the early years of the program, and today remains one of the larger SNAs within the Twin Cities 7-county metro area. It protects the entirety of 92-acre Boot Lake and its undeveloped shoreline, along with surrounding uplands featuring beautiful white pine-hardwood forest and oak forest. At the outlet of the lake, a small stream flows northward through an open wetland on shallow peat that supports alder swamp, rich fen, and wet meadow. A small, peat-filled basin near the southeast corner of the SNA hosts a tamarack swamp with a carpet of sphagnum moss.

The lake and peat-filled depressions lie within a tunnel valley system created when this area was covered with glacial ice more than 12,000 years ago. As described by legendary U of MN professor Herb Wright, tunnel valleys are "wide stream-cut trenches, now filled with lakes, swamps, and… streams, pictured as the products of high-velocity streams in subglacial tunnels, driven by the great hydrostatic pressure resulting from the thick mass of still-active ice." Boot Lake is part of a chain of so-called ice block lakes within this tunnel valley system, formed when large pieces of a glacier broke away and were covered by a dome of insulating till that later collapsed when the ice melted.

Through the years, this SNA has been habitat and home for a rich mix of native plant and animal species, including the Common Loon, Blanding's turtle, Louisiana Waterthrush and snowshoe hare. Birds of the boreal forest such as the Nashville Warbler and Pine Warbler are attracted to the white pines around Boot Lake, and wild rice in the lake attracts waterfowl in autumn. Sandhill Cranes are sometimes seen and often heard, given their regular use of the Carlos Avery Wildlife Management area just east of the SNA.

Along forest edges near wetlands, watch for plants such as the blue-bead lily, ground-cedar, blueberry and huckleberry. In late September, as the red maples are turning, look for bright red fruits of the winterberry shrubs. Note that parts of this SNA are posted as a sanctuary and closed to the public in the interest of protecting red-shouldered hawk nest sites. As visitors familiar with this site may know, a 2017 storm took down two bald eagle nest sites that were formerly within a sanctuary area of the SNA.

The Anoka Conservation District (ACD) is assisting with control of invasive species here. In 2016/2017, ACD began efforts to eradicate glossy buckthorn in a 26.5-acre wetland containing native water-willow, a state-listed special concern species. This tall, graceful plant is associated with shoreline habitats, where it may be seen arching over the water with slender leaves and clusters of purple flowers aligned along stems approaching 6 feet in length.

The water-willow could be considered a marker for one of the most important and increasingly rare natural features protected by this SNA: undeveloped shoreline. In this Land of 10,000 Lakes, undeveloped shoreline makes an important contribution to water quality, a healthy fishery, and habitat for native species.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift dedicated as the Janet & Arthur Hartwell Memorial.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Carlos Avery Wildlife Managment Area and Martin-Island-Lynwood Lakes Regional Park are adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From Grand Rapids 10 miles N on MN Hwy 38, then 0.8 mile W on Co Rd 244. Park on road shoulder near wood-routed sign on S.

name: Botany Bog SNA
description:
Botany Bog was recognized by the DNR Natural Heritage program as an ecologically important site as early as 1970. Plant surveys had revealed a concentration of rare peatland species here, including the small white water lily, montane yellow-eyed grass and olive-brown spike rush. At the time, few occurrences of these species were known in the state, none of which were on land owned/managed for conservation.

Nearly half a century later, these species are still ranked among the state's rarest plants. Fortunately, the status of the site changed in 1990 when 132 acres were acquired for SNA designation.

Most of the site is open to the sky. The bog surrounds two bodies of water: a small pond and a shallow lake that connects the SNA's northern and southern sections. Watch for the trademark plants of the bog: scattered tamarack trees; low shrubs such as bog rosemary, leatherleaf and small cranberry; the forbs (flowering plants) such as pitcher plant and three-leaved false Solomon's seal; and grasses/sedges including tussock and tawny cottongrass, and three-seeded bog sedge.

Small upland areas of the site are densely forested in black spruce and jack pine. In this comparatively nutrient-rich environment, the understory is a different story altogether, with such familiar woodland wildflowers as wild ginger, jack-in-the-pulpit, starflower and blue-bead lily.

Visit in early spring to listen near dusk for the "peent" of the woodcock, and witness its spiraling, feather-whirring courtship flight. Early summer, explore the bog to the "witchety-witchety-witchety" of the Common Yellowthroat and the "zee-zee-zee-zoo-zee" of the Black-throated Green Warbler. If you should spot blooming small white water lilies, take care not to disturb them. Beyond the growing season, photographers will especially appreciate the subtleties of the winter landscape and the sculptural qualities of the bog vegetation, evolved over time to thrive in this unique environmental setting.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Brownsville 1.2 miles S on MN 26, then about 100 feet S on access road. Park and hike past gate S and W into site. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Brownsville Bluff SNA
description:
This bluffland SNA overlooks the Mississippi River in Houston County in the far, southeast corner of the state. It features high relief topography characterized by oak-hickory woodland (with bur oak, shagbark hickory, American elm) on drier, more exposed, south- to west-facing bluffs, and oak-basswood forest (with basswood, northern red oak and sugar maple), on north- to northeast facing slopes. The flat to rolling blufftops, cultivated in the past, will be restored in time to prairie and/or oak savanna.

At its northern end, this rugged site adjoins and includes part of Wildcat Bluff, well known to local Brownsville residents. Early historical accounts capture the area in rapturous poetry and describe it as the "highest point along the river for miles…and a prominent landmark for early steamboat pilots."

Outcroppings of bedrock are a distinctive feature of the site, and a key reason for its SNA designation. Tony Runkel, Chief Geologist, Minnesota Geological Survey relates the origins of the bedrock underlying the bluff: "Most of the bluff is composed of Cambrian age (about 500 million years old) sandstone, siltstone and shale, laid down in a shallow sea that covered much of the continent at that time. Exposures of Wonewoc, Lone Rock and Jordan Sandstone may be seen within the SNA. Capping the bluff is the Oneota Dolomite of the Prairie du Chien Group, about 480-million years old. The Oneota is a harder rock than underlying formations, made up of dolostone. It serves as the hard, resistant cap that forms the bluff top in the SNA, as it does across much of the bluff country from Red Wing down into Iowa."

While not rare in the blufflands of the Paleozoic plateau, such rock outcroppings offer potential habitat for a number of Minnesota's native snakes including the milk snake and western fox snake. Consequently, a portion of this site is designated as a sanctuary, with access limited to permitted researchers.

Those who don't mind hills will appreciate the portion of this site open to the public. Come in spring and early summer to find wild ginger, bloodroot, Virginia waterleaf and the ethereal Indian pipe in the understory; or in fall when changing color in the oak-dominated woodlands coincides with passage of waterfowl and raptors down the Mississippi Flyway. Even if only passing by below on Minnesota Highway 26 like the trains along the adjacent Chicago Milwaukee line, look up at the exposures of bedrock and know that this SNA is doing what it is designed to do, protecting Minnesota's natural heritage.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).

See also Geologic Atlas of Houston County, Minnesota, esp. Plates 2 (bedrock) and 3 (surficial materials and glacial-related history).
notes: Sanctuary (posted sanctuary portion closed). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

parking.directions: From Brooten 3 miles W on Co Hwy 8, then 3 miles S on Co Hwy 37. Park at water access on E. Site is 1.75 miles SE in Lake Johanna. Accessible by boat. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Bruce Hitman Heron Rookery SNA
description:
This 4-acre island SNA is located on the southern end of Lake Johanna in Pope County (not to be confused with a lake of the same name in Ramsey County). Although described as a heron rookery, the island is an important colonial waterbird nesting site for a variety of species. Annual DNR surveys since the 1970s have documented a remarkable nine species nesting and/or present here during the breeding season (though not all in the same year). These have historically included Great Blue Heron, Great Egret, Cattle Egret, Snowy Egret, American White Pelican, Double-Crested Cormorant, Little Blue Heron, Black-Crowned Night Heron and Louisiana Heron.

In more recent years, there has been confirmed nesting of Double-crested Cormorant, Great Egret, American White Pelican and (to a lesser extent) Great Blue and Black-crowned Night Herons, with more than 1000 total active nests.

According to a 2016 report prepared by Dr. Francesca Cuthbert and Derek Hamiliton of the University of Minnesota Department of Fisheries, Wildlife and Conservation Biology, the relatively high elevation of the island (10-12 feet above the water level) may contribute to the reproductive success of birds nesting here, making them less vulnerable to changes in water level than at other colonial waterbird nest sites in the state.

Not surprisingly, colonial waterbirds are notoriously tough on woody vegetation, both directly and indirectly. Island soils, already thin, become more acid from the guano of thousands of birds concentrated in one area for months. According to DNR Nongame Wildlife Technician Bruce Lenning, standing trees—living or dead—are becoming increasingly scarce on the island. This has meant a corresponding increase in relative numbers of ground-nesting species (such as cormorants and pelicans) over tree-nesters (herons and egrets).

The site is named for ornithologist and researcher Bruce Hitman who first observed the island's birds in 1965 and undertook repeated surveys in the following years. Hitman's dedication is clear in the casual way that he describes an experience on the island in July of 1970. Writing for the Minnesota Ornithologists' Journal, The Loon,* he notes: "After several hours of concealing myself in the 8-foot high stinging nettle, an adult Snowy Egret in adult plumage alighted on a dead branch not more than 20 feet away." A great observer, he made detailed sketches of the island showing where each species tended to concentrate and the principle vegetation in these areas, offering insight into habitat associations. His work helped establish the value of the site and supported its SNA designation in 1989.

This SNA is designated as a sanctuary and is closed to visiting from April 1 – July 15 each year. (Sorry, this includes people willing to hide in stinging nettle.) If viewing the island from the water by boat, please keep a reasonable distance that does not cause the birds to take flight, leaving their nests/young unprotected.

*Bruce Hitman, (in) "Cattle Egret, Little Blue Heron, and possible Snowy Egret Nestings at the Lake Johanna Rookery, Pope County, Minnesota (in) The Loon, Summer 1972, Vol. 44, No. 2.
notes: Sanctuary (closed April 1 - July 15). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities

parking.directions: From Ely 6.75 miles W on MN Hwy 169, then 2.25 miles N and W on Co Hwy 404 (Wolf Lake Rd). Park at water access on N. Site is 1 mile N in Burntside Lake. Accessible by boat.

name: Burntside Islands SNA
description:
This SNA protects a chain of undeveloped, forested islands in the southwest part of Burntside Lake in Minnesota's Border Lakes Subsection. At 7,139 acres, Burntside Lake is vast and deep, its shores and many of its 150 islands (plus or minus, depending on who's counting) dotted by homes, resorts, cabins and campsites. The SNA islands complement the scenic beauty of this popular recreational lake, while protecting wildlife habitat and natural features of remarkable ecological value.

Pine Island contains a rare remnant of old-growth red and white pine forest with no known history of logging. A 1989 ecological evaluation estimated the oldest red pines here at 300 years old. Younger age classes present (including some jack pine) date from fires in 1862 and 1910. In the interior of this 15-acre acre island is a small and shady fern-walled canyon, and a dry south-facing cliff with junipers. With its range of native vegetation, University of Minnesota forest ecologist Lee Frelich observes, "It's like a tiny vignette of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness." Nearby Snellman Island was logged for pine in 1905, and today hosts mature second growth forest with a mix of white pine, spruce-fir and aspen-birch forest.

A more recent addition to the SNA, the Gaul (also called Hayes) Islands with their large white cedars anchor the eastern side of this chain. These islands are in view of Listening Point, the cabin retreat of celebrated author and conservationist Sigurd "Sig" Olson. Inspired by this landscape, Olson understood such wild places to be essential to the human spirit and culture: "We all need a listening point," he writes, "someplace of quiet where the universe can be contemplated with awe."

This SNA also protects suitable nesting habitat for Minnesota's state bird, the Common Loon, which relies on areas of undeveloped shoreline on large lakes. Burntside Lake is well known as an important breeding area for the species, and its loons have recently been the focus of scientific study. In 2011-2013, a number of adult loons from territories adjacent to the SNA islands were marked by USGS scientists using geo-tags and radio-telemetry. According to LaCrosse-based researcher Kevin Kenow, "A male loon from Burntside Lake was among those marked in Minnesota that highlighted the importance of Lake Michigan as a fall staging area, and was among 86% of Minnesota marked loons that wintered in the Gulf of Mexico." Such studies do more than illuminate understanding of the species' migratory patterns. "Since the Common Loon was one of the species injured by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill," says Kenow, "the linking of Minnesota Common Loons to the Gulf of Mexico has significance for potential remediation funds for the state." Any funds received will be directed toward conservation work on behalf of loons in Minnesota, under a restoration plan developed by the DNR Nongame Program. If you are in the vicinity of the islands in summer, enjoy hearing the tremolos or yodeling of loons at a respectful distance from the birds. Or, for an experience of a different sort, wait for the lake to freeze over and make the trek from shore by snowshoe or ski. Popular guided winter outings to the islands are occasionally offered by SNA program staff in partnership with the Ely Field Naturalists: a great way to learn about this special place.

* Minnesotans who purchased Critical Habitat license plates deserve some of the credit for the 2013 addition of the Gaul Islands to the SNA. Funding for the acquisition came in part from the Reinvest in Minnesota (RIM) critical habitat match program, which is supported by proceeds from sale of these plates.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy and the Trust for Public Lands.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Madelia 3.5 miles NE on MN Hwy 60, then 3 miles N on Co Rd 119. Park on W road shoulder.

name: Butternut Valley Prairie SNA
description:
Described by regional SNA staff Brad Bolduan as "a little jewel," this small prairie remnant showcases outstanding biodiversity with little invasion of non-native species. Never drained, cultivated, nor grazed the only regular activities included haying, seed harvest and burning which has contributed to the site's excellent condition.

The mesic prairie on the majority of the SNA includes a wide variety of native wildflowers and grasses including Indian grass, big bluestem, porcupine grass, prairie dropseed, mountain mint, golden alexanders, prairie phlox, northern plains blazing star, and silver leaf scurf pea. A wet prairie in the southeast corner includes wildflowers such as white camass, northern bog violet, and heart-leaved alexanders.

On a June walk here, keep an eye out for mating Monarchs, or the bold orange, black and white caterpillars of the buckeye butterfly. Mid- to late summer, find the deep rosy blooms of Sullivant's milkweed (a MN-threatened species) or the white blossoms of rattlesnake-master (MN-special concern) rising from the prairie on stems nearly 5' foot high. Linger until dusk to catch a prairie sunset under wide-open skies.

Ownership & Origins: Protection of this site as an SNA was recommended by Wayne Feder, a local high school teacher who often used the site as an outdoor classroom to introduce his students to the prairie ecosystem.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Grand Marais 7 miles SW on MN Hwy 61. Park in pull-off on N. Hike across Hwy 61 to site. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Butterwort Cliffs SNA
description:
Vivid orange crustose lichen drapes the bedrock shores and crowns the cliffs of this site near Grand Marais, located within Cascade River State Park. Butterwort Cliffs SNA consists of a narrow, 43-acre strip of land between Highway 61 and Lake Superior, with wet rocky shore and dry bedrock shore communities, fringed by aspen-birch forest.

In 1992, many large aspen trees within the SNA were lost in a major blowdown. While devastating in the short term to those who appreciate a mature woodland, blowdowns are part of the natural disturbance regime in the North Shore's lake terrace forest. A temporary "reset" to an earlier successional stage—if patchy and irregular across a large area—can enhance diversity. Here, the event is just a recent chapter in the long evolutionary story of the site.

This SNA was protected largely in the interest of the native plant community that occupies the areas of wave-swept rock shore and basalt cliffs. The cool, moist microclimate along the lake provides habitat for an unique assemblage of rare arctic-alpine plants including butterwort and Hudson Bay eyebright, both listed as special concern species in Minnesota. Superior's north shore is known to host at least 23 of these arctic "disjunct" species, so named because they are separated from their main ranges. As co-authors Chel Anderson and Adelheid Fischer write in their book, North Shore, these plants are "holdovers from glacial times, which became separated in some cases by more than six hundred miles from their main ranges in the Arctic tundra or in the cordilleran, or mountainous, regions of western North America."

Butterwort, for which this SNA is named, is an insectivorous plant that grows in fragile mats. Its leaves are equipped with two glands: one that secretes a sticky solution that traps insects and the other, the enzymes to digest them. It is recognized by its blue-purple flowers appearing singly on slender stems arising from a basal rosette of yellow-green leaves, often found clustered in overlapping patches. Look closely, you'll likely see insects that have met their match.

The cliffs on Egro Bay within the SNA offer nesting habitat for a Herring Gull colony as well as Peregrine Falcons. To avoid potential disturbance, the SNA is designated a sanctuary and closed to visiting each year April 1-July 15.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy dedicated as the Tom Savage Memorial to honor of Tom's long-time advocacy for protection of critical lands along the North Shore.
notes:
Sanctuary (closed April 1 - July 15). This site has no maintained trails. Recreational facilities available in Cascade River State Park.

This is a rocky coastline hemmed by trees, in places with sheer vertical drops to Lake Superior.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Effie 17 miles W on MN Hwy 1, then 5 miles NE on Co Rd 27, then 2.3 miles E on Smallpox Forest Rd. Park at opening. Trek 1.4 miles E on snowmobile trail, then 0.35 mile due north off trail to SW corner of SNA (no boundary signs). GPS recommended.

name: Caldwell Brook Cedar Swamp SNA
description:
This remote, 80-acre site within Pine Island State Forest features northern lowland white cedar forest, a community typed ranked S3 in Minnesota, or vulnerable to extirpation (destruction).

Slow growing and long-lived, northern white cedar is at the western edge of its U.S. range in Minnesota. According to University of Minnesota forest ecologist Dr. Lee Frelich, the oldest known white cedar was dated at 1650 years of age, a tree from the Bruce Peninsula in Ontario. In Minnesota the oldest well documented Northern white cedar is about 550 years—a tree cored by Frelich on Seagull Lake.* "There are definitively older trees out there," notes Frelich, "but they're hollow and can't be dated." The cedars of Caldwell Brook Cedar Swamp SNA are believed to be comparable in age to adjacent stands administered by DNR Forestry, ranging from 130-150 years. Protected within the SNA, and barring catastrophic fire or blowdown, this forest may still be alive to be enjoyed by another 16 generations of Minnesotans.

These wet cedar forests have their own style of beauty. Sinewy-barked cedars lean in all directions. Dim light filters through feathery green leaves. Lines of saplings sprout from moss-covered nursery logs, lucky if they grow three inches in a year. Northern Parula Warblers sing from the high canopy and gather strands of Usnea sp. moss (grandfather's beard lichen) for their nests. Among the hummocks and pools, wildflowers such as blue-bead lilies and star flowers open their blossoms into shade. Regional SNA Specialist AmberBeth VanNingen documented three species of orchids in the site's more southerly parcel here: showy lady's slipper, yellow lady's slipper, and the fragrant tall northern bog orchid. (Platanthera huronensis).

The SNA takes its name from Caldwell Brook, which feeds into the Big Fork River nearby but does not provide a water route into the SNA. It's an understatement to say that visiting this SNA is a challenge during the growing season, given the generally wet terrain and extensive alder thickets on the approach to the site. (The word "impossible" has been floated by some who have ventured here.) In the best of circumstances, plan for a minimum 4-5 hour round-trip trek in summer or consider a winter visit by snowshoe.

* The age of this tree was later verified by Kurt Kipfmueller at the University of Minnesota Center for Dendrochronology.

Ownership & Origins: This site was established from a land transfer with the U.S. Department of Interior, Bureau of Land Management.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.This site is within Pine Island State Forest.

parking.directions: In Faribault, just N of bridge over Cannon River on MN Hwy 3. Parking on E. Site is about 2.5 miles NE (downstream). Accessible by boat.
From Faribault 1.5 miles N on MN Hwy 3, then  0.5 mile E on 166th St, staying right on field road as 166th turns N. Park at dead end.

name: Cannon River Trout Lily SNA
description:
Two trout lily species—the white and the dwarf—are found at this site. But the 3" high dwarf trout lily is the conservation priority, and for good reason. Naturally occurring populations of this federally endangered species have been documented in three Minnesota counties—Goodhue, Rice and Steele—and nowhere else in the world.

Elegant and delicate, the dwarf trout lily blooms here along the Cannon River and its tributaries for a few short weeks each spring. Tiny buds on threadlike stems open into flowers no larger than a dime. Each nodding blossom has 4-6 recurved (back-bending) petals, typically ranging in color from pale pink to white. Historically, they bloomed in late April and May. Bloom times have now shifted earlier, even into March, possibly due to Minnesota's changing climate.

The limited range of this federally-endangered species is owed in part to its means of reproduction. As Nancy Sather describes in the Natural Heritage Program report Minnesota dwarf trout lily: an endangered Minnesota wildflower, the lily grows from an underground bulb that renews itself annually. Population size is only increased when the underground stem of a flowering plant produces a single offshoot runner bearing a new bulb.

This SNA has two sections, the southern section accessible only by boat on the Cannon River. The signed entrance is on the northern section, where visitors will find a low-lying "Big Woods" forest remnant laced by backwater channels and subject to seasonal flooding. An unmaintained, discontinuous roadbed crosses the site. While here, watch for bald eagles circling the sky above the river, where cliffs of St Peter Sandstone are capped by oak forest. In any season, please avoid fragile, erodible floodplain slopes to avoid impacts to the dwarf trout lily.

Ownership & Origins: Portions of this site were gifts from the Izaak Walton League of America and the Kitzman-Morris family. The Nature Conservancy assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Cannon River Water Trail passes through this site.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Cannon Valley Trail).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From downtown Red Wing 5 miles W on US Hwy 61. Park in water access N of Cannon River. Hike back across bridge 0.5 mile to site on both sides of 61. Restricted entry, see details above.

From downtown Red Wing 8 miles W on US Hwy 61, then 0.75 mile SW on Co Rd 18 (Welch Shortcut), then  0.6 mile S on Circle Dr. Park on pull-off on NW. Hike corridor (SE of road) 0.45 mile to site. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Cannon River Turtle Preserve SNA
description:
This SNA protects a stretch of the Cannon River downstream of Welch, in a meandering section of the river not far from its confluence with the Mississippi River. Sandbars and adjacent uplands here offer potential nesting habitat for turtles, and parts of this SNA are seasonally designated as sanctuary areas.

Of course, not only turtles stand to benefit from this site's protection. The SNA is a richly diverse mosaic of plant community types, with 530 acres of southern terrace forest dominated by silver maple, green ash and cottonwood, 130 acres of oak-hickory woodland, and relatively smaller areas of maple-basswood forest and floodplain forest. These forest communities, together with the river, its sandbars, shorelines and backwaters, offer a range of habitats for wildlife, including birds such as the Red-Shouldered hawk and Cerulean Warbler, both special concern species in Minnesota.

Keeping the shoreline undeveloped and naturally-vegetated along this roughly 6-mile segment of the river also promotes water quality by limiting sediment-laden run-off. While adjacent up- and downstream areas of the Cannon have been listed by the EPA as impaired* for turbidity, the section of river within the SNA has not.

As visitors will discover, this is a dynamic, ever-changing environment. Low-lying areas are routinely scoured by ice and currents. Sandbars and shorelines can be submerged by high waters until mid-summer, and subject to flooding during periods of heavy rain. Whether you hike in, bike by on the Cannon Valley Trail or canoe through the SNA, note that all sandbars are designated as sanctuary areas (closed to access) from May 1 – October 15 to avoid potential impacts on turtles or their eggs. While a short stop or simple picnic on a sandbar seems innocent enough, studies have demonstrated that such activity attracts nest predators such as raccoons, dramatically decreasing turtles' reproductive success.

This segment of the Cannon River (from Cannon Falls to its confluence with the Mississippi) is classified as "scenic" under the Minnesota Wild & Scenic Rivers System.

* The 2016 proposed impaired waters list submitted to EPA in January, 2017 cites exceedances of standards for E.coli, nutrients, PCBs in fish tissue and turbidity in this stretch of the river. "Turbidity" is a lack of light penetration in the water due to suspended and dissolved material, commonly sediment eroded directly or carried in run-off.

Ownership & Origin: The Nature Conservancy assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: Sanctuary (sandbars closed May 1 - October 15). The Cannon Valley Trail and Cannon River Water Trail pass through site. This site is an Audubon Important Bird Area..

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Franklin 1.35 miles S on Co Rd 5 (becomes Co Rd 11 in Redwood County) then 0.5 mile W on minimum maintenance road. Park at dead end, in lot for Cedar Mountain WMA. Hike 0.5 mile W on field road into site.

name: Cedar Mountain SNA
description:
Cedar Mountain SNA is one of a string of SNAs aligned along the meandering Minnesota River in Yellow Medicine, Renville and Redwood Counties. While each is unique, they share a common history, influenced both by the Des Moines lobe of the most recent glacial period and the subsequent torrent of Glacial River Warren.

Cedar Mountain is notable for being underlain by gneisses and diorite representing some of North America's oldest known bedrock—estimated to originate 3.6 billion years ago. The so-called "Cedar Mountain Complex" includes these ancient rocks and relatively younger (1.8 billion year-old) bedrock formed when magma flowed into cracks in the older rock. These igneous intrusives include two distinctive rock types described only from this location: Cedar Mountain Gabbro and Cedar Mountain Granodiorite, visible here in knobs and outcroppings.

Glacial River Warren left its mark on this site in many ways. All but the highest knobs here were inundated at some point during the river's flow. According to geologist Carrie Jennings in the Minnesota Biological Survey report Native Plant Communities & Rare Species of the Minnesota River Valley Counties, there were two time periods when this may have occurred, as Glacial Lake Agassiz drained to the south via Glacial River Warren. The first period was from roughly 14,000 to 12,900 years before present, and the second, roughly 11,000 to 9200 years before present.*

Researchers have estimated peak "catastrophic" flows of this monstrous glacial river at .364 Sv, which is equivalent to about 3000 times the modern-day baseflow conditions of the Minnesota River at Mankato.** The torrent swept away glacial sediments from the recent and earlier glaciations and left erosional features on the bedrock including scour channels, potholes and depressions of all sizes. Many of these "tracks" of Minnesota's glaciers and erosional features now hold small ponds, marsh-filled basins and ephemeral pools.

Today, the SNA reflects a calmer time. Visitors will find a rolling landscape dominated by oak woodland-brushland and mesic prairie. The low-lying, northern part of the SNA nearest the river features floodplain forest. Rock outcroppings support a number of rare plants, including devil's tongue (also known as plains prickly pear cactus) and waterhyssop.

Management here has focused on restoring a more open landscape, guided in part by historic 1938 aerial photographs of the site. Says SNA Regional Specialist Brad Bolduan, "It had become pretty overgrown. We've been steadily working to remove plum and cedar, along with doing some prescribed burns. Removal of invasive buckthorn and honeysuckle is the main emphasis in the near term. Long term, the aim is to bring back oak savanna and prairie where those communities previously occurred."

Water level changes can make it challenging to cross Wabasha Creek, near the southern boundary of the SNA. Access roads on the west side of the SNA (where the SNA adjoins Cedar Mountain Wildlife Management Area) are also subject to seasonal flooding.

* Estimated time periods given for the flow of Glacial River Warren are in calendar years before present, converted from radiocarbon years provided in Jennings' report (±100) and rounded to the nearest hundred. Prior to rounding, these calendar years before present were 13,399 (±140), 12,868 (±105), 10,948 (±163) and 9,187 (±135). These should be considered approximations. ** Peak flows have been estimated by Fisher as high as 0.364 Sverdrups (Sv) [Fisher, T. G. 2004 (November): River Warren boulders, Minnesota, USA: catastrophic paleoflow indicators in the southern spillway of glacial Lake Agassiz. Boreas, Vol. 33, pp. 349358. Oslo. ISSN 0300-9483]. What does that mean? According to Jim Almendinger, hydrologist, St. Croix Watershed Research Station, 0.364 Sv translates to 12,854,660 cubic feet per second. This represents roughly 2983 times the modern-day Minnesota River at Mankato, approximated by Almendinger using "long-term median flows, which are (about) baseflow conditions."
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. Cedar Mountain WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: Dogs (must be under control, must be leashed from April 16-July 14).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Redwood Falls 1.5 miles W on MN Hwy 19, then 6.5 mile N on Co Hwy 17. Park on E road shoulder.

name: Cedar Rock SNA
description:
Just south of the present-day Minnesota River and flanked by the Cedar Rock Wildlife Management Area (WMA), the rock outcroppings that distinguish this SNA's landscape recall an earlier time.

As Fred Harris relates in the Minnesota Biological Survey report Rare Species and Native Plant Communities in the Minnesota River Valley, the rosy, knob-like exposures of Morton gneiss here represent some of the oldest rocks discovered at the earth's surface. Described as "crystalline" bedrock, it first formed as an igneous (granite-like) rock from molten magma that cooled very slowly deep below the earth's surface as long as 3.6 billion years ago (Grant 1972*). Extreme heat and pressure over the next 1 to 1.5 billion years then altered its crystalline structure and transformed it into metamorphic rock. When Glacial Lake Agassiz drained via the Minnesota River Valley in the torrent of Glacial River Warren roughly 11,000 years ago, this ancient rock was exposed, revealing its colorful mix of pink and gray feldspar, white quartz, and black biotite and amphibole.

These rock outcroppings present a unique set of conditions for plants, with limited water, soil and wide temperature extremes. Lichens are successful in pioneering the exposed rock faces. In shallow rock crevices and thin soils, species such as small-flowered fameflower, brittle prickly pear cacti, rusty woodsia, green-flowered peppergrass, and bluets are able to eke out a living. The relatively deeper soil between rock exposures hosts familiar prairie species such as big and little bluestem and blue grama grass.

Pools of rainwater that gather in hollows of the rock offer a temporary but vital micro-habitat that supports aquatic plants such as the Carolina foxtail, ovoid spikerush and waterhyssop, a threatened species in Minnesota. This adaptable little plant, with its white to white-blue flowers less than 1/2" in diameter, is found blooming in these shallow, ephemeral pools in spring and early summer. It disappears shortly after the pools dry up, only to return again when the pools refill (sometimes later the same year, more often the following spring).

This area was graced at least historically by another rarity—the Ottoe Skipper butterfly (Hesperia ottoe). An individual found near here in the early 1980s represents the only record of this species in the Minnesota River valley. Sadly, the population of the species has since plummeted in the state, with no reported occurrences in western Minnesota since 1995.

Management efforts here will include periodic prescribed burns and removal of red cedar to open up the canopy.

*Fred Harris, citing Grant: Grant, J.A. 1972. Minnesota River valley, southwestern Minnesota. In Geology of Minnesota: A centennial volume, ed. P.K. Sims and G.B. Morey, 177-96. St. Paul: Minnesota Geological Survey, University of Minnesota.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Cedar Rock WMA is adjacent to this site.

Rock climbing for sport, including bouldering, is not allowed on Scientific and Natural Areas.

parking.directions: From LeSueur 4 miles S on Co Rd 36 (Ottawa Rd), then 0.4 mile W on Twp Rd 69 (380th St). Continue across railroad grade, then park in lot on NW where road turns S.

name: Chamberlain Woods SNA
description:
Chamberlain Woods SNA lies within a meander of the Minnesota River, bordered on the north and west by the river and on the east by the tracks of the Union Pacific Railroad. On the other side of the tracks, an active sand mine offers stark contrast.

Not surprisingly, the vegetation of this site is defined by the river. It features an outstanding example of floodplain forest with a dense, multi-layered canopy characterized by silver maple interspersed with giant cottonwood, basswood and elm trees. An 18-acre stand of northern pin oak – bur oak woodland occupies the far southeastern corner of the site where the land rises in elevation above the reach of seasonal floodwaters.

Of particular scientific interest here are "point bars" on the inside of the river's bends, where sediment drops out in the slower current. Point bars mark the old banks of the river, capturing a visual history of how the river route has changed over time and offering opportunity for study of plant succession.

By early fall, in many years, one can walk more than a mile and half along the river's shoreline here. Listen for the "PEET-sah" song of the Acadian Flycatcher before it heads to its wintering grounds in southern Central America and northern South America. Listed as a Special Concern species in Minnesota, it is one of many species documented here that is associated with large, unfragmented blocks of forest.
