Sometimes, a natural area escapes development and disturbance because of one family. This is one of those places. Horace and Esther Chamberlain acquired the 302-acre property piece by piece, over time, in four parcels. In 1988, they gifted it to the state for designation as an SNA. While they have since passed away, this diverse and beautiful natural area continues to support an abundance of life through the seasons as their legacy. And the Minnesota River, as ever, rolls on.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from Horace F. and Esther J. Chamberlain.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. The Minnesota River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From Cherry Grove 0.5 mile S on Co Rd 5 then 1.25 miles E on Co Rd 20, then 0.1 mile N on Twp Rd 379. Park in pull-off on W near wood-routed sign. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Cherry Grove Blind Valley SNA
description:
This SNA is far more than meets the eye. From the road, one sees a grove of trees, bordered on the north by a Wildlife Management Area planted in native grasses. Yet, there is more afoot here, quite literally.

Enter the SNA to find the land pitted by sinkholes and crossed by stream channels that abruptly end, known as "blind valleys." A small stream called Jessie's Kill flows into the site, gradually loses water, then disappears. Except on rare occasions, surface water that enters this site doesn't exit—at least, not above ground.

All are clues to a Karst landscape and this site's most outstanding feature, Goliath Cave (originally named Coon Cave). The cave's natural entry is gated at the base of a well-like depression, walled by bands of limestone and shale. From this point, the multi-level, multi-branched cave system extends eastward far beyond the SNA boundaries.

U of MN researcher Calvin Alexander has extensively studied this cave system. According to Alexander, the portion of the cave within the SNA developed largely within the DuBuque Formation, while the rest of the cave (part of the adjacent, privately owned Karst Preserve) is associated with the older Stewartville Formation. These formations date to the Ordovician Period (443.7—488.3million years before present), when what is now Minnesota was located south of the equator and covered in shallow seas.

Hydrology studies including dye tests have revealed that water from the Goliath cave system re-emerges at "Big Springs" in Forestville State Park, where it enters Canfield Creek. On its underground journey, the water is cooled to a trout-friendly temperature of 48 degrees.

To appreciate the big picture, plan a road trip connecting the dots, as suggested by Forestville State Park interpretive naturalist Bob Storlie. Begin at the SNA to see the blind valley, sinkholes and cave entrance. Then drive the five miles to Forestville State Park for a guided tour of Mystery Cave which—like Goliath Cave—developed in carbonate rocks of the Stewartville and Dubuque Formations. Portions of Mystery Cave developed in carbonate rocks of the Maquoketa Formation of the Ordovician Era. Finally, hike to "Big Spring," where Goliath's waters gush from the base of a cliff into Canfield Creek. Dip your fingers in the icy water. If you're lucky, you'll see a leaping trout. Perfect.
notes: Sanctuary (below ground portion closed). This site has no recreational facilities. Cherry Grove WMA is adjacent to this site. See detail map for locations of interpretive signs.

parking.directions: From Hastings 4 miles S on US Hwy 61, then 2 miles W on Co Rd 77 (205th St E). Continue 1 mile S on Co Hwy 89 (Joan Ave). Park on W road shoulder.

name: Chimney Rock  SNA
description:
This site is one of relatively few SNAs in which preservation of a significant geologic feature was the primary reason for a site's designation. Chimney Rock is described in Minnesota's Geology, as "an erosional remnant of the St. Peter Sandstone standing like a kingpin ready to be bowled over by the next glacial advance."

Nearly 30' tall and 10' at the base, the shape of this so-called "castellated" bedrock pillar suggests the turret or spire of a castle. It is composed of St. Peter Sandstone, originating during the middle Ordovician period roughly 458 – 453 million years ago. While most of the spire is poorly cemented sandstone, its cap is harder and more resistant to weathering, thanks to calcite that percolated down in water from overlying limestone of the Platteville Formation, now gone.

The fact that this delicate structure still stands is "clear evidence that the area has not been touched by glacial ice for over 100,000 years," according to geologists and professors Charles Matsch and John Green, who prepared a background report* on the site's landforms. As they describe, two different ice lobes associated with the last glacial advance in the region (16,000 – 14,000 years before present) stopped just short of this area.

The glacial era did leave a legacy of sediments carried in meltwater and windblown silt which, in time, eroded away to leave the bedrock exposed. Whittled by wind and water, it has been a local landmark for generations.

Outcroppings associated with this same sandstone bedrock formation jut from the hillsides here. On south-facing slopes at their base, Minnesota Biological Survey ecologists have mapped areas of bedrock bluff prairie grading to sand-gravel prairie further downslope. Elsewhere, the rolling terrain of this SNA is dominated by pin oak–bur oak woodland, which replaced pre-European settlement oak openings and barrens in the absence of fire. Four rare plant species were documented in early surveys here including kitten-tails, beach heather, narrow-leaved pinweed and Canada frostweed.

Chimney Rock knows no season: a visit any time of year is worthwhile to view this evidence of the region's Quaternary geologic history. Still, it is hard to rival the period from late summer through October, when the blazing stars and goldenrod are in bloom, the big and little bluestem grasses hang heavy with seed, and the leaves on the oak begin to turn.

Tom Lewanski, former Conservation Director of Friends of the Mississippi River, and Al Singer, Director of the Dakota County Farmland and Natural Areas Program, were instrumental in the effort that led to this site's acquisition from willing sellers and its designation as an SNA. Says Singer: "This project highlights the importance of timing, strategic partnerships and relationships, and patience—often crucial to many of these land protection projects."

*Chimney Rock— Geologic History Background (Appendix A, 2007 Ecological Evaluation)

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from a private landowner. Dakota County assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. As shown on the map, a private home and driveway are surrounded by the SNA. Please respect this private property and stay on the SNA when visiting.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From downtown Grand Rapids 2 miles NW on US Hwy 2, then 2.5 miles W on Co Rd 63, then 0.8 mile S on Tioga Beach Rd. Park at water access on W. Site is 1 mile E in Pokegama Lake. Accessible by boat.

name: Chisholm Point Island SNA
description:
Long and narrow, its two sides joined by a narrow isthmus, 28-acre Chisholm Point Island in Lake Pokegama was designated an SNA to protect a rare natural treasure: an old-growth, little disturbed maple-basswood forest with sugar maples well over 200 years old. Equally impressive is the strong component of "up and comers" with diameters of roughly 2 feet. Large northern white cedar and bur oak join sugar maple and basswood in the canopy.

While not a rare species, Canada yew is known for being displayed here in uncommon splendor. This evergreen shrub with its bright red, gum-drop like fruit is typically heavily browsed by deer, but in 2002 (when this SNA was established) the yew carpeted the forest floor with large, spreading clones up to 7 feet tall. Deer have since unfortunately "discovered" the island and the yew is much diminished but still present. Its failure to rebound from deer browsing even in deer exclosures may point to other factors, such as climate change.

This SNA exists in large part because of support from the local Greater Pokegama Lake Association. According to past-president Richard Libbey, the Association has been instrumental in a number of acquisitions involving conservation lands, including Chisholm Point Island SNA, Drumbeater Island Natural Area (now an Itasca County Park) and Nesbitt Island WMA in Pokegama Lake as well as Bass Brook WMA along the Mississippi near Grand Rapids. In the case of Chisholm Point Island, Libbey and fellow members initiated outreach to the landowner, contacted the DNR, then led efforts to raise necessary funds (matched by the Reinvest in Minnesota, or RIM funds). Members also joined SNA regional specialist Steve Wilson in helping make the case for the SNA at local government meetings.

Says Libbey, "Islands are special. People enjoy them, they provide wildlife habitat, and the natural shoreline is good for water quality. Fortunately, the previous owners—Dick White and family—had pretty much left it alone. Once something is developed it rarely, if ever, goes back. We were glad that the state worked with us on this and was willing to own and manage the land. As public land, now it belongs to everyone." *

Libbey is the first to say that no-one knows this island as well as SNA site steward Randy McCarty. As early as 1994/95, McCarty was asked by his neighbors, the Whites, to "keep an eye" on the island when they were away for the winter. Now, it's the rare day in summer when he doesn't do at least a quick circuit to see that all is well. In winter, it's at least once a week.

"This is an extremely well-traveled lake," says McCarty, "but the island feels untouched for generations, with its big old cedars and white pines." A list of his personal observations reads like a field guide to northwoods wildlife: beaver, mink, fisher, marten, grey fox, wolves, black bear, grouse, O sprey, Barred owls, young otters sliding down the island's steep slopes into the lake, a faithful pair of eagles—known by lake residents as Harold and Maude—believed to have nested on the island for as many as 30 years. "Dick (White) wanted it preserved in perpetuity," says McCarty, "and making it an SNA was a way to do that."

Although he continues to keep an eye out for the occasional visitor that needs a reminder of the SNA rules, he says the island is "still as pristine as you could ever ask for. Pretty much everybody in the community understands exactly what this place is about."

* It could be said that Richard Libbey inherited his appreciation for wild places, at least in part, from his father. Wes Libbey, who passed away in 2010 at the age of 101, was not only one of the founding members of the Greater Pokegama Lake Association, but a nationally-known and respected conservationist.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from the Greater Pokegama Lake Association.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Clear Lake 1.75 miles W on Co Rd 57 (90th St), then continue 0.7 mile S on Co Rd 57 (58th Ave). Park in pull-off on W. No parking allowed along 58th Ave.

name: Clear Lake SNA
description:
Clear Lake SNA has the distinction of being the first land parcel acquired under the state's Wild and Scenic Rivers Program. The SNA features .65 miles of shoreline on the east side of the Mississippi River, near its confluence with the Clearwater River in Sherburne County.

The 55-mile stretch of the Mississippi from St. Cloud to Anoka was designated as a Minnesota Wild and Scenic River in 1973 to "preserve and protect the river's outstanding scenic, recreational, natural, historical and scientific values." This island-dotted section of the river features a broad valley flanked by 50-100 foot bluffs, with large expanses still forested and undeveloped. The SNA makes an important contribution to the ecological integrity of the river corridor here.

Visitors can expect to encounter steep topography. On the SNA's extreme northern end, the forested bluff drops abruptly to the river's edge. From this point, a prominent ridge line angles inland to the south and east, and the land along the river levels out into a terrace.

Oak woodland dominates the SNA, with a canopy of northern red oak, northern pin oak, and white oak with lesser amounts of bur oak and red maple. This is complemented by southern terrace forest nearest the river, where species such as American elm, boxelder, silver maple, green ash, hackberry and basswood are subjected to occasional flooding. A small (half-acre) sedge meadow along the southern boundary continues onto adjacent land.

Rare species documented here include a small population of Hill's thistle and butternut—a tree once relatively common but largely eliminated in the state's forests due to a widespread lethal fungus that attacks the cambium, or growing layer, of the tree just inside the bark.

This SNA is included on the map produced for this section of the Mississippi State Water Trail which offers interesting background information and the regional context for this site.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Mississippi River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From Clinton Falls 0.5 mile N on Co Hwy 45. Park in water access on W. Hike S across bridge, over guard rail, past powerlines, and into woods of site. Also accessible by boat from water access.

name: Clinton Falls Dwarf Trout Lily SNA
description:
This SNA's "claim to fame" is that it contains the largest known population of the dwarf trout lily in the world. Naturally occurring populations of this federally-endangered species are limited to three Minnesota counties.

At 20.5 acres, the SNA is a relatively small but critical site in the conservation of this rare species. The Straight River makes a sweeping S-curve here at its confluence with Crane Creek, riffling over boulders as it loops between two forested peninsulas. Visiting the site, one can see tufts of grass, sticks and other debris are caught high in the branches of trees on the eastern peninsula, a clear sign of the river's potential to flood. Over half the SNA is sometimes under water, and the majority of the dwarf trout lily colony can be submerged during extreme high water events. Thus far, the colony has survived, though it remains vulnerable to the erosion, debris and sediment associated with flooding.

Flooding may actually have played an important role in historic distribution of the species. In a 1990 report for the DNR Natural Heritage Program, ecologist and botanist Nancy Sather writes, "…It is likely that the plants were spread by floodwaters uprooting them from an original location somewhere on the Cannon River. Torn loose...these plants would have been re-deposited on slopes and floodplains downstream. (This may explain) the plant's limited geographic distribution at elevations of 960 to 1000 feet within the Cannon River watershed and its tributaries."

One key to the lilies' survival is sustaining the forest cover here. Although technically classified as an Elm-Ash-Basswood Terrace Forest, it contains a wide variety of deciduous trees, including silver maple, bitternut hickory, ironwood, and cottonwood. Over the years, this woodland has likely eluded fire, protected within the river's meanders.

This SNA benefits from devoted volunteer site stewards Jerold and Karen Ibberson. Together, they have monitored lily populations, removed invasive dame's rocket and buckthorn, and offered presentations to local civic groups. Notes Karen, "It's an honor to help in the lilies' preservation."

Dozens of species of wildflowers bloom here, among them Dutchman's breeches, bloodroot and nodding trillium. Pileated Woodpeckers hammer away at downed trees and snags. Visitors may be lucky to spot the shell of a rare ellipse mussel in the midden piles left by raccoons along the shore.

Please tread lightly here, in the interest of Minnesota's rarest lily.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR)..
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Straight River Water Trail passes through this site.

parking.directions: From Clinton 6 miles W on Co Hwy 6. Park in pull-off on N, near wood-routed sign.

name: Clinton Prairie SNA
description:
Willa Cather's description of a "rolling open country like the sea" could easily have been written for Clinton Prairie SNA and its topography of gently rolling ground moraine with broad, rounded swells and shallow depressions. The mesic blacksoil prairie here is exceedingly rare in the state's cornbelt, where row crops occupy nearly all of the upland soils built by prairies over the centuries from the raw material of calcareous (lime-rich) glacial drift from the Des Moines Lobe.

Dominated by native grasses and sedges-side-oats grama, slough sedge, Indian grass, porcupine grass-it's no surprise that this is a haven for grassland birds. Species include the upland sandpiper, the endangered chestnut-collared longspur, dickcissels and horned larks. Hear the "bubbling, jangling, rising warble" of the male bobolink in spring and early summer, its dun-colored mate somewhere nearby on her ground nest. Find orb spiders by the dew shining on their webs anchored among the grasses, and keep an eye out for the rare poweshiek skipper. Shallow wetlands provide migrating northern shovelers, northern pintail ducks, and other waterfowl with opportunity to rest and refuel on abundant invertebrates.

Biodiversity here has benefited from work by volunteer site stewards to keep invasive birdsfoot trefoil in check, a non-native that would otherwise tend to form large, vegetative mats at the expense of native species.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Cold Spring 1.5 miles NE on MN Hwy 23, then 400 feet S on Co Rd 140, then 0.3 mile E on 233rd St. Park at dead end.

name: Cold Spring Heron Colony SNA
description:
Imagine: a great blue heron colony studied for 35 years! At it's peak in 1974, there were 1,585 nests built in predominantly elms, basswood and black ash at this site along the Sauk River, which the late Professor Emeritus Max Partch described in 1990 as "an old forested river levee separating a peat bog forest to the north from a partly wooded flood plain to the south." Professors and generations of students from St. Cloud State University closely followed the colony until it abandoned the site in 1989 for unknown reasons, though a storm in 1983 and severe drought in 1988 are believed to be contributing factors.

Such long-term research generates important insights for conservation management of colonial nesting sites. Great blue herons are one of Minnesota's 17 species of colonial waterbirds: a habit that brings a measure of security but also vulnerability, in that a single catastrophic event has potential for devastating impacts on a large number of birds and their young.

Today, the two parcels of this SNA encompass a hill with native dry sand-gravel prairie, and the adjacent floodplain area where once the herons nested: important for the habitat they provide to as many as 79 species of birds, along with many other native species. Of course, there is always and ever the possibility that the herons will return. Each year, the students from St. Cloud State still scan the floodplain forests for nests.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Worthington 7 miles SW on MN Hwy 60, then 3 miles W on Co Hwy 6, then 1 mile N on Co Hwy 9, then 1.5 miles W Co Rd 56 (290th St). Park on N road shoulder.

name: Compass Prairie SNA
description:
A small SNA at 20 acres, Compass Prairie is nonetheless the largest known native prairie remnant in all of Nobles County. Over fifty representative species of tallgrass prairie are here, including downy gentian, prairie wild onion, rough blazing star, wild bergamot, prairie turnip and field blue-eyed grass. The site's namesake compass plants rise 6-8 feet tall on gentle slopes beside a creek that feeds the Rock River.

This mesic blacksoil prairie remnant is among the places from which the poweshiek skipperling has seemingly vanished. As Robert Dana writes in SNA Nature Notes, "This little butterfly was until recently the most commonly encountered of the prairie specialist butterflies in Minnesota, almost as reliably present in prairie remnants as leadplant or blazing stars." Habitat fragmentation, fire, a limited range and low dispersal rates (individuals traveling <1 mile from hatch sites) may be factors in the decline. As such the species was recently listed as endangered under the provisions of the Endangered Species Act.

One function of Compass Prairie-and all the state's SNAs-is to foster resilience and population recovery of imperiled native species by maintaining critical habitat. It's particularly important in this instance, since nearly half of all known historically documented sites for the poweshiek skipperling worldwide are in Minnesota. With concerted effort, one future year this "quintessential tallgrass prairie skipper" may again be found here, depositing its eggs on slender prairie grasses, taking flight for a few short weeks of summer.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Sanborn 0.65 mile E of US Hwy 71 on 110th St, then 0.5 mile S on 460th, then 0.25 mile E on 165th St. Park in pull-off on N.
From Springfield 3 miles W on US Hwy 14, then 3 miles S on Co Hwy 2. Turn W (staying on 2) and after 0.5 mile park on W, before bridge.

name: Cottonwood River Prairie SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


Extending across nearly 3 miles of Brown County, this SNA is known by three contiguous management areas: the Prairie Champion unit to the west, the Prairie Sky unit to the east, and the narrow Railroad Prairie stretching between them.

Remnants of dry sand-gravel prairie are found throughout, complemented in the Prairie Champion unit by wet prairie, mesic prairie, and a large prairie wetland complex. The terrain rises in the Prairie Sky unit, where a ridge offers impressive views as well as south- and north-facing slopes, the latter favored by a population of federally threatened prairie bush clover. The abandoned rail line at the heart of the Railroad Prairie unit exemplifies the long-standing association between prairie conservation and railroad corridors, which provide accidental refuge for native species on the uncultivated rights of way (along with an occasional spark-generated revitalizing fire). Most of the infrastructure is gone here, but the trestles remain, including one crossing the Cottonwood River. Perennial and intermittent reaches of Mounds Creek add yet another dimension to this site.

Visitors will enjoy displays of purple coneflowers, lead plant, puccoon and blazing stars with their nectaring butterflies and bees, and 135 bird species reflecting the range of habitats, including western meadowlarks, blue-winged teal, horned larks, northern harriers, ruby-crowned kinglets, great-crested flycatchers, and (unusual for Minnesota) blue grosbeaks.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Scandia 1.6 miles E on MN 97 (Scandia Trail), then 0.8 mile N on MN 95 (St Croix Trail, then 0.3 mile E on 220th St, then 0.3 mile S on Quarry Ave. Park only on E road shoulder. Hike 0.15 mile S along marked corridor to site.

name: Crystal Spring SNA
description:
A 2016 addition to the state's SNAs, this site was called Miniboha by its former owner, Gregory Page, who was a good steward of its natural features for 40 years. It's a Dakota word Page gleaned from an 1890 Dakota-English dictionary, which translates to "a gulch, a ravine made by water."

Made by water—an apt description of the pine-rimmed, rock-walled gorge that defines this site. For brief periods during the year, heavy rain and seasonal snowmelt enter from above, coursing through ravines and dropping over a sandstone ledge into the gorge. But the real action here is less about this fleeting waterfall than about what happens year-round at the foot of the ledge, where a perennial spring seeps from between layers of Jordan sandstone. "This is a retreatal gorge formed by spring sapping," says DNR hydro-geologist Greg Brick. "The spring continually undercuts the ledge, which periodically falls, so that the ledge retreats over time."

These springs feed a creek that flows a short distance to the St. Croix. A management plan prepared by the Carnelian-Marine-St. Croix Watershed District describes the creek's route, from the "exceptionally beautiful area of moist to wet cliff and talus slope with bryophyte communities" within the SNA, across areas of private land, through a culvert under a railroad bed to "a mixed hardwood seepage swamp" along the river, protected as the Rustrum Wildlife Management Area.

Overall, the dominant plant community within the SNA has been mapped by the Minnesota Biological Survey as an excellent (A-rank) red oak – basswood forest, with steep slopes hosting sugar maple and white pine. Portions exhibit old-growth characteristics, with large diameter trees.

Gregory Page recalls thinking, when he first saw this site, that "no one person should own this land, but if someone can, I'd like to be the one." Forty years later, when it became his time to sell, he says "I wanted to make sure it was in protected for the public, and the SNA program helped accomplish that."

In doing so, he has helped protect natural features of immeasurable biodiversity significance and geologic value. Three formations from the Upper Cambrian period are exposed here—Jordan Sandstone, St. Lawrence and Tunnel City Group (Mazomanie Formation) —laid down between 495 to 490 million years ago. The springs emerging from these rock layers support abundant life: from tiny shrimp-like amphipods in small ledge pools, to in the undisturbed stream beds, to brook trout in the creek's lower reaches, to rare mussels in the St. Croix.

Crystal Spring or Miniboha—this is a truly fragile site, where clambering on wet rock and slopes would quickly translate to loss of delicate mosses and water quality, the unraveling of ecological relationships long in the making. Enjoy gently.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The steeps cliffs and rugged terrain here present a safety hazard to visitors. The plant communities on cliffs are also sensitive to disturbance. Stay back from cliffs and off steep slopes noted on the detail map. This site is in an Aububon Important Bird Area.

The site is within the Lower St. Croix National Scenic Riverway.

parking.directions: From Windom 3 miles SE on US 71, then 3 miles S on Co Hwy 79, then 0.9 mile W on Co Rd 30. Park in water access on N. Hike NE into site.
From Windom 3 miles SE on US 71, then 2 miles S on Co Hwy 79. Park in pull-off on W.

name: Des Moines River SNA
description:
Look outward in any direction from the boundaries of Des Moines River SNA and consider the prescience of Arthur Rose who, in his 1910 account of Jackson County, remarked: "Except for the area actually taken up by the water of lakes and creeks, all is tillable, even to the tops of the hills and knolls and in the bottom lands." Tillable, indeed-over 86% of the county has since been cultivated.

Look to the interior of this SNA, either on foot or from a canoe on the Des Moines River, for remnants of a different world. Mesic upland prairie predominates here, blanketing the rolling terrain of the Coteau Moraines with big bluestem and prairie dropseed grasses, and wildflowers such as puccoon, blazing stars, and wild bergamot. In mid-July, one of the largest known populations of federally threatened prairie bush clover comes into bloom, with pale pink- to cream-colored flowers. Sparse woody vegetation traces the beds of intermittent streams, growing denser along the floodplains of the Des Moines River, where migratory waterfowl are seen in spring and fall.

Stewardship efforts here include prescribed burns, selective tree removal, and prairie reconstruction in several old fields using seed collected on site, improving habitat for native plant and animal species.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Des Moines River Water Trail passes through this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Park Rapids 14.2 miles N on US Hwy 71, then 1.9 miles W on Co Rd 42 (Boot Lake Dr), then 1 mile S on Dinner Lake Loop, then 0.4 mile S and W on Little Dinner Road, Park at intersection, then hike 0.5 mile SW on access/snowmobile trail into site.

name: Dinner Creek SNA
description:
This is among the state's newer SNAs, designated in July of 2018. Rich black spruce swamp dominates the 241 acres, with scattered islands of slightly higher elevation supporting northern mesic hardwood forest of quaking aspen, balsam fir and paper birch. Fire-dependent jack pine woodland occupies a series of gravelly, excessively drained ridges that trend from NE to SW along the western edge of the SNA. This woodland community type was historically a major landscape component in the Chippewa Plains and Pine Moraines & Outwash Plains Subsections of north-central/west-central Minnesota. Once the dominant plant community on the often extensive sandy outwash plains, it has been largely eliminated due to conversion to red pine plantations and irrigated cropland (often potatoes). It is now rare in the state, with a Conservation Status ranking of S1/S2, or imperiled to critically imperiled.

The site is within a 3,250-acre area of outstanding biodiversity significance located south of Itasca State Park in Becker and Hubbard Counties: a complex of lakes with undeveloped shoreline, streams, and mature to old-growth forest on rolling, morainal topography. Evaluations by the Minnesota Biological Survey found the extent and quality of the natural features in this complex to be of regional and statewide importance. Says MBS ecologist Mike Lee, “it merits conservation action and management with maintenance of native biodiversity and ecological processes as the primary goals.”

Those who explore the SNA's rugged terrain in late May and early June may be fortunate to spot a blooming Ram's Head orchid (Cypripedium arietinum). Related to Minnesota's state flower, the Showy Lady's Slipper, the smaller Ram's Head may be recognized by its more conical “slipper” with white, silky-haired interior and exterior richly-veined in purple. This is a threatened species in Minnesota, vulnerable to illegal collection but also to forest management activities such as herbicide application, discing and rock raking, use of heavy equipment during the growing season, and removal of the canopy by timber harvest. It is one of many sensitive species documented within the SNA and in the larger Dinner Creek complex, much of which is public land, including School Trust Fund land, state forestry and county lands. An interdisciplinary management plan has been proposed as a means of protecting the many high value natural features documented within the area, minimizing new roads and trail corridors that may otherwise fragment the site.

Hardy travelers en route to nearby Itasca State Park may wish to explore this relatively remote site. Visitors to the extensive black spruce swamp here will find a closed canopy and relatively open understory where moss-covered hummocks alternate with wet, mucky hollows. Despite the SNA's name, Dinner Creek itself meanders near but does not pass through the site. Birders, in particular, will appreciate the many breeding and migratory species that use the diverse patches of native plant communities. Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) documented in or near the SNA include snapping turtle, veery, ovenbird, white-throated sparrow, rose-breasted grosbeak and black-backed woodpecker.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: Eagle's Nest Lake No. 4 does not have a public access. Access may be gained through adjacent county land. Site is in Eagle's Nest Lake No 4. Accessible by boat.

name: Eagles Nest Island No. 4 SNA
description:
This site takes its name from the lake in which it is located—Eagle's Nest Lake #4—one of 4 lakes in the Eagle's Nest chain of lakes here near popular Bear Head Lake State Park.

Transferred to the state by the Federal Bureau of Land Management, this 5-acre bedrock island is crowned with old-growth white and red pine. It is one of the state's smallest SNAs, but what it lacks in size it makes up for in species richness.

On its western side, the island rises in a ridge with north- and south-facing slopes. To the east, the terrain is low-lying and more level. Survey work done by ecologists from Emmons and Olivier Resources along with SNA program staff found an impressive assembly of native plants here, with variations across the site based on subtle differences in topography, soil character and moisture gradients.

The west side of the island features a continuous canopy of large white and red pine, along with paper birch and white cedar. Adding to the mix in the sub-canopy are balsam fir, mountain ash, mountain maple and black spruce. The shrub layer hosts bush honeysuckle, chokecherry, beaked hazelnut and lowbush blueberry. Rising from the thin soils covered in pine needle duff are Canada mayflower, wild sarsaparilla, large-leaved aster, starflower and pipsissewa. On the south-facing slope, bunchberry and wintergreen grow low to the ground, bearing white flowers in spring and red berries in fall.

Surveyors found that the character of the vegetation shifts with "wetter incursions" in the lower, eastern side of the island. Black spruce and balsam fir join the canopy and become more prevalent, with Labrador tea and bog laurel making an appearance.

Five Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) from the Border Lakes Subsection have been documented here, including American Bittern, Cape May Warbler, Common Loon, Common Merganser, and Belted Kingfisher.

In this northern lake with its summer recreational homes, this undeveloped* island offers valuable habitat. Shorelines provide opportunity for nesting loons and waterfowl. Tall pines tempt nesting Bald Eagles and Osprey. Mink and snowshoe hares leave their prints in winter snow, and the native vegetation includes many food plants favored by northern birds and wildlife.

* As strong windstorms have made clear, "undeveloped" does not mean unchanging. A number of the island's large pine trees have been downed in recent years by this natural disturbance.

Ownership & Origins: This site was established from a land transfer from the U.S. Department of Interior, Bureau of Land Management.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

At present, there is no public water access on Eagle's Nest Lake #4.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Snowmobiling on designated trail (Snowmobile Trail 62: Arrowhead State Trail).

parking.directions: From International Falls 10 miles SE on US Hwy 53, then 4.25 miles E and S on Co Rd 119. Park in pull-off on E. Trek 1 mile E into site. GPS recommended.

name: East Rat Root River Peatland SNA
description:
This SNA is located in Koochiching County near the Canadian border, at the western edge of Voyageurs National Park. It is one of two peatland SNAs on either side of the Rat Root River ("rat" referring to muskrat) that together encompass over 4300 acres. High quality examples of two peatland landforms occur here, including a minimally disturbed raised bog and featureless water track.

This site was included in a detailed survey undertaken for the Field Guide to the Vegetation of Voyageurs National Park, which describes the Rat Root River Peatlands as a "striking feature of this sub-boreal landscape." West of sprawling Lake Kabetogama's Tom Cod Bay, the peatland is expressed in extensive areas of black spruce bog, black spruce leatherleaf (semi-treed) bog, and leather-leaf bog. Relatively smaller areas of fen (including tamarack scrub poor fen and poor fen) are found in and around the water tracks, with localized areas of rich fen in the most mineral-rich areas. While it might take a botanist to parse the subtle differences between these mapped communities, we can all appreciate that these patterns form the basis of life in this wild place.

Native plants here include the carnivorous pitcher plant and round-leaved sundew, as well as the stemless lady's slipper orchid. On the faunal front, Minnesota Biological Survey lepidopterist (butterfly and moth scientist) Kyle Johnson notes that "most of Minnesota's peatland butterflies are common here, among them the dorcas copper, bog copper, Arctic fritillary, bog fritillary, freija fritillary, frigga fritillary, red-disked alpine and jutta Arctic." Over sixteen species of peatland moths occur here as well, including two species of owlet moths identified as Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN).

These species display various adaptations to peatland conditions and to northern environments in general, notes Johnson. "Darker coloring on the wing scales absorbs heat, allowing species like the frigga fritillary to fly at colder temperatures. Some species—such as the jutta Arctic—are well camouflaged against the trunks of black spruce, and also have biennial life cycles (taking 2 years to complete metamorphosis) which is an adaptation to a short growing season."

Both East and West Rat Root River Peatland SNAs are within the Rainy River watershed and contribute to water quality in the region as a whole. Walleye are among the beneficiaries, since the Rat Root River has historically been a natural spawning area for Rainy Lake walleye.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within Kabetogama State Forest and adjacent to Voyageurs National Park.

parking.directions: From Ashby 2 miles S on MN Hwy 78. Park in water access on E. Site is 1.35 miles SE in Pelican Lake. Accessible by boat. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Egret Island SNA
description:
When The Nature Conservancy purchased this island in 1978, DNR Nongame Wildlife Program supervisor Carroll Henderson cheered the acquisition as "an outstanding wildlife conservation achievement." Henderson knew the island well. The previous year, the Nongame Program had documented 10,000 nesting pairs (and 7 species!) of colonial waterbirds using the site.*

Gifted to the state and designated an SNA in 2007, this 35-acre island in Pelican Lake continues to be among the state's most significant colonial waterbird nesting sites.

The number of nests and representation by species varies from year to year. Inventories over the past ten years have documented nesting Great Egrets, Double-crested Cormorants, Great Blue Herons and—to a lesser extent—Cattle Egrets and Black-crowned Night Herons. Little Blue Herons may also nest here in small numbers.

The first-ever confirmed record of pelicans nesting on the island (or on Pelican Lake) was in 2017. Bruce Lenning of the DNR Nongame Wildlife Program led the early June survey, in which more than 100 nests were documented. Both hatchling pelicans and eggs were observed.

Spring is a wild time at this SNA. With wheeling wings and raucous calls ranging from croaks to snores to oinks to squawks, the birds return en masse to nest in trees and on the ground. For months, they occupy the island's two sheltered bays and its forest of white ash, basswood and slippery elm. Local lakes supply frogs, fish, crayfish and invertebrates to suit the species' varied diets.

Nesting success in a given year can be affected by factors such as predation, disturbance, and changes in water level. In general, such "aggregation" sites where animals gather in large numbers (i.e. mussel beds, bat concentration sites, migratory bird stopover areas, winter eagle roosts) call for special conservation measures, since a single catastrophic event can devastate a population. Please note the season when the island is designated a sanctuary and not open to visit.

One can still enjoy the spectacle of Egret Island by boat, for it is truly a sight to behold. Dr. Francesca Cuthbert, professor in the University of Minnesota Department of Fisheries, Wildlife and Conservation Biology, has studied colonial waterbird population dynamics throughout the Great Lakes and in Asia. She has a special appreciation for Egret Island. "If I would choose one colony in Minnesota as truly magical, that is the spot."

* Nesting colonial waterbird species noted in the 1977 DNR Nongame Wildlife Program inventory include western grebes, great blue heron, double-crested cormorant, black-crowned night heron, little blue heron, great egret, and cattle egret

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: Sanctuary (closed April 1 - July 15). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

name: Englund Ecotone SNA
description:
This site protects one of few remaining natural areas in rapidly developing Benton County. By definition, an "ecotone" is a place of transition between two biological communities or biomes. Here, this is expressed both in the transition from a sedge meadow and pin oak–bur oak woodland, and—at a larger scale—the gradual transition from the state's Eastern Broadleaf Province to the Laurentian Mixed Forest Province.

Dry oak woodlands dominate the site, interspersed with lowlands occupied by sedge meadow. The sedge meadows host such species as tussock, beak and lake sedge, as well as Vermont Bristle-berry, Wheeler's blackberry and the small white lady's-slipper. Although located on private land and without protected status, the existence of a high-quality dry barrens oak savanna on dunes north of the SNA gives this area state-wide biodiversity significance.

"Englund Ecotone SNA exists in a mixed use area of the Anoka Sandplain, reflecting both natural and cultural history," says Mark Hauck, planner for Ecological and Water Resources based in Sauk Rapids. "You'll find oak forest or groundwater-fed water features interspersed with areas converted for crops, pastureland, golf courses, housing developments. Where natural areas persist, its generally because the land was not suitable for another use, and because the native vegetation is better able to tolerate the tough, often dry, conditions of the Sandplain."

This SNA's history also reflects an important stage in the early development of Minnesota's Scientific and Natural Areas program. It was first protected as a preserve in 1975 by The Nature Conservancy, at the urging of Dr. Max Partch of St. Cloud State College. Surveys at the time did not find any state-listed species present on the site, which was then a requirement for SNA designation. A turning point came in 1988, when SNA criteria were expanded to include "undisturbed plant communities maintaining themselves under prevailing natural conditions typical of Minnesota." With its pin-oak bur oak woodlands and sedge meadows, the Englund Ecotone site met this standard. It was acquired by the state and designated an SNA in 2007. Undisturbed native plant communities are now recognized as one of the most significant natural features protected within SNAs—in their own right and not only as related to rare species.

As part of its "Million Acorn Campaign," the nonprofit Great River Greening has assisted with management activities on the SNA, conducting prescribed burns and restoring an old field along the north perimeter of the site to oak savanna. This work was done in part to foster habitat for Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) associated with the oak openings and barrens that existed in the Anoka sandplain in presettlement times, before suppression of fire. It is hoped that—in time—these efforts will bring an upswing of species such as the Red-headed Woodpecker, Eastern Meadowlark, Loggerhead Shrike and Grasshopper Sparrow. Stay tuned!

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: There is no legal public access to this site.

parking.directions: From Copas 2.75 miles N on MN Hwy 95. Park in Wind-in-the-Pines Township lot on E near wood-routed sign.
From Copas 3 miles N on MN Hwy 95. Park in lot on E near wood-routed sign.

name: Falls Creek SNA
description:
The work of water and time is expressed in dramatic terrain at Falls Creek SNA. Streams carve a winding path through steep-sided ravines as they make their way to the St. Croix River. Slopes face in all directions, providing a range of growing conditions and setting the stage for biodiversity.

Find lofty white pine, yellow birch, bitternut hickory, red and sugar maple, northern red oak, even butternut, an endangered species in Minnesota. Drier ridge tops are occupied by oak forest, while openings in the pine canopy on south-facing slopes favor sun-loving bluff prairie. Woodland wildflowers include lily-leaved twayblade and downy rattlesnake orchids, hepatica, trilliums, wild ginger and white trout lily.

The SNA's namesake creek is ephemeral in its upper reaches, seasonally dry but flowing in early spring and during heavy rains. Less than a mile from the St. Croix it becomes a perennial (permanently flowing) stream. Downstream of the SNA, where it passes through private land, Fall's Creek supports a naturally-reproducing population of brook trout.

In addition to helping protect the water quality of this trout stream, the SNA offers breeding habitat and a stopover site for migratory birds of the St. Croix Flyway. Listen for flocks of kinglets, the conversational notes of Red-breasted Nuthatches, and the ethereal call of a Hermit Thrush. During spring and fall migrations, visitors will note the passing of Trumpeter Swans, Sandhill Cranes, eagles and Broad-winged Hawks.

For geology buffs, faulting of bedrock here offers an interesting window into the past. Exposures span some 40 million years, from late Ordovician era Decorah shale (formed roughly 455 million years ago) through Cambrian Era Tunnel City sandstone (formed roughly 495 million years ago). These geologic features were part of the reason that the site was designated as an SNA.

A Scandia city park called Wind in the Pines Preserve borders Falls Creek SNA on the southeast. Its trails provide a beautiful and easy access to the SNA (which does not have trails). Please note that the fishable areas of Falls Creek pass through private land, and neither Falls Creek SNA nor Wind in the Pines Preserve currently offer public access to the St. Croix River.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (Bicentennial Unit only), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Felton 3.5 miles E on Co Hwy 34, then 1.3 miles S on unnamed gravel road. Right after road turns W park on S shoulder. Watch for gravel trucks. Hike 0.25 miles S on field road (county land), next to gravel pit to NW corner of site.
From Felton 3 miles E on Co Hwy 34. Park in pull-off on N, near wood-routed sign.
From Felton 4.5 miles E on Co Hwy 34, then 1.6 miles N on Co Rd 110. Park in lot on W.

name: Felton Prairie SNA
description:
The Felton Prairie complex is the most important gravel prairie complex in Minnesota, its four units associated with beach ridges (former shorelines) of Glacial Lake Agassiz. Mesic blacksoil prairie predominates, with gravel prairie on the ridges and wet black soil prairie occupying the swales. Among its rare features are a calcareous seepage fen, western prairie fringed orchids, Assiniboia and Dakota skippers, chestnut-collared longspurs, marbled godwits and loggerhead shrikes. The site is part of a designed Audubon Important Bird Area (IBA) and has long been a magnet for birders.

Visitors to this SNA will understand the 1962 site assessment of then-Wildlife Supervisor D. B. Lawrence, who noted that "all have been thrilled with the magnificence" of Felton Prairie. Over three dozen species of grasses and sedges blanket the landscape, interspersed with wildflowers such as blazing stars, wood lilies and Indian paintbrush. Glacial erratics rise from a largely treeless plain: looming boulders of red granite and other rocks of the Canadian shield carried here by glaciers from their points of origin 150 to more than 1,000 miles to the north.

Through the years, this prairie has inspired advocacy efforts from many quarters. Local citizens and youth groups, universities and research institutions, nonprofit as well as business interests have all played a role in its conservation.

Ownership & Origins: Portions of this site were gifts from Amoco Oil Corporation and the Red River Valley Sugar Beet Association. Portions of this site are owned by The Nature Conservancy and Clay County.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Taylors Falls 3.25 miles SW on US Hwy 8, then 1.25 miles S on MN Hwy 95. Park in pull-off on E.
From Taylors Falls 3.25 miles SW on US Hwy 8, then 0.75 mile S on MN Hwy 95, then 370 feet E on drive. Park and hike E within signed corridor to bluffs. No parking along Franconia Trl.

name: Franconia Bluffs SNA

wildflower.cname: White trout lily (Past flowering may have been yellow trout lily)

description:
Although it has no river frontage, Franconia Bluffs is one of four SNAs along the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway between Taylor's Falls and Scandia in what has been identified as a priority conservation area for the St. Croix Watershed.

With its forest cover, the SNA adds to the block of unfragmented habitat needed for forest interior birds, provides a buffer for floodplain marshes on National Park Service land, and benefits the St. Croix's fishery and rich mussel community by limiting erosion of nutrients/sediments into tributary streams feeding the river—a top water quality issue. The rare Higgins eye mussel, listed as an endangered species at state and federal levels, has been documented in this stretch of the St. Croix.

Enter either of the site's two parcels, and you'll soon encounter steep slopes flanking wide ravines. White pines are seen along ridges, but hardwoods predominate throughout. By mid-May, much of this SNA drops into shade.

Northern red oak, sugar maple and basswood are the most abundant canopy trees in the western parcel, with sugar maple and ironwood in the sub-canopy. The eastern parcel is dominated by oaks (northern red, northern pin and white) in the canopy with red maple common in the understory. A fenced deer exclosure atop the bluff marks a reforestation project, where former agricultural lands and a conifer plantation have been replanted to oak woodland using locally sourced acorns and seedlings. Much of this work has been accomplished by volunteers (including local youth) with the assistance of the nonprofit Great River Greening. In the years ahead, it will be interesting to watch these trees grow and merge with the surrounding forest.

Among the most special—and fragile—features here are the spring lines that characterize these St. Croix River terraces, traceable for miles. Here, the headwaters of springs are associated with alluvial fans: ramps of fine sediment at the head of lush, green gully runs. "It's called spring sapping," says DNR hydrologist Greg Brick, "the gnawing of a spring back into the hillside above it." Skunk cabbage and other aquatic plants growing high on a slope are also telltale signs of seeps and springs.

This site is located at the transition between two of the state's major ecological provinces. As Minnesota Biological Survey Supervisor Hannah Texler describes, Franconia Bluffs SNA is at the southern edge of the Laurentian Mixed Forest Province, in a section defined by Des Moines lobe sediments (calcareous till, clayey soils). Just a few miles downriver, Falls Creek SNA is within the Eastern Broadleaf Forest Province, in a section defined by Superior Lobe deposits (non-calcareous till, more sandy soils). "It's a broad transition zone," says Texler, "so bedrock, slope and aspect* may play a more significant role than province in the vegetation of these two SNAs.

Visit here in spring before the early flush of wildflowers begins to fade for bloodroot, trillium, Virginia spring beauty, and the delicate white spires of miterwort and clusters of blue phlox. Listen for the repeated "kee-ah" of a Red-shouldered Hawk, and watch for other rare/listed species documented in the vicinity including the Cerulean Warbler, Acadian Flycatcher, Louisiana Waterthrush and wood turtle.

*Aspect is the direction that a slope faces. In general, north-facing slopes tend to receive less direct sun and therefore offer more moist/cool conditions. South-facing slopes tend to receive more direct sun, are drier/warmer.

Ownership & Origins: The Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Syre 4 miles E on MN Hwy 113, then 1.1 miles N on Co Hwy 36. Park in lot on W.

name: Frenchman's Bluff SNA
description:
At 1350 feet in elevation with 200 feet of local relief, Frenchman's Bluff overlooks the Red River Valley from one of the highest points in northwestern Minnesota. The view is courtesy of a glacial moraine deposited roughly 9000 years ago, now vegetated by mesic and dry sand-gravel prairie.

As one climbs the slope, the plant community reflects increasingly drier conditions, not unlike driving cross-country from Minnesota west into the deepening rainshadow of the Rocky Mountains. Making allowances for the influence of slope direction on moisture, note a general shift in relative abundance from tall grasses (big bluestem, Indian grass) on the lower slope, to mid-height grasses (prairie dropseed, little bluestem, porcupine grass), to shorter grasses more typical of western prairies (blue grama and needle-and-thread grass) at higher elevations.

The SNA offers an important refuge for native species vulnerable to herbicides, grazing and gravel mining. Of special note is the state-endangered Frenchman's Bluff moonwort, unknown to science before it was discovered here and named for the site in 1986. To date, only five populations of this tiny fern have been documented in the country, two of which are in Minnesota. Also found here is the Northern grasshopper mouse, a state special concern species. Truly a rodent with a reputation, this carnivorous, sometimes cannibalistic mouse is known for its complex communication system that includes howling during its nocturnal hunting forays.

This SNA has been extensively used by the University of Minnesota Itasca Biological Station and other university groups for education and research into the dynamics, flora and fauna of Midwestern prairies.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

This site has abundant stands of poison ivy.

parking.directions: From Tracy 3.5 miles W on US Hwy 14, then 1.75 miles N on Co Hwy 9. Park in pull-off on W.

name: Glynn Prairie SNA
description:
In its comprehensive plan, Lyon County recognizes places within its governance as having "intrinsic natural value" and worthy of preserving for generations to come. Among these is Glynn Prairie.

Roughly half of the site's 80 acres is occupied by high quality, undisturbed mesic blacksoil prairie, with an impressive species list that includes leadplant, ground plum, larkspur, prairie gentian, bergamot, purple coneflower, and grasses such as big bluestem, Indian grass and prairie cordgrass. Areas of the site impacted by former grazing are being enhanced over time through restoration of native vegetation using local seed.

Visitors will find gently sloping terrain cut by two intermittent stream channels, and a shallow artificial pond where waterfowl may be seen. Listen for bobolinks, Western meadowlarks, the "witchedy-witchedy" of common yellowthroats, even the trademark wolf-whistle of the upland sandpiper, considered to be a 'species of greatest conservation need' (SGCN) due to concerns for its population status.

Unseen but no less important is the prairie's below-ground diversity. This was one of more than 30 sites in eight states around the nation included in a recent (2013) study using genetic analysis to reconstruct microbial diversity of pre-agricultural tallgrass prairie soils-information intended to guide conservation efforts related to this fragmented ecosystem.

The site takes its name from the local family that donated the land to be preserved in its natural state

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy through a donation from the Glynn family.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Granite Falls, 1.5 miles E on MN Hwy 212, then 2.75 miles S on Co Rd 40, then about 0.1 mile W on 170th St SE. Park on N road shoulder.
From Granite Falls, 1.5 miles E on MN Hwy 212, then 2.5 miles S on Co Rd 40. Park on W road shoulder near wood-routed sign.

name: Gneiss Outcrops SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


In his fine essay, A World within a World, the late Paul Gruchow writes of the "improbable serenity" of this place that now lies within a large meander of the Minnesota River, in the presence of ancient rock that has known episodes of Paleozoic seas, the migration of continents, and the weight of glacial ice.

The Gneiss Outcrops, formed approximately 3.6 billion years ago, are among the oldest known rock on the earth's surface. This SNA's significance steadily increases as other outcrops along the Minnesota River are exploited for granite mining, housing, and recreational use. These pyramidal outcrops along the Glacial River Warren Valley rise to about 50 feet above the general level of the land, revealing parallel bands of gneiss.

Granitic gneiss is light-colored, pink to red; the less common hornblende-pyroxene gneiss is darker, ranging from gray to black. Garnet-biotite gneiss appears in dark and light gray variations. In addition to these metamorphic rocks, the outcrops reveal igneous rock complexes, formed by heat and pressure below the earth's surface.

A natural lake, known by the Dakota as Bde Caåotidaå, lies between the two major rock outcrops, providing a stunning contrast to the adjacent rock cliffs. The rare plains prickly pear and brittle cactus can be found on dry rock; Carolina foxtail, little barley, and mousetail grow in shallow depressions among the outcrops.

Explore the outcroppings in early July to see the yellow blossoms of the plains prickly pear cacti and smaller brittle cacti anchored in the crevices between lichen-covered rocks. Take in the splendid views across the river valley, or-as Paul Gruchow did-find a ledge to rest above the lake, and consider the workings of time.

Scientific research at this SNA has included investigations to determine potential habitat suitability for five-lined skink.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Minnesota River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From Ponsford 3.5 miles W on Co Hwy 26, then 1 mile N on Co Hwy 37, then 1.5 miles W on Co Hwy 35. Park in lot on S.

name: Greenwater Lake SNA
description:
At the heart of this SNA lies 77-acre Greenwater Lake. The lake is over 50 feet deep, very clear and relatively low in productivity. Its water chemistry is affected by calcareous material that was carried here by glaciers from the northwest, now represented as calcium carbonate deposits in near-shore areas. Inflows to the lake are almost entirely from seeps and springs. A single permanent stream flows on the SNA, running north out of Greenwater toward Ice Cracking Lake, its waters bound for Hudson's Bay.

Curiously, researchers have found a particular diatom (algae) species that is uncommon in area lakes to be abundant here. Fragilaria nanana* is known to be one of the few diatom species able to tolerate conditions in so-called "meromictic" lakes: lakes that remain permanently stratified in temperature layers rather than the more typical mixing during twice-yearly turnovers. (Argo and Deming Lakes at nearby Itasca State Park are examples.) Greenwater Lake is not known to be meromictic, but it's speculated that the high calcium content of its water may be influencing the temperature profile of the lake and limiting the degree of mixing that occurs.

For many years, this SNA was under the watchful eye of Ruth Berquist, longtime volunteer Site Steward. Berquist, who passed away in late 2017 at the age of 82, had loved this area since she was a girl and her family had a summer cabin on nearby Round Lake. She enjoyed seeing wildflowers such as shinleaf and fringed gentian, the trusted pair of nesting loons, the occasional wolf. She especially appreciated the undeveloped shoreline and the size of the trees. Speaking in 2017, she remarked; "Compared to surrounding areas that have more recently been logged—usually clear cut—you can really recognize a difference here, in the maturity and diversity of the forest." Hopefully, others will carry on her tradition, getting to know and love this SNA as well as she did.

With 815 acres, this is among the largest of the state's SNAs not dominated by peatland. Terrain varies from gently rolling to steep hills: what geologists call "kettle and kame" topography. Historically, white and red pine were a major component of the forest cover. These have been largely replaced by a mix of oak-aspen-red maple forest, sugar maple-basswood forest and jack pine woodland. Wetland communities include alder and black ash swamps, as well as sedge meadow and rich fen at the lake's north end.

Early inventories here documented river otter, bobcat and black bear, along with small mammals such as the boreal redback vole, meadow jumping mouse and arctic shrew. Nearly three dozen species of butterfly were reported, among them the Appalachian brown, mustard white and pine elfin.

Even those Minnesotans who never choose to visit can take comfort from knowing the life that thrives here. In Greenwater Lake SNA, the state has protected a real jewel.

*Fragilaria nanana: This species was earlier reported variously as Synedra nana, Synedra filiformis. Information provided is from a 1980 ecological evaluation completed for this site, with additional input from Mark Edlund, Senior Scientist, St. Croix Watershed Research Station.
notes: The North Country National Scenic Trail passes through site, see detail map. This site is within the White Earth Indian Reservation.

parking.directions: In Cottage Grove, from US Hwy 61 0.75 mile S on Jamaica Ave, then 0.4 mile W on 100th St, then 1 mile S on Ideal Ave, then 0.5 mile W on 110th St. Park in lot at dead end.
In Cottage Grove, from US Hwy 61 0.75 mile S on Jamaica Ave, then 1.4 miles W on 100th St, then 0.25 mile S on Hadley Ave. Park in lot on E. Hike E then S on field road into prairie area of site.

name: Grey Cloud Dunes SNA
description:
The landscape here grandly illustrates the story of the Mississippi River's past. Two terraces roughly 50 and 110 feet above the present-day water surface are the handiwork of Glacial River Warren, which drained Glacial Lake Agassiz between 12,000 and 10,000 ago. Atop the terraces are dunes that formed later, during a mid-Holocene warm/dry period 8,000–4,000 years ago, when wind-driven sands from Grey Cloud Island were deposited on the slopes above.

Today's river flows far below the bluff line, but the size of its valley reflects this turbulent past. University of St. Thomas geologists Drs. Thomas Hickson and Melissa Lamb set the scene in a report prepared for the site's nomination as a National Natural Landmark: "Standing on the high terrace of the SNA and looking southwest at the Mississippi River valley, one has to imagine the River Warren spreading out across the entire width of that valley from bluff to bluff to get a sense of the scale of this torrent."

Local citizens actively advocated for this site's protection. "It was a fortuitous event to save it," notes avid birder and Cottage Grove resident Tom Bell, who recalls earlier proposals to develop the area as a golf course. Community volunteers now help with restoration work, collecting native seed to restore prairie on parts of the site once cultivated for corn, peppers and soybeans.

This SNA showcases a variety of native plant communities. Uplands host dry prairie, oak woodland and savanna, while lowlands along the river contain a floodplain forest of elm, silver maple, cottonwood and box elder. A small pond, backwater slough, and a half-mile of shoreline along the river add to the diversity of the site.

Each season has its merits for visitors. In winter, enjoy vistas of sky and still-golden prairie grasses. Spring and summer offer a riot of wildflowers, occasional sightings of a blue racer snake or prairie skink, and grassland birds such as Lark Buntings and Henslow's, Clay-colored and Grasshopper Sparrows. Large numbers of raptors and waterfowl may be seen moving along Mississippi flyway during spring and fall migrations.

Please steer clear of sparsely vegetated areas of dune slopes and 'blow-outs.' These fragile areas offer habitat for sea beach needle grass (also known as seaside three-awn) a species with very limited distribution in Minnesota.

An active line of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad bisects this site, and frequent trains rumble through. A tunnel beneath the tracks provides access between the SNA's two sections.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Ashland Incorporated.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Mississippi River Water Trail is adjacent to this site. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Gully 2.5 miles N on Co Rd 2, then 0.75 mile E on Twp Rd 667. Park on S shoulder.

name: Gully Fen SNA
description:
Located southwest of Lower Red Lake in Polk County, this site of outstanding biodiversity significance occurs in a transitional zone between the coniferous forests of the Laurentian Mixed Forest Province and the prairies of the Prairie Parklands Province. The landscape here owes its topography to Glacial Lake Agassiz.* Vast areas of level lake plain are interspersed with low dunes, beach ridges and wet swales (low moist land) left behind when the lake abandoned its bed approximately 9,000 years ago. The "gully" in Gully Fen SNA is a reference to the nearby town of Gully, MN, which in 2014 had a population of 66.

The SNA showcases a diversity of groundwater-influenced seepage communities that include open rich peatland, forested peatland, wet forest, and wet meadow components. In addition to a 500-acre area defined as a "wetland seepage complex," the Minnesota Biological Survey has documented eight native plant communities mapped here, six of which are ranked as S3, or vulnerable to extirpation (destruction) in Minnesota. Among the many rare, state-listed species within the SNA are the ram's head orchid and white adder's mouth orchid. The site is also home to nearly two dozen Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) identified under Minnesota's Wildlife Action Plan, including such species as Nelson's Sparrow, Veery, Willow Flycatcher and Sharp-tailed Grouse.

The Natural Heritage Information System database lists three types of fens as occurring on this SNA: Rich Fen (prairie seepage), Prairie Rich Fen, and several Calcareous Fens. "Calcareous seepage fens are among the most special features of this site," says SNA Program Regional Specialist Shelley Hedtke. Roughly 100 acres of this nationally-rare community exist on the SNA in pockets within the seepage wetland complex and, to a lesser degree, in forested peatlands. Calcium-rich groundwater seeps from the base of sand dunes and the downslope side of beach ridges to support a community of "calcifiles," or calcium-loving plants, including such species as sterile sedge, hair-like beak rush and beaked spikerush.

Prior to SNA designation, this 1,610-acre site was threatened by logging and rice paddy operations. Today, the ground-water sensitive features within its boundaries remain vulnerable to surrounding land uses with the potential to affect hydrology, such as mining and irrigation.

Fortunately, this part of the state has increasingly celebrated the value of its vast bogs and fens, once seen as wastelands. Local residents led the effort to establish Big Bog State Recreation Area in Beltrami County in 2000, which now draws more than 90,000 visitors annually to the region. Says Park Manager Doug Easthouse, "You'd be surprised at how far people have traveled to see this remote landscape. The tourist dollars are important to area communities, for sure. But I think there's also a growing awareness among the people who live in this part of the state that these places really are unique and special."

Would-be visitors to this site will want to be aware: as the native plant communities present here suggest, conditions across this large SNA range from wet to more wet.

* Detail on Glacial Lake Agassiz, from Gully Fen Management Plan: Glacial Lake Agassiz was the largest glacial lake to occur within Minnesota, and covered over 300,000 square kilometers across northern Minnesota, eastern North Dakota, Manitoba, and Ontario over the course of its existence (10). Glacial Lake Agassiz formed around 11,700 years ago and was completely drained by approximately 9,000 years ago, thus spanning 2,700 years. Gully Fen SNA lies within the southwest edge of the Glacial Lake Agassiz Lacustrine Plain.
notes: Larix WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Baudette 2.5 miles W on MN Hwy 11, then 10.8 miles S on Co Rd  3 (Co Rd 1/Wilderness Dr), then 11.9 miles W on Co Rd 87 (Stoney Corners Forest Rd), then 2.1 miles S on unnamed road to large clearing. Park and trek W into site. GPS recommended.

name: Gustafson's Camp SNA
description:
Dense, dark, lush, wild: these are the words that come to mind for SNA regional specialist Shelly Hedtke when she thinks of Gustafson's Camp SNA.

Named for an early logging camp, this site is distinguished by its stands of old-growth red pine and white pine that occur as pockets within mature aspen woods on the eastern part of the SNA. Such stands are very rare in the Agassiz Lowlands. Pine forests were never common here, even prior to European settlement, and these old-growth stands are among only a few in existence today in the Baudette Forestry Area. Scattered, individual "supercanopy" pines may also be seen rising above the canopy of quaking aspen, balsam fir, paper birch and white cedar.

The aspen/pine forest is surrounded by lowland conifer forest to the north, south and west, where an active beaver flowage adds diversity to the site.

"This site is definitely a gem for northwest Minnesota," says Area Wildlife Manager Scott Laudenslager. "In summer of 2017 we cored a white pine in the SNA that was 178 years old. Think about it: these trees originated before the Civil War."

Calypso (fairy slipper), Hooker's and the Minnesota threatened ram's head orchid bloom here in early summer, rising from moss-covered hummocks and the tip-up mounds of fallen trees. In spring and fall, waves of migrating warblers briefly mingle with Mourning, Yellow, Chestnut-sided, and Black-and-white Warblers on their summer breeding grounds. Spruce Grouse (which eat spruce needles and buds) have also been documented here, finding their preferred habitat in this SNA's lowland conifer forest.

For the most part, this site has been left to its own devices. Managers keep an eye on the regeneration of pine, which can benefit from a degree of soil disturbance and fast, low intensity fire. Visitors will notice a deer exclosure, installed to prevent browsing of young trees (although site steward Martin Kehoe reports having seen a snowshoe hare inside the exclosure!).

The access road to this SNA is rough in the best of circumstances and can be impassible during wet seasons/periods. To reach the parking area depicted on the map, one must first follow this road for roughly a mile across tribal lands owned and managed by Red Lake Band and another 2/3 mile of DNR Forestry land. It's wise to inquire about the road's condition before visiting by calling the Baudette Area Wildlife Office at (218) 634-1705.

Listen to this call of a spruce grouse, recorded by Steve Wilson and Peter Neubeck in Superior National Forest, near Ely!
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within the Beltrami Island State Forest.

parking.directions: From St Cloud 2 miles S on US Hwy 10, then 0.2 mile SE on Frontage Rd. Park in lot for Sand Prairie WMA. Shuttle boat 1.75 miles S on US Hwy 10, then 2 miles E on Co Hwy 3. Site is about 1 mile S (downstream) via Elk River. Accessible by boat.

name: Harry W. Cater Homestead Prairie SNA
description:
Accessible only by water via the Elk River, "Cater Prairie" displays a continuum of habitats from dry, upland bur oak savanna, to mesic and wet-mesic prairie openings in aspen groves, to floodplain forest, wet meadow and marsh. The river skirts the eastern boundary of the SNA, making two small loops into the site.

To see this SNA in context requires a broader view, both in terms of time and geography. "Zoom out" on the map view below and you'll see that this site lies within a strip of land bordered on the east by the Elk River on the west by the Mississippi River. Although not as dramatic as the Mississippi Valley terraces at Grey Cloud Dunes SNA south of the Twin Cities Metro, the sandy, droughty soil here is also derived from Mississippi River terrace deposits, dating from the last stages of glacial melting roughly 10,000 years ago. At the time of the Government Land Survey 150 years ago, this 'land between the two rivers' was dominated by prairie. That prairie has since been largely converted to other uses (residential, agricultural). In those places where native vegetation remains, as in the SNA, the lack of fire has allowed the incursion of woody plants such as aspen, oak, dogwood and willow.

Today, bur oak savanna and wet-mesic prairie are considered the most significant native plant communities within the SNA: both of which are rare in this landscape region. As noted by MBS surveyor Barb Delaney who evaluated this site prior to its SNA designation, the prairie openings on the site occur in an area of old meanders in the Elk River floodplain. These abandoned river channels, says Delaney, are barely perceptible on the ground but are visible in aerial photographs.

As cars pass by on Highway 10 half a mile away and planes take off and land from the nearby St. Cloud airport, the oak savanna and native prairie at Harry W. Cater Homestead Prairie SNA are no less active: anchoring the soil, sustaining bees and other pollinators, and offering habitat for birds such as the Red-shouldered Hawk and Golden-winged Warbler.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from the Harry W. Cater family.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: In Hastings on MN Hwy 291 near eastern city limits. Park in CP Adams City Park. Hike E to site.

name: Hastings SNA
description:
The Hastings SNA consists of two parcels totaling 64.9 acres. The northwest parcel, about 26 acres, is entirely in the Vermillion/Mississippi River floodplain and consists of floodplain forest and emergent marsh. The Vermillion River covers about 3 acres here as it meanders through this parcel. Silver maple dominates the forest, with green ash and small diameter American elm. The southeast unit, about 43 acres, is dominated by mesic oak forest, with old-growth red oak, sugar maple, and basswood on steep north-facing bluffs and bluff tops. Sugar-maple basswood forest covers a small section of the mid-slope, and emergent marsh, pond and floodplain forest cover low-lying areas.

A wide diversity of plant species has been documented on this site, including kittentails and a population of snow trillium first documented in 1905. Talus slopes and steep escarpments of dolomitic limestone provide habitat for mosses, lichens, and liverworts. The site topography is varied, with a 52-meter (170 feet) difference in elevation across the site.

The nonprofit group Friends of the Mississippi River (FMR) has been very active here. FMR's Restoration Ecologist Karen Schik prepared a management plan for the site and has also coordinated volunteers on projects ranging from monitoring the snow trillium population to "rescuing" native plants that would otherwise have been impacted by rebuilding of the state highway that runs through this SNA. The group harvested, stored and replanted plants of many native species, including but not limited to maidenhair fern, wild leek, wood anemone, wild ginger, blue cohosh, Dutchman's breeches, and large-flowered bellwort.

Context matters here.
