At least seventeen state-listed threatened and endangered species are found within a mile of this SNA, including at least one federally-endangered species, the winged mapleleaf mussel. As former FMR Conservation Director Tom Lewanski notes, "From a landscape perspective, the Hastings SNA is part of a conservation corridor that helps link the Hastings Sand Coulee SNA to the south and the Gores Pool Wildlife Management Area and the Mississippi River to the north." FMR has played an instrumental role in these and many other natural areas along the river.

Flood events are a part of the natural disturbance regime here, affecting both access to the site and the structure of the native plant communities present. During major flood events, the Mississippi River floods into the Lower Vermillion, reversing the flow of water and flooding the entire north parcel of the SNA. These events have increased in frequency in recent years, a trend that bears watching.

This SNA's bluffs, spring-fed pools, river shoreline and relatively small parcels—which are further fragmented by roads—make it vulnerable to disturbance. Visitors are encouraged to avoid the steeper areas of the site in the interest of protecting these fragile habitats.
notes: This site has no maintained trails. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Recreational facilities available in adjacent CP Adams City Park.

parking.directions: From Hastings 1 mile SE on MN Hwy 316, then 0.6 mile E and S on Tuttle Dr. Park at stormwater utility and hike maintenance road NE into site.
From Hastings 2.4 miles SE on MN Hwy 316. Park in lot on SW, just past guard rail.

name: Hastings Sand Coulee SNA
description:
Originally designated in 2007 as a 77-acre SNA and since expanded to include three parcels totaling more than 267 acres, this site takes its name from the Hastings Sand Coulee, a 2.5 mile-long valley once occupied by a glacial stream that now supports the most significant dry prairie in Dakota County.

A tributary stream to the Vermillion River meanders through all three parcels of this SNA, which serve to protect high quality native plant communities including dry sand-gravel prairie, mesic prairie, oak woodland and oak forest in an area otherwise dominated by agricultural land use and expanding housing developments.

A remarkable assembly of native species find critical habitat within this SNA, among them plants such as James' polanisia, sea-beach needlegrass, and clasping milkweed, and animals such as the regal fritillary butterfly, Ottoe skipper, gopher snake, blue racer and loggerhead shrike.

One step along the way that piqued interest in potential SNA designation for this site was a prescribed burn conducted at the adjacent Hastings Wildlife Management Area that resulted in the emergence of a surprising number of native prairie plants. Clearly, the land still remembered its roots.

It is notable that land acquisitions for this SNA relied upon many voluntary agreements with private landowners holding small but important parcels: local residents who wished to participate in protecting this important site.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from the Murnane family in honor of Joseph and Joanne Murnane. Friends of the Mississippi River and Dakota County Farmland and Natural Area Program assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: The scenic slopes and ravines of the coulee are vulnerable to erosion. Please take care to avoid damage to the slopes when visiting the area. This site has abundant poison ivy. Hastings WMA is adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From MN Hwy 65 in Bethel 1 mile E on Co Hwy 24 (237th Ave N), then 3.5 miles S and E on Co Hwy 26 (229th Ave N), then 0.25 mile S on Co Rd 15. Park in pull-off on W.

name: Helen Allison Savanna SNA
description:
If you have never seen an oak savanna, come here! See the large, open-grown bur oaks with a prairie understory. Understand why people love savannas.

Helen Allison Savanna was named for Helen Allison Irvine, "Minnesota's grass lady," who wrote a text on the 180 grasses of Minnesota. This SNA lies within the Anoka sand plain, providing an excellent example of sand dune plant succession, with blowouts and dunes in various stages of stabilization by pioneer species.

Community types found on the site include oak sand savanna, dry prairie with bur oak and pin oak, thickets of willow and aspen, and sedge marshes in scattered depressions. Trees and shrubs characteristic of a savanna are found here: pin oak, bur oak, American hazelnut, chokecherry, and quaking aspen. Other savanna species include lead plant, smooth sumac, slender willow, steeple bush, aster, and goldenrod. Look on the dunes for pioneer sand plants such as sea-beach needle grass and hairy panic grass. Sedge meadows contain tussocks of Hayden's sedge, along with marsh fern and blue-joint grass. Other rare plant species occurring here include rhombic-petaled evening primrose and tall nut-rush.

The ecological significance of this site must be understood in the context of the larger landscape, which includes the adjacent Cedar Creek Ecosystem Science Reserve.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Willard Munger State Trail).

Deer hunting only allowed (only muzzleloader by permit through Jay Cooke State Park), see the regulations handbook for hunting details. Varies year to year, check current regulations handbook for information.

parking.directions: From Esko, 2.2 miles S on Co Rd 1 (Thompson Rd), then 1.0 mile E on E Palkie Rd, then 0.75 mile S on Co Rd 151 to parking area on E. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Hemlock Ravine SNA
description:
A little more than a mile from the great gorge of the St. Louis River, rooted in steep slopes prone to erosion and mudslides, are 9 eastern hemlock trees of significant size. Their trunks measure between 9.6 and 48.1 centimeters diameter (about 3.5–19 inches) at breast height. Many Minnesotans have likely never seen a hemlock tree. The species is at the extreme western edge of its U.S. range here, and this small stand actually represents one of the 3 largest populations in the state.

The trees are in a precarious position. In 2012, a 10" rainfall from a single storm resulted in a devastating mudslide that is still clearly visible. Two large hemlocks were lost and many others (including smaller saplings) were put in jeopardy. To protect what remains, parts of this SNA are marked and designated as sanctuary areas (see map), not open to visitors.

Visitors honoring the sanctuary zone will still be able to catch site of this graceful coniferous tree. The hemlock's dark green needles are flat, soft to the touch and shorter than those of the more common balsam fir. See the delicate twigs weighed down at their tips by small cones, and the trunks of larger hemlocks patterned with the drill-marks of yellow-bellied sapsuckers. It is encouraging to note the many hemlock seedlings and saplings growing within in the protection of fencing, giving hope for the future of the species at this site.

Hemlocks are listed as endangered in Minnesota, and are considered one of the state's most imperiled trees. Yet, the fine old growth northern hardwood forest here is in itself rare.

Characterized by sugar maple, yellow birch and basswood on the uplands, it is complemented on the slopes by paper birch, mature cedar, the hemlocks, and large white pine. In its entirety, this forest offers important breeding habitat for interior-forest northern birds such as the scarlet tanager, and (together with adjacent Jay Cooke State Park) is a hot spot for viewing songbirds during spring and fall migrations.
notes: Sanctuary (posted sanctuary portions closed). The Willard Munger State trail is adjacent to site, see detail map. Recreational facilities available in Jay Cooke State Park.

restrictions: All hunting allowed (no waterfowl, Hole in the Bog Lake is a waterfowl refuge), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Bena 2.5 miles S on Co Hwy 8. Park in pull-off on W. Trek 0.25 mile W into site. GPS recommended.

name: Hole in the Bog Peatland SNA
description:
Hole in the Bog Peatland is located in north central Minnesota, south of the Agassiz Lowlands, between Leech Lake and Lake Winnibigosh. This is the most southwesterly peatland SNA and also one of the few outside a major glacial lake plain. It contains relatively undisturbed examples of raised black spruce bog and open bog. These peatland communities surround a small lake (named, not surprisingly, Hole-in-the-Bog Lake).

This is a world of hummocks and hollows, with expansive carpets of moss rich in sphagnum moss. In the areas of the site characterized by spruce bog, it's interesting to note how the cover and distribution of trees changes across the site. Density of black spruce is greatest on the drier, upper portions of the raised bog crest, where drainage is best, then becomes progressively sparser toward the base of the crest and in drains (channels) where the water table is higher. Scattered tamarack, which require more light, appear in those areas where black spruce has grown sparse. In the open bog, dead or stunted trees may be found at shrub level among Labrador tea, leather leaf and bog laurel, in some places dropping out altogether as woody vegetation gives way to graminoids (grass-like plants) such as bog wiregrass and tussock cottongrass.

Raised above the surrounding peatland, the bog is out of reach of groundwater and runoff. By definition, bogs are ombrotrophic: receiving minerals and nutrients only from what falls out of the sky or is carried by the wind, as dust fall or precipitation. Since only 25 species of vascular plants are known to persist in such conditions—and only 6 forbs (flowering plants)— it doesn't take long to become familiar with them. Here, one can find the three-leaved false Solomon's seal with its cluster of white, star-like flowers, as well as the carnivorous round-leaved sundew, which also has white flowers but is better recognized by its orbs of finely shaped red leaves, each glistening with a sticky droplet at the tip.

The Minnesota Biological Survey has documented the freija fritillary butterfly here, along with 9 species of peatland moths. The lake is designated as a wildlife refuge, and is used by a variety of waterfowl. Research here has included a study of breeding Ring-necked Duck populations.

Typical of bogs, the terrain here is not easy to negotiate on foot, but this site is more accessible than many of the state's peatland SNAs. A relatively short walk across Bowstring State Forest from the parking area on Cass County 8 will bring you to into the site.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within Bowstring State Forest.

parking.directions: From Windom 4.5 miles SE on US Hwy 71, then 4.5 miles S on gravel road (becomes Co Rd 19), then W 0.75 mile on minimum maintenance road. Park in lot on S.

name: Holthe Prairie SNA
description:
Dry hill prairie is the most abundant native plant community represented on the rolling terrain here, but Holthe Prairie SNA is best known for its calcareous fen, among the largest in the Des Moines River Valley.

This 3.5-acre calcareous fen is of a type ranked S2, or imperiled, in Minnesota. It lies at the base of a terrace, flanked by seepage meadow/carr and bordered on one side by the Des Moines River in the southwestern corner of the SNA. Groundwater comes to the surface in open, marly* areas of active upwelling reaching 10' in diameter. Species that thrive here in these alkaline waters include marsh arrowgrass, grass-of-Parnassus, prairie sedge and cottongrass.

Although grazed prior to SNA designation, the hill prairies here retain a diversity of native prairie vegetation, with big bluestem, little bluestem, Indian grass, junegrass, grass, grama grass, plains muhly and prairie dropseed. The site is also notable for the presence here in 1996 and '97 of a small population of federally and state-listed as threatened prairie bush clover which has not been documented in subsequent years.

The dry, upland prairie here provides habitat for a declining grassland bird species of particular interest, the grasshopper sparrow. University of Minnesota researcher Lisa Harn Elliott and DNR Nongame Wildlife Specialist Lisa Gelvin-Innvaer ("Team Lisa") have utilized this site for research into the distribution and habitat associations of the Grasshopper Sparrow and its usefulness as an indicator species for grassland birds in southwest Minnesota.

In a story for the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer magazine, Elliot describes this unobtrusive bird with its "brown and taupe coloration alleviated only by dots of yellow just above its eyes." This unlikely hero, she writes, is considered a surrogate species "characteristic of a whole suite of unassuming grassland species." If Grasshopper Sparrows decline in the state, it is likely these other species are declining as well, along with the upland prairie habitat they require. Elliott and Gelvin-Innvaer's work on the species here has provided valuable baseline information to help guide future research, monitoring, and conservation on both public and private lands.

Holthe Prairie SNA gains in value from its location in a relatively unfragmented landscape with many biologically significant areas in close proximity. Along with privately owned prairies (including Native Prairie Bank easements) are publicly-owned parks and natural areas including Kilen Woods State Park, Belmont County Park, Des Moines River SNA and Caraway Wildlife Management Area. Together, these sites provide critical habitat for species —like the Grasshopper Sparrow and many prairie-dependent butterfly species—that rely on the state's diminished grassland habitats.

* Mineral-rich groundwater, laden with calcium and magnesium bicarbonates, that precipitates out at the surface to create an alkaline soil condition that only a select group of plants can tolerate.

Origins and Ownership: A portion of this site was a gift from the Holthe family.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: ATVs on designated trail (Boyd Road Trail and Stevens Spur ).
Biking on designated trail (Boyd Road Trail and Stevens Spur ).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Snowmobiling on designated trail (Boyd Road Trail and Stevens Spur ).

parking.directions: From Hovland 0.2 miles N on Co Rd 16, then 2.6 miles W on Co Rd 69 (North Rd), then 4.6 miles NE on Co Rd 70 (Camp 20 Rd) Stay right at Y. In 0.25 mile park at Superior Hiking Trail lot on right. Hike trail 1.2 miles E to site. GPS recommended.

From Hovland 6.7 miles on Co Rd 16, then 1.2 miles W on Irish Creek Rd. Park in lot at junction of Boyd Rd. Hike 0.8 mile on Boyd Rd into site. Boyd Rd is also used by ATVs and dogsleds. GPS recommended.

name: Hovland Woods SNA
description:
Nearly 30 years of effort have been invested in documenting this site's ecologically significant features and acquiring parcels for protection through the Scientific and Natural Areas Program.

It is hard to imagine time better spent.

The two tracts of the SNA encompass a complex landscape, hosting over a dozen mapped native plant communities (see detail map) and laced by a variety of water features, including the Swamp River, beaver flowages, and headwater areas of the Flute Reed River and Irish Creek watersheds. The Swamp River, its tributary, and a number of tributaries to the Flute Reed River within the SNA are designated trout streams.

Aspen-birch forest (balsam fir subtype) blankets roughly half of the SNA's 1,280 acres. Priority features for conservation here are the site's sugar maple forest (232 acres), upland white cedar forest (180 acres), white cedar swamp (44 acres) and lowland white cedar forest (43 acres). As described by an interpretive sign displayed on site, these hardwood forests are able to persist near Lake Superior's north shore in part because of the lake-moderated climate with cooler summers, milder winters and higher humidity.

The western tract hosts more old-growth and generally more mature forest of all types than the eastern. This is due in large part to their differing fire history: most notably, a 1936 fire that burned 10,000 acres in the central part of the Grand Portage State Forest, including what is now the eastern tract of the SNA in its entirety, and the extreme eastern corner of the western tract.

Topography throughout the SNA ranges from steep to gently rolling. Ridges and stream cuts add to the diversity of habitats, hosting small but interesting cliff/talus communities.

Sugarloaf Cove Interpretive Association Naturalist Margie Menzies has visited the SNA often: hearing Parula Warblers, finding abundant moose sign, encountering an active beaver lodge. Hiking in on the Superior Hiking Trail via Camp 20 Road, she notes, one can readily observe the contrast between clear-cut areas on private land and the forests protected within the SNA.

Although in many respects a remote site, access is far greater on the eastern tract, which is crossed by ATV/multi-use trails. The western tract is crossed by the Tom Lake/Tower Road* and is skirted along its southern boundary by the Superior Hiking Trail, accessed via Camp 20 Road (also called Cook County 70). Before visiting either tract, please review the allowable uses (see above).

Note that this site is just north of Judge C. R. Magney State Park and is one of a cluster of SNAs protecting important natural features in the region, which includes Spring Beauty Northern Hardwoods and Myhr Creek Ridge SNAs.

* While it seems an easier access in the map view, condition of this road can be variable. Though maintained as a Township Road, travelers may still want to consider the season and vehicle when attempting to visit.
notes: The Superior Hiking Trail passes through site, see detail map. This site is within Grand Portage State Forest.

parking.directions: From Claremont 2 miles S, then 1.5 miles W on Co Hwy 1. Park in pull-off on N.

name: Hythecker Prairie SNA
description:
Depending on your perspective, this native prairie remnant could be considered small or large. A map of Minnesota prairie at the time of the Public Land Survey (1847-1908) shows Dodge County with over 203,000 acres of prairie. Measured against this history, the 26.1-acre remnant preserved at Hythecker Prairie is small indeed. Yet it ranks among the largest of the surviving bits of prairie scattered across the county today.

The rarity of such sites makes their preservation all the more important to researchers. For example, in 2014 Hythecker Prairie was one of six Minnesota SNAs used as collection sites for a National Science Foundation-funded initiative called the Baseline Seedbank. In the first phase of this project, collaborating institutions from across the U.S. and Canada are working to create and curate a North American research seed bank with 5-8 million seeds from 64 species. Pending future funding, the collection may expand to additional species.

As part of this project, Indiangrass seed collected from Hythecker Prairie is now stored at the USDA National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation. Researchers will be able to withdraw seeds 5-10 years after their collection, for comparison studies with seeds collected in later years. Dr. Julie Etterson is Principal Investigator on the NSF grant and associate professor of biology at the U of MN Duluth. She notes: "This is a powerful approach to studying evolution, since big genetic shifts can occur over a short time frame."

Etterson stresses the research value of Hythecker Prairie and other SNAs now and in the future; "I've been relying on SNAs since the very beginning of my career as a scientist. The foundation work that I did twenty years ago to assess evolution in wild plant populations in response to climate change was accomplished using seeds sampled from Kellogg Weaver Dunes SNA. I continue to rely upon seed collections from SNAs to provide a time capsule of genetic information that will help us assess the resilience of native populations in this era of rapid global change."

If you are a novice to the world of native prairie, this SNA is a fine place to begin. Be aware that this site contains both mesic and wet prairie, so waterproof boots may be in order. Bring a book of prairie wildflowers and grasses and learn as you go. Watch for prairie smoke, leadplant, swamp milkweed, bottle gentian, rattlesnake master, hoary puccoon, compass plant and many others, referencing the plants lists provided (see above). You'll find that it takes only a minute or two to be pleasantly lost in a prairie, whatever the size.

Ownership & Origins: The Nature Conservancy assisted in protection of this site through a land sale from the Hythecker family.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Gitchi Gami State Trail).

parking.directions: From Gooseberry Falls State Park, 3.1 miles N on MN Hwy 61. Park in Twin Points water access on E. Hike northeast on Gitchi Gami State Trail then follow signs to site.

name: Iona's Beach SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


This SNA was acquired to protect one of the largest and least disturbed Lake Superior beaches in Lake County.

Iona's Beach curves in a salmon-colored crescent for over 300 yards along Superior's North Shore. It is bound to the north by a roughly 30' high cliff of pink rhyolite and felsite bedrock—source for the stones that make up the beach—and on the south by a headland of grey basalt.

Even when no one is here, this is an active place. Some days Superior's waves play the beach, rhythmically lifting and then dropping the flattened stones so that they fall together with a high-pitched, ringing chime that listeners have likened to singing. Meanwhile, the exposed basalt headland booms and shudders as the lake surges into crevices in the rock, steadily hollowing it out from the inside.

To envision the origins of this landscape, stand within the SNA at its northern boundary and look down the length of the beach, free of human development. Consider that roughly a billion years ago, magma rose here from the earth's mantle and poured out as lava from a fissure in the earth known as the Mid-Continental Rift. As it cooled, it solidified into basalt or rhyolite based on its mineral content. It could be said that time itself is gathered in these rocks.

Walk the beach in any season, passing through a stand of pines into the open sky. Consider how the bright orange crustose lichen survives on the bare rock, exposed to the elements. Watch for one of the thirteen species of warblers sighted here, gleaning insects from the fringe of woodland with its alder, paper birch, balsam popular, mountain ash, currant and dogwood. As late as November, see dragonflies tracing their patterns out over the water. Find the big lake at work, steadily remaking the land.
notes: The Gitchi Gami State Trail and the Twin Points Water Access are adjacent to site, see detail map.

parking.directions: From Hayfield 1 mile S on MN Hwy 56, then 0.5 mile E on Co Rd N (740th St). Park in lot on S, at old railroad grade.
From Hayfield 2 miles S on MN Hwy 56, then 0.75 mile E on Co Rd M (750th St). Park in lot on N, at old railroad grade.

name: Iron Horse Prairie SNA
description:
Iron Horse Prairie is a triangular shaped site between two diverging abandon railroad spurs. For many years, the "iron horses" of the railroad served to protect this 35-acre site from cultivation or other disturbance, leaving what is now the finest and largest contiguous example of mesic tallgrass prairie remaining in this southern corner of the state. Species diversity is very high on this site and includes the rare plant species Sullivant's milkweed, Indian plantain, wild quinine, and valerian.

Descend the grade of the abandoned railroad bed into this triangle of land and find what has been called a "treasure trove of native plants." Come in spring for blooming prairie smoke, swamp saxifrage and valerian, or wander the tall grass in mid-summer, when the air is filled with the scent of bergamot and purple prairie clover. One late summer day, DNR Regional Ecologist Hannah Texler chanced to visit this SNA just as thousands of southbound monarch butterflies moved through on migration, stopping briefly to feed on the yellow flowers of stiff goldenrod, then lifting again, filling the air with the sound of their wings.

It's another reminder, if we needed one, of the known and unknown purposes served by the native plant communities protected within the state's SNAs.
notes:
A bioblitz on June 29, 2019 documented plants and animals found at Iron Horse Prairie SNA; see the results!

This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Park Rapids 20 miles N on US Hwy 71, then 7 miles NW on MN Hwy 200, (1 mile W of Itasca State Park entrance), then N and W 0.3 mile on gravel road. Park on S shoulder.

name: Iron Springs Bog SNA
description:
Only two miles northwest of Lake Itasca and the storied headwaters of the Mississippi, this SNA has its own distinctions. Generations of students from the nearby University of Minnesota Itasca Biological Station have spent time along Sucker Creek and its nameless tributary here, conducting research and using this SNA as a field study site.

Dr. David Biesboer, former Director of the Itasca Biological Station, is among the many professors who has brought students here over the years. His own research* has also focused on nutrient and nitrogen cycling at this intriguing site.

Technically speaking, Iron Springs Bog has no bog. Red and jack pine occupy the drier ridge tops and upland slopes. Boreal forest occupies lower slopes, with balsam fir, white spruce, paper birch and trembling aspen. Bordering the creeks is a conifer swamp forest: a wetland type more typically dominated by white cedar, but here by black spruce.

The interesting twist is that this conifer swamp forest is situated on a seepage slope associated with a gravel moraine rather than in a depression. Mineral-rich groundwater comes to the surface in upwellings and springs along this seepage slope. For plants, this water contains the macro-nutrients calcium and magnesium as well as iron, a micro-nutrient needed in small but essential amounts to produce chlorophyll. Orange pools—the telltale sign of iron—dot the carpet of moss.

The existence of this "groundwater-influenced sloping forested peatland" with its distinctive flora not typical of conifer swamp forests, led to designation of this site as an SNA.

The varying water chemistry across the site has led to an interesting assembly of plant species including the carnivorous pitcher plant and round-leaved sundew, and a diversity of orchids. Among the rare, state-listed species that flourish here are winter bentgrass and bog adder's mouth and the ram's head orchid.

If your mental image of a swamp forest is less than positive (or if you need six good minutes in your day) check out the photo essay produced by volunteer site steward Angela Shogren, titled "Take a Walk with Me thru Iron Springs Bog SNA."

* Biesboer, D.D. 2002. Nitrogen balance in Iron Springs Bog: a coniferous seepage slope. Ver. Internat. Verein. Limnol. 28: 1151-1644.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within Mississippi Headwaters State Forest.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (firearms only, including muzzleloader season). Varies year to year, see the current regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: In Itasca State Park, 20 miles N of Park Rapids. Sanctuary can be accessed along Wilderness Drive. Park at Landmark Interpretive Trailhead.
In Itasca State Park, 20 miles N of Park Rapids. Sanctuary can be accessed along Wilderness Drive. Park at Big Red Pine Trailhead.
In Itasca State Park, 20 miles N of Park Rapids. Sanctuary can be accessed along Wilderness Drive. Park at Bohall Trailhead.

name: Itasca Wilderness Sanctuary SNA
description:
The 1600-acre Itasca Wilderness Sanctuary holds an important place in Minnesota's conservation history. It was established in 1939 within Itasca State Park at the suggestion of the Minnesota Academy of Science, to preserve a part of the wilderness character of the state that existed prior to logging and settlement. In 1965, it became Minnesota's first National Natural Landmark. Most of the Sanctuary (1601 acres) was designated a state Scientific and Natural Area in 1989, as the finest example of Great Lakes Pine Forest in north-central Minnesota.

The SNA is located along the western side of Lake Itasca and protects roughly two miles of undeveloped shoreline along the lake. A mosaic of eighteen native plant occupies the site, dominated by fire-dependent red pine–white pine forest communities. As related by DNR forester Chris Gronewald, the SNA contains 848 acres of designated old-growth forest in 16 stands. Among these, a 1998 inventory documented a 190-year-old red pine stand and 200-year- old white pine stand.

Mesic hardwood forests are also well represented in the SNA, composed of sugar and red maple, basswood, aspen and birch. Low-lying areas support a diversity of communities ranging from shrub, tamarack and white cedar swamps, to sedge meadow, marsh and rich fen. Open water habitats add diversity, including two lakes—Bohall Lake and the smaller Snail Lake, and stretches of Boutwell and Nicollet Creeks. Many nameless little spring-fed streams filter into Lake Itasca.

More than 280 native plant species have been documented here, including several varieties of lady's-slipper orchids. State-listed plant species include but are not limited to Oakes' pondweed (endangered in Minnesota), cuckoo flower and goblin fern (both threatened in Minnesota).

In its earliest days, management of the Sanctuary was guided by the philosophy that it should "remain unaltered by man" and "its fate determined by natural forces alone." Over time, it became clear that human activities on the larger landscape (in particular, fire suppression) presented a problem for the site's pine forests. Studies of historic fire frequency by researcher Sidney Frissel, Jr. and others pointed to the importance of fire in providing "the necessary combination of mineral seed beds, reduced shrub competition, and thinned overstory" needed for pine regeneration.* When this natural disturbance is lacking, managers must now conduct prescribed burns if there is to be another generation of pines to take the place of today's old-growth trees.

The Itasca Wilderness Sanctuary was preserved with a purpose in mind, to be a place "where, through the study of its many plants, animals, soils, and waters, man may yet understand and appreciate the life in this region in its primeval condition." During her recent tenure as a volunteer site steward here, Janet Rith-Najarian helped to advance this ideal by steadily building a biogeography database for the SNA, documenting observations of flora and fauna on the iNaturalist on-line platform.

Unlike many SNAs, this site does have a few trails. One of these leads to an overlook on Bohall Lake. Another leads to a red pine tree that was the former state record holder (and national co-champion) for size. Before it lost its tip (and its titles) this tree was 126' tall, with a 120" circumference, and aged at over 300 years old when cored. Fortunately, other pines of the same stand remain, of comparable—if not record-worthy—grandeur.

This area of the park truly is a place apart, retaining much of its wilderness character. According to park naturalist Connie Cox, black bears and bobcats rear their young in the Sanctuary, Solitary Sandpipers feed in ephemeral pools, Trumpeter Swans return in spring to Bohall Lake, and the boreal forest still rings with its trademark sounds, from the foraging taps of Black-backed Woodpeckers to the howls of winter wolves.

* Frissell, Sidney S. "The Importance of Fire as a Natural Ecological Factor in Itasca State Park, Minnesota." Quaternary Research 3, 397-407 (1973)
notes: The Bohall Wilderness Trail passes through site. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. Recreational facilities available in Itasca State Park.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From New Ulm 8 miles S on Co Rd 13, then 2 miles W on Co Rd 22, then 0.25 mile N on 180th St. Park on E road shoulder.

name: Joseph A. Tauer Prairie SNA
description:
This prairie was owned by Joseph A. Tauer, whose personal philosophy of farming and choice of farming practices preserved the virgin prairie portions of this SNA. Tauer used only horses to farm until the 1980s. He limited his farming to the high, dry uplands of the several hundred acres of his holdings, leaving the low areas undisturbed, thus protecting their native vegetation. Upon his retirement, Tauer enrolled 80 acres of the land in a Prairie Bank easement program, later gifting the site to the state.

Today, the farmed, upland portions are being restored while the low, undisturbed areas continue to support native mesic to wet mesic prairie with two rare species-tuberous Indian plantain and rattlesnake master-found here at the western limits of their ranges. Prairie clover, gray coneflower, star toadflax, tall blazing star, sneezeweed, wood betony, northern bedstraw, and other flowers bloom among the prairie grasses on this exceptionally rich, fertile soil.

Walk the site with all its diversity, knowing that (in the words of poet Mary Oliver) it could be otherwise, if not for the vision of Joseph Tauer and his family. Watch your step for ground-nesting birds concealed in the grasses, and keep an eye open for a short-eared owl, observed here in recent years.

Scientific research at this SNA has included surveys of jumping spiders, part of a comprehensive effort to document species and their relative abundance.

Ownership & Origins: This land was gifted to the state of Minnesota by Joseph A. Trauer after a lifetime of good stewardship.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Kasota 2 miles S on Co Hwy 21, then 1.5 miles W on 480th St, then 0.75 mile N on 367th Ave. Park on E road shoulder.

name: Kasota Prairie SNA
description:
Situated on an extensive rock terrace 70 feet above the Minnesota River Valley, the Kasota Prairie is named for its view, the word kasota from the Dakota language meaning "a cleared place." When the Glacial River Warren originally carved the Minnesota River valley, the flooded river covered this terrace. Today, prairie, wet meadow, oak woodland, and lowland hardwood plant communities thrive in the thin soils, only 12 inches deep here.

Shrubby patches of wild plum, wolfberry, and narrow-leaved meadowsweet provide habitat for open-country birds such as horned larks and upland sandpipers. The increasingly rare loggerhead shrike (MN-threatened) has been documented here as well.

The palette of wildflower color ranges from the first pasque flowers and prairie violets in early spring, on to summer's yellow stargrass, pale-spike lobelia, and sunflowers, deepening with the last gentians in October. Look for rattlesnake master, actually a member of the parsley family, which marks the northern extent of its range right here at Kasota Prairie SNA.

This important prairie site is now part of a large prairie complex on adjacent lands, but the coming years are expected to bring big changes to the area, most notably a frac-sand mine operating within 200' feet of the SNA on three sides. The impacts of this operation on the natural features of the SNA remain to be seen.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

parking.directions: From Ely 1.5 miles E on MN Hwy 169, then 4.7 miles SE on Co Rds 58/16 (Kawishiwi Trl), then 0.45 mile S (opposite water access on Farm Lake) on gravel road, then left on road for 2.2 miles. Park at gate and trek 0.3 mile SW to site. GPS recommended.

name: Kawishiwi Pines SNA
description:
This site hosts a 29-acre stand of old-growth white pine dating back to a regeneration period following fires in 1854. Look carefully to see the lingering effects of windstorms in the 1920s and 30s: the downed trees and "tip-up" mounds of their unearthed roots have since become nurse logs where new seedlings established.

The upland pines and surrounding black spruce bog, sedge meadows and open wetlands offer diverse habitat for wildlife. Reports from visits by volunteer site steward Norma Malinowski offer a glimpse of the transition from winter to spring on this north woods site. From December-March, she notes an occasional raven and chickadee, tracks of deer and snowshoe hare, a flushed grouse. Then, in April-June comes the clamorous wave of returning migrants, with yellow-bellied sapsucker, brown creepers, ovenbirds, broad-winged hawk, mallard, chipping sparrow, Swainson's and hermit thrushes, red-eyed vireo, and pine, black-throated green, common yellow-throat, Cape May, Blackburnian, parula, Nashville, magnolia, and black-and-white warblers.

In the understory, find the ethereal Indian pipe, blue-bead lily, bunchberry and starflower, the carnivorous round-leaved sundew in boggy areas, a rare lichen (Sticta fuliginosa) and a number of orchids, among them the green adder's mouth and Hooker's orchid.

A unique way to experience the Kawishiwi Pines is by sled dog with local guides: a use atypical for SNAs but permitted here. "We love to share this amazing place with people, to let them experience how different an old-growth forest looks and feels," says Susan Schurke who with her husband, Paul, were leading advocates for the site's protection.

Ownership & Origins: This site's old-growth white pine were protected from timber harvesting through an agreement between Hedstrom Lumber Company and the Minnesota DNR.
notes: This site is within Bear Island State Forest.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed. Varies year to year, see the current regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Kellogg 5.5 miles E and S on Co Rd 84. E on Twp Rd 141 about 0.2 mile, stay left at fork and continue about 0.375 mile to parking at end of field road.
From Kellogg 4.3 miles E and S on Co Rd 84. Park in WMA lot on W. Hike E to site.

name: Kellogg Weaver Dunes SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


At Kellogg Weaver Dunes, the Paleozoic Plateau is jumping, literally and figuratively. Iridescent jumping spiders; rare Ottoe skipper and regal frittilary butterflies; newly discovered, as yet unnamed species of microlepidoptera (tiny moths of the genus Filatima); researchers radio-tracking snakes, the daily summer show of rough-seeded fameflowers opening their small, pink blossoms for a few hours each afternoon; ragged vees of trumpeter swans migrating overhead, sweeping views across a terrace above the Mississippi with the state's greatest expanse of imperiled dry barrens prairie and savanna-and these do not even include the attribute for which this SNA is perhaps best known.

Geologic studies conducted in the vicinity suggest that this complex of dunes may have originated during one of two major dune-forming periods in this part of the Mississippi Valley, mostly likely between 18,000 and 14,000 years ago, when sediments deposited by glacial meltwater became "remobilized" by wind. While habitat for many species, these dunes are critically important for one particular reptile that many Minnesotans have come to recognize by its bright yellow throat and high, domed carapace: the state-threatened Blanding's turtle.

This is the primary nesting site for one of the most significant populations of the species throughout its limited range in the U.S. and Canada. Every June, as many as 1000 female Blanding's turtles (from an estimated population of 5000) trek as much as a mile from surrounding wetland areas to lay their eggs within this complex of dunes. In late summer and fall, on their own, those hatchlings that have survived nest predation try to make that same trek back through the dunes to the wetlands. Posted signs alert drivers and a cadre of dedicated volunteers does their best to help the turtles survive a local road crossing between the wetlands and nesting territories.
If visiting, offer any turtle in the dunes a wide berth and utmost solitude. She will have come a long way, and has important work to do!

Ownership & Origins: Both parcels of this SNA were once owned by The Nature Conservancy, which sold the northern (Kellogg) parcel to the DNR in 1982, but maintains ownership of the southern parcel. The southern parcel, along with other Conservancy lands in the area not designated as an SNA, are known collectively as the Weaver Dunes Preserve.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. McCarthy Lake WMA and the Upper Mississippi Wildlife & Fish Refuge are adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From Hinckley 3 miles E on MN Hwy 48. Park in water access on S. Hike across bridge to site on N.

name: Kettle River SNA
description:
This SNA is located along the state-designated Wild and Scenic Kettle River, which forms part of the site's western boundary.

Elevation varies across the site by nearly 100 feet, providing a range of growing conditions for native plant communities. In the southern third of the site, floodplain forest is represented by silver maple, black ash, basswood and elm. In contrast, the poorly drained lowlands in the central and northern parts of the site are occupied by sedge meadows, cattail marsh, willow/alder shrub thickets, and mixed woodlands of black spruce, tamarack, yellow birch and balsam fir. Bedrock terraces and well-drained uplands are dominated by aspen-birch forest, with oak savanna and stands of red pine contributing to the mix.

Add the Kettle River, two streams (Wilburn and Fox Creeks), and several small lakes occupying former river channels, and it is hard to imagine a more richly diverse example of the state's natural heritage. It is no surprise that this SNA is known for its impressive array of bird species (see bird list), including the Louisiana Waterthrush, a state-listed species of special concern. Rare native plant species documented here include bog bluegrass and American water pennywort.

Of special geologic interest is the Douglas Fault, which crosses the SNA enroute from east-central Minnesota to northern Wisconsin. Fracturing and uplift along the fault line has brought bedrock of widely varying ages together, putting 700 million year-old Hinckley Sandstone on a level with ancient basalt of the Chengwatana Volcanics, associated with the 1.1 billion year-old Mid-Continental Rift System.*

The maze of backwater channels makes foot travel challenging if entering from the south along Highway 48. Access may be easiest in winter and during periods of low water when these channels are more easily crossed.

* As Richard Ojakangas and Charles Matsch point out in their book, Minnesota Geology, history might well have unfolded differently here. If North America had continued to spread apart along the Mid-Continental Rift (rather than ceasing as it did "after only a few tens of millions of years"), the gap would likely have been filled by a broad ocean. The city of Hinckley might have been a seaside city on the east coast of "Continent West!"

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Dr. R.M. and Betty Christianson.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Kettle River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only by permit through Great River Bluffs State Park), see the regulations handbook for hunting details. Varies year to year, check current regulations handbook for information.

parking.directions: From Winona 20 miles SE on US Hwy 61, then 4 miles S on Co Rd 3, then E into Great River Bluffs State Park. Park in lot 0.4 mile past office. Hike trail E and N to site.

name: King's and Queen's Bluffs SNA
description:
This SNA is comprised of two parcels totaling 178 acres in the northern section of Great River Bluffs State Park. The parcels protect dozens of rare and significant natural features associated with two bluffs long known as local landmarks-King's Bluff and Queen's Bluff-that rise 660 and 500 feet, respectively, above the Mississippi River.

Queen's Bluff supports a bur oak savanna atop the bluff and goat prairie on its southerly slopes, grading to deciduous forest at lower levels. Of special interest is a disjunct population of white cedars anchored in rock crevices just below the dry cliffs at the top of the bluffs, a species more typically found in the northern part of the state. Queen's Bluff is designated as an educational unit and requires a permit for access.

King's Bluff features goat prairies on its southwest slopes and deciduous forest on its northeast slope. Readily accessed by an interpretive trail, it offers a tremendous view of the adjacent Queen's Bluff and river valley beyond.

Where to begin? More than 70 years ago, the eminent University of Minnesota Professor Walter Breckenridge brought botany students here to study this ecologically significant site. Or, one could instead back up to 1883, when Mark Twain wrote of Queen's Bluff as being "-just as imposing a spectacle as you can find anywhere." Better still, rather than in cultural terms, one might consider the value of this blufflands habitat for the native species of the blufflands who were once common rather than rare, whether peregrine falcons that nested on cliff faces, or reptiles that basked on rocky outcrops, or the butterflies whose emergence from their cocoons coincided with the blooming plants of the goat prairie. Define grandeur as one might, it is found here.
notes: Sanctuary (Queen's Bluff open by permit only). This site is in a Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. An interpretive trail passes through King's Bluff. Recreational facilities available in Great River Bluffs State Park.

restrictions: Dogs (must be under control when used for hunting, otherwise leashed).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Becida 4.5 miles W on Co Hwy 9. Park in lot on N.

name: La Salle Lake SNA
description:
La Salle Lake SNA is part of a larger landscape recognized for many years as an exceptional place.

The clear-running LaSalle Creek, its source in Itasca State Park, meanders north at the base of a steep-sided glacial tunnel valley. Fed by seeps and springs, the stream flows through many high-quality plant communities such as red pine-white pine forest, white cedar swamp, sedge meadows and willow-dogwood shrub swamps before joining the Mississippi River downstream of the popular Coffee Pot canoe landing.

At the time of the SNA's designation, one of its most ecologically-significant elements was a 60-acre mature jack pine forest of a subtype* ranked S1, or critically imperiled, in Minnesota. In 2012 a massive blow-down occurred when a July thunderstorm with high winds moved through the area. The jack pine forest was the hardest hit: nearly all the trees were toppled.

In the Winter 2016 issue of SNA Nature Notes, SNA Outreach Coordinator Kelly Randall tells the tale of the storm and efforts to revive this woodland. Work has included limited clearing of the debris, monitoring seedlings and construction of deer exclosures to control overbrowsing. This natural event reinforces the merits of the SNA program's policy of acquiring multiple representative sites for protection of rare resources. The Badoura Jack Pine Woodland SNA in Hubbard County has taken on greater significance with the (hopefully temporary) setback of this native plant community here at LaSalle.

This SNA and the encompassing La Salle Lake State Recreation Area are host to a rich diversity of wildlife. Watch for river otters, trumpeter swans, eagles and osprey. Listen for the howls of gray wolves, the call of a loon, and the ethereal songs of the Veery. Spring through fall, catch sight of colorful warblers gleaning insects from the branches of trees and shrubs, among them the Blackburnian, Black-throated Green, Chestnut-sided and Golden-winged. The last of these may actually benefit from the storm-induced "reboot" of the forest here, since Golden-winged Warblers are associated with early-successional environments and young, even-aged conifers. Time will tell.

Visitors will also appreciate the view from the juncture of LaSalle Creek and the river, looking out over the Mississippi Valley.

* Jack Pine – (Bush Honeysuckle) Woodland, Bracken subtype

Ownership & Origins: The Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: A hiking trail passes through site, see detail map. Recreational facilities available in La Salle Lake State Recreation Area. The Mississippi River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Bigfork 8.3 miles SE on Co Rd 7, then 3.1 miles NE on Co Rd 344, then 0.25 mile NW (left) on unimproved road to gate. Park and hike 0.15 mile to Y, stay left, continue 1 mile. Trek 260 feet NW to SE corner of site. GPS recommended.

name: Ladies Tresses Swamp SNA
description:
Named for the ladies tresses orchid, this is one of the SNA Program's more remote and inaccessible sites.

Wet and wetter is the general theme, with pools of standing water persisting through the growing season, saturated soils and the water table never far from the surface. According to SNA regional specialist AmberBeth VanNingen, a variety of lowland conifer forest types may be found here, including white cedar swamp (the majority of the site), lowland white cedar forest, black spruce swamp and a young forest (black spruce, tamarack and cedar <70 years). Along the western edge of the site is northern wet-mesic boreal hardwood conifer forest, characterized by such understory plants as wild sarsaparilla, Canada mayflower and sweet-scented bedstraw.

These shade-filled forests are home to an array of native orchids, including ram's head orchid (threatened in Minnesota), yellow and showy ladyslipper, small northern bog orchid, large and small round-leaved, white adder's mouth orchid (special concern in Minnesota) and hooded ladies' tresses orchids. At least five species of ferns—including rattlesnake and crested ferns—unfurl their fiddleheads in late spring. Twinflowers and creeping snowberry find purchase on moss-covered hummocks and downed cedars.

Lowland coniferous forests make up 11% (and lowland forests of any type, only 30%) of state and federal lands in Itasca County that have been reserved from timber harvest as "representative samples" of the county's ecosystems under criteria outlined by the Forest Stewardship Council. In one sense, the focus on upland forests is understandable: they are considered more vulnerable to immediate loss, given their easier access and often higher economic value for timber purposes.

But sites like Ladies Tresses Swamp SNA remind us why lowland forests warrant protection. Lowland conifer forests—in particular, white cedar swamp and lowland white cedar forest of the type found here—offer potential habitat for birds such as the Spruce Grouse and Short-eared Owl, amphibians like the four-toed salamander, and mammals like the Northern myotis bat and smoky shrew.

Our own species is somewhat less well adapted to this environment. Those who venture here will benefit from skills with a map and compass and an appreciation for thick alder. Any time of year, expect tough going, with vistas of the small but rewarding kind.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from the U.S. Department of Interior, Bureau of Land Management.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within George Washington State Forest.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only select units of site, see map for details), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Cushing 1.5 miles N on Co Hwy 5 (Bear Rd). Park in pull-off on W.
From Lincoln at US Hwy 10: 2.8 miles E on Co Hwy 3, then 0.5 mile S on Lakeview Dr, then 0.2 mile W on Thoroughfare Rd, then 0.18 mile S and W on Lawrence Dr. Park at gate on S.

name: Lake Alexander Woods SNA
description:
Classic "kettle and knob" topography is a striking feature of this Central Minnesota SNA. The land rises and dips, courtesy of the Rainy glacial lobe. Upland forests are dominated by mature oak, large-toothed aspen and birch. Lowlands are occupied by lakes, sedge meadows, marshes, swamps and fens.

The three units of this SNA brim with life. Migrant songbirds filter through the woods, while the understory blooms with purple-hued hepatica and other ephemerals. Ruffed Grouse and woodcock flush in a rush of wings. Waterfowl feed on the ponds. State-threatened bog bluegrass grows at the edges of springs in the company of marsh marigolds, and the work of beavers is everywhere in evidence.

The ecological value of this site is enhanced by the abundance of nearby lands managed with conservation in mind. The SNA is part of a 155,500-acre Important Bird Area (IBA) comprised of both public and private lands. Among these is The Nature Conservancy's nearby Lake Alexander Preserve—which protects over 1700 acres—and Camp Ripley, where gray wolves, bears, and as many as 228 species of birds have been documented. Collectively, these lands allow wildlife populations to be resilient in the face of disturbance. They also benefit "interior forest dwellers" such as the Wood Thrush and Scarlet Tanager, as well as the Red-shouldered Hawk, a species of special concern in Minnesota.

Research here has brought new insights into a rare species of "Slippery Jack" fungus, Suillus subaureus. While the genus Suillus is famous for associating exclusively with conifers as mycorrhizal hosts, a study led by University of Minnesota graduate student Lotus Lofgren has offered the first conclusive documentation of this species growing in association with angiosperms, in this case colonizing red oak trees at Lake Alexander Woods. As Lofgren's paper notes, fungi-plant relationships are key to nutrient cycling, water availability and soil-building in forest eco-systems. This study was part of a larger project led by Associate Professor Dr. Peter Kennedy, Department of Plant Biology and Ecology.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

parking.directions: Contact Lake Bronson State Park at 218-754-2200 for directions. The Park office is 2 miles E of Lake Bronson, on Co Hwy 28.

name: Lake Bronson Parkland SNA
description:
Here in Kittson County, the transition between the Great Plains of the west to the forests of the east is expressed in a beautiful landscape called the Tallgrass Aspen Parklands. The sky is big, the views are long. Spring through fall, the calls of Sandhill Cranes fill the air.

This is the scene for what has been variously described as a battle and a dance: the place where a combination of factors including climate, soils, hydrology and topography—together with their influence on fire—begin to tip the balance in favor of woody vegetation over prairie grassland.

Minnesota hosts only a small part of the Tallgrass Aspen Parklands province, which lies almost entirely in Canada. As Minnesota Biological Survey Ecologist Robert Dana relates, its foundation here is an expanse of low-relief till (mix of sand, gravel and clay) plain created by glacial ice flow and further smoothed by a period of shallow submergence beneath Glacial Lake Agassiz. The most significant topographic features in this plain are low scarps (steep banks) and beach ridges marking shoreline positions as the lake level fluctuated during the final period of the Pleistocene, between roughly 11,700 and 9,000 years before present.

Broadly speaking, across the Parklands the shift from prairie to forest occurs somewhat gradually as one moves from west to east. This corresponds to a gradual increase in precipitation that suppresses the prairie fire regime, allowing a number of shrubs and a few fire-tolerant tree species such as trembling aspen, balsam poplar and bur oak to become an increasingly important presence in the prairie. But as one moves from southern Polk County down through Becker County, says Dana, the balance tips more abruptly in favor of forest. Here, the plain meets a fire-resistant, lake-rich, hilly landscape of piled up glacial drift that (combined with the east-west precipitation gradient) tips the balance more abruptly in favor of forest. Although the transition in the parkland is in the larger view gradual,subtle variations in topography and soils superimpose a patchy pattern at the local level.

This SNA is within a larger area of high biodiversity. It is comprised of two parcels that lie east of Lake Bronson State Park, both aligned along the South Branch of the Two Rivers River. A recent 40-acre addition to this SNA spans a prior gap between the park and the more westerly of the parcels. Predominant native plant communities within the SNA include wet meadow/carr, wet brush prairie and (mainly wet) aspen woodland, with areas of marsh near the river. The recently acquired parcel adds to the diversity with mesic brush prairie.

A highlight of this SNA and the basis for its designation is the occurrence of a population of the western prairie fringed orchid, a species listed as Federally-threatened and endangered in Minnesota. Sphinx moths are among the known pollinators, attracted by a heady scent released by the orchids at dusk. Northern green orchids and small yellow lady's slipper orchids have been documented here as well.

Lake Bronson State Park assists with management of this site, which has included brush mowing to open up the canopy. The introduction of fire through prescribed burns is also part of the ongoing management of this SNA.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

parking.directions: From Starbuck 11.5 miles S on MN Hwy 29, then 1 mile W on 320th St, then 0.5 mile S on 320th St, then 0.25 mile W on 325th St. Park in pull-off on S. Hike field road corridor 0.8 mile S to site.

name: Langhei Prairie SNA
description:
This small but important prairie is a relatively recent addition to the state's SNAs. It preserves a rare, high quality remnant of native mesic (moderately wet) to wet prairie, as well as several prairie pothole wetlands. These communities once covered most of the Minnesota River basin but have been nearly eliminated by wetland drainage.

Areas of mesic prairie are dominated by big bluestem, Indian grass, switchgrass, and prairie cordgrass. An impressive diversity of blooming forbs may be seen throughout the growing season, with blazing star, great blazing star, heart-leaved Alexanders, prairie phlox, and Maximilian sunflowers. Long, linear swales arc between two potholes on the SNA, with wet meadows in the wettest portions and wet prairie on the margins.

Periodic prescribed burns help to sustain this prairie. Fire returns nutrients to the soil, prevents encroachment of woody vegetation, and knocks back invasive plants such as reed canary grass. But no more than half the site is burned at a time, in alternating years, to minimize impacts to prairie-dependent butterflies and other insects that can be killed by fire. The stakes are high, since prairie remnants like this one are essentially islands in a sea of cropland. There are no nearby refuges of similar habitat from which butterflies could travel to replenish a population here if it were lost.

In visiting this lush site, one is reminded of the tremendous bio-diversity associated with Minnesota's prairie potholes and related native plant communities. It fairly bursts with life in spring: the grasses greening, the birds returning to fill the air with their songs. At least seven Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) identified under the state's Wildlife Action Plan have been documented here: Bobolink, Sedge Wren, Swamp Sparrow, Upland Sandpiper, Willow Flycatcher, Marbled Godwit and Northern Harrier.

A 2007 inventory found over 100 native plant species—67 of which were forbs. Discover wild strawberry and small white lady's slipper orchids growing low to the ground; bottle gentian and prairie wild onion at knee-level; slender spires of great blazing star and blue vervain rising to shoulder height or higher still; Joe-pye weed towering above, its pink blossoms a magnet for bumblebees.

The "little dipper" shape of this SNA is explained by an easement acquired by the state to provide access to the site. Visitors can park on the road in the designated area, then walk 3/4-mile down this (seasonally muddy) field road to reach the SNA. Watch for an wood routed sign at the entrance to the SNA. Please honor the posted boundaries, especially to the north and east, where the prairie continues onto private land.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Fishing (without live bait and outside of the sanctuary).
Deer hunting only allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Taylors Falls 2.5 miles SW on US Hwy 8/St. Croix Trail, then 0.1 mile S on Unity Ave. Park in pull off at corner where Unity Ave turns W. Hike west through old field into woods of site. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Lawrence Creek SNA

tree_shrub.sname: Lonicera tatarica, L. morrowii, L. x bella

description:
Just down river of Taylor's Falls, this SNA protects an area of high biodiversity significance, with many rare and high quality natural features. It lies within a region known as the Franconia—St. Croix corridor, which displays nearly the full range of native plant communities found in the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway.

At the heart of the SNA is a 2.5-mile stretch of Lawrence Creek, a designated trout stream supporting habitat for both brook and brown trout. Red oak-basswood forest dominates the site, but ridgetops and steep slopes on the eastern part of the SNA host smaller areas of mature red pine–white pine woodland, a forest type ranked as imperiled in Minnesota.

Rare/listed species documented here include the Cerulean Warbler, Acadian Flycatcher, and Louisiana Waterthrush. But the sheer diversity of birds here is in itself a marvel. In addition to these rare species, with a sharp eye and "educated" ear, DNR Central Region Assistant Manager, Liz Harper has documented Scarlet Tanager, Indigo Bunting, American Redstart, Brown Creeper, Black-and-white Warbler, Pine Warbler, Yellow Warbler and a host of others.

This is a site of high topographic relief and hydro-geologic interest. A broad ravine flanks the creek, with seepage areas at the base of their slopes. Jordan sandstone is exposed in rock outcroppings and cliffs throughout the site, and a small bridge crossing the creek also offers a view of St. Lawrence siltstone, recognized by its distinctive greenish hue. DNR hydro-geologist Greg Brick visited this SNA as part of an ongoing state-wide survey of springs, and was surprised to come upon a gas spring along the creek. "It's not uncommon to see an occasional, lazy bubble of methane rising out of bottom sediments, but this was bubbling furiously."

Beneath a near-continuous canopy of oak, basswood and sugar maple, the forest floor is in bloom throughout the growing season. Most showy are the flowers of spring: bloodroot and hepatica, large-flowered trillium, starflower, and the low-lying cups of wild ginger with their surprise pop of color inside.

This is a lovely site that calls for a certain degree of care in those who visit—both in the interest of safety and protection of sensitive features. Please move cautiously near steep slopes and along the creek, avoiding fragile areas where the ground is wet with seeps.

Ownership & Origins: The Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: Sanctuary (posted sanctuary portion closed). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The steeps cliffs and rugged terrain here present a safety hazard to visitors. The plant communities on cliffs are also sensitive to disturbance. Stay back from cliffs and off steep slopes. This site is an Audubon Important Bird Area. The site is adjacent to the Lower St. Croix National Scenic Riverway.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Motorized watercraft (access through Lester Lake Aquatic Management Area).

parking.directions: From Laporte 2 miles W on MN Hwy 200, then 3.5 miles S on MN Hwy 64. Then 1.5 miles SE on Co Hwy 37 (S Kabekona Lake Dr), then 375 feet W to parking lot.
From Laporte 2 miles W on MN Hwy 200, then 3.5 miles S on MN Hwy 64. Then 1.5 miles SE on Co Hwy 37 (S Kabekona Lake Dr), then 0.5 mile W then S on road to water access. Park in lot at dead end.

name: Lester Lake SNA
description:
This SNA is located east of Leech Lake and immediately south of Lake Kabekona. Its 440-acres are managed jointly as a Scientific and Natural Area (320 acres) and Aquatic Management Area (120 acres). At its heart is 70-acre Lester Lake, its undeveloped shoreline rimmed by sedge meadow.

The area is characterized by the rugged terrain and rolling hills of the Itasca moraine, an end moraine associated with the Wadena lobe of the most recent glaciation. As described in an ecological evaluation prepared by Tim Whitney and Erika Rowe, a highlight of this site is the matrix of lowland communities present on the south side of the Lester Lake, which includes northern wet ash swamp, white cedar swamp, alder swamp and sedge meadow. These lowland communities gradually slope toward the northeast, with many iron rich seeps and springs that drain into the lake. Together with oak-aspen-red maple forest and a pocket of red pine-white pine forest at higher elevations, this site displays a full spectrum of upland, lowland and aquatic communities and was recognized by the Minnesota Biological Survey as a site of high biodiversity significance. It is also notable for the existence of a small population of white adder's-mouth orchid.

When this property came up for sale, the local Kabekona Lake Association was instrumental in its protection, citing the value of Lester Lake's undisturbed shoreline and the lake's importance as waterfowl habitat. Kabekona's resident population of lake trout and wintering "brookies" also rely on the water quality of inflows received from Lester Lake via Sucker Creek. Without the Association's efforts, this site would likely have faced a very different future, with expansion of timber operations or the likelihood of housing developments overlooking the lake. The nonprofit Trust for Public Land was also an active participant in this acquisition.

Management today focuses on reforestation of the uplands on the north side of the lake, which were logged as recently as 2005. Scattered sections of fencing on the south side of the lake are also being removed. These are remnants of an interesting footnote in this site's history, which included a short-lived commercial fur farming effort that aimed (unsuccessfully) to raise albino beaver.

Ownership & Origins: The Trust for Public Land (with the Outdoor Heritage Fund) and the Kabekona Lake Foundation assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is adjacent to Paul Bunyan State Forest and Lester Lake Aquatic Management Area.

restrictions: Dogs (must be under control, allowed when used for hunting).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Deer River 22 miles N on MN Hwy 6, then 0.2 mile W on Co Rd 313. Park on SW road shoulder.

name: Little Too Much Lake SNA
description:
This SNA protects 62 acres of old and old-growth mesic hardwoods and 2600 feet of undeveloped shoreline on the north side of Little Too Much Lake in Itasca County. The primary forest community types are sugar maple-basswood forest and aspen-birch-red maple forest. Within the latter of these, one can find scattered "super canopy" red and white pines, including a red pine more than 275 years old.* Stumps of aspen and pine indicate that the site was selectively logged—likely in the early 1900s—but does not appear to ever have been clear-cut.

As noted by retired Minnesota Biological Survey plant ecologist Kurt Rusterholz, this SNA contains equal parts of two subsections of Minnesota's Ecological Classification System (ECS), straddling the boundary between the St. Louis Moraines subsection and the Chippewa Plains subsection.

While nearly level along its northeastern corner, the land slopes steeply south/southwest toward the lake. This slope is cut by a number of deep, narrow ravines that contain small streams fed by drainage from a complex of small black ash swamps. At the mouth of these ravines where they open to the lake, these streams feed into sedge meadows. Adding to the diversity of this site is a band of bulrush marsh in the shallow waters off-shore, benefiting fish and invertebrate communities in this lake dotted by homes and cabins.

Like many SNAs, this site is used as a study site for research. A "bee box", a wood block with small holes of different sizes drilled into it was mounted on a tree here and intended to attract the attention of nesting bees. It was part of a 3-year study related to the University of Minnesota Extension Bee Atlas. Boxes are collected each fall and sent to a University of Minnesota entomologist, where any larvae will be reared and identified. Please keep in mind that any research equipment found in the field at SNAs should not be disturbed.

This is one of two Itasca County SNAs (the other being Potato Lake SNA) made possible by land donations from Jerry Martin of Illinois. Martin came to love Minnesota's northern lake country as a boy, when his family made summer trips to the area to fish and vacation. He began to purchase parcels of undeveloped land—in particular those with lakeshore—as he saw opportunities arise. Later, he donated the properties to the Scientific and Natural Areas Program and to the nonprofit Minnesota Land Trust for long-term preservation. Thanks to his foresight and generosity, these places will endure.

* As of 2017, based on ecological evaluation referencing 2004 site visit when a red pine was cored, with 264 rings at breast height

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Jerry Martin.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the Chippewa National Forest.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Alvwood, 11 miles E on Co Hwy 29, then 2 miles N on Co Hwy 26, then 0.8 mile W on Forest Rd 2240 (Lost 40 Rd). Parking in lot on S.

name: Lost 40 SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


Lost 40 SNA owes its old-growth pine forest to a surveying error that occurred during the Public Land Survey in 1882. As the story goes, the pines were missed by loggers because surveyors mistakenly mapped the area as Coddington Lake. (The lake is actually located a half-mile to the southeast. Oops.). The site was re-surveyed and the error corrected in 1960. Shortly after, it was incorporated into Big Fork State Forest and its old trees have since endured.

The literal crowning feature of this SNA is its nearly 32 acres of designated* old-growth white pine – red pine forest. This old-growth forest is found in two stands, both of which extend beyond the borders of the SNA. The largest of these is 30 acres in size, and extends an additional 18.94 acres on adjoining federally-owned land in the Chippewa National Forest. **

White pine – red pine forest is ranked as S-2 (imperiled) in the state's conservation ranking of native plant communities, and designated old-growth represents less than 1/4 of 1% of all of Minnesota's forests.

A 2009 study found the oldest individual trees within the SNA to be red pines 230-240 years old. The stand on adjoining land within Chippewa National Forest reportedly originated as early as 1745, and includes the "champion red pine" of Minnesota's Native Big Tree Registry, measured at 115" in circumference and 120' high.

Also of interest is the glacial landform that underlies the old forests at Lost 40: an elevated, steep-sided peninsula variously described as an esker or esker-like ridge. Carrie Jennings helped prepare a 2005 Minnesota Geological Survey map of surficial geology of Northwest Itasca County that includes this area. "This is ice-contact material," she notes, "which just means it was deposited in contact with glacial ice, generally during the slow wasting of a glacier. It's typically coarser, sorted sediment. The topography of the ridge suggests an esker, which would have been deposited by a meltwater stream flowing through a tunnel in the ice or even on top of a glacier in an ice-walled channel." It would have formed between about 13,000 to 14,000 years before present, says Jennings, in association with the Koochiching lobe, considered a branch of the Red River lobe, during the latest stage of the last glaciation in Minnesota.

Unlike most SNAs, this site features a marked trail that loops through the "Lost 40 Site" which includes the SNA and the adjacent national forest land. Along this upland route, visitors will encounter the old-growth pine forest as well as spruce-fir forest, with views to surrounding lowlands occupied by alder swamp and black spruce bog. Moose Brook, a tributary of the Big Fork River, meanders across the northwest corner of the SNA.

Regional SNA Specialist AmberBeth VanNingen offers more detail about this SNA's natural features in radio interviews: Northland Outdoors and Minnesota Public Radio.

* Forests without this official designation may still have old-growth characteristics and may be evaluated for future designation. See the state's criteria and goals for preserving old-growth forests. ** The 18 acres on USFS land is part of larger 144-acre area adjacent to the SNA as the 'Lost 40 Biologically Unique Area,' which is managed to maintain its old-growth character.
notes: An interpretive trail passes through site, see detail map. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. This site is within the Chippewa National Forest.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Snowmobiling on designated trails (Snowmobile Trail 62: Arrowhead State Trail and Snowmobile Trail 204: Iron Ore).

parking.directions: From Tower 5 miles W on MN Hwy 169, then 1.25 miles W on MN Hwy 1, then 1 mile N on Co Rd 476 (Holter Rd), then 1 mile NW on Co Rd 458 (Roberts Rd). Park in water access at dead end.

name: Lost Lake Peatland SNA
description:
This Scientific and Natural Area nearly encircles its namesake lake. The 1991 Wetland Conservation Act established a 2,660-acre SNA here, 200 acres of which are owned by the state. The SNA represents the most ecologically significant core of a larger, 10,000-acre Lost Lake Peatland that sprawls across the low-lying area southwest of Lake Vermillion. It is ranked among the least disturbed peatlands in the state.

A featureless water track, ribbed fen and raised bog occur here, along with a number of state-listed special concern species, including montane yellow-eyed grass, Torrey's mannagrass, small green wood orchid, bog rush and coastal sedge. Populations of this rare sedge have been observed growing here in one of the classic peatland patterns described as "strings," in which the plants are aligned perpendicular to the flow of water.

Lost Lake Peatland has its stalwart fans. In an article for the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer, neighboring landowner Marshall Helmberger relates his experiences in the 10,000-acre area through the seasons: crossing the "moat" at the perimeter with its tangle of alder and willow; hearing sharp-tailed grouse and savannah sparrows; coming upon orchids amid the sedges; finding islands with massive cedars, yellow birch, white spruce and white pine that managed to evade both loggers and fire.

Helmberger's appreciation for peatlands is shared by his son Max, who remembers exploring the site as a boy—donning high rubber boots in summer, snowshoes in winter. Years later, at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, the younger Helmberger focused his undergrad research on soil insects and spiders of Lost Lake Peatland's forested islands. Familiarity breeds curiosity.

Those less familiar with the terrain will find travel here challenging at best, and should be aware that features within the SNA are sensitive to disturbance. A public water access on Lost Lake does offer opportunity to glimpse the SNA's environmental setting from the vantage of a canoe or shallow-water boat, or snowshoes if one prefers a winter adventure.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from the Fairbanks family.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. The Arrowhead State Trail (primarily a snowmobile trail) passes through the site. The Sturgeon River State Forest is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Snowmobiling on designated trails (Forest Road 246 and Forest Road 248: on established trail).
