parking.directions: From Big Falls 17 miles SW on US Hwy 71, then 3 miles NW on W Gemmel Forest Rd, then 3.25 miles NW on Lost River Forest Rd (last 1.25 miles are minimum maintenance). Park and trek 1 mile N into site. GPS recommended.
From Washkish 2 miles E and N on Washkish Rd NE, then 6 miles E on Co Rd 112 (becomes Pine Island Forest Rd). Park on S road shoulder at corner. Trek 1.75 miles SE into site. GPS recommended.

name: Lost River Peatland SNA
description:
This nationally-significant site in the bed of Glacial Lake Agassiz is Minnesota's 3rd largest peatland SNA. The peatland encompasses 11,888 acres, all but 40 of which are owned by the state. A great diversity of peatland features is on display here, developed in response to a range of chemical and hydrological conditions. High quality examples of ribbed fen, teardrop (ovoid) islands, featureless water track and raised bog are all found here. "Peatlands basically make their own landscape," notes hydrologist Jim Almendinger of the St. Croix Watershed Research Station, one of many researchers involved in studies here over the years.

Especially notable here are a number of spring fens, one of which is unique in the state for its large, forested dome with anastomosing (braided) stream channels. Peat (partially decomposed organic matter) core studies led by Paul Glaser (Research Associate, University of Minnesota Limnological Research Center) indicate that the origin of this fen can be traced to groundwater that began to discharge at the site roughly 1,200 years ago, transforming what was then a raised bog into an extremely rich fen.

Spring fen channels with their upwellings of calcium-rich groundwater represent "hotbeds for rare species," says Minnesota Biological Survey plant ecologist Erika Rowe. Eleven state-listed rare plants have been documented within the SNA, four of which are ranked as threatened: hair-like beak rush, beaked spike rush, sterile sedge and the ram's head orchid. A number of rare sundews are found in the large patterned peatland in the site's southern-most parcel. Wildlife documented here in early inventories included the northern bog lemming, at the southern limit of its range in central North America. The few state records of this small mammal are from patterned peatlands, where it is associated with open bogs.

Remote, complex and relatively inaccessible, peatlands have offered up many mysteries for scientists to unravel. One of these studied at Lost River has been the phenomenon of "bog breathing" in which the surface of a bog or fen can rise and fall as much as 14 inches a day, at irregular intervals and to varying degrees. Once thought to be related to water storage in peat, recent studies now suggest that it may instead be associated with the accumulation and release of greenhouse gases. Understanding of peatlands, like peatlands themselves, continues to evolve.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within the Pine Island State Forest.

parking.directions: From Saint Paul 18 miles SE on US Hwy 61, then 1 N mile on MN 95, then 2 miles E on Co Rd 78 (110th St), then 0.5 mi N on Nyberg Ave. Park at dead end.

name: Lost Valley Prairie SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


Lost Valley Prairie is a beautiful bedrock bluff prairie featuring a series of limestone ridges and dry swales. Ridge crests and upper slopes host little bluestem, prairie drop-seed, side-oats grama, hairy grama, Indian grass, and big bluestem; wildflowers such as puccoon, stiff gentian and prairie smoke; as well as potential habitat for mammals such as groundhogs, fox, coyote and American badgers. Of special interest are the fire-dependent Hill's thistle, a Minnesota special concern species, and state-threatened rock sandwort with its tiny white flowers and slender leaves, typically found much farther north and known to occur at only a few sites in the state. Among its many values, this SNA contributes to good water quality in the nearby St. Croix River, which receives the naturally-filtered flows from intermittent streams that cross the site.

"When you go down into this valley, the grasses can be 7 feet high, there's prairie on every horizon against the sky, and the rest of the world disappears," says site steward Jim Smetana, "I love that." He admires the purple haze of bird's foot violets blooming on the limestone knobs in spring, the striking landforms revealed when invading trees and brush are removed, and the way a prairie plant he hasn't seen before will suddenly appear after a prescribed burn; "You just never know what's waiting in the seed bank for the right conditions." Smetana is one of a group of faithful volunteers who have assisted with stewardship here, removing invasives and collecting on-site seed to reconstruct prairie in areas of the site formerly used for agriculture.

Ownership and Origins: The Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Slayton 3 miles S on Co Rd 33 (160th Ave), then 1 mile E on 61st St. Park on S road shoulder.

name: Lundblad Prairie SNA
description:
In a part of the Minnesota largely converted to agriculture, Lundblad Prairie SNA offers a rare glimpse of the pre-settlement landscape. It was designated to protect one of the largest and best examples of mesic, deepsoil prairie remaining in the southern part of the state.

Situated on a gently undulating topography, this site hosts high quality mesic and wet prairie surrounding an area of wet meadow and shallow emergent marsh that flows into North Badger Lake. It features roughly 40 acres of upland prairie and 30 acres of wet prairie, meadow, and cattail marshes. In the years since the SNA was acquired, an old field area along the eastern margin of the site has been restored to prairie vegetation.

Big bluestem dominates the mosaic of switchgrass, prairie dropseed, and Indian grasses associated with these deep soils; prairie cordgrass is common in the wet-mesic prairie. Patches of higher salinity are marked by foxtail barley, alkali plantain, and Hall's sedge, (Minnesota-threatened). Sullivant's milkweed (Minnesota-special concern) has been documented here as well. The mix of upland and wetland environments—along with an intermittent stream that runs north/south for the length of the SNA—attract a diverse mix of bird species. During the summer breeding season, one might expect to see and hear such species as Yellow-headed Blackbirds, Bobolinks, Sedge Wrens, Wood Ducks and Western Meadowlarks.

Lundblad Prairie SNA has been one of the featured sites in a series of public interpretive hikes around the state hosted by the Scientific and Natural Areas Program. Led by Veronika Phillips, the hike offered people the opportunity to experience one of the few remaining mesic prairies in southwestern Minnesota. Armed with cameras, field guides, sketch books and binoculars, participants enjoyed capturing the beauty found in this diverse prairie landscape and learning about the value of restoration efforts in improving habitat for native species.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed (only deer hunting allowed within Scherer Conservation Unit), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Lutsen 1.5 miles S on MN Hwy 61, then 0.75 mile N on Co Hwy 5 (Ski Hill Rd). Park on E then take ski trail E into site.
From Lutsen 1.5 miles S on MN Hwy 61, then 1.4 miles N on Co Hwy 5 (Ski Hill Rd). Park on E then take snowmobile trail E into site.
From Lutsen 1.4 miles N on Co Hwy 4 (Caribou Trl), then about 300 feet W on Homestead Road. Park on N road shoulder prior to where road narrows. Take snowmobile trail SW into site.

name: Lutsen SNA
description:
This site's ridges, slopes, cliffs and valleys support one of the largest blocks of essentially undisturbed old-growth northern hardwood forest in Minnesota.

At the heart of the SNA is the 240-acre Scherer Conservation Unit, donated to the state for this purpose by local landowner Lloyd Scherer and his family. Scherer had purchased the land in three parcels in the late 60s and 70s, understanding the value and rarity of its undisturbed forest. In the following years he spent countless hours walking the site in all seasons, becoming intimately familiar with the forest and the wildlife that inhabited it: wolves, pine marten, deer, red fox. He was determined that it would not be lost to logging or development.

The Scherer family gift spurred protection of additional land at the site. Soon after its designation, the SNA tripled in size when acreage to the east and south was acquired with the help of the Trust for Public Land.

This is a rugged landscape, with parts of two ridges of the Sawtooth Mountain Range. Eagle Mountain* and Raven Ridge rise over a thousand feet above Lake Superior, about two miles to the southeast. The Minnesota Biological Survey has documented ten native plant communities on the 720-acre SNA, including 276 acres of old-growth northern hardwood forest and upland white cedar forest. Individual trees as of 2017 include a 213-year old white cedar, 135-year old yellow birch and 123-year old white spruce.**

As one can see on the detail map, upland areas of the SNA are dominated by sugar maple forest, aspen-birch forest (balsam fir subtype) and white cedar – yellow birch forest. North and northwest-facing slopes of both ridges host upland white cedar forest, while the steeper, rocky slopes of Eagle Mountain support scrub talus (rocky slope at base of a cliff) and mafic (igneous rock rich in iron and magnesium) cliff communities. Lower elevations are occupied by lowland white cedar forest, black spruce swamp and part of a large beaver complex that extends onto adjacent land.

Margie Menzies, naturalist at Sugarloaf Cove Interpretive Center, leads periodic public field trips to this SNA. "One of the features I like to focus on is the ferns. There is a really glorious northwoods assembly that occurs on the site, including sensitive, ostrich, rattlesnake, interrupted, bracken, lady, oak, beach and spinulose wood ferns. By early summer, some can be waist high. They were my first introduction to Lutsen SNA, all that green under those massive old cedars and maples." She fondly recalls another outing, when the group encountered a pine marten that lingered for a time before darting off. "It was hard to tell which was more interested in the other!"

Ownership & Origins: The Scherer Conservation Unit of this site was a gift from Lloyd Scherer. The Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site.

For a real sense of this SNA (and of Lloyd Scherer), see the essay, Tales From Lutsen Woods from Paul Gruchow's book Worlds within a World: Reflections on Visits to Minnesota Scientific and Natural Area Preserves, © 1999, Minnesota Department of Natural Resources.

* This is one of two Eagle Mountains in the vicinity. The other, 17 miles away, is the highest point in MN.
** Estimated ages of trees in 2017, extrapolating from coring done in 1998.

Ownership & Origins: The Scherer Conservation Unit of this site was a gift from Lloyd Scherer. The Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: A ski trail and snowmobile trail pass through site, see detail map. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within the Superior National Forest.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Warroad 16.5 miles S on Co Hwy 5 (becomes Dick's Parkway Forest Rd), then 2 miles W on Luxemberg Lake Forest Rd. Park and trek 0.5 mile W into site. GPS recommended.

name: Luxemberg Peatland SNA
description:
Large areas of this peatland are treeless or nearly so, with scattered stunted tamarack. Patterned and featureless water tracks predominate. These water tracks support Northern Rich Fen communities with a wealth of sedges, including fen wiregrass sedge, lead-colored sedge and candle-lantern sedge. Smaller areas of tamarack swamp are present as well, with shrubs from the heath family such as leather leaf and bog rosemary.

Word to the wise: aerial photos may be the best way to "visit" this wild place. On the ground, GPS is helpful, but retired DNR peatland specialist Norm Aaseng says "Better to go with a good guide who is familiar with the area." It takes a half mile cross-country trek from the nearest recommended parking to reach the border of this site, through a landscape laced by water-filled ditches. Depending on conditions, the state forest access road may or may not be passable, or will get you in but not out. Aaseng speaks from experience, remembering half a day spent digging out a truck buried to the axels: "In the early days we were kind of dumb."

Fortunately, species persist that are better adapted to the peatland environment than Homo sapiens. Access is not a challenge for the Short-eared Owl, Yellow Rail, English sundew or small white waterlily

The ground-nesting Short-eared Owl benefits from the lack of disturbance here, the expansive tract of habitat, and the availability of voles as a food source. Once common throughout the state, reports of these owls are now mostly limited to northwestern counties, and conservation of peatlands will likely play an important role in the future of the species here. For now, the owls' presence is part of what defines Luxemberg Peatland. It flies most often at dawn and dusk, low to the ground, with black marks on the wrists (midway down the leading edge of the wing) and a bouncy, moth-like flight. While the owl goes in search of its prey, carnivorous sundews and pitcher plants wait in place for their meal. Soon enough, food will find them.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the Beltrami Island State Forest.

parking.directions: From Crookston 9 miles W on Co Hwy 9, then 2 miles S on Co Hwy 56, then 0.25 mile E on gravel road. Park on S shoulder.

name: Malmberg Prairie SNA
description:
Surrounded by agricultural fields, this remnant of native wet and mesic tallgrass prairie offers a glimpse of the diversity of Minnesota's Red River Valley landscape prior to European settlement. Although extensively hayed prior to its preservation, these 80 acres were neither plowed nor grazed. Especially rare here is the northern mesic prairie: a plant community with a conservation status ranking of S2, or imperiled, in the state. This type of prairie was often the first lost in conversion to agriculture, since the moderate moisture levels that support mesic prairie tend to be ideal conditions for crops as well.

While designated an SNA, the site is owned and managed by The Nature Conservancy (TNC). It offers critical habitat to many native species ranked as special concern in Minnesota, including birds such as the Nelson's Sparrow , Short-eared Owl and Yellow Rail; mammals such as the prairie vole, and plants such as the small white lady's-slipper and Hall's sedge.

This is the northernmost SNA in Minnesota's Prairie Parkland ecological province. Visitors who walk the near-level terrain here will be walking on the plain of Glacial Lake Agassiz with its lake-deposited, clayey soils. Throughout the growing season, one can witness an array of forbs come into bloom: the orange-yellow of hoary puccoon; the blues and purples of bottle gentian, purple prairie clover and rough blazing star; the yellow of Maxmilian's sunflower, which can rise to heights of more than 8 feet. Native grasses range from the relatively taller prairie cordgrass and big bluestem, to mid-height grasses such as prairie dropseed and little bluestem, to the comparatively lower-growing tufts of mat muhly grass, which is more common in Minnesota than in neighboring Wisconsin and Michigan.

This SNA is also notable for having a number of examples of the subtle but intriguing topographic features known as "mima mounds:" round to oval, vegetated mounds of loosely consolidated soil. Similar features (called by different names) have been documented across North, Central and South America. While their origins have been the subject of much scientific debate, the mounds in northwest Minnesota are thought to have been formed by pocket gophers over long periods of time. In their published report Ecology of Mima-type Mounds in Northwestern Minnesota,* authors Ross, Tester and Breckenridge described those found at Waubun prairie in nearby Mahnomen County as "puffs of soil formed primarily by animals disturbing and mixing the soil." They play an interesting role in prairie ecology, and in western Minnesota are known to serve as communal overwintering sites by hibernating Canadian toads (Anaxyrus hemiophyrys).

In its stark contrast with the surrounding landscape, this remnant of native prairie expresses so clearly what SNAs are about. Without the existence of such preserves and the ongoing management required to retain their native plant communities, the sounds of grassland dependent species such as Sedge Wrens, Western Meadowlark and Bobolink might forever be lost, and future generations of Minnesotans might never startle a white-tailed jackrabbit to bound, kangaroo-like, across the prairie.

* Ecology of Mima-type Mounds in Northwestern Minnesota. B. A. Ross, J. R. ;Tester, and W.J. Breckenridge. Museum of Natural History, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Buffalo 4 miles E on Co Hwy 35, then 0.5 mile S on Twp Rd 126 (Edmunson Ave NE). Park on E shoulder near wood-routed sign.

name: Mary Schmidt Crawford Woods SNA
description:
This 120-acre SNA preserves one of the finest remnants of Minnesota's "Big Woods" forest in the northern reaches of the Twin Cities area. Ranked S2, or imperiled in the state, Sugar Maple-Big Woods Forest once occupied nearly 3000 square miles of the pre-settlement landscape. Here, it occurs on flat to gently rolling terrain, dotted by several sedge meadows in low spots and crossed by an intermittent stream. Sugar maple and basswood predominate, with relatively lesser amounts of northern red oak and bitternut hickory. Along its eastern boundary, the SNA includes a small part of Schmidt Lake.

The family name of this SNA traces back to the days of Minnesota's early statehood, when in 1860 Traugott Schmidt homesteaded 160 acres in Wright County's Buffalo Lake Township. After Traugott served in the Civil War, he and his wife, Marguerite, gradually acquired additional property (including the SNA's 120-acre parcel) eventually owning a total of 600 acres between Green Mountain Lake and Schmidt's Lake. These 120 wooded acres later passed to Emil Schmidt, one of their six sons, then to Emil's daughter, Mary, before being sold to The Nature Conservancy in 1984. Two years later, it was acquired by the state and designated an SNA.

In spring and early summer this rich, moist woodland is filled with wildflowers: find bloodroot, anemones, nodding trillium, jack-in-the-pulpit. The "whee-eep" of flycatchers and the ethereal, flute-like songs of the Veery and Woodthrush can be heard, and warblers and vireos flit among the trees, gleaning insects. Increasingly rare, such large, relatively undisturbed blocks of forest offer important habitat for these migrant songbirds.

Invasive garlic mustard is a management concern at this SNA. Since this species spreads by dispersal of seeds, the aim will be to remove of any existing plants prior to seed set. Watch for volunteer opportunities through the SNA program to be part of this effort.

Visitors may find the walking challenging here in spots, given the thorny undergrowth and lack of trails. For a little perspective, it's good to recall Marguerite Schmidt—grandmother of Mary Crawford Schmidt—who, according to historical accounts, "often picked blackberries and gooseberries and, putting them in three-gallon buckets, trudged to Monticello (roughly 10 miles), where she exchanged them for groceries." Old stories, like old trees, live on in SNAs.

Ownership & Origins: The Nature Conservancy assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: ATVs on designated trail (Soo Line North ATV Trail).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From McGregor 2 miles S on MN Hwy 65. Park on E, near wood-routed sign at Soo Line Trail crossing.

name: McGregor Marsh SNA
description:
"Water and sky," says SNA regional specialist AmberBeth VanNingen: for her, the first words that come to mind when describing McGregor Marsh.

It's an apt description for the water-rich mosaic of plant communities here in the bed of Glacial Lake Aitkin, with over 300 of its 399 acres occupied by sedge meadow, willow-dogwood shrub swamp, alder swamp and fen. Even the 90-odd acres of hardwood forest lean toward the wet-mesic, associated with a high local water table.

To drivers passing by on busy Highway 65, this landscape may seem more remote than inviting. But McGregor Marsh and its surrounding environs are well-known: at least to the state's avid birders. Together with the Rice Lake National Wildlife Refuge and Kimberly Wildlife Management Area, the SNA is recognized as an Important Bird Area (IBA) designated by the Audubon Society.

Leading Minnesota bird expert and author Robert Janssen created lists of the occurrence of birds for 50 of the state's SNAs, including McGregor Marsh. "Its one of the few places in the state where one can see the rare and secretive Yellow Rail plus Nelson's Sparrow," notes Janssen. "Birders from all over the country have visited this area to see these two species." Both of these Minnesota special concern species are highly sensitive to slight changes in water level in the sedge wetland habitats they occupy, resulting from seasonal variations or activities (i.e. irrigation and ditching) that impact local hydrology. The large expanses of public conservation lands in and near the SNA make it more likely that the birds will be able to find the conditions they require for breeding in any given year.

The SNA is not without its signs of human development, divided north/south by a power line corridor and east/west by a drainage ditch. The raised bed of the old Soo Line railway—now the Soo Line North ATV Trail— also crosses the site's southwest corner. For visitors, this trail has the benefit of offering some "dry foot" access to the site: a place to peer out across this landscape of water and sky. And even when there is no-one to hear the "ticking" of theYellow Rails or the "wheezy, gaspy sputtering" songs of the Nelson's Sparrow, the SNA fulfills its purpose by their presence here from spring through fall.
notes: This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. The Soo Line North ATV Trail passes through this site, see detail map.

restrictions: Dogs (must be under control, allowed when used for hunting).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Garrison 1.6 miles S on US Hwy 169. Then 1.5 miles W on Co Rd 26. Park along S Tower Rd shoulder.  Hike past gate (do not block) 0.5 mile N and W along maintained road to fire #8356. Then hike 0.13 mile N on unmaintained road to SNA boundary gate.

name: Mille Lacs Moraine SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


This is the sole SNA in Crow Wing County. Designated in 2012, it is a quieter complement to the activity of Mille Lacs Lake to the east, with its hum of summer boats and winter trucks across the ice, and Borden Lake to the north, its shoreline dotted by cabins and homes.

Steep, forested slopes, small lakes and wetlands characterize the landscape of this 318-acre site. The topography reflects the most recent glacial era, roughly 15,000 years before present, when an advancing glacier stalled, then retreated, depositing rock and debris as a moraine along its melting edge. Within the SNA, this moraine explains the abrupt, 160' rise in elevation to the west and south of Sunfish Lake.

Mature hardwood forest dominates the uplands, with red oak, sugar maple and basswood. Low-lying areas host a range of open and forested wetland communities, including wet ash swamp, rich tamarack swamp, willow-dogwood swamp, poor fen, cattail marsh and sedge meadow. Sunfish Lake—frequented by nesting loons—lies entirely within the SNA, along with portions of Fawcett and Hogsback Lakes.

This site is part of larger region of outstanding biodiversity significance, noted for its diversity of native plant communities, rare/listed species, undeveloped shorelines and unfragmented forest with few roads. In particular, the combination of mature deciduous forest in close proximity to wetland openings offers critical breeding habitat for Red-shouldered Hawks, Purple Martin and Cerulean Warblers, all state-listed special concern species.

Those who venture here will be rewarded by the diverse understory, with hepatica, bloodroot and marsh marigold following on the heels of the snow, soon followed by jack-in-the-pulpit and clusters of pale green blue-bead lily rising from the moist soil as the canopy closes above.

The Nature Conservancy was instrumental in the protection of this site, together with the property's prior owners, the Geordie Hormel family. A newspaper account at the time of the SNA's designation shared the family's perspective, offered by Jaimie Hormel, whose late husband Geordie grew up in Austin, Minnesota: "He would be proud to know that the land he loved will be preserved."

Ownership & Origins: The Nature Conservancy assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. There are, however, unmaintained roads through the site. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: In Duluth, from I-35 4.8 miles SE on Lake Ave (becomes Minnesota Ave after aerial lift bridge). Park in public lot on W just before Sky Harbor Seaplane Base. Hike trail NE of hangars and runway 0.75 mile to site.

name: Minnesota Point  Pine Forest  SNA
description:
This SNA hosts a magnificent old growth pine forest near the eastern tip of Minnesota Point, the 7-mile long sandbar that shelters the Duluth Harbor and Superior Bay from the open waters of Lake Superior. Large red and white pines are anchored in the sandy soil of beach ridges. Many are between 120 and 200 years old, their crowns rising higher than 100 feet.

It's an old forest on a geologically young sandbar which is itself a significant natural feature. Ideas about the origins of this baymouth bar system (which includes 3-mile long Wisconsin Point) are still evolving. Dr. Andy Breckenridge, University of WI-Superior, theorizes that it may have formed during a period of rising lake levels less than 1200 years ago, when sediments carried in longshore currents were deposited along a pre-existing beach ridge.*

The SNA is comprised of two parcels, each of which is surrounded by other public lands. One of these spans the .3-mile width of the Point, its north side exposed to the wind and waves of Lake Superior and its south (bay) side more protected. Bands of vegetation correspond to the increasingly stable conditions as one moves inland from the water's edge. Wave-washed shoreline and open beach transition to beachgrass dune, then to juniper dune shrubland, and finally, to the pine forest on the interior. Rare plants that occupy these specialized habitats include beach heather, slender hair grass, and American beach grass (listed as threatened in Minnesota, and at the western edge of the species' natural range here).

Together with the adjacent St. Louis River estuary, this is a hot spot for birds and birders. During spring and fall the Point serves as a critical stopover area for migratory birds funneling along the North Shore to rest and refuel. The SNA's old growth forest also offers summer breeding habitat for up to 16 species of northern forest birds.

As visitors enter the cool, shady forest of the SNA with its towering red and white pines, the benefits of its preservation are abundantly clear. There is nowhere else in Minnesota quite like it.

* Breckenridge et al., 2016, Duluth Harbor Geologic History Boat Cruise: Quaternary to Anthropocene, ILSG proceedings and field trip guidebook, v. 62, 160-192.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Superior Power and Light through assistance from the Minnesota Land Trust.
notes: This site has a hiking trail, see detail map. The city of Duluth's Park Point is adjacent to this site. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From US Hwy 2 near Blackberry 4.8 miles S (right) on Co Rd 72 (Happy Hollow Rd), then 0.3 miles W (right) to boat access on Mississippi River and park. Site is 5.5 river miles S on the Mississippi River. SNA is on E (left) riverbank. Accessible by boat.

name: Mississippi Oxbow SNA
description:
Mississippi Oxbow SNA is located south of the unincorporated community of Blackberry in Itasca County, where the river takes a serpentine route, looping in tight meanders known as oxbows. The island site is both a recent addition to the SNA roster and a relatively recent island, geologically speaking. According to early accounts, the 23 acres were separated from the west bank in 1911 when the river created a short cut, slicing a new channel that bypassed an earlier loop.

Roughly two thirds of the island supports terrace forest dominated by black and green ash, with some basswood, bur oak, and blue beech, the last of which is at the extreme northern edge of its range here. Relatively lower elevations support floodplain forest of black ash and silver maple, while the abandoned oxbow channel is covered in meadow-like River Shore vegetation with Tuckerman's sedge, lake sedge, and common woolgrass. Much of the SNA rises only 4-6 feet above the river level of 1,234 feet, and is periodically submerged. Only a small, (~1.5-acre) knob at the western tip of the island remains reliably high and dry, supporting an upland forest with a canopy of white pine, red pine, white spruce, and paper birch. Here, one finds a diverse understory of blueberry, beaked hazelnut, prickly gooseberry, groundpine and balsam fir.

Why protect a relatively small site in such a dynamic environment? It's important to see this SNA in a landscape context, for the contribution it makes to the health of the larger floodplain system. The high quality, undisturbed terrace and floodplain forests here are part of a stretch of riverway ranked as “outstanding” by Minnesota Biological Survey ecologists, containing the best example of a floodplain forest complex in the Tamarack Lowlands Subsection. Nearby lands with conservation value include 134 acres of state land to the east with designated old-growth lowland hardwood forest, and an 89-acre private parcel to the west protected by an Aquatic Management Area (AMA) easement. To the north of the SNA, land on both sides of the river is part of a designated Itasca County wildflower sanctuary and recreation area. Collectively, these provide critical habitat for rare, state-listed species, including Northern goshawk (special concern) and Blanding's turtle (threatened), both documented within two miles of the SNA.

In spring and summer, listen here for the rackety tea-CHER tea-CHER, tea-CHER of ovenbirds and the flute-like songs of wood thrushes. Watch for red-eyed vireos and Northern parula warblers flitting in the treetops, foraging for insects, and keep an eye out for sign of black bear. Or make the steep climb up to the island's western edge for a dry vantage point from which to consider the meandering Mississippi, minute by minute remaking its route.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Elk River at junction of MN Hwy 10 and 101. Park in Babcock Highway Rest Area. First island is 1 mile N (upstream) in Mississippi River. Accessible by boat.
From Monticello on MN Hwy 25 0.58 mile SE on River St, then E on Washington St. Park in Elison Park. First island is 3.25 miles E (downstream) in Mississippi River. Accessible by boat.

name: Mississippi River Islands SNA
description:
This SNA protects a string of islands within a roughly 7-mile stretch of the Mississippi River just upstream of Elk River, Minnesota, between Highway 25 and the Parish Bridge. It's located in an increasingly populated part of the state, with a mix of farms and residential development. But the river corridor itself, with wooded shorelines and islands, retains a surprisingly wild character and has abundant wildlife.

"Actually? I don't know what doesn't use these islands," says DNR Conservation Officer Mitch Sladek, who has worked this stretch of the river for over 16 years. "You'll see Wood Ducks, Hooded Mergansers, geese, otter, mink, and beaver. Bald Eagles nest here every year. Deer swim between the islands, and come down to shelter in the river valley in winter when the cold hits."

Early bird survey work by the SNA program here documented 48 species, including such species as Indigo Bunting, Red-headed Woodpecker, woodcock and Black-billed Cuckoo. Great Egrets and Great Blue Herons stalk frogs and small fish in the shallows, while Belted Kingfishers perch on overhanging branches. In mid-winter, one can hear the low, resonant hoots of Great Horned Owls from the islands, and find tracks of Ruffed Grouse.

On the water, Sladek knows from experience the route he needs to take with his boat on this section of the river. Still, he watches for the shimmer on the surface that suggests shallow areas. "It changes all the time down here." The same is true of conditions on the SNA islands. "You'll get huge ice jams that might flood an island in 4-5' of water, or scrape it down to dirt, leaving only the cottonwoods standing. But right next to it, another island might be completely undisturbed, covered in ferns." Storm winds are also a natural disturbance, periodically taking down some of the islands' big trees, with their shallow root systems.

The islands of the SNA feature a mix of southern terrace and floodplain forest. The Minnesota Biological Survey defines the dominant native plant community as elm-ash-basswood terrace forest, which has a state conservation ranking of S2 (imperiled). Elevation varies—in places rising to 30' above river level—but all the islands are influenced to some degree by seasonal high water. Of the tree species found here, silver maple, green ash, and cottonwood can tolerate prolonged flooding, while hackberry, bur oak, American elm and box elder will tolerate only moderate flooding. By early summer as the river grows shallower, sandbars and small islands re-emerge, offering suitable nesting habitat for turtles.

DNR Area Fisheries Manager Eric Altena has done extensive studies of the world class smallmouth bass fishery in this stretch of the river. "You can't overstate the value of protected shoreline on these islands for smallmouth, especially on the downstream side, which offers a 'velocity refuge' out of the main current for nesting." says Altena. "Our studies have shown that individual males have high fidelity to their same exact nest site each year—going as much as 17 miles upstream, even to the same piece of wood along the shore. Undeveloped, naturally vegetated shorelines also promote water quality. By mid-July, you can have 3-5 feet of visibility in some areas. People are surprised to see it in the Mississippi, but the Clean Water Act is really showing its benefits here."

This part of the river is recognized as part of Minnesota's Wild and Scenic Rivers system*, and the SNA exists within the context of other public lands, including Aquatic Management Areas and—more recently established— the city-owned William H. Houlton Conservation Area on the river front in Elk River. "I hope there are up-and-coming young people who will have a passion for conserving this place," says CO Mitch Sladek, "people who will really get to know it. That's what it takes."

* In 1973, this segment of the Mississippi (from St. Cloud to Anoka) was designated a Minnesota Wild & Scenic River to "preserve and protect the river's outstanding scenic, recreational, natural, historical and scientific values."
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Mississippi River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only by archery and firearm on specific dates), see regulations handbook for hunting details. Varies year to year, check current regulations handbook for information.

parking.directions: From Duluth on MN Hwy 61 N on Lester River Rd (Co Rd 12) for 3.4 miles. Park in lot on E.

name: Moose Mountain SNA
description:
Moose Mountain SNA is located in Duluth, in the North Shore Highlands. According to John Green, Professor Emeritus, University of Minnesota, Duluth Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, the bedrock ridge that forms Moose Mountain is "held up" by an underlying erosion-resistant diabase sill, formed by intrusion of magma between pre-existing rock layers. At its peak, the mountain rises nearly 550 feet above the elevation of Lake Superior, which is less than a mile away as the crow (or raven) flies.

The SNA straddles the ridge, hosting both north- and south-facing forested slopes. It was selected for protection as an excellent example of northern hardwoods, in particular a 55-acre stand of old-growth sugar maple-basswood forest. This stand has been the focus of research into dynamics of northern hardwood communities along Minnesota's north shore, exploring ways that human-caused climate change might affect the distribution of sugar maple trees.

The remainder of the site's uplands are dominated by aspen-birch forest, while lowlands in the northwest corner of the SNA near the Lester River are occupied by wet forest, with black ash, aspen and balsam poplar.

This SNA is also notable for being along one of the nation's most travelled routes for migratory birds. Moose Mountain is within sight of and a familiar landmark used in spotting birds from Hawk Ridge Bird Observatory in Duluth, where since 1972 researchers have done systematic annual counts (and banding) of raptors migrating along Superior's north shore. More recently, songbirds and other non-raptors have been counted as well.

Over the years, when threats have arisen that could degrade this migratory corridor, local citizens have stepped up to the challenge. In 1987-88, Duluth resident Laura Erickson spearheaded a campaign against a proposed 300' lighted cell tower on Moose Mountain, drawing on the expertise of top birders and ornithologists across the region. The group was successful in having the tower downsized to a 100' unlighted tower (without guy wires) to prevent mortality to migratory raptors and songbirds.

With its cover of sugar maple, basswood, yellow birch, northern red oak and aspen, this SNA is a flash of color in autumn, which is also the peak time to catch the spectacle of bird migration through the Duluth area. Watch for Sharp-shinned and Cooper's Hawks shooting past like arrows on a northwest wind, Ospreys with their nearly 6' wingspans, even an occasional Peregrine Falcon.

As Count Director Karl Bardon reports, counts of non-raptors and raptors at Hawk Ridge as well as non-raptors nearby along the shore of Lake Superior have documented over half a million migratory birds passing through the area between August and November in a given year.*

A power line corridor crosses this site, which is sometimes used by visitors as an informal trail. Please note that this SNA features steep/sloped terrain throughout. Visitors may find a topographic map useful in planning. Note that there are two Moose Mountains along the Superior's north shore: the other (541' higher) peak is in Cook County, near Lutsen, and is part of the Sawtooth Range.

* Counts vary from year to year. In 2015, a total of 517,908 non-raptors and 76,859 raptors were counted, which included raptors counted at Hawk Ridge and non-raptors counted both at Hawk Ridge and along the shore of Lake Superior one mile from Hawk Ridge. Find out more at Hawk Ridge and The Loon 84:8-20, Fall Diurnal Migration of Passerines and other Non-raptors at Hawk Ridge and Lake Superior, Duluth (2007-2011), Karl J. Bardon
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: In Morton, on NE corner of US Hwy 71 and MN Hwy 19. Ask permission to park at the gas station, then hike NE into site.

name: Morton Outcrops SNA
description:
It’s a mind-bending scene: a high knob of 3.6 billion-year-old bedrock next to a motel, with modern day traffic passing by on the two-lane road out front.

Classified as “Morton Quartz Monzonite Gneiss,” this SNA features the oldest known bedrock in Minnesota and among the oldest in the world. Rosy-hued Morton gneiss is a type of crystalline granite, characterized by bands of white quartz, pink and grey feldspar, black biotite and amphibole. It was exposed when the torrent of glacial River Warren formed the Minnesota River Valley roughly 10,000 years ago, scouring through glacial drift of the Des Moines lobe and underlying cretaceous sediments to reveal the ancient bedrock. Today, the Minnesota River flows past to the south, a quarter mile away and 100 feet lower in elevation than the highest point of the SNA. But potholes in the rock here are testament to the time when all was submerged by the swirling waters of River Warren.

This site has outstanding biodiversity significance, supporting one of the state's largest and highest quality examples of Crystalline Bedrock Outcrop Prairie (Minnesota River Valley sub-type). Shallow soils on the margins of the bedrock exposures host plants adapted to this drought-prone microhabitat, including rock spikemoss, small-flowered fameflower, little barley, Carolina geranium and brittle cactus. Ephemeral pools in shallow depressions on the rock support a distinct set of species including ovoid spikerush, Carolina foxtail, and flattened spikerush. Small areas of deeper soil support dry to mesic prairie, with Indian grass, big bluestem and prairie dropseed.

Rare species found in the surrounding greater Morton Outcrop/prairie complex include the regal fritillary (state-listed as special concern) and prairie bush clover (state and federally listed as threatened). Wolf's spikerush (state-listed as endangered) and fox snake (a watchlist species) are known to occur within the SNA.

The prior landowner, Carl Colwell, was instrumental in the site's preservation. After a career in the military, Colwell had returned to his home town of Morton, where he served for six years as mayor and also as longtime director (now retired) of the Renville County Historical Society. He purchased the acreage with the outcropping along with an adjacent vacant schoolhouse in 2009. “I bought it as a private citizen, mortgaging ten acres I had inherited from my dad,” he recalls. For years, the building and land were made available to the local Dakota Wicoha community, and served as a home base for the nonprofit Minnesota Valley History Learning Center. It was a place to gather and to interpret the region's natural and cultural history, especially for youth, says Colwell. “I didn't think that many of the younger people knew anything about the rock, the ancient River Warren, or the Dakota War. I wanted those stories to continue. They were all touchstones for me growing up, and I wanted to share them with others.”

Colwell is pleased at the SNA designation for the site. He reflects: “When I was a boy, the Dakota story I heard was that the rock was the keeper of all knowledge. It had seen everything since the beginning of time, and if someone would ask in the correct way, they would learn the answer. It was almost like a library. I, of course, didn't believe that story at the time. Once I started escorting geologists, anthropologists and “ists” of all sorts through the site, I started to hear the same story repeatedly. The rock has seen everything since the earth cooled. If we look carefully and study hard, we will learn the answers to our questions.”

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed (only on unit north of Highway 16), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Hokah 3.5 miles W on MN Hwy 16. Turn NW at Carlson Rd and park in pull-off on W.
From Hokah 4 miles W on MN Hwy 16, then 0.1 mile S on Mound Prairie Dr, then 0.6 mile E and S on Golfview Dr. Park at gated dead end and hike forest road E and S into site.

name: Mound Prairie SNA
description:
Mound Prairie is located within the high-relief, stream-dissected blufflands of Houston County, overlooking the Root River within the Richard J. Dorer Memorial Hardwood State Forest. It showcases dry bedrock bluff prairie: a native plant community ranked as S3, or vulnerable to extirpation (total loss) in the state. The examples here are among the largest and highest quality in the state.

Bluff, or "goat" prairie as it is often called, is associated with thin, droughty soils over bedrock on steep terrain, generally with a sunny south or west exposure. Minnesota Biological Survey surveyors have documented 92.7 total acres of goat prairie in the three parcels of this SNA, occurring in scattered patches on its steep south- and southwest facing slopes. These open areas can readily be seen by choosing the aerial photo toggle on the map below, flanked by dry mesic forest of red oak, white oak and sugar maple.

Historically, these forests were far less dense than they are today. The pre-settlement vegetation here was characterized by oak openings and barrens, and aerial photos show that the forest has encroached considerably on the bluff prairie even since the 1930s.

Today, management focuses on maintaining the open character of the bluff prairies with selective cutting of trees and brush, as well as use of prescribed burns. Special care is taken in the timing and frequency of burns to minimize potential negative impacts on native fauna, in particular insects and reptiles. The Survey has documented numerous Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) here associated with the dry prairie and rock outcroppings, including prairie voles, Lark Sparrows, milk snakes and six-lined racerunners.

In his 1999 book Worlds within a World, Paul Gruchow tells of a late spring day spent exploring Mound Prairie SNA with Bob Djupstrom, then supervisor of the Scientific and Natural Areas Program. After climbing up a forested back slope, Gruchow writes, the two "came out onto the prairie, an open sweep of hillside so steep that we had to mind our steps to keep our footing." They heard Rufous-sided Towhees and Indigo Buntings, and found blooming bird-foot violets, prairie violets, yellow lousewort, blue-eyed grass, hoary puccoon, and the silvery gray leaves of scurf-peas. Djupstrom pointed out a number of the rarer plants protected within the SNA: goat's rue, plains wild indigo, and narrow-leaved milkweed, the last of which is endangered in Minnesota, known only to occur at this SNA. Looking out on the landscape of forested and prairie-covered hills, farmsteads, and the winding river and road below, Gruchow writes: "If there was a handsomer place on earth, we did not know at that moment where it might be found."
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: Dogs (only when used for hunting, must be under control).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Gary, South Dakota 1.5 mile E on MN Co Rd 4, then 3 miles S on Co Rd 15, 0.5 mile W on Co Rd E3, then 0.4 mile S on 115th St. Park in pull-off on E.
From Gary, South Dakota 0.5 mile E on MN Co Rd 4, then 1 mile S on 110th St, then 0.4 mile W on 260th St. Park on S road shoulder.

name: Mound Spring Prairie SNA
description:
This SNA is comprised of two parcels quite different in character, separated about a mile as the crow flies. It is located within a landscape of rolling hills formed along an ice margin during the late Wisconsinan glaciation, marking an edge where the Des Moines lobe stagnated for a period of time.

The northern parcel lies on Minnesota's border with South Dakota. Dominant native plant communities here include dry hill prairie, mesic prairie, wet prairie and seepage meadow/carr, the last of which occurs where groundwater emerges along drainage ways between hills. Numerous species here are state-listed as special concern, among them Western white prairie clover (which is at the extreme eastern edge of it's U.S. range here), a large population of small white lady's-slipper, yellow-fruit sedge, and Buellia nigra, a lichen. The extent, diversity and quality of the wet prairie are also worthy of note, since many such areas were long ago drained and converted to agriculture in this part of the state. Big bluestem; the delicate flowers of yellow star grass and blue-eyed grass; the spiky, ball-shaped fruits of giant bur-reed; Northern green orchid; woolly and hanging bottle-brush sedge; Riddell's goldenrod, smooth rattlesnake root: together, their presence here indicates an intact, relatively undisturbed place.

The smaller, more southerly unit was a later addition to the SNA. In the words of DNR ecologist Fred Harris, it offers a particularly dramatic and breathtaking example of the hummocky topography of the region. Between 400 and 500 feet of glacial till overlay the bedrock here. Harris was the first to inventory the site for the Minnesota Biological Survey in 1998. What had looked promising on aerial photos proved to be true on the ground. He found that this former pasture hosted a fine example of dry to dry-mesic glacial till hill prairie with a diversity of native species including prairie plum, prairie dropseed and porcupine grass, Floodman's thistle, scarlet gaura, hoary puccoon and Scribner's panic grass. Among the state-listed plant species found here are a number of Great Plains species and specialists in exceedingly droughty soils formed in sand or gravel: Missouri milk-vetch (special concern) and yellow prairie violet (threatened). There are only a handful of records of this tiny, April-blooming yellow violet in Minnesota, all of which are near the South Dakota border. The 160 acres of this unit were acquired by the SNA program through sale from the private landowner in 2012. Harris was pleased that a site he had inventoried later became an SNA, “Playing a part in helping protect a site is one of the most rewarding aspects of my job.”

Signs of prior land use are still visible in the form of retired crop/pasture land and clearings associated with former homesteads. Restoration to native vegetation is an ongoing effort with prescribed burns, selective removal of woody vegetation and release of spurge beetles for bio-control of leafy spurge. Multiple cooperative agreements with local farmers allow for prescribed haying as well as limited planting of row crops during the period of transition. It will be exciting to watch this SNA evolve in the coming years.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding support from the Outdoor Heritage Fund.
notes:
A bioblitz on August 11, 2018 documented plants and animals found at Mound Spring Prairie SNA; see the preliminary results!

This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Mound Spring WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: Contact Red Lake Wildlife Management Area Office at 218-783-6861. Office located from Roosevelt 1.5 miles W on Twp Rd (280th St), then 13 miles S on Roosevelt-Norris Forest Rd, then 2 miles SW on Faunce-Butterfield Forest Rd. Office on W.

name: Mulligan Lake Peatland SNA
description:
Mulligan Lake Peatland SNA straddles the border between Beltrami and Lake of the Woods Counties. It includes the headwaters of the Roseau River, which flows west and then north to join the Red River of the North in Manitoba, Canada.

The patterned peatland on this SNA with its water tracks, ribbed fen and tear-drop islands is largely inaccessible. But the southwestern portion of this site may be seen by canoe, putting in on the Roseau River downstream of the Roseau Flowage Impoundment (off Dick's Parkway in the Red Lake WMA). A few hours (give or take, depending on beaver dams) up the meandering creek will bring you to Mulligan Lake. This beautiful lake is surrounded by a rich fen mat, beyond which a forested swamp reaches into the distance.

A number of state-listed threatened and special concern species are found here. The small white waterlily blooms here in July, opening its flowers for only a few hours each day. A small population of ram's head orchid has been documented, along with linear-leaved and English sundew, few-flowered spikerush and McCalla's willow.

Birds of particular interest include the Short-eared Owl, Nelson's Sparrow and Yellow Rail, as well as the Wilson's Phalarope. In an essay for the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer magazine, Minnesota Biological Survey ornithologist Steve Stucker notes the nocturnal habits of the reclusive Yellow Rail and Nelson's Sparrow, both of which sing at night. The word "song" is misleading for non-birders, since the rail is known for its "odd clicking calls" and the song of the Nelson's Sparrow has been compared to the sound of "hot metal being placed in water." Imagine these sounds emanating from the peatland in the depths of night, far from any city lights.

Quieter but no less impressive are the butterflies and moths. Minnesota Biological Survey entomologist Kyle Johnson reports finding many of Minnesota's peatland butterfly species to be common here, including dorcas and bog coppers, Arctic and frigga fritillaries, red-disked alpine and jutta Arctic, and more than a dozen species of moths.

This is one of few peatlands in the state not impacted by ditching. Over her 26-year tenure, Red Lake WMA manager Gretchen Mehmel has come to appreciate Mulligan Lake Peatland with its natural hydrology as a "giant sponge" that helps to retain floodwater. "In June of 2002 we had 12 inches of rain over a 24-hour period. Even though Dick's Parkway had water over the top of it, the small dam held at Roseau Flowage and it was likely the Mulligan Lake Peatland had a lot to do with that."

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was donated in memory of Christopher D. Curry, from Dennis M. Curry and Patti M. Curry, and in memory of Ben Faus, Sr., from Ben and Susan Faus.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within the Red Lake WMA.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Hovland 0.2 miles N on Co Rd 16, then 1.7 miles W on Co Rd 69 (North Rd). Park in pull-off on S.

name: Myhr Creek Ridge SNA
description:
This remarkable SNA straddles a 4-square mile, east-west oriented ridge of Keweenawan bedrock that rises 439 feet above Lake Superior near Hovland. Droughty conditions on the upper slopes, with patches of exposed bedrock and dry, shallow soils, have historically set the stage for fire. Fires, in turn, have perpetuated these conditions by consuming forest litter that would otherwise contribute to soil development. Tree ring data and personal accounts indicate that fires swept the ridge in 1894 (year of the Hinckley Fire) and 1918 (year of the Cloquet/Moose Lake Fire) and likely in 1908 as well, on the heels of another infamous period of drought in the area.

Over time, these factors contributed to the development here of a fire-dependent upland black spruce/jack pine woodland complex that is extremely rare in the North Shore Highlands. Longtime MBS ecologist Chel Anderson conducted field surveys of the SNA and surrounding 2450-acre Myhr Creek Ridge macro-site, and prepared the report on the area's ecological significance. Reflecting on a recent site visit, she comments: “As always, what I was aware of was how distinctly different it is: the visuals all around, the feel underfoot, the complexity of the topography and the intricacies of the native plant community mosaic, how the daily weather feels here compared to most of the highlands.”

Relatively deeper, more organic soils on lower slopes in the northern part of the SNA (near Cook County 69) support less fire-prone communities of aspen-birch forest, wet meadow forest, alder and black ash swamps and a beaver wetland.

In late 2019, the SNA was expanded with the addition of an adjacent 80-acre parcel. The land adds important elements to the diversity of the SNA, says Anderson, “providing excellent representation of Crystalline Bedrock Outcrop, Bedrock Shrubland (inland) and the fire-dependent Jack Pine Woodland (Bedrock) communities, as well as high-quality Northern Poor Dry-Mesic Mixed Woodland. The prior landowner notes: “I had thought of building a small cabin on the property, something that would be a retreat of sorts. The land had the feel of a place to be quiet. I always appreciated that the Myhr Creek SNA was adjacent and when it was clear to me that I was not going to be building my retreat, it would be best if it could be included in the SNA rather than sold and built upon. It's just a good place to be set aside for appreciation of the land and its features. I'm pleased that it was included for SNA designation.”

Wolves are at home in this landscape, as are many bird species associated with coniferous forest, such as the black-backed woodpecker, red-breasted nuthatch and evening grosbeak. Patches of open bedrock add to the diversity with their native flora of lichens, mosses, poverty grass and sedges.

Visitors who explore this remote SNA can expect to encounter challenges in the form of beaver wetlands, steep terrain and downed trees from recent blowdowns. During the growing season, find familiar wildflowers of the north such as wild sarsaparilla, bluebead lily, bunchberry, twinflower and Canada mayflower. (It's also worth noting that for many years the local name for this ridge was Blueberry Hills.) Whatever the season, take time to appreciate the signature trees of this fire-dependent woodland: scattered, fire-scarred jack pine over a hundred years old (origin circa 1894) whose form and character speak to the story of this place.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from the Trust for Public Land.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within Grand Portage State Forest.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

From Effie 6.3 miles N/NE on Co Hwy 5, then 4 miles E/N on Co Rd 62, then 0.4 mile W on Loftgren Forest Rd. Park at intersection with Deer River Line. Trek past closed gate (or ATV if open) 4.5 mile N on Deer River Line to site on E. GPS recommended.

From Effie 6.3 miles N/NE on Co Hwy 5, then 2.25 miles E/N on Co Rd 62, then 10.7 miles E on Holmstrom Forest Rd. Park at intersection with Kendall Forest Rd. Trek 3.5 miles N on Kendell Forest Rd, then 0.6 mile W into site. GPS recommended.

name: Myrtle Lake Peatland SNA
description:
Myrtle Lake Peatland is a perfect example of the kind of "natural laboratory" that the Scientific and Natural Areas program was founded to protect.

In the original ranking of the state's peatlands as candidates for protection by legislative statute in 1991, Myrtle Lake Peatland was second only to the Red Lake Peatland in overall score. It matched Red Lake for its scientific research value, and bested it for lack of disturbance, since (unlike the state's other major peatlands) it has not been impacted by ditching.

This undisturbed quality is still a hallmark of Myrtle Lake Peatland. "Pristine" is not a word that plant ecologists use easily, but it's the word that DNR peatland specialist Erika Rowe attributes to this SNA.

Aerial images convey the striking features of this patterned peatland: a massive raised bog with spruce trees radiating from its crest; large water track; ribbed fen with "strings" (ridges) and "flarks" (pools) oriented at right angles to water movement; and both circular and tear-drop shaped islands. In the 11,700 years since Glacial Lake Agassiz departed its lakebed in the region, over 12 vertical feet of peat has slowly accumulated here, the water table rising along with it. Myrtle Lake itself, rather than filling in over time, still shines like a blue eye in the vast landscape.

In the history of Minnesota conservation, the name Bud Heinselman is perhaps best remembered for his work related to the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness But in the international scientific community, those who study the state's peatlands will always associate Dr. Miron ("Bud") Heinselman with Myrtle Lake Peatland.

Heinselman's pioneering research at the site led to important advances in understanding of boreal peatland development. Starting in the 1950s, he worked to define what he called the "extraordinarily complex series of interactions" at play here, including chemical, microbial, climatic, topographic and mineralogical factors. He sought for decades to puzzle out the direction—if one existed—of the peatland's evolution, in part by studying core samples of peat for fossil clues to past vegetation. The transect line he set up to collect these core samples is still known as "The Heinselman Trail." While the trail is now barely discernible in the landscape, his body of work endures.

Rare plant species here include the ram's head orchid, white adder's mouth, coastal sedge, twig rush, bog rush and English sundew. Interesting butterfly finds recorded by Minnesota Biological Survey lepidopterist Kyle Johnson include the bog copper and Arctic fritillary.

Myrtle Lake Peatland, is also a National Natural Landmark.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the Koochiching State Forest.

parking.directions: From Silverdale 5 miles N on MN Hwy 65, continue 3 miles W on 65, then N and E for 0.6 mile on unimproved road. Park and trek 0.5 mile NE into site. GPS recommended. Site only open by permit from Bois Forte Band of Chippewa.

name: Nett Lake Peatland SNA
description:
Nett Lake Peatland SNA is in Koochiching County on the southwestern corner of Nett Lake, and is part of a larger peatland that completely surrounds the lake. Of particular interest here is a spring fen channel that supports a number of state-listed plants, including sterile sedge, beaked spikerush, twig rush, and swan moss.

It's important to note that this SNA lies entirely within the Nett Lake tract of the 105,000-acre Bois Forte Reservation, and contains no state land. (See Visitor Note above). The Wetland Conservation Act of 1991 established boundaries for this site, in recognition of its value as "a striking example of undisturbed spring fen patterns, matched only by Pine Creek peatland." The first record of beaked spikerush (Eleocharis rostellata) in Minnesota was at this location. A type of sedge, this species is common in salt marshes along the Atlantic coast, and is known to extend inland only in the rare, specialized habitats of calcareous seepage fens and spring fens in acid peatlands. In a 1983 article in the Michigan Botanist, Paul Glaser of the University of Minnesota Limnological Research Station described the environmental setting where the small population was found here. "Transverse (crosswise) peat ridge in a narrow, sinuous water track bearing highly calcareous water, part of a network of open channels that dissect a minerotrophic* swamp forest at the southern margin of Nett Lake."

A study by the U.S. Geological Survey in cooperation with the Bois Forte Reservation Tribal Council found a close relationship between the lake and surrounding peatlands. Not only are the peatlands within the area of direct run-off into the lake, as wetlands they help to regulate high seasonal flows in streams that feed the lake by storing and gradually releasing water. Data from monitoring wells also indicates that shallow groundwater discharges into the lake through 3-12 feet of underlying peat.

Maintaining these hydrologic patterns—and water quality in Nett Lake—is of great interest to the Bois Forte band of Ojibwe. Fifty percent of the reservation's Nett Lake tract is wetland, and supports one of the largest contiguous wild rice production areas in the world. It has also long been recognized as important habitat for breeding and migratory waterfowl.

* Minerotrophic: fed chiefly by ground and surface water and hence supplied with dissolved minerals [Oxford Dictionaries]
notes: This site is only open by permit from the Bois Forte Band of Chippewa. Contact the Bois Forte DNR at 218-757-3261. While the state recognizes this as an ecologically significant site, it owns no land here.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Warroad 11.6 miles S on Co Hwy 5, then continue 6.8 miles S on Dick's Parkway Forest Rd, then 3.75 miles E on Highwood East Forest Rd. Park and trek 1 mile SE into site. GPS recommended.

name: Norris Camp Peatland SNA
description:
Norris Camp Peatland SNA lies at the western edge of the Agassiz Lowlands, an area characterized by virtually level terrain in the former bed of Glacial Lake Agassiz. This open peatland hosts a water track and northern rich fen community dominated by sedges, grasses and rushes. Note the array of fine-leaved sedges in the plant list above (fen wiregrass sedge, lead-colored sedge, creeping sedge, candle-lantern sedge) as well as characteristic rushes (flattened spikerush, Hudson's Bay bulrush).

Although it may seem surprising for such a remote site, from an ecological perspective this is considered the most disturbed of the peatland SNAs. Unsuccessful efforts to drain the area for agriculture in the early 1900s have left a legacy of altered hydrology. To most of us, the degradation may not be immediately evident. But in a peatland, changes in hydrology have a ripple effect in the native plant community that, in turn, impacts species with specialized habitats. Here, the affected areas of the peatland tend to be drier, showing an increase in shrub cover.

The western edge of the site is somewhat less impacted by ditching. A ribbed fen supports a thriving population of English sundew (Drosera anglica), a special concern species in the state. This small, carnivorous sundew is something of a "canary in the coal mine" because of its association with highly sensitive rich fen environments. Its presence here is a good sign.

This SNA is located within the Beltrami Island State Forest and is part of the Big Bog Important Bird Area. The peatland takes its name from nearby Norris Camp, headquarters of Red Lake WMA. Through the years, many researchers have used this former Civilian Conservation Corps camp as a base for work in the surrounding area, including surveys of native plant communities as well as studies of game and nongame wildlife, ranging from dragonflies to butterflies and bears to bats.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within the Beltrami Island State Forest.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Snowmobiling on designated trail (Snowmobile Trail 305: Haggerman Voyager Lowman).

parking.directions: From Loman 2.2 miles S on MN Hwy 11, then 13.2 miles S and W on Co Hwy 32 (Black River Rd). Park in pull-off on N. Hike 0.375 miles NW, past powerlines to site. GPS recommended.

name: North Black River Peatland SNA
description:
This peatland shares the flat terrain of the Agassiz Lowlands with the meandering North Black River, not far from International Falls and the Canadian border.

Key landforms include a large water track, raised bog, ribbed fen, and a highly developed ovoid (egg-shaped) island that contains an internal water track.

This peatland was ranked among the top four of the state's peatland SNAs in national and even international ecological significance, surpassed only by Red Lake, Myrtle Lake and the Lost River Peatlands. It has high value for comparative studies, since it contains good examples of several so-called "peatland complex types" in close proximity, each classified by the size and arrangement of bog, fen and mineral soil formations.

University of Minnesota Professor of Earth Sciences Dr. Paul Glaser is a peatland expert and among the leading researchers who have utilized the site to advance understanding of peatland development. An early article published in the Canadian Journal of Botany offers a glimpse of his findings. In it, he writes, "Bog and fen patterns in this peatland are consistently related to topographic features along the upland crest of each peatland watershed, indicating that topography controls the path of minerotrophic* runoff draining onto the peatland, and thus creating zones with either enriched minerotrophic flows (in which water tracks develop) or stagnation zones (where bogs develop) on the peatland downslope."

The availability of mineral-rich run-off is reflected in the distribution of rare plants, which are concentrated here in the internal water track and ribbed fen. Four plant species ranked as special concern in Minnesota have been documented, including coastal sedge, bog rush, and English sundew and linear-leaved sundew.

* Minerotrophic: fed chiefly by ground and surface water and hence supplied with dissolved minerals [Oxford Dictionaries]
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Pine Island State Forest is adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: In Wanamingo just W of MN Hwy 57 on Co Hwy 30. Park in lot on N. Site is about 4 miles W (upstream) via North Fork Zumbro River. Accessible by boat.

name: North Fork Zumbro Woods SNA
description:
Accessible only by water, this SNA consists of two heavily wooded parcels, each capturing a small stretch of the Zumbro River's North Fork. Forest community types change as the topography rises, transitioning from an elm-ash-basswood terrace forest flanking the river (ranked as imperiled in Minnesota), to southern mesic hardwood communities providing a diverse canopy of sugar maple, red oak, basswood, elm and hackberry.

The SNA serves as an important refuge for species long gone from the surrounding landscape, including a trio of rare plants. Low-lying terraces along the river support a plant that is both endemic to Minnesota and its only federally endangered plant species, the dwarf trout lily. This lily is found in three counties in the state—Goodhue, Rice and Steele— and nowhere else in the world. Another rare plant occurring on the floodplain and alluvial terraces here is the glade mallow. As Hannah Dunevitz (Texler) writes in the Minnesota Plant Press (newsletter of the Minnesota Native Plant Society) at the time this plant was rediscovered here in 1990, there were only three confirmed occurrences of the species in the state. Snow trillium completes the rare trio. This early-blooming spring ephemeral has white petals set against a whorl of blue-green leaves. Like the dwarf trout lily and glade mallow, it has a close association with water, and in Minnesota has not been found more than 600' from a stream.

Marchner's map of presettlement vegetation shows that, prior to European settlement, Goodhue County was dominated by oak openings, barrens and prairie. Even then, woodlands like this one at North Fork Zumbro Woods SNA would have been rare, found only in fire-protected areas.

Today, this forest is surrounded instead by agricultural lands, as one can see by zooming out on the aerial photo map, select the inset below. The rare natural features within the SNA currently benefit from being part of a larger block of forest that continues onto adjacent, privately owned land. As is often the case, the future of the natural features within the SNA will be influenced by what happens beyond its borders.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from the Weswig family.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Oronoco 1 mile S on US Hwy 52, then 2 miles E on Co Rd 112, then continue S on Co Rd 112 for 0.3 mile. Park in pull-off on W.

name: Oronoco Prairie SNA
description:
Oronoco Prairie SNA occupies a small valley with hills and steep-sided slopes, its terrain dissected by intermittent streams that flow toward the nearby Zumbro River. Limestone bedrock is found at and near the surface, its fragments scattered throughout the well-drained, loamy soil.

No fewer than six rare plant species have been documented by the Minnesota Biological Survey here: wild white indigo, rattlesnake master, and prairie moonwort, tuberous Indian plantain, edible valerian and prairie bush clover, the last of which is listed as threatened at both state and federal levels. The predominant native plant community is a high quality remnant of dry bedrock bluff prairie, a community type ranked S3, or vulnerable to extirpation (loss) in the state.

The constellation of so many state-listed species on a single site may add to this SNA's biodiversity significance, but University of Minnesota researcher Dr. Ruth Shaw's interests at Oronoco Prairie extend beyond the rare. This is one of 23 SNAs (and more than 3 dozen sites statewide) used thus far as collection sites for seeds and microbes in the Healthy Prairies Inititiative.

A professor in the Department of Ecology, Evolution and Behavior, Shaw is working with colleagues and a host of volunteers on a multi-pronged effort to bolster the success of statewide prairie restoration efforts. Says Shaw, "We're increasing the total amount of seed available, the species represented, and the geographic range of collection sites, so that restorations using this seed can retain rather than reduce genetic diversity." The team is also obtaining and culturing soil organisms—the "microbial partners" of native prairie plants—for use in experimental settings to investigate their role in the plants' survival and reproductive success.

Still another subset of the project is a study of genetic adaptation in prairie plants that digs into the question; How local is local? In other words, explains Shaw, "How far away from a plant's place of origin can you plant it before its growth and fitness are compromised? At what point—in terms of distance as well as time, measured in generations—is it so genetically maladapted that it fails to produce offspring that will establish as the basis of a growing population? These questions are endlessly fascinating, and bear directly on the health of both remnant and restored prairies."

You might not see it when you visit, but Oronoco Prairie—like every SNA—has this dual role: preserving the features of a unique piece of land, and at the same time contributing to understanding and preservation of the state's natural heritage as a whole.

What you will see if you visit this SNA is a quiet valley carpeted in native grasses, with prairie dropseed, sideoats grama, little bluestem, porcupine grass, big bluestem and Indian grass moving in the slightest breeze. You'll see the evidence of ongoing restoration efforts: hills cleared of encroaching woody vegetation, re-planted with prairie seed collected on site with the help of former volunteer site steward Jim Ivy. Come in mid- to late summer, and you'll see the prairie in its glory: the showy and subtle, a new season's growth over the enduring bedrock.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Kiester 3.5 miles E on Co Rd 2, then 1.25 miles S on 610th Ave. Park on W road shoulder.

name: Osmundson Prairie SNA
description:
Osmundson Prairie is Minnesota's southernmost SNA, less than a mile from the Iowa border on the Faribault/Freeborn County line. It is also one of the state's smallest SNAs, at 6 acres.

This hilly little remnant of southern mesic blacksoil prairie hosts two state-listed plants. Rattlesnake master offers a striking presentation on the landscape, with its long, yucca-like leaves, round white flower heads and height of nearly five feet. The tuberous Indian plantain also has a distinctive appearance, with its clusters of white, tubular flowers.

For managers, such small prairie remnants always raise the issue of viability. The natural disturbance regimes and dynamics that sustain prairies operate best at a large scale. The configuration of Osmundson Prairie—long and narrow—also means that any given part of the SNA is in close proximity to the site's boundary, making it vulnerable to threats such as herbicide drift from surrounding agricultural lands. "We have observed some loss in diversity on the western part of the SNA," notes Regional SNA Specialist Brad Bolduan, "and invasive species such as Queen Ann's lace and wild parsnip are an ongoing concern."

Despite its challenges, like the strips of prairie found along railroad beds, this site nonetheless supports a diversity of native forbs and grasses. Periodic prescribed burns help to sustain such species as lead plant, prairie coreopsis (stiff tickseed) and the beautiful downy gentian, described by one observer who found it here as "welcome burst of brilliant blue."
