Through the years, a number of grassland bird species have been documented here as well, with summer records of Upland Sandpiper, Dickcissel, Sedge Wren, Eastern Meadowlark, Vesper Sparrow and Bobolink. In fall, watch for the elusive LeConte's Sparrow passing through on migration, finding temporary harbor in this preserved piece of Minnesota's natural heritage.

The Albert Lea Audubon Society assisted with this site's preservation, which was made possible by the donation of land to the state of Minnesota by Mildred Osmundson Wickman. The Osmundson family farmed in northern Iowa, and this site honors their memory.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Mildred Osmundson Wickman, with the assistance of the Albert Lea Audubon Society.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Fergus Falls 7 miles S of I-94 on Co Hwy 1, then 7 miles W on Co Rd 112 (become 140th St), then 1 mile S on 135th Ave, then 1 mile W on 130th St. Park in pull-off on N.

name: Otter Tail Prairie SNA
description:
This western Minnesota SNA hosts high quality examples of mesic (moderately moist) and wet prairie. Very little mesic prairie—or native upland prairie of any kind—remains in the state today. Upland sites were understandably the first to disappear in the conversion of land for other uses, offering rich soil for cropland and few obstacles to development. Many wet prairies were drained and used for cropland as well, or were overtaken by trees and shrubs in the absence of fire.

Here (with a knee-high pair of waterproof boots) one can still see both of these communities in fine form. Subtle shifts in vegetation respond to small changes in relief across the mostly flat terrain. Tall grasses define the mesic prairie, with dominants big bluestem, Indian grass and prairie dropseed, along with shrubs such as leadplant and prairie rose. In the wet prairie, you might expect to find prairie cordgrass, big bluestem and northern reedgrass. In small, scattered patches of wet saline prairie across the northern portion of the SNA, find salt grass, Nuthall's alkali grass and little bluestem. Across the SNA over four dozen species of forbs provide an ever-changing array of blooming flowers spring through fall, including rare small white lady's slipper and bright blue northern gentian.

Many of the grassland birds you'd hope to see are here: Greater Prairie Chickens on their booming grounds, bobolinks, dickcissels and western meadowlarks. The wet prairie environment also invites species such as sedge wrens, Wilson's Phalarope and Marbled Godwit.

In describing the abundant natural assets found here, it would be remiss to stop at the border of the SNA. Take the acreage within the SNA—320—and multiply it by ten to include the surrounding adjacent land protected within a prairie grassland complex known as the "Western Township Corridor Area." This block of state Wildlife Management Areas, federal Wetland Protection Areas, private easements, and property owned by the Fergus Falls Fish and Game Club covers 4.5 miles north to south and collectively totals roughly 3200 acres. Regional SNA Specialist Shelley Hedtke appreciates the role of the Club in this wider effort, which has created a buffer for the SNA and is an example of the importance of landscape connectivity of grassland parcels in parts of the state that have lost this important habitat type.

"Let's just say it didn't happen by accident," says Tony Rondeau, a member of the nearly 100 year-old Fergus Falls Fish and Game Club. The Club has been a major player in creating this corridor in the past two decades: purchasing land, putting together partnerships, writing grants, supporting initiatives by public agencies and other private groups, and generally helping to make things happen. Club resources are devoted to acquiring land for public access, restoring habitat, and supporting local initiatives educating youth about the outdoors. Hunting is an important aspect of the Club's culture, but both game and nongame species benefit from their efforts. Retired after 30 years working for the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service, Rondeau says that the passion continued after the paycheck stopped. "You want enough appropriate habitat for wildlife to be able to move into new areas, enough so that they can be successful. It's nice to see the pintails and blue-winged teal out there, and all the grassland nesting birds that you know wouldn't be there if the habitat wasn't sufficient." A discerning eye can still pick out the remnant native prairie within the SNA from the restored prairie on surrounding land, notes Rondeau. But with time, there's hope that might get a little harder to do.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. Doran and Prairie Ridge WMAs are adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From St. Joseph 4.5 miles N on Co Hwy 3. Park on W road shoulder near interpretive sign.

name: Partch Woods SNA
description:
Partch Woods is a climax maple-basswood forest: a world shaped by shade. During the growing season, full sunlight reaches the forest floor only in early spring before the leaves unfurl, or when a tree falls due to wind or decay. Small trees below—even shade tolerant maples—may never get the sun they need to reach the canopy.

A shrub layer is largely absent, giving the forest an open aspect. The understory is dominated in spring by a burst of ephemeral wildflowers (hepatica, wood anemone, bloodroot), followed in summer by lush ferns.

SNA outreach coordinator Kelly Randall recalls a visit to Partch Woods SNA on an October day as bright yellow maple leaves were raining down and piling up on the gently rolling terrain below. "Forests like this really resonate with people; the big trees, the long views. A maple-basswood forest is familiar, part of the culture here in central Minnesota."

Few such stands of the 'Big Woods' forest type remain in this part of the state. This one would be gone as well if not for the visionary actions of Dr. Max Partch, a biology professor at nearby St. Cloud State University (and himself a former student of visionary Aldo Leopold). It was Partch who first purchased the land to preserve its natural features.

In a 1966 Conservation Volunteer magazine article, Partch recalled his first sight of the woodland in January of 1957, "In knee-deep snow I went to look—and was amazed." When he learned the land was for sale, Partch tried to muster support for its purchase by the (then) Minnesota Department of Conservation, but it was sold instead to a Wisconsin veneer company. Loggers had already removed 110,000 board feet of maple, basswood, red oak, ash, birch and elm before Partch borrowed money and bought the land himself to protect the remaining trees, along with an adjacent seepage spring and sedge meadow. Years later, he donated the land to The Nature Conservancy, which transferred it to the SNA program.

Partch often took SCSU students on field trips here during his 30-year tenure. He also used the area for research, creating an archive of phenological data on the timing of such annual natural events as plant bloom periods, bird nesting and migration.

Max Partch retired in 1979 and passed away in 2003, but his legacy lives on in this Central Minnesota woodland that changes with the seasons in ways he knew so very well.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Mentor 12 miles W on Co Hwy 45, then  3 miles S on Co Hwy 44, then 0.75 mile E on Twp Rd 78. Park in pull-off on N.
From Mentor 10.25 miles W on Co Hwy 45. Park in pull-off on S.
From Mentor 10 miles W on Co Hwy 45. Park in lot on N or pull-off on S.

name: Pembina Trail SNA
description:
Pembina Trail SNA is notable in its own right, but also for being part of a landscape-scale tallgrass prairie initiative in Polk County that includes Glacial Ridge National Wildlife Refuge and over half a dozen nearby Wildlife Management Areas. The SNA takes its name from its proximity to Pembina Trail (also sometimes called the Woods Trail), one of the routes used in the mid-1800s to haul trade goods by ox-cart between the northwest prairies of the Red River Valley and St. Paul, Minnesota.

This 2,377-acre SNA is composed of three units: from north to south these are the Crookston Prairie, Pembina Trail Preserve SNA (owned by The Nature Conservancy and largest of the three, at 1660 acres) and Foxboro Prairie.

The site ranges from near-level to gently undulating, with a prominent Lake Agassiz beach ridge running along the eastern side of the SNA, expressed in the local topography as a 10-15' rise in elevation. As explained by Dr. Harvey Thorliefson, Director of the Minnesota Geological Survey, this wave-deposited, sand and gravel ridge marks the historic shoreline of the lake during its Tintah phase, and was formed an estimated 11,500 to 13,000 calendar years before present. This ancient beach ridge not only offers insight into Minnesota's geologic past, it adds to the biodiversity of the landscape by supporting sand-gravel prairie.

Most of the SNA has been mapped by the Minnesota Biological Survey as Agassiz Interbeach Prairie Complex, defined as "a mosaic of upland prairie, wetland prairie, and sedge meadow communities in areas of shallow swales and rises on calcareous soils formed in glacial Lake Agassiz lacustrine deposits." Relatively smaller areas of wet-mesic aspen and aspen-oak woodland may be found as well, along with small fen communities in areas of groundwater discharge high in calcium and magnesium bicarbonates.

Despite a land-use history that includes haying, cultivation and grazing in parts of the SNA, a remarkable diversity of native species persists here. Rare species include Hall's sedge, hair-like beak rush, Dakota skipper butterfly, small white lady's-slipper, northern gentian, and grassland birds such as Upland Sandpiper, Yellow Rail, greater prairie chicken, marbled godwit and Wilson's Phalarope. This is one of few places in the state where the federally-threatened western fringed prairie orchid still perfumes the summer nights.

The Nature Conservancy (TNC) has long had a presence in this region, not only acquiring native prairie remnants for preserves but also bringing together public and private partners to restore the intervening lands to prairie. These efforts culminated in a 24,158-acre land acquisition by TNC in the year 2000, which became the heart of the Glacial Ridge National Wildlife Refuge.

Brian Winter has worked in various capacities for TNC in this region for more than 30 years, and is now the organization's Program Director for Stewardship in Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. "Pembina Trail SNA stands out in my mind for its native prairie and rare species," says Winter. "It's been both the blueprint and seed source for the massive Glacial Ridge Project, which is mostly reconstructed prairie." He adds, "For me, personally, I'll always remember Pembina as the place where I saw three of Minnesota's native grouse in one day: Ruffed Grouse, Sharp-tail Grouse and Greater Prairie Chickens. It was a real treat to be able to do that."

So often we read about the tallgrass prairie as something of the past: a broken, fragmented landscape. Here, we see the beginnings of a new story, one that gives hope that we may retain at least some of the prairie's rich diversity and ability to function. Among the good signs observed by TNC is that hydrology is returning to more natural conditions in parts of the Glacial Ridge landscape, with increased retention of water in the surficial soils. With each passing season, the native prairie at Pembina Trail SNA finds itself in better and better company.

"Lake Agassiz was an immense ice-dammed lake that filled the Red River Valley during the retreat of the continental ice sheet at the end of the most recent Ice Age. The history of the lake was complicated, but overall its level fell stepwise, as the outlet channel to the Minnesota River Valley was eroded, and as lower outlets across the Iron Range, or leading to the Great Lakes and/or Arctic Ocean were opened as the ice retreated.

Each level of the lake left behind shoreline features that are now in many cases mined for sand and gravel. The principal shorelines that drained south to the Minnesota River Valley are named after towns on a rail line in western Minnesota between Morris and Wahpeton – from highest to lowest, these are the Herman, Norcross, Tintah, and Campbell. Much research has addressed the age of these shorelines, with conflicting estimates for the Tintah's age ranging from about 11,500 to 13,000 calendar years."

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. Glacial Ridge National Wildlife Refuge and Burnham WMA are adjacent to this site.

parking.directions: From Bemidji 16 miles E on Co Hwy 12, then 1.5 miles N on Co Hwy 39. Park in lot just N of site, then hike S to site. Visitor permit required, call 218-308-2620.

name: Pennington Bog SNA
description:
When this site was designated in 1979 it was one of only ten SNAs in the state. Located near Bemidji, Pennington Bog is a little-disturbed tract of lowland-coniferous forest within the Chippewa National Forest. According to Regional Forest Ecologist Nick Jensen, most of the SNA can be characterized as a northern cedar swamp community. Peaty, mucky soils have formed here on near-level terrain, in ground moraine deposited by the retreating Des Moines lobe of the late Wisconsin glaciation. Sphagnum moss, Labrador tea, carnivorous sundews and pitcher plants, marsh marigold, bog buckbean, cranberry, and many orchid species are found in the understory beneath a canopy of white cedar, balsam fir, and black spruce. Water features prominently. The water table is at or near the surface throughout the site, and an intermittent stream—Sucker Creek—bisects the SNA as it flows from Kitchi Lake to Popple Lake.

This SNA is best known for the succession of orchids that come into bloom during the growing season. With a careful step and watchful eye, one might spot calypso, green adder's mouth, ram's-head lady's slipper, dragon's mouth and small northern bog-orchid, among others. Other inhabitants documented here over the years have included golden-winged warblers, indigo buntings, chorus and mink frogs, fisher, and southern (Gapper's) red-backed voles, notable among voles for their tree-climbing ability.

It's a fragile site, requiring special care. Even well-intentioned visitors, in too great a number, could result in trampling of delicate vegetation, soil compaction, and ad hoc footpaths that would alter the site's hydrology, which is vital to the native plant communities here. Accordingly, it has been designated as a Sanctuary, and a user-friendly permit system is used to manage the number of visitors present on site at any given time and on any given day. (See Visitor Notes, above.)

Access to the SNA is from its western boundary along Beltrami County Highway 39. The 28-mile stretch of 39 between Blackduck and Highway 2 (east of Cass Lake) is known as the Lady Slipper Scenic Byway. A major effort was undertaken here with the help of local organizations and community volunteers to salvage, store and re-plant lady's slipper orchids growing naturally along the roadway during a multi-phase road construction project. The final phase of this construction was underway in 2019. Lady's slippers rescued from the last 3-mile segment are waiting in their storage/nursery site to be put back along the roadsides in the years to come. Both the Herculean effort of the undertaking and the people who travel here to enjoy the results offer testament to Minnesotans' appreciation for their natural heritage.

Included in this project was creation of a parking area northwest of the SNA with a small boardwalk overlooking a variety of orchids salvaged from the construction. It's a nice alternative for visitors that does not require a permit, and also helps to reduce impacts on the SNA.

All native orchids are protected by law in Minnesota, and collecting from the wild is prohibited.
notes: Sanctuary (open by permit only, see sanctuary link for how to apply). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the Buena Vista State Forest and Chippewa National Forest.

parking.directions: From I-494 in SE Metro, exit at Hardmann Ave, N to Verderosa Ave, E over trail/levee to water access on Mississippi River. Site is 1 mile N (upstream).  Accessible by boat. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Pigs Eye Island Heron Rookery SNA
description:
Named for colorful character Pierre "Pig's Eye" Parrant., this island SNA has been the focus of volunteer clean-ups, citizen activism to prevent development, and research on toxic perfluorinated compounds (PFCs) in bird eggs.

A floodplain forest of green ash, silver maple, cottonwood and black willow became established on the 80-acre island here, providing suitable nesting habitat for colonial waterbirds. The Pig's Eye Island rookery is the largest and longest-occupied site for colonial nesting birds in the metro area, and among the largest in the state.

Total breeding population and species distribution have changed at the Pig's Eye colony over the years. In 1987, for example, spring surveys indicated a total of 1300 active nests, or an estimated adult breeding population of 2600 birds. Researchers documented 540 great egret nests, 496 black-crowned night heron nests, 180 great blue heron nests, and 84 double-crested cormorant nests. Compare this to a 2015 survey documenting 554 nests, or an estimated adult breeding population of 1108 birds. These included 253 great blue heron nests, 118 American white pelican, 181 great egret, and 2 black-crowned night heron. Once among the most plentiful, black-crowned night herons are now the least represented among nesting species utilizing the site.

The expression “strength in numbers” doesn't always hold true for birds that nest in communal settings. The reliable source of food can make depredation of nests (in particular, by raccoons and great-horned owls) a serious problem; and the birds take a toll on their own habitat with their highly acidic droppings.

The SNA's urban setting also presents threats and challenges. Studies in 1993 and again in 2010-2011 found PFC concentrations in some heron eggs collected from the island to be among the highest measured in bird eggs worldwide. As reported by the authors of the latter study*, numerous manufacturing facilities and landfills for PFC-related waste, as well as a wastewater treatment plant, are located within 20 km (12.42 miles) of the colony: a distance great blue herons regularly travel from nest sites for daily feeding. PFCs (also referred to as PFASs) are a family of synthetic chemicals associated with harmful physiological and neurological effects in birds. Of particular and ongoing concern are certain “long chain” types—a reference to the number of carbons—which according to the EPA are “persistent in the environment, bioaccumulative** in wildlife and humans, and toxic to laboratory animals and wildlife.” A voluntary partial phase-out of PFCs was undertaken from 2000-2002 by the 3M Corporation, a major source of the toxins in the Pig's Eye area.

The island was also nearly lost to development. In 1984, the St. Paul Port Authority proposed a dredge-and-fill project that would have destroyed the natural area to create off-channel slips for barges. Thankfully, over 40 citizen, environmental, labor and sportsmen's groups organized as the Pig's Eye Coalition to successfully campaign against the project.

Community involvement remains critical to the area's conservation. Kudos to volunteers from Boston Scientific (formerly Guidant Corporation)'s Green Team and the many other partners who have sponsored and participated in regular trash clean-ups of this site. As of 2014, eight successive efforts had removed 15,760 pounds of tires, plastic, and other debris trapped by the island's vegetation during high water periods. According to Tiffany Lovik of Boston Scientific, the work is dirty, sweaty, sometimes muddy and always fun: “People are happy to get out there and do their part to help the environment.” Want to help? For many years coordinated by the DNR, the Adopt-a-River Program clean-up events are now managed by the Conservation Corps.

*Custer et al, Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry, Vol. 32, No. 5, pp. 1077-1083, 2013, Perfluorinated Compound Concentrations in Great Blue Heron Eggs near St. Paul, Minnesota, USA, in 1993 AND 2010-2011
** building up over time in an organism

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by Ramsey County, Parks and Recreation Department.
notes: Sanctuary (closed April 1 - July 15). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Chatfield 4 miles SW on Co Rd 5, then .07 mile S on Twp Rd 332. Park in pull-off on E.

name: Pin Oak Prairie SNA
description:
This Filmore County SNA site captures a meandering stretch of the Root River's Middle Branch, along with adjacent lowlands and slopes that rise more than 240 feet within the boundaries of the site. Sandy soils derived from St. Peter Sandstone set the stage for three native plant communities here, with dune-and-swale topography in the floodplain and sand terraces above.

Pin Oak Prairie is remarkable for having a high quality sedge meadow, which is rare in the blufflands of the Paleozoic Plateau. The SNA harbors one of the last and largest remnants of dry barrens prairie in southeast Minnesota. It also hosts an oak-shagbark hickory woodland dominated by even-aged, mature northern pin oak.

A number of state-listed rare plants benefit from the varied habitats here: wild sweet William in the wet meadow, glade mallow on the stream banks and floodplain, and clasping milkweed on the dry, sparsely vegetated areas of upland prairie. Visitors will appreciate the vistas here of open-grown oaks and the diversity of prairie grasses, with big and little bluestem, Indian grass, porcupine grass, prairie cord-grass.

The history of this site's preservation is something of a happy accident. Prior to becoming an SNA, the land was part of a larger tract owned by longtime farmer Emil "Bud" Kark. Although grazed, its terrain and sandy soil made it unsuitable for cultivation. In the early 1990s, local residents Tim and Susan Gossman first met Bud Kark when friends suggested he might be able to provide the sand they needed for a sandbox they were building for their daughter. Kark said they were welcome to have a pick-up load, so they drove the 3-4 miles from their house to his farm. While they were there, Susan—who had been a biology major in college and was interested in botany—noticed blue bottle gentian in bloom. Bud Kark remarked that they should return in spring, when he said the hillside would be full of wild crocus (pasque flower).

"At about the same time," says Tim, "we were part of a local volunteer group called Prairie Smoke* that was getting started as part of the Chatfield Fish and Game Club." Members of Prairie Smoke were interested in prairie preservation and restoration—in particular, helping private landowners with prescribed burning. With Bud's permission, they did their first prescribed burn on several acres of the sand prairie there. The group's volunteers returned in later years to conduct additional burns, and also did some seed collection at the site for a small prairie restoration project in town. "DNR nongame wildlife specialist Jaime Edwards was part of our group," notes Tim, "and I think our volunteer efforts there helped put the site on the radar of the DNR." By 2000, Bud Kark had sold the 180 acres to the state to become Pin Oak Prairie SNA. Thanks to Mr. Kark—with a little help from Prairie Smoke—the wild crocus will continue to bloom on these sandy slopes above the Root River for a long, long time.

* Prairie Smoke has since become a nonprofit organization, dedicated to "Encouraging the restoration, propagation, and maintenance of prairies of all sizes, urban and rural, through education and assistance to landowners, both public and private."
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: Waterfowl hunting only allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Baudette 1 mile W on MN Hwy 11, then 11.5 miles N and E on MN Hwy 172 to water access on Rainy RIver on S. Site is about 3 miles N in Lake of the Woods. Accessible by boat. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Pine and Curry Island SNA
description:
"On the boat ride back around the island at the end of the day, piping plovers were seen nearly continuously the length of Pine Island…" Field Examination Report, 1979, Paul Rundell, Dr. Harold Peters, Jeff Barnard

This SNA is part of a string of barrier islands that shelter 4-Mile Bay from the open waters of Lake of the Woods near the outlet of the northwest-flowing Rainy River. The eastern side of this "string" lies across the international border in Ontario and is designated as the Sable Islands Provincial Nature Reserve. The western side is in the U.S. and (together with Morris Point on the mainland) is designated as Minnesota's Pine and Curry Island SNA.

Undeveloped sandy coastlines on large, freshwater lakes are rare, and island sites in particular represent a haven for nesting shorebirds. This is one of few such sites in Minnesota where both Piping Plover (state-endangered, federal-threatened) and Common Tern (state-threatened) have been reported to nest. For the Piping Plover, the situation is especially dire.

By all accounts, the Piping Plover is in trouble in Minnesota. Nesting of the species in the state, if any, is believed limited to a handful of sites in Lake of the Woods, one of which is this SNA. In the early 1980s, roughly two dozen breeding pairs of Piping Plovers nested on Pine and Curry Island. But the population of this colony has since plummeted, with "0-2" nesting pairs reported during the breeding season in recent years. The story is similar on the adjacent Sable Islands Provincial Nature Reserve in Ontario, where the last documented breeding observation of Piping Plover occurred in 2007. As Chris Martin, Management Biologist of the Kenora District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry relates, even occasional sightings of individual birds and nest scrapes has tapered off, with no birds or eggs observed by Ministry staff since 2012.

SNA designation unfortunately does not ensure the birds' nesting success. The islands are already narrow (ranging in width from 50-1000') and erosion accelerated by high water levels is causing loss of coastal habitat. Nests are vulnerable to predation by gulls and mammals, as well as disturbance by humans (however well meaning) and their dogs. More broadly, populations of these species have been declining on a regional scale, so fewer birds are available to disperse into this area.

The birds' plight makes protection of suitable nesting habitat here all the more important. Visitors can help by honoring the seasonal period during which part of the SNA is designated as a sanctuary to maximize the birds' opportunity for successful nesting.

This is a place of wind, waves, and open sky. Vegetation transitions in zones from the wave-washed shoreline and its band of open, sandy beach, to sparsely vegetated beach-grass dune characterized by Canada rye, beach pea and wormwood. Farther inland on the wider, more easterly part of the island is a mixed forest with large white pine in the canopy, and hackberry and burr oak in the sub-canopy. Small, wetter pockets contain black spruce, cedar and boxelder.

A diversity of shorebirds, raptors and passerines (songbirds) use this site, their numbers rising during migration seasons as they loaf and refuel in the barrier islands. Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) here include the Piping Plover, Common Tern, White Pelican, Ruddy Turnstone, Greater Yellowlegs and Short-eared Owl.

Note: So, is Pine and Curry Island one island or two ? For the moment, one. In the past, two. In the deeper past, one again, connected to each other (and also to Morris Point) forming a peninsula reaching out from the mainland. It's a dynamic environment, an eternal work in progress.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy
notes: Sanctuary (posted sanctuary portions closed April 1 through July 15). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Mississippi River Regional Trail).
Dogs (on leash only, and only on Mississippi River Regional Trail).
Picnicking (only at trailhead facilities for Mississippi River Regional Trail).

parking.directions: In Inver Grove Heights from I-494 7 miles S on US Hwy 52, then E over 52 on 117th St, then 0.8 mile N on Courthouse Blvd (frontage road), then 0.25 mi E on 111th St. Park in lot on S.

name: Pine Bend Bluffs SNA
description:
Find stunning views from 200 foot bluffs overlooking the Mississippi at this SNA, one of the least disturbed sites along the river in the Twin Cities.

Dry to mesic oak forests dominate the site's rugged terrain, complemented by stands of white pine on north-facing slopes, dry prairies on south- and east-facing slopes, and black ash seepage swamp at the river's edge. Numerous rare species find appropriate habitat, among them James' polanisia and butternut (both MN endangered), kitten-tails (MN threatened), and red-shouldered hawk (MN Special Concern).

The site serves research purposes as well. Studies by the Great Lakes Inventory and Monitoring Network have focused on monitoring bald eagle nestlings for DDE (a metabolite of the pesticide DDT), PCBs and mercury, environmental contaminants that can persist and even amplify over time through the food chain in wildlife populations.

It is a wonderful place from which to witness the twice-yearly migration, when tundra swans, pelicans, waterfowl, hawks and eagles make their passage along the Mississippi flyway; or to explore in spring and early summer when hepatica, blood-root, wild ginger and jack-in-the-pulpit bloom beneath the oaks. As you do, you'll be fulfilling the wish of the late Dwight Malcolm, who donated the initial parcel of land for this SNA so that future generations might enjoy the site's inestimable natural beauty.

[Scientific research at this SNA has included investigations of anuran populations (frogs, toads, and tree frogs) to record species number and diversity, collect data on habitat usage and conditions, record dates of metamorphosis and hatching, and observe evidence of predation, habitat change and threats from human activities.]

Ownership & Origins: The Trust for Public Land, Friends of the Mississippi River and Dakota County assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: The Mississippi River Regional Trail passes through site, see detail map. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. The Mississippi River Water Trail is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Roseau 6 miles W on MN Hwy 11, then 9 miles NW on MN Hwy 89, then 2.5 miles N on Twp 151 (320th Ave). Park at corner and trek 0.75 mile E into site. GPS recommended.

name: Pine Creek Peatland SNA
description:
Pine Creek Peatland SNA protects the U.S. portion of a much larger peatland complex that extends across the international border into Manitoba. The importance of this area has been recognized on the Canadian side as well, with designation in 2015 of the 1,927-acre Piney Ecological Reserve in Manitoba.

This SNA is ranked as a site of "Outstanding Biodiversity Significance." Key peatland landforms here include a large water track, ribbed fen and spring fen channels. Portions of the water track exhibit flarks (pools) oriented perpendicular to groundwater flow, where rare linear-leaved and English sundew may be found. Other rare plant species include sterile sedge, twig rush and ram's head orchid.

Over two dozen Lepidoptera (moth and butterfly) species have been documented on the site. In 2014, MBS entomologist Kyle Johnson reported an especially exciting find, of the first Minnesota record of the Aweme borer moth. Writing at the time of the discovery, Johnson remarked,"It was the moth I was seeking but certainly not actually expecting to catch— a single Papaipema aweme! This non-descript light brown 'Holy Grail' of moths was previously known from only 8 specimens worldwide."

Bird counts led by ornithologist Steve Stucker have identified many Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) here, including Sandhill Cranes, Sedge Wrens and Black-billed Cuckoo. Among these are habitat specialists such as the Connecticut Warbler, which nests in sphagnum peat and is confined to lowland conifer peatland habitats. The Great Grey Owl is found in comparable habitats nearby and is likely here as well.

Together with Piney Ecological Reserve to the north and Sprague Creek Peatland SNA to the east, this site will continue to serve as a refuge for these and many other native species. Such vast, relatively undisturbed landscapes also offer scientists a window into the past and an opportunity to study large-scale processes and phenomena such as climate change.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the Lost River State Forest.

restrictions: ATVs on designated trail (Horseshoe Forest Trail, check for closures in George Washington State Forest).
Dogs (must be under control, allowed when used for hunting).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Togo 4.3 miles W on MN Hwy 1, continue 0.8 on Co Rd, then 5.3 miles N on Co Rd 542 (Button Box Forest Rd), then 1.2 miles W (left) on Horseshoe Forest Rd (minimum maintenance) to site. Park on pull-offs along road.

name: Potato Lake SNA
description:
This Itasca County SNA is largely forested, with the exception of a small fen at the southern edge of the property and a narrow band of shoreline along Potato Lake. It features a 59-acre block of red pine-white pine woodland approximately 100 years old.* This woodland varies in composition across the site from nearly pure pockets of red pine to a mixed canopy of big toothed aspen, quaking aspen, red pine and paper birch.

The terrain rises steeply away from the lake, climbing to a ridge that plateaus at 1450 feet then descends gradually on the north end of site, where one can find aspen-birch forest, aspen-birch-red maple forest and two basins of conifer swamp. Defined in the Minnesota Biological Survey (MBS) classification system as Poor Black Spruce Swamps these areas are characterized by black spruce with an understory of dry, hummocky sphagnum moss and the shrubs Labrador tea, bog laurel, bog rosemary and leatherleaf. "Poor" in this case refers to a relative lack of nutrients and an acidic, saturated environment. An interesting community of plants thrives in this seemingly inhospitable environment; watch here for pitcher plants among the hummocks.

The red pine-white pine woodland may be considered the natural feature of greatest ecological significance here, but MBS ecologist Ethan Perry also notes the research value of the aspen-birch communities. "The aspen- and birch-dominated portions of the site were likely never clear-cut," says Perry, "and only experienced the removal of scattered pines and cedars. These areas provide an opportunity to follow the successional trajectory of old aspen stands in the absence of logging."

This is one of two Itasca County SNAs (the other being Little Too Much Lake) made possible by land donations from Jerry Martin of Illinois. Martin came to love Minnesota's northern lake country as a boy, when his family made summer trips to the area to fish and vacation. He began to purchase parcels of undeveloped land—in particular those with lakeshore—as he saw opportunities arise. Later, he donated the properties to the Scientific and Natural Areas Program and to the nonprofit Minnesota Land Trust for long-term preservation. Thanks to his foresight and generosity, these places will endure.

* based on county/state inventory data supported by the 2006 coring of a 110-year old red pine on site.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from Jerry Martin.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the George Washington State Forest.

restrictions: Snowmobiling on designated trail (Snowmobile Trail 112: Cottonwood and Jackson County).

parking.directions: From Windom 8.5 miles S on Co Hwy 17, then 1.5 miles E on Co Hwy 24 into Kilen Woods State Park. Park in lot near office and hike trails S to site.

name: Prairie Bush Clover SNA
description:
This 13-acre SNA is designated within Kilen Woods State Park in Jackson County, one of a string of SNAs aligned along the Des Moines River.

The SNA is located in an area of the park where ridge tops and steep side slopes host glacial till hill prairie and a small calcareous fen. As the name suggests, this site is most notable for its population of prairie bush clover (Lespedeza leptostachya), listed as a threatened species at both state and federal levels. This species is restricted to the tallgrass prairie region of the upper Mississippi River Valley in the states of Illinois, Iowa, Wisconsin, and Minnesota.

The two colonies of prairie bush clover found within this SNA have been the focus of the longest continuous study of the species, with annual monitoring begun in the early 1980s by Welby Smith and continued by Nancy Sather, botanists with the Minnesota Biological Survey. The study has fostered many insights that inform management across the species' range. "For example," says Sather, "by following the fate of individual plants, we've learned that a single plant can live for years; and, while fecundity (seed production) can be enormous, seedling survivorship is very poor. Also, the appearance of a given plant does not necessarily indicate its age. An established plant that flowered one year may revert to a smaller, non-flowering plant the following year, going back and forth in an unpredictable pattern. The relationship between these morphological changes and their drivers (causes) has not been statistically analyzed, but it is likely drought is a contributing factor."

As Sather, now retired, relates, this SNA is a great example of the substantive and high quality contributions of citizen science. After establishment of the study by Welby Smith, the effort has continued with the contributions of Girl Scouts, 4-Hers, and citizen scientists under the supervision of DNR botanists with the Minnesota Natural Heritage Program and its successor, the Minnesota Biological Survey.

Monitoring goes largely unseen by the public, in steep and relatively inaccessible ravines. But seen or unseen, it's a good reminder of the science that takes place in Minnesota Scientific and Natural Areas, and the cadre of researchers working to understand and protect the state's natural heritage. Long-term studies such as this have merits beyond measure: the data they generate serving as a repository of answers to future questions, not only about the prairie bush clover but about the functioning of Minnesota's ecosystems as a whole.

Visitors here will enjoy ascending the ridge along a mowed park trail to the lovely hill prairie here. Watch for spring's first pasque flowers, and summer's yellow heart-leaved alexanders and orange butterfly weed, blooming among little bluestem and sideoats grama. It's a wonderful opportunity to see this remnant hill prairie in the context of the larger landscape of Kilen Woods State Park with its Des Moines river shoreline, oak forest, oak savanna and overlook of the surrounding bluff country of southwestern Minnesota. As you do, know that somewhere in a quiet draw, a prairie bush clover plant may be shape-shifting for the coming season, for reasons we have yet to fully understand.

Note: It's best not to seek out prairie bush clover here, which on this small site is easily disturbed, vulnerable to inadvertent spread of invasive species, and found in areas with precarious footing.
notes: A hiking trail passes through site. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area and Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. Recreational facilities available in Kilen Woods State Park.

restrictions: Dogs (only when used for hunting, must be under control).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Pipestone 10 miles NE on MN Hwy 23, then 0.5 mile W on Co Rd 81 (181st St), then 1 mile N on Co Rd 80 (150th Ave), then 0.5 mile E on 191th St. Park at dead end.
From Pipestone 10 miles NE on MN Hwy 23, then 0.25 mile E on Co Rd 84 (181st St). Park on N road shoulder.
From Pipestone 10 miles NE on MN Hwy 23. Park in lot on W, across railroad grade.

name: Prairie Coteau SNA
description:
Take a one minute tour of the site

This video was filmed by Dale Bohlke with permission from the Scientific and Natural Area Program.


Prairie Coteau SNA is one of the most important and stunning prairies in southwestern Minnesota. It occupies an area of steep slopes and valleys that cut through the Bemis glacial moraine, and takes its name from the larger, 20,000 square mile plateau of which it is a part, the Coteau des Prairies,' or prairie highlands. Painter George Catlin, traveling to the region in the 1830s, offered a description of the approach from the surrounding plains that still holds true today: "For many miles we had the Coteau in view in the distance before us, which looked like a blue cloud settling down in the horizon."

At this 420-acre site, deep stony till deposited from 18,000 to 12,000 years ago lies exposed on eroded slopes, while the flat ridge tops are covered by loess (fine, windblown sediments of glacial origin). Rolling, treeless topography hosts native dry sand-gravel prairie on the higher elevations and prairie meadow/carr (a type of wet prairie) in lowland areas and along drainages occupied by intermittent streams. Rare Dakota, and Ottoe skippers are among at least 40 lepidoptera (butterfly and moth) species documented here, along with more than 60 species of grasses, sedges and rushes, and over 200 wildflower species, including the small white lady's-slipper.

The site is not without evidence of human activity: a road and parallel railroad grade bisect its southeast corner, wind turbines turn on adjacent lands, and ongoing restoration efforts target areas impacted by historic grazing. Still, the native prairie and dramatic setting offer a visual feast for visitors. Come in late spring for puccoon and prairie smoke; midsummer for wood lilies and prairie phlox; late summer for blazing stars, asters, goldenrods and sunflowers.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Buffalo Ridge WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only muzzleloader by permit through Nerstrand Big Woods State Park), see the regulations handbook for hunting details. Varies year to year, check current regulations handbook for information.

parking.directions: From Nerstrand 0.5 mile W and 1 mile N on MN Hwy 246, then 1 mile W on Co Hwy 30. Park on S road shoulder.

name: Prairie Creek Woods SNA
description:
This SNA is about the survival of a species. The dwarf trout lily's natural range is limited to a 200 square-mile area in Minnesota, where isolated colonies are found occurring on roughly 600 acres scattered across two watersheds. One of those places is here.

The dwarf trout lily is federally endangered and one of only a few species endemic (native and restricted) to Minnesota, believed to have originated in the Faribault area after a glacial retreat 13,000 years ago. This rare lily is only visible for about two months of the year. In early spring, first mottled leaves and then the slender, bud-tipped flower stalks rise from underground stems. During a 2-week blooming period, the dime-sized, white to pink flowers close each night and reopen each day. By summer even the leaves have fallen away, decomposing in the litter of the forest floor.

The site lies adjacent to Nerstrand Big Woods State Park on the park’s northern border. From the designated parking area, cross a restored prairie to reach the SNA boundary, where the land drops into a broad, forested ravine that follows the course of an intermittent stream. Rock outcroppings dot the ridgeline beneath a mature forest of sugar maple, basswood and bitternut hickory. This is part of the legendary forest that early French explorers called the Bois Grands—the Big Woods.

It is hard to find a better place to greet the spring than a maple-basswood forest. Visitors will find the hillsides alive with returning migrant songbirds. Watch and listen for Wood Thrushes, Indigo Buntings, Scarlet Tanagers, American Redstarts, and dozens of species of warblers.

Management here focuses on protection of the dwarf trout lily, control of invasive plants (notably, garlic mustard), and restoration of forest on upland old fields using saplings reared from locally collected seed. You can help prevent the spread of garlic mustard by learning to identify it and avoiding spreading its tiny seed that can be transported on clothing and shoes.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails. This site is in a Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. Recreational facilities available in Nerstrand Big Woods State Park.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only anlerless), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Fertile 5 miles S on MN Hwy 32, then 1.2 mile W on 310th Ave. Park at gated pull-off on N. Hike 0.25 miles N to dunes.
From Fertile 4.7 miles S on MN Hwy 32,  Park at pull-off on W.

name: Prairie Smoke Dunes SNA
description:
The slightest breeze will stir the rose-colored haze that settles on the dunes here in spring; not smoke, but the wispy, threadlike styles of this SNA's namesake wildflower after it has bloomed.

Fine sand characterizes the ancient inter-beach area along the east margin of the Agassiz lake plain, site of Prairie Smoke Dunes SNA, where an intact dune complex together with a state-threatened native plant community (dry sand savanna) led to this site's protection.

Dramatic dunes in the northern portion of the site range from 40 to 50 feet high, with the leading edge of the dune forming an abrupt scarp nearly 60 feet high. The dry sand savanna community associated with the dunes features skeleton weed, ricegrass, and purple sand-grass in the understory with patchy bur oaks, occasional basswood and green ash; frequent blow-outs and sparsely vegetated slopes punctuate the landscape. Vegetation changes dramatically at the crest of the dune faces, transitioning to dense forest on the far (north) side, while areas of lower elevation support a variety of sedge meadow, wet prairie, and wet-mesic prairie communities.

Rare and notable plants include the state flower, the showy lady slipper, along with yellow lady slippers. In July, watch for the blooming of the endangered western prairie fringed orchid, attracting pollinating moths—often a sphinx or hawk moth—with a heady fragrance that grows stronger as night falls.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Snowmobiling on designated trail (Snowmobile Trail 61: Taconite State Trail).

parking.directions: From Ely 12 miles W on MN Hwy 169, then 4 miles S on Co Hwy 128, then 2 miles E on Forest Rd 598 (Purvis Forest Rd). Park on S shoulder and hike 500 feet S (past Taconite State Trail) into site.

name: Purvis Lake-Ober Foundation SNA
description:
This SNA is located on the eastern shore of Purvis Lake in Bear Island State Forest not far from the Eagle's Nest chain of lakes and about 10 miles southwest of Ely. Its topography reflects the Border Lakes subsection, where numerous glacial advances have produced a pattern of lakes, bogs and rocky ridges. While most of the surrounding area has been actively managed for timber, the mixed upland forest in the SNA—dominated by aspen, birch and pine—has been largely untouched. The size and relatively undisturbed nature of this site, along with its old-growth features, give this site its high preservation value.

A local legend, Charles Sumner (Sam) Purvis reportedly moved to Ely in 1907, when he took up residence on this land and began to build a homestead, obtaining ownership by patent in 1913. He lived here in a two-room cabin until shortly before his death in 1970. Purvis was well known in the community for actively defending his land's wildlife and forests. He himself lived lightly on the land, without running water or electricity. He took care to harvest and clear only what was needed to sustain himself, leaving the remainder of the land undisturbed. As a friend related in a July, 1979 article in the Ely Echo, he was often known to say, "I got the only place left in the whole world."

The SNA Program now carries on his legacy of preservation. The state was able to acquire the land from Mr. Purvis' estate, thanks to contributions from the private Ober Foundation through the coordinating efforts of The Nature Conservancy.

Visitors will find bedrock at or near the surface throughout the SNA, with exposures revealing Giants Range Granite and the ancient (2.6—2.7 billion year-old) Ely Greenstone. Two eastward-flowing streams cross the site: the Beaver River and a smaller stream, Purvis Creek that drains Purvis Lake. Roughly three-quarters of the site is occupied by mixed upland forest, in which aspen, paper birch, jack pine, red pine, white pine, balsam fir and white spruce intermingle in the canopy. A mature red pine stand is found on the northeast shore of the lake and a white cedar stand on the southeast shore. Small pockets of black spruce bog are scattered across the SNA in peat-filled depressions.

Listen here for loons and ravens; watch for sign of black bear, wolves and moose; catch sight of a boreal red-backed vole skittering up a tree. In spring, await the wave of returning warblers, among them the Black-and-White, Parula, Chestnut-sided, Nashville, Black-throated Green. Walk the banks of a north country stream through a forest of diverse ages and species, with lofty white and red pine. Stand quietly at the edge of a seasonal pond. Be glad for the grit of Charles Sumner Purvis, who devoted the better part of a century to keeping this wild place wild.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within the Bear Island State Forest

parking.directions: In Waite Park, from MN Hwy 23 0.65 mile S on 10th Ave, then 0.75 mile W on Co Rd 137 (7th St). Park in lot on S for Quarry Park (fee required). Hike trails S through park and into site.

name: Quarry Park SNA
description:
This is a richly storied site. Quarry Park SNA's 323 acres are embedded within a 684-acre Stearns County Park, on land known for its history of granite mining during the first half of the 20th century.

Turn the clock farther back, and you will find the origins of that granite in a mountain-building episode. Known as the Penokean Orogeny, this episode began approximately 1.9 million years ago, when the collision of two continents caused extreme thickening of the continental crust. Geologist Terry Boerboom of the Minnesota Geological Survey explains: "As this over-thickened crust collapsed and thinned, high-temperature magma welled up from the earth's mantle and pooled beneath it. The addition of the magma to the already hot base of the crust caused it to melt and mingle with the underlying magma from the mantle. Batches of this mixture rose upward to a depth of about 10 miles below the surface, where it slowly cooled to form the granite. The different colors of granite reflect the varied degrees to which the two different magma sources were mixed."

The northern part of the park (outside of the SNA) has more evidence of the granite quarrying industry and is developed for recreational use (including swimming in the old quarry pits, one of which is 116' deep). A self-guided Eco-Walk offers insights into both natural and cultural history.

Sometimes called Quarry Park South, the SNA offers a less altered setting, preserving what has been described as central Minnesota's best example of a granite bedrock outcrop community. Unlike the towering cliffs that surround the quarry pools, the bedrock here is generally at or slightly above the ground's surface. It supports a native plant community described by the Minnesota Biological Survey as "Crystalline Bedrock Outcrop" which is ranked S2, or imperiled in the state. Relatively few species can tolerate the moisture and temperature extremes of this exposed environment where soil is scarce. Here, one can find such plants as pale corydalis, lowbush blueberry, poverty grass and brittle prickly pear cacti, the last of which is considered a rock outcrop specialist, its range restricted to this rare habitat type.

In addition to the vegetation associated with the granite outcrops, this SNA protects large expanses of high quality wet meadow, wet prairie, oak woodland and oak forest. These varied habitats host species such as the tubercled rein orchid (threatened in Minnesota) and birds such as the Red-shouldered Hawk and Acadian Flycatcher (both Minnesota special concern).

Students from the College of St. Benedict, St. John's University and St. Cloud State University as well as local k-12 schools regularly make use of the Park and SNA as a field site for study of geology, biology and wetland science. Fortunately, this site is open to us all: even those with school days behind them can still gain insights into the natural world in this fascinating landscape.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by Stearns County.
notes: Hiking trails pass through this site. Recreational facilities available in Quarry Park and Nature Preserve.

parking.directions: From Racine 1.75 miles N on US Hwy 63. Park in pull-off on E.

name: Racine Prairie SNA
description:
This 6-acre remnant of mesic prairie is the most northerly of three SNAs in Mower County, all associated with abandoned railway rights-of-way (see also Shooting Star Prairie SNA and Wild Indigo SNA). Rare species found along the half-mile stretch of former railway include white wild indigo and rattlesnake master (both state-listed as special concern). This site was among the earliest in the state to be acquired for SNA designation, based in part on a resource inventory documenting 138 native species.

The aerial photography view of this SNA (see map below) shows the isolation of the native plant communities here. Very little remains of the tall grass prairie that was once found in southeastern Minnesota, which historically exhibited greater species diversity than any other prairie community type in the state. Some species, such as white wild indigo, occur in SE Minnesota at the extreme northwestern edge of their range.

In 1997-98, the Minnesota County Biological Survey conducted a survey of numerous railroad rights-of-way which led to SNA designation for a number of important sites. But even as SNAs, these sites face unique challenges. Their narrow, linear nature puts them into close contact with surrounding land use. In an agricultural area, this can mean exposure of the native vegetation to the damaging impacts of herbicide drift. The high ratio of “edge” to interior of such sites also increases opportunity for spread of invasive and nonnative species into the natural area. Here, where a highway borders the SNA, the practice of roadside mowing unfortunately favors the dispersal of non-native species into the site.

Ongoing management efforts at Racine Prairie SNA include control of encroaching aspen, sumac and birds-foot trefoil.

Visitors can watch for the showy, tall (up to 6 feet!) spires of wild white indigo blooming here in June and July. Mid- to late-summer brings the distinctive rattlesnake master with is round, bristly flower heads and long, pointed leaves with spines along the margins. Later in the season, well into September, this little prairie offers opportunity to see blue bottle (closed) gentian, reliant on bumblebees to pry open its flowers for purposes of pollination, but also visited here by sphinx moths. Like the rest of us, they are drawn to what remains of southeastern Minnesota’s prairie.

Note to Visitors: Take care to avoid skin contact with poison ivy and wild parsnip, both of which are abundant here and can cause severe rash/burns. Learn to recognize these species prior to visiting.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

This site has abundant stands of poison ivy.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Washkish 13 miles N on MN Hwy 72. Park on pull-off near ditch crossing. Site is on E. Or trek 3.5 miles W into western portion of site. GPS recommended.

name: Red Lake Peatland SNA
description:
"When international peatland experts come to the U.S., it's Red Lake Peatland they want to see," says Norm Aeseng, retired peatland ecologist and botanist with the Minnesota Biological Survey. A National Natural Landmark, Red Lake Peatland is the largest and most diversely patterned boreal peatland in the country.

Roughly 50 miles long and 12 miles wide, the Red Lake Peatland formed in the flat, poorly drained lake plain once occupied by Glacial Lake Agassiz. It showcases a wide array of classic peatland landforms, including a large, highly developed water track, ribbed fen, tear-drop islands, circular islands, ovoid islands and raised bog.

Difficult to observe on foot but striking in aerial photos (see a few above), these patterns developed over thousands of years in response to the slow movement of the water and the varying levels of nutrients—such as magnesium and calcium—that it carries. Many of these features may be seen elsewhere in the state's peatland SNAs, but nowhere on such a grand scale as here.

This site is widely studied. Early studies used fossils and pollen from peat cores to reconstruct paleo-environments of 5000 years ago. Other research has focused on subjects ranging from methane production, to carbon sequestration, to sensitivity of peatlands to climate change. Paul Glaser, professor of Earth Sciences at the University of Minnesota is among the scientists from collaborating institutions from around country using data from the Red Lake Peatland Observatory, an integrated network of 15 instrument stations that continuously monitor changes in water, greenhouse gases, and heat.

Wildlife species documented here include the gray wolf, Short-eared Owl, Wilson's Phalarope, Yellow Rail and Greater Sandhill Crane. Rare plants include montane yellow-eyed grass, twig rush, bog rush, coastal sedge, and both linear-leaved and English sundew. The SNA is also within the Big Bog Important Bird Area, in which 289 species of birds have been documented.

Like most of the state's peatlands, Red Lake is not without its scars from ditching. Still, as co-authors Norm Aeseng and Bob Djupstrom write in the book, The Patterned Peatlands of Minnesota, it "offers the rare opportunity to preserve a functioning ecosystem intact."

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift in the memory of Maurice O'Link.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area, Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area and is recognized as a wetland of distinction. This site is within the Red Lake WMA and adjacent to Big Bog State Recreation Area and Pine Island State Forest.
county: Beltrami, Koochiching, and Lake of the Woods

parking.directions: From Becker 9.25 miles N on MN Hwy 25. Turn W at drive and park in pull-off on S at fork.

name: Rice Lake Savanna SNA
description:
Referred to as a "flat-land" savanna, this SNA is located in the Anoka Sand Plains of Sherburne County on outwash sands deposited by glacial meltwater.

This site was designated an SNA to protect a rare, 60-acre remnant of dry, bur-oak savanna, its understory dominated by native prairie grasses and forbs. Oak savanna has been called "the single most imperiled ecological system in Minnesota and globally rare" by Wayne Ostlie of Great River Greening, lead organization in the Anoka Sandplain Habitat Partnership, a public/private collaborative with 25 member organizations. Less than 1% (< 12 square miles) remains of this native plant community in the Anoka Sand Plain region. Even where it exists on public land, it is threatened by invasive species and encroachment of woody vegetation due to lack of fire. Fire is an important part of the natural disturbance regime in savannas, needed to keep woody vegetation in check and also to enhance native seed production.

Here at Rice Lake Savanna, management has focused on maintaining the open character of the savanna and oak woodland. Outdoor Heritage Funds have helped to support activities such as prescribed burns and removal of woody invasives, as well as restoration of old field and pine plantation to savanna using seed collected on site.

With initiatives like the Anoka Sand Plain Partnership, sites like this one—and the wildlife that depend on the state's dwindling savanna habitats—have a fighting chance. Restoration and enhancement work on public lands in this region benefits as many as 97 Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) identified in the Minnesota Wildlife Action Plan.

As visitors will discover, the SNA also features pockets of shallow wetlands, with a number of depressions occupied by sedge meadows. These small wetlands add diversity to the site and likely played a role in moderating historic fires, giving the oaks an opportunity to establish in the prairie.

From the pale pasque flowers of spring to the bright orange-golds of hoary puccoon and butterfly weed, to the last purple blazing stars and asters of autumn, the prairie understory here offers beauty for the eye and sustenance for pollinators. But in some respects a savanna comes into its own in winter months, when the leafless, twisted branches of bur and pin oak can be seen against the sky, their buds already set for the coming growing season.
notes:
This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

This site has abundant poison ivy.

parking.directions: From Rothsay 7 miles NW on Co Hwy 52, then 1.5 miles E on Co Rd 188. Park on field road on S, or road shoulder.

name: Richard M. and Mathilde Rice Elliot SNA
description:
This SNA protects a high quality remnant of native mesic prairie on the fringe of the Rothsay Prairie Complex, an important focus area of the Minnesota Prairie Conservation Plan.

Glacial Lake Agassiz—which was never deeper than 45 feet here—has long retreated from this landscape, but water is still a defining feature. In the interbeach habitat of this preserve, water discharges from the base of nearby Agassiz beach ridges and flows laterally across the shallow former lakebed. Wet prairie occupies roughly 100 acres of the nearly 500-acre site, with the remainder occupied by a prairie-wetland complex comprised of intermingled mesic prairie and sedge meadow. For these native plant communities, the site's poor drainage has been their salvation. While the site has historically been mowed, early attempts to plow the land met with failure and were soon abandoned, leaving a few scars but the native vegetation little disturbed.

Visitors will find a landscape of minimal relief, with a slight gain in elevation as one moves from west to east. On a smaller scale, an interesting element of "micro-topography" here is the occurrence of many scattered, shallow depressions across the site that range in size from 4 to 10 feet in diameter. Their origin remains something of a mystery, attributed variously to Dust Bowl-era blowouts and bison wallows.

The Nature Conservancy recognized the conservation value of this remnant native prairie in the early 1970s and acquired the tract. Soon after, it was designated an SNA. The opportunity to protect a high quality remnant of Minnesota's prairie ecosystem was of primary interest, along with protection of habitat for a diversity of grassland flora and fauna. In its preserve description, the Conservancy notes the occurrence here of numerous rare/state-listed species, including the northern gentian, Marbled Godwit, regal fritillary, prairie vole, and the Wilson's Phalarope. Like nearby Western Prairie SNA, it also offers critical habitat to the Greater Prairie-Chicken, an iconic grassland bird whose elaborate courtship rituals are a hallmark of spring in this former lakebed of Glacial Lake Agassiz.

Matt Mecklenburg is land steward for the Conservancy within the Agassiz Beach Ridges landscape, which encompasses 22 preserves, a number of which are designated SNAs. "We have a very healthy partnership with the SNA Program," he notes. Cooperative management here at Rice Elliot SNA focuses on periodic prescribed burns and control of the invasive, exotic reed canary grass, which could represent a threat to the native prairie species. In his role as land steward, Mecklenburg has witnessed this site through the seasons and through the years. He recollects seeing hundreds of prairie chickens one winter during a Rothsay Christmas Bird Count years ago, and this is where he saw his first prairie falcon in Minnesota, as it actively hunted over the prairie. "No doubt about it," he says, "every bit of remnant native prairie in this landscape is significant."

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Little Falls 7 miles N on MN Hwy 371, then 0.7 mile E on Co Hwy 48, then 1.4 miles N on Co Rd 282. Park in pull-off on E.

name: Ripley Esker SNA
description:
The word esker, as author Paul Gruchow noted in his book, Worlds within a World,* derives from the Irish word eiscir, for a narrow, winding ridge. Eskers are composed of stratified (layered) sand and gravel deposited by a meltwater streams tunneling through the ice at the base of a glacier or within ice-walled channels. Their serpentine shapes are left lying on the land, unmolded from their icy casts, as glaciers retreat.

This glacial landform takes center stage at this SNA, which protects a 3/4-mile long segment of the 6 3/4 mile-long Fort Ripley Esker. According to Barbara Lusardi, who mapped Morrison County for the Minnesota Geological Survey, this esker likely formed roughly 18,250 to 24,500 years before present. "It's comprised of sediment that appears to be of Superior provenance, given that it contains abundant fragments of red sandstone and red volcanic rocks transported from the Superior basin in the northeast. The esker's east/west orientation also parallels the westward-trending advance of the Superior lobe." That said, she conjectures, it may also have been influenced by the Brainerd lobe (of Rainy provenance, originating in the north/northeast) either concurrently or later, which was active in the region during this general period. "It's a complex region, and we're still mapping in this area, so our thoughts continue to evolve on the subject."

The Fort Ripley Esker is widely recognized as a "textbook" example of this glacial landform. Roughly 250' wide at the base and narrower on its rounded crest, it rises to a maximum of 60' above the surrounding plain of level to rolling glacial till.

Well-preserved eskers are rare in the state, given their appeal for gravel-mining operations. The designation of this site as an SNA for its scientific and educational value ensures that it will continue to be available for the public to enjoy. Generations of geology students from nearby schools and universities have utilized the SNA as a field study site.

Oak-aspen woodland is the dominant native plant community here, but there are stark differences in the structure of vegetation across the site, as Gruchow observed on an early spring visit. He writes: "When I stood atop the esker facing east and looked to my right, I saw a remnant bur oak savanna, a prairie landscape, and beyond it an old field reverting to prairie. And when I looked to my left across the few feet of open ridge top, I saw running down the north slope of the esker a mixed hardwood forest—bur and pin oaks, paper birches, quaking aspens—a northern landscape, and beyond it, a little ice-block pond, still frozen over, drifts of snow lingering among the cattails at its edge. The esker…functions like a mountain range, dividing the forest from the prairie with almost surgical precision. To walk the ridge is to wander simultaneously in two worlds."

In Minnesota, today's school children learn at an early age how the state's landscape was shaped by ice, but the theory of the Ice Age was controversial when Louis Agassiz first presented his theory of glaciation to the scientific community in 1837. Ripley Esker SNA exists as physical testament to that journey of inquiry, research and understanding, while preserving the opportunity for scientific advancements yet to come.

* Worlds within a World: Reflections on Visits to Minnesota Scientific and Natural Area Preserves ©1999, Minnesota Department of Natural Resources

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Cannon Valley Trail).

parking.directions: From Cannon Falls 4.5 miles E on MN Hwy 19, then 2.5 miles N and E on Sunset Trl. Park in pull-off on S.

name: River Terrace Prairie SNA
description:
Even viewed from a mile away, this prairie is a striking feature on the landscape. This site was protected as an SNA for its dry sand - gravel prairie (Southern subtype), which is ranked as an imperiled native plant community in the state. It occurs here on glacial outwash atop an isolated terrace of the Cannon River that rises sharply 30 feet above the surrounding lower terrace.

This is the sole remnant of appreciable size of this native plant community type documented by the Minnesota Biological Survey in Goodhue County. It is notable for supporting one of the largest known populations in the state of kitten-tails, listed as a threatened species in Minnesota. This population has been the subject of a University of Minnesota Landscape Arboretum initiative led by David Remucal, which works to preserve rare plants through development of long-term seed banks. A state-listed special concern species, the devil's tongue (Plains prickly pear) cacti, is documented here as well.

Such dry prairie terraces along the Cannon River are considered suitable habitat for a number of the state's seventeen snake species, including the bullsnake (Pituophis catenifer sayi) a subspecies of gopher snake.

Invasion by woody plants is among the chief threats to dry prairies, and management here has focused on cutting and prescribed burning to reduce eastern red cedar. There are also efforts underway to restore old field areas to native prairie vegetation.

Spring comes early to dry gravel prairies. Depending on the year, spectacular displays of pasque flowers may be seen here as early as April. Late spring to early summer, watch for bumblebees (maybe even the Federally endangered rusty patch bumblebee) on the showy large-flowered beard tongue. Mid-June through July, catch the yellow flowers of the Plains prickly pear cacti in bloom, or later in the season, the deep red fruits on the edges of its spine-covered pads. Any time of year the prairie grasses can be enjoyed both in the long view and up close, where the delicate structures of species such as side-oats grama express an intricate complexity of form almost too fine to be believed.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Dogs (only when used for hunting, must be under control).
Horseback riding (only on trails and open seasonally May 15- October 15, when conditions allow).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Redwood Falls 1.5 miles W on MN 19, then 7.9 mile N on Co Hwy 17 (Co Hwy 21 after crossing Minnesota River), then W 0.4 miles on Co Rd 15. Park at pull-off and walk SW into site.

name: River Warren Outcrops SNA
description:
Situated within a meander of the Minnesota River, this SNAs contains some of its oldest bedrock. Outcroppings of crystalline bedrock here are part of a complex of gneisses classified as Morton Gneiss, which date from approximately 3.6 billion to 3.04 billion years before present. Buried by glacial till and weathered bedrock, the bedrock was exposed by the torrents of glacial River Warren during the period when it served as a southern outlet for the waters of Glacial Lake Agassiz.

Here, the rosy-hued gneiss is encountered in flat expanses, boulders and knobs, covered to varying degrees in vegetation. Rock outcroppings support their own distinctive flora. On the lean side, bare rock hosts patches of lichen and moss. Where soil gathers in cracks or thin layers, one finds species such as rock spikemoss, devil's tongue (also called plains prickly pear) cacti, brittle cactus, small-flowered fameflower and rusty woodsia: all tolerant of drought and temperature extremes. Where the soil layer is a bit deeper over the bedrock, one can find dry prairie, with leadplant, alumroot, little bluestem and side-oats grama. "This is one of few places in the Minnesota Valley where we've found intact dry prairie on the margins of rock outcroppings," says Minnesota Biological Survey plant ecologist Fred Harris. "It's limited to the least disturbed sites."

Arriving at this SNA, a visitor may be surprised to find much of it forested, with scattered openings created by surface bedrock and ponds. Bur oak occupies the bedrock knobs, and a 22-acre area of floodplain forest along the river is dominated by silver maple, American elm and rock elm. One tree of particular interest here is the native but uncommon Kentucky coffee tree, with its deeply furrowed bark, fragrant, greenish-white flowers, 10" long reddish-brown seedpods and large (up to 3 foot) long leaves, divided into up to 100 leaflets. As Fred Harris points out, this species is the subject of some intriguing speculation by researchers, suggesting that its seeds are adapted to survive passage through the guts of a now extinct Pleistocene mega-fauna. If they are waiting for a passing hungry mammoth in order to reproduce, they may need to wait awhile longer.

Watch for a transformation of this site in the years ahead, with prairie restoration on the northern edge of the SNA and removal of woody vegetation—in particular, eastern red cedar and sumac— that has encroached upon the bedrock outcroppings.
notes:
Horse trails riders are encouraged to reduce the introduction of invasive species. For example grooming prior to entering the SNA. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

Rock climbing for sport, including bouldering, is not allowed on Scientific and Natural Areas.

parking.directions: From Jeffers 7 miles E on MN Hwy 30, then 3.25 miles N on Co Rd 2. Park on W road shoulder.

name: Rock Ridge Prairie SNA
description:
This SNA is part of the Red Rock Ridge prairie landscape; a series of prairie preserves associated with a discontinuous, 23-mile long ridge of Sioux quartzite outcrops that include Jeffers Petroglyphs State Historic Site* and The Nature Conservancy's Red Rock Prairie Preserve.

As described in Minnesota's Geology, Sioux quartzite underlies much of southwestern Minnesota, extending westward as far as Mitchell, South Dakota.

The scientific literature is rich with studies of this region's bedrock, which has been used to inform understanding of continental growth and development. Geologist David L. Southwick relates that, as early as the mid-19th century, geologists and topographers recorded field observations of these exposures in expedition journals. Today's researchers are able to "see" below these outcroppings using aeromagnetic and gravity data gleaned from airplane flights over the region.

Many exposures of this 1.7–1.6 billion year-old Sioux quartzite have been lost to mining. Where it remains, it is often associated with remnant native prairies, since rocky sites were more likely to be spared the plow in this largely agricultural region.

According to Regional SNA Specialist Brad Bolduan, this site features a roughly 50-50 mix of remnant native prairie interspersed with restored prairie. "The last of it was seeded in 2017," he notes, using locally-sourced native seed. Native plant communities mapped by the Minnesota Biological Survey here include southern mesic prairie and crystalline bedrock outcrop prairie (Sioux quartz subtype) a native plant community ranked as imperiled in the state. Rare/listed plants found here include a population of prairie bush clover (threatened at both state and federal levels) and two Minnesota special concern species: buffalo grass and tumble grass. Both of these grasses are characteristic of dry prairies of the Great Plains. In Minnesota, they are found almost exclusively on outcroppings of Sioux quartzite.

The open landscape here with its expanses of low, short-grass vegetation and scattered rock outcrops makes this a good place to see grassland birds. Grassland birds sighted here in the past have included such species as Smith's Longspur, Sprague's Pipet and the rare Burrowing Owl, while breeding bird surveys have documented Bobolinks, Dickcissels, Grasshopper Sparrows, Western Meadowlarks and Savannah Sparrows.

If you visit, make a day of it and explore other, nearby preserves in the Red Rock Ridge landscape to get a sense of this region's unique character, where there is so much at your feet— pasque flowers, downy gentians, prairie smoke—all in the company of ancient rock.

*The Jeffers Petroglyphs Historic Site offers interesting background reading on Sioux quartzite, the Red Rock Ridge, and related regional geology: see "Geology of the Site" and "The Rock"
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.
