parking.directions: From Roscoe 2 miles W on Co Hwy 16, then 0.6 miles S on 273rd Ave. Park in pull-off on E.

name: Roscoe Prairie SNA
description:
Acquired by The Nature Conservancy in 1968 and designated an SNA in 1981, this Stearns County site hosts southern mesic prairie, dogwood shrub swamp and cattail marsh on level to gently rolling terrain. It occupies an outwash sand plain associated with the Des Moines lobe of the last glaciation, which descended from Canada roughly 16,000 years before present. As the ice sheet retreated, meltwater deposited the sediments and grey drift that form the plain. Scattered large boulders—glacial erratics—date from this period as well, offering quiet testament to the power of ice.

Roughly 20 acres of southern mesic prairie is found here in a band across the southern, more upland, part of the site. It is a small but important example of one of Minnesota's rarest native plant communities, with a conservation status rank of S2, or imperiled.

One can't talk about Roscoe Prairie without talking about butterflies. It was local Roscoe resident Jim Muggli who alerted scientists to the native prairie here, and who is credited with the state's first record of the Dakota skipper, which was discovered at this site. Surveys in 1976/77 documented 37 species of butterflies*, including many so-called prairie obligate species, which cannot persist outside of their native prairie environment. "Indeed," says Minnesota Biological Survey ecologist Robert Dana, who participated in the early surveys, "Roscoe Prairie used to be home to nearly all of Minnesota's prairie obligate butterflies—Dakota skipper, Poweshiek skipperling, dusted skipper, arogos skipper, gorgone checkerspot, regal fritillary."

Unfortunately, this is one of many prairie remnants across the state from which these species have quietly disappeared in recent decades, their populations experiencing steep declines for reasons not fully understood. Regal fritillaries are faring somewhat better than the others, notes Dana, likely because they are more wide-ranging and able to take advantage of scattered patches of prairie, unlike more localized species.

The Conservancy's Roscoe Prairie Preserve remains an important harbor for biological diversity, where visitors throughout the growing season can experience the prairie's transformation from the first pasque flowers and prairie smoke of spring to the last asters and goldenrods of autumn. One might spot a boldly patterned "regal," witness the courtship flights of Marbled Godwits, or find a small white lady's-slipper finally coming into bloom after its long (12-year) period of maturation. Keep an eye on the purple coneflower for a chance appearance of the inconspicuous, moth-like Dakota skipper, easily missed.

In the years ahead, we can all watch with interest the outcome of a recent reintroduction effort in southeastern Minnesota, in which The Nature Conservancy and the Minnesota Zoo have released Dakota skippers reared in captivity. It's all the more reason to protect suitable habitat within SNAs and other prairie preserves throughout the state.

*Refers to insects within the order Lepidoptera. Skippers are often seen as more similar to moths than to butterflies, but scientists group them with the Lepidoptera families that are regarded by all as butterflies.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: An undeveloped portion of the Glacial Lakes State Trail is adjacent to site.

parking.directions: From I-35 (Rush City Exit) 4 miles on W Co Hwy 1. Park in water access on W.  Site is 3.25 miles SW in Rush Lake. Accessible by boat. Restricted entry, see details above.

From I-35 (Rush City Exit) 5.3 miles W on Co Hwy 1, then 2.3 miles W on Co Hwy 2, then 1.5 miles S on Co Rd 4, then 0.2 mile E on 515th St. Park in water access at dead end. Site is 1.5 miles S in Rush Lake.  Accessible by boat. Restricted entry.

name: Rush Lake Island SNA
description:
In 1974, this small island in Chisago County's Rush Lake became the state's first Scientific and Natural Area.

The island was then one of the largest colonial bird nest sites in the state, and seasonal host to over 500 active Great Blue Heron nests, along with lesser numbers of Great Egrets. This colony had its beginnings in the 1930s, when 25-50 pairs of 'great blues' reportedly nested on the island. In later years, surveys also documented Black-crowned Night Herons.

This site is well known to lakeshore residents and locals, who know the island as 'Crane Island' or simply 'Bird Island'. Unfortunately, the colony has experienced a steady decline: the number of nests dropping to an estimated 175 in 2004, to as little as dozen by 2013.

The reasons for decline in colonial nesting populations and/or abandonment of nest sites are not always clear. Here, one might point to the loss of American elms—the original favored nest trees—due to Dutch Elm disease, and the loss of other suitable nest trees due to the herons themselves.* Great Blue Heron colonies are known to be very hard on trees and understory vegetation, given the acidity and abundance of their guano. In that respect, they can make their own breeding sites uninhabitable. Changing water level (in particular, flooding) and shoreline erosion have been known to impact other colonial nest sites in the state. Disturbance—by people or predators—can also be a factor. The decline here is likely due to a combination of causes.

With time, the colony may rebound. In any case, the Rush Lake Island SNA continues to serve an important conservation purpose, with its diversity of native plants, wildlife habitat and undeveloped shoreline. Please note the island is a sanctuary during the breeding season (April 1 to July 15) and is not open to visit.

* Great Blue Herons commonly use both live and standing dead trees for nesting, so the greatest impact on the colony occurs when the canopy trees eventually fall. A 1980 resource inventory of the island found that standing dead trees made up nearly 30% of the nest trees actively in use.
notes: Sanctuary (closed April 1 - July 15). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Rushford 3 miles W on MN Hwy 16. Park in pull-off on S. Hike S, E, then S along fenced corridor to site.

name: Rushford Sand Barrens SNA
description:
Embedded within the Richard J. Dorer Memorial Hardwood State Forest, this site showcases the dramatic topography and remarkable biodiversity of the Minnesota Bluffland's subsection.

Missed by the most recent glacial episode, this eastern part of Filmore County "may have been free of ice for more than a million years" writes Howard Hobbs of the Minnesota Geological Survey. Still, that's not to say that the Wisconsin glaciation (which ended roughly 11,700 years ago) didn't leave its mark. Climb up the 300' bluff and you'll encounter a prominent terrace roughly 50 meters (164 feet) above the valley floor. Such terrace features, as well as the sandy outwash in the valley bottoms here, were formed by material carried in (and eroded by) glacial meltwater roughly 14,000 years ago. Winds of the late Wisconsin period carried silt that tops the uplands in the SNA's southern corner, and bitter cold brought permafrost that accelerated erosion, breaking up exposed bedrock to create the loose rubble known as "colluvium" perched on valley walls and accumulated at the foot of cliffs.

Bedrock is never far from the surface: primarily Cambrian age (about 500 million year-old) sandstone, siltstone and shale, capped by the harder Oneota dolostone. Generally speaking, the drier, more exposed, south-facing slopes within the SNA host bluff prairie, dry barrens prairie and black oak barrens savanna, along with areas of fire-dependent oak woodland. The more sheltered, mesic, north- and east-facing slopes support denser forest, with maples and basswoods joining oaks in the canopy.

Among the rare plant species here are the rough-seeded fameflower, clasping milkweed and seaside three-awn. The SNA also hosts a robust population of Canada forked chickweed, a species at the northwest corner of its range here and strongly tied to the barrens. The dry barrens prairie (22 acres) and dry barrens oak savanna (11 acres) are ranked respectively as imperiled and critically imperiled native plant communities, considered at risk of elimination in the state.

While "barrens" conjures images of a bleak landscape, DNR botanist Mike Lee reminds us that the native plants found in the dry barrens communities are well adapted to the low-nutrient, droughty soil conditions. "Rather than bleak, says Lee, "I'd say you get a sense of openness from the scattered black oak interspersed with sunny prairie patches." Fire is an essential element here, without which the barrens prairie and savanna quickly become overgrown. "Prior to the 1960s, it was a common practice for landowners to periodically burn their bluffs," notes Lee, who grew up in the area. "But you can see on aerial photos taken through time how many of these areas became woodlands with the onset of fire suppression. If you see a savanna of this quality today, it's a sign that someone is caring for the land, providing the fire that the ecosystem needs to function."

This SNA is part of a larger complex of lands with high biodiversity significance that have been the focus of public and private conservation efforts in this immediate area.

Spring through fall, raptors ride the thermals in the skies above and an occasional six-lined racerunner zips across the sand below. Every few weeks the color palette changes in the prairie wildflowers and grasses. In the woodlands, after the first flush of spring ephemerals, the leaves of the canopy drop the forest into shade and the understory grows tangled and thick, nearly impenetrable. Rain, when it comes, brings intermittent streams alive at the base of the slopes, etching the valleys just a little deeper as they flow toward the Root River.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Isabella 13.8 miles W on MN Hwy 1, then 6.8 miles S on Co Hwy 2, then 0.5 mile W on Sand Lake Rd. Park in water access at dead end. Site is 0.9 mile W across Sand Lake. Accessible by boat. Then trek 0.25 mile W into site. GPS recommended.

name: Sand Lake Peatland SNA
description:
One word: "Outstanding." That's the statewide biodiversity ranking for the Headwaters Site, a 38,713-acre area of public and private lands in northeastern Minnesota that includes the Sand Lake Peatland SNA. Four rivers emanate from this remote, relatively undisturbed landscape, including the St. Louis River, a major tributary to Lake Superior.

Sand Lake Peatland SNA contributes to the diversity of the Headwaters Site with 36 native plant communities. Northern spruce bog and poor fen dominate overall, with good representation of northern rich fen and rich tamarack swamp in association with water tracks.

Unlike peatlands to the north and west that occupy the abandoned lakebed of Glacial Lake Agassiz, the raised bog, ribbed fen and water track features here formed in an outwash plain. Snaking eskers (ridges) and mineral islands add relief to the landscape. A number of lakes—Bonga, Lobo, Cougar—lie all or partly within the boundaries of the SNA.

State-listed special concern plants here include English sundew, bog rush, small green wood orchid, and sooty-colored beak-rush. The SNA and larger Headwaters Site landscape also offer habitat for the gray wolf, moose, Great Grey Owls, and Boreal Owls. This is one of few known locations in Minnesota for the taiga alpine butterfly (Minnesota special concern). This species is at the extreme southern edge of its range here and considered vulnerable to a warming climate.

In a story for the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer Magazine,* Gustave Axelson recounts a 2009 trip to the "inhospitable" Sand Lake Peatland with plant ecologist Bruce Carlson. The morning after a day-long, wet-footed slog through hazel brush and alder, the two finally made their way onto the raised surface of a bog. Axelson describes the sphagnum moss as "the connective tissue holding this bog mat together," and explains how it captures and stores carbon that could otherwise contribute to climate change. "Carbon," he writes, "is continually fixed by the mosses and vascular plants and trees in sphagnum bogs. When those plants die, their sequestered carbon remains stored for hundreds of years in the bog because the cold, wet conditions inhibit decomposition."

His words take on special meaning here, with the taiga alpine butterfly literally waiting in the wings.

* See July/Aug 2009, "Into the Inhospitable Peatland, Gustave Axelson.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is within Finland State Forest.

parking.directions: From Twin Valley, 6.5 mi W on Co Rd 27, then 1.5 mile S on 310th St. Park on pull-off on E.

name: Sandpiper Prairie SNA
description:
"It's a stunning place," says Regional SNA Specialist Shelley Hedtke of Sandpiper Prairie SNA. "You can stand on a beach ridge, look to the west, and see all the subtle gradations of prairie laid out on the landscape."

The series of low beach ridges crossing this site were formed by Glacial Lake Agassiz at different stages of the lake's elevation over time. They rise above the surrounding level lake plain here with a gradual slope of just fifteen feet over half a mile. It's not a lot of gain in elevation, but the varied soil and moisture conditions are expressed in a remarkable diversity of plant communities.

Northern wet and mesic prairie predominate, but the Minnesota Biological Survey has documented a total of ten native plant communities here, five of which are ranked as either critically imperiled or imperiled in the state.

There are overlaps in species between these plant communities, but it is interesting to note the shifts in dominance. In the well-drained, sandy-gravelly soils of the beach ridges find little bluestem, side-oats grama, porcupine grass, and such forbs (blooming flowers) as golden puccoon and blanketflower. At mid-slope with more loamy, mesic (moderately wet) soils find leadplant (a small shrub), grasses big bluestem, Indian grass and prairie dropseed, and forbs purple prairie clover and smooth aster. Lower still, wet prairie features cordgrass and a variety of sedges, as well as Canada goldenrod, Maximillian's sunflower and Virginia mountain mint. Interspersed in the wet prairie are small areas of salt flats hosting saline prairie, with species such as bunch speargrass and alkali cordgrass.

In addition to its namesake the upland sandpiper, this SNA provides important habitat for many of Minnesota's increasingly rare grassland birds. Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) found here include the Wilson's Phalarope, Nelson's Sparrow, Greater Prairie Chicken and Marbled Godwit; as well as Grasshopper Sparrow, Sedge Wren, Dickcissel and Bobolink.

A number of active Prairie Chicken booming grounds, or "leks," are found within and in the near vicinity of the SNA. John Toepfer, leading researcher and authority on the species, points to the value of undisturbed native grass cover for the birds throughout the year. "You can't just focus on the nesting season, you need to look at where they will feed and rest in spring, summer, fall, winter." The birds also benefit from periodic patchy prescribed burns (fall burns are preferred, in Toepfer's view), as well as the large block of suitable habitat that extends beyond the SNA on adjacent lands enrolled in the Wetland Reserve Program and land owned by the Norman County/Ada-Twin Valley airport.

Current management efforts here are focused on a 40-acre prairie restoration and control of invasive birdsfoot trefoil.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Mahnomen 5 miles N on US Hwy 59, then 2.5 miles E on Twp Rd 184. Continue E on unimproved/field road 1 mile. Park and hike E into site.

name: Santee Prairie SNA
description:
Santee Prairie SNA hosts a mix of mostly wetland community types on level terrain. Its 449 acres are roughly one-third mesic prairie (concentrated on the slightly higher, southern part of the site) with the remainder composed of cattail marsh, wet prairie, a prairie wetland complex and willow-dogwood shrub swamp.

Rare species documented here include the Wilson's Phalarope, Hall's sedge, small white lady's-slipper, and Greater Prairie Chicken.

This is one of 40 high-quality, native prairie sites selected in 2008 to be the subject of a long-term prairie monitoring project under the Minnesota Wildlife Action Plan. While most sites are monitored once every 6 years, four sites (one of which is Santee Prairie SNA) are monitored annually. Surveyors conduct "point counts" of birds (watching and listening from set locations) and record native plant species along transects 25 meters long and 10 cm wide.

"It's a combination of research and management," says DNR Nongame Specialist Mike Worland. "We're asking: 'How can we optimally manage these sites and surrounding landscapes to improve native plant diversity and reverse the steep declines we're seeing in grassland bird populations?' We don't want prairies that resemble big gardens; we want functioning prairies that sustain diverse plant and wildlife communities through time." A roadmap for developing functioning prairie systems in Minnesota can be found in the Minnesota Prairie Conservation Plan

According to Worland, in the initial years of monitoring (2008-2016), native plant diversity in studied remnant prairies has generally been at least stable and in some areas has increased. During the same period, grassland bird diversity in the studied remnant prairies declined by 3 percent per year, with populations of some species (such as Sedge Wren, Upland Sandpiper, and Ring-necked Pheasant) declining by around 5 percent per year.

"Our data to date show that land use surrounding remnant prairies affects grassland bird populations," says Worland. "Diversity of grassland birds and densities of some species (such as Upland Sandpiper, Western Meadowlark, Grasshopper Sparrow) are lower in small, isolated sites than in larger sites embedded in grassland landscapes." In this respect, Santee Prairie SNA benefits from the natural vegetation of the neighboring Wambach Wildlife Management Area. Still, there is more to learn about what makes these places "tick" for grassland birds if they are to have a secure future here.

Worland and fellow Nongame Specialist Christine Herwig conduct their bird surveys at sunrise to catch the morning chorus, but visitors can be immersed in the rich diversity of Santee any time of day from spring through fall. Walk under an open sky among blooming Indian paintbrush, bottle gentian, hoary puccoon, blazing stars and asters. Listen for the sounds of Sandhill Cranes. Wonder at the known and unknown relationships that make a prairie a prairie.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. Wambach WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: In Savage 0.5 mile S on MN Hwy 13, then 0.25 mile E on 128th St. Park on S side near dead end.
In Savage off MN Hwy 13, 0.35 mile S, E, then S on Xenwood Ave. Park on W road shoulder.

name: Savage Fen SNA
description:
The outstanding significance of the natural features protected here have long been recognized. As early as 1926, the Naturalist's Guide to the Americas called for preservation of this site.

The effort to protect this site as a Scientific and Natural Area has spanned more than two decades. In 1989, the first 42.5-acre parcel was acquired for designation as an SNA. In 2009, the Trust for Public Land partnered with conservation-minded private landowner Karl Bohn to add his adjacent 68+-acres to the SNA. Most recently (in 2013) an exciting land exchange with the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service added over 188 acres to the SNA.

Located between Minnesota Highway 13 and the Minnesota River in Scott County, this SNA protects one of the rarest native plant communities in Minnesota. This site hosts 55 acres of the southeastern subtype of calcareous fen (known as a Prairie Extremely Rich Fen) which is ranked S1, or "critically imperiled" in the state.

Calcareous fens are described in the DNR's profile of this community as "distinctive wetlands characterized by a substrate of non-acidic peat and dependent on a constant supply of cold, oxygen-poor groundwater rich in calcium and magnesium bicarbonates." This native plant community exists here because of a series of alkaline seeps and springs that emerge at the base of a bluff formed of calcareous glacial deposits, associated with the Des Moines lobe of the most recent glaciation.

Not all plants can thrive or even survive in these conditions. Those that do tend to be as rare as fens themselves. Among the many rare species found here are five plant species listed as threatened in Minnesota, including sterile sedge (which is found almost exclusively in fens), whorled nutrush, valerian, hair-like beak rush and beaked spikerush

Their reliance on groundwater makes calcareous fens vulnerable to surrounding land uses that alter hydrology, so long-term protection of this site will rely on "fen-friendly" practices in the surrounding area.

The calcareous fen exists here in a diverse complex of native plant communities including seepage meadow, mesic prairie, and southern mesic hardwood forests dominated by sugar maple, basswood, elm, black ash. These provide habitat for at least 18 Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) identified under Minnesota's Wildlife Action Plan.

Ownership & Origins: The Nature Conservancy and the Trust for Public Land assisted in the protection of this site. A portion of this site was a gift from a private landowner. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Please do not park along Dakota Avenue (Co Hwy 27).

parking.directions: From Brooton 3 miles N on Co Rd 18, then 0.75 mile E on Co Rd 27. Park in pull-off on N.

name: Sedan Brook Prairie SNA
description:
This SNA contains a high quality remnant of native prairie and wetland along a roughly 1-mile stretch of Sedan Brook in the farm country near Brooten. Minnesota Biological Survey plant ecologist Mike Lee describes it as "the best example of mesic prairie in Stearns County and one of few remnants larger than 10 acres in this part of the state."

The prairie here occurs on approximately 60 acres of level to very gradually sloping terrain. About half of this is true, mesic blacksoil prairie, with a water table 1-3 feet below the surface. Big bluestem is the dominant grass, and a diversity of forbs (flowering plants) include gayfeather, meadow golden-alexanders, death camas and wood lily. Between this mesic prairie and the stream, the plant community transitions first to wet-mesic prairie—where prairie cordgrass becomes co-dominant with the big bluestem—then to wet meadow and willow swamp.

"Much of this site is influenced by groundwater seepage," says Lee. The rich fen community has developed along a roughly 8-acre band where this seepage is most pronounced. It features a sedge mat dominated by tussock sedge, along with shrubs such as bog birch and sage-leaved willow.

Sedan Brook's winding passage through the SNA adds to the diversity of habitats, making this an interesting (albeit wet) site to visit. State-listed special concern species documented here include the small white lady's-slipper and regal fritillary butterfly. Visitors may also be fortunate enough to see and hear many Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) identified under the state's Wildlife Action plan, including Upland Sandpiper, Marsh Wren, Northern Harrier and Bobolink. The last of these—the Bobolink—offers a good introduction to Minnesota's terrific Breeding Bird Atlas. While relatively abundant in Minnesota, the species ranks within the "high" zone on the Continental Concern Score provided in the Atlas; a good reminder that conservation efforts here in Minnesota have implications beyond our borders.

Fortunately, the multiple landowners whose former properties make up this SNA were willing sellers, interested in working with the state. Looking ahead, management will reintroduce fire to the remnant native prairie and wet meadow with prescribed burns, and also restoring former agricultural fields to native prairie vegetation using seed sourced on site.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift in memory of Sarah Vest. A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail Minnesota River Bluffs LRT Regional Trail.
All hunting allowed (only by archery), see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From downtown Chaska 2 miles E on Chaska Blvd (becomes Flying Cloud Dr). Park in lot on N.

name: Seminary Fen SNA
description:
This SNA protects one of the state's finest examples of calcareous seepage fen, a nationally rare wetland type associated with emergence of cold, mineral-rich groundwater. Seven state-listed rare plants have been documented in this fen, five of which are ranked as threatened: sterile sedge, beaked spikerush, whorled nutrush, hair-like beak rush and valerian.

The 73-acre SNA lies within a larger complex of wetlands on this north side of the Minnesota River Valley. An ecological evaluation by the Minnesota Biological Survey describes the setting: "These wetlands occur primarily on a deep shelf of peat located at the foot of the steep valley side slopes. Soil cores have identified areas where the peat is at least 10 feet deep, indicating that peat has been accumulating in this site for over 8000 years." Assumption Creek, one of only a few cold-water trout streams remaining in the Twin Cities metro area, flows through the site, gaining flow from groundwater.

This site combines outstanding biodiversity significance with extreme sensitivity: never an easy alliance. The future of its rare features relies on local decisions in the urbanizing area beyond the boundary of the SNA. Both the fen and trout stream will benefit from efforts to maintain groundwater flow and to minimize paved (impervious) surfaces in the watershed, which accelerate run-off of warmed, contaminated storm water. There is much to gain by such efforts. More than 8,000 years in the making, Seminary Fen's wetland complex uniquely reflects the environmental health of the community. Fens offer natural flood control, filter pollutants, contribute to the flow of area surface waters, store carbon, and provide habitat for native species that are rare or nonexistent outside of calcareous fens.

This SNA also reminds us, should we need to be reminded, of the beauty of the natural world. Listen here for the song of the lark sparrow. Watch for the small white lady's slipper in late spring, or the shimmer of a trout in the cool waters of Assumption Creek.

Calcareous fens are afforded specified legal protections under the state's Wetland Conservation Act.
notes: Raguet WMA is adjacent to site. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Leroy 4.5 miles NW on MN Hwy 56. Turn W at 130th St and park on N road shoulder.

name: Shooting Star Prairie SNA
description:
This small but diverse mesic tallgrass prairie remnant, roughly two-thirds of a mile long, survives on a stretch of abandoned Milwaukee Railroad right-of-way adjacent to State Highway 56. As the growing season unfolds, one can see blooming wild bergamot, tall meadow rue, whorled milkweed, rattlesnake master and white wild indigo, the last two of which are state-listed special concern species. Blazing stars and asters bloom well into fall, when big bluestem grasses nods heavy with seed and monarchs work their way south.

The SNA is named for prairie shooting star (Dodecatheon meadia), a native plant species first discovered in Minnesota in 1980 and state-listed as endangered in the 1996. Similar in appearance to the more common jeweled shooting star (Dodecatheon amethystinum) it is characteristic of prairie remnants to the south and east of Minnesota (for example, at The Prairie Enthusiasts Swenson Bluff/Shooting Star Prairie, west of Madison, WI). But there are only two records for native populations of the species in the Natural Heritage Information System database, both in Mower County. Seed collected and propagated from these small native populations has been used in plantings at Lake Louise State Park, where it may be seen blooming in May. It is not known to occur on the SNA, historically or currently.

The shooting star has become symbolic of a larger effort to preserve this region's prairie heritage. Many partners have come together to celebrate, protect and restore native plants in this part of southeastern Minnesota in conjunction with the legislatively authorized Shooting Star State Trail and adjacent Shooting Star Scenic Byway.

Railway rights-of-way have emerged as important sites for conservation, in many cases preserving the last remnants of native prairie in an otherwise developed landscape. To persist, sites like Shooting Star Prairie SNA require active management. Limiting pesticide and herbicide drift from adjacent agricultural fields, prescribed burns, and thoughtful approaches to recreational use are all part of the mix. (Note, for example, that the route of the Shooting Star State Trail goes around the SNA.)

According to SNA Region 4 Specialist Brad Bolduan, the portion of the SNA between the railroad bed and the highway contains a very diverse mesic prairie. This fortunately extends well into the highway right-of-way, where the Department of Transportation has agreed to manage the land for its prairie values. “Efforts are underway to restore the entire SNA to diverse prairie,” Bolduan notes. This will require control of native woody species in the portion of the SNA between the railroad bed and crop fields to the south, and addressing the ongoing threat of invasive species such as non-native honeysuckle, garlic mustard, Dame's rocket and bird's-foot trefoil.

Native pollinators stand to benefit from these efforts. We will soon have a much better picture of the status of wild bee populations here and across the state, thanks to surveys underway by the Minnesota Biological Survey. According to MBS bee survey specialist Nicole Gerjets, in 2017 researchers documented 17 species of wild bees in the vicinity of the SNA, among them the yellow bumble bee, bicolored striped sweat bee, and two-spotted long-horned bee.

If visiting the SNA as a side-trip along the route of the Shooting Star State Trail, please note that the SNA has no trails and is open to foot traffic only. Please take care not to accidentally introduce seeds to the site on clothing and footwear.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Big Falls 9 miles W on Co Hwy 30, then 9.25 miles NW on Toumey Forest Rd, then 4 miles N and then NE on Manilla Summer Forest Rd. Park and trek 2.75 miles N into site. GPS recommended.

name: South Black River Peatland SNA
description:
South Black River Peatland contains a large, semi-circular raised bog with "a patterned fen that moves around the outskirts," notes peatland specialist Erika Rowe. Within the Agassiz Lowlands, this peatland stretches for miles. Among its rare features are linear-leaved and English sundews which occur in sunny, shallow pools of water tracks, dominated by low-growing sedges and mosses.

As retired Regional SNA Specialist Steve Wilson will attest, this site is largely inaccessible throughout the growing season. Wilson looks back on a memorable 15-mile round-trip trek into the site. He was well accustomed to backwoods travel, but with only a few miles of upland terrain, nearly all of the route involved the kind of high-stepping required to traverse a bog. "After about mile 12 I was on robo-pilot, and began to wonder whether I might be found by some 22nd-century archeologist." Emerging near dark, he was "never so happy to see a truck."

"That's unfair, of course," says Wilson, "because it was a very special day in a special place, and I was aware I was covering ground seldom, if ever, trod by humans in an unfrozen state. I recall the stunted spruce bog; and the realization that the spruce trees shorter than me could easily be 100+ years old. It was a good reminder about checking our often limited human perspective in favor of keeping an open mind to nature's reality. I also recall the dramatic transition from a featureless water track to a raised bog." A photo taken by Wilson that day conveys the remoteness of the site. The view looks out over the featureless water track, which slowly grades into a rich fen and then into a "formidably thick white cedar rich swamp."

At nearly 6000 acres, the sheer scale of the South Black River Peatland SNA is one of its key values. More than three decades after publication of the 1984 DNR report, Recommendations for the Protection of Ecologically Significant Peatlands in Minnesota, a passage in its introduction still holds true: "Too often the preservation of ecosystems, such as Minnesota's prairie or the "Big Woods," has been more difficult because development has proceeded to the point where only isolated remnants of former ecosystems remain intact." The statutory designation of peatland SNAs (including this one) in 1991 has helped to secure a different fate for this important feature of the state's natural heritage.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within Pine Island State Forest.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Roseau 9 miles N on MN Hwy 310. Park on pull-off on W near "Canadian Border" sign. Hike 0.6 mile W on snowmobile trail to site. GPS recommended for trekking off trail.

name: Sprague Creek Peatland SNA
description:
Sprague Creek Peatland is a place defined by both political and natural borders. The Canadian border is less than a mile to the north, beyond which peatland continues to be a major feature of the Manitoba landscape. To the west is a border between two of the state's ecological provinces, where the Laurentian Mixed Forest gives way to the Tallgrass Aspen Parkland.

Like nearby Pine Creek Peatland, Sprague Creek Peatland lies within the shallow lake plain once occupied by Glacial Lake Agassiz. It's one of the smallest of the peatland SNAs, but has the largest "Watershed Protection Area" relative to its size.

Since the ecologically significant features within peatlands are extremely sensitive to changes in water level and water chemistry, buffer zones called Water Protection Areas have been delineated around each of the state's peatland SNAs. The size and configuration of these areas varies from site to site, based on the hydrologic setting and factors such as orientation of water flow. Certain guidelines apply to development in these buffer zones: for example, mining is restricted, subject to conditions defined under state Administrative Rules. Sprague Creek Peatland SNA's Watershed Protection Area of 10,790 acres helps to maintain the ecological integrity of this important site.

This SNA harbors one of only five spring fens known in Minnesota. Upwellings of mineral-rich groundwater feed into a network of open (unforested) channels that branch, then rejoin, as they drain through an extensive swamp forest of black spruce, tamarack and white cedar.

State-listed plant species documented here include twig rush, northern oak fern, hair-like beak rush and the ram's head orchid.

On the wildlife front, this SNA is located in part of the Lost River State Forest that has been the focus of management for Great Grey Owl habitat. Great greys typically use nests built by other species in extensive stands of dense, 50-100+ year old tamarack or mixed tamarack/black spruce, and hunt in adjacent open, boggy areas. DNR Nongame Specialist Christine Herwig describes some of the key habitat features important to the great grey. "They need expanses of older, closed-canopy forest; large trees (especially snags, broken-topped and deformed trees) suitable for the ravens and hawks whose nests the great greys use; and clearings with irregular edges that provide hidden perch sites from which the owls can hunt."

Ideally, notes Herwig, these are features that can be retained, given the natural disturbance regime within the SNA and harvest management in the surrounding state forest. Other species associated with this habitat stand to benefit as well, including birds such as the Boreal Owl, Northern Hawk Owl, Sedge Wren, Cape May Warbler, LeConte's Sparrow and Spruce Grouse, and mammals such as the gray wolf, northern bog lemming, and Arctic shrew.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Hovland 2.4 miles N on Co Rd 16, then 1 mile W on Hovland Tower Rd, then 0.3 mile W (stay left) at Tom Lake Rd junction. Park at gate. Hike W to site.

name: Spring Beauty Northern Hardwoods SNA
description:
As locals know, for many years the landmark used to find this site was the Hovland Fire Lookout Tower*, an 80' ladder tower erected in 1931 and removed in summer of 2017. While the fire tower is gone, the old-growth northern hardwood forest thankfully persists.

Visit the SNA—or look at a topographic map—and it's immediately clear why this site was chosen for a fire tower. From a high plateau, the land falls away steeply on both sides, dropping more than 400 feet in elevation within the boundaries of the SNA. One can look north toward Moosehorn Lake or southeast toward Lake Superior over a densely forested landscape.

Conditions here along the north shore are well suited to northern hardwood forest, with a relatively humid, lake-moderated climate. This site was acquired for SNA designation to protect its rare, 115-acre stand of old-growth northern hardwoods dominated by sugar maple and upland white cedar forest. Aspen-birch forest occurs on site at comparatively lower elevations, and a small beaver complex is found at the northern edge of the SNA along the Flute Reed River. Two state-listed rare species of sweet cicely have been documented, including a small population of Chilean sweet cicely, (Osmorhiza berteroi) and its relative the blunt-fruited sweet cicely (Osmorhiza depauperata).

The "spring beauty" for which the SNA is named is the Carolina spring-beauty (Claytonia caroliniana), an ephemeral wildflower found in extreme northeastern MN. This species was once thought restricted in Minnesota to old-growth, northern hardwood forests along the north shore of Lake Superior, but is now understood to be both more common and more widely distributed among different forest types. Rare or not, it is a pleasure to encounter populations of this delicate, white-pink wildflower blooming here in spring, rising from the damp brown leaf litter on the forest floor.

This SNA is situated along the northerly edge of the 270,000-acre focus area of the North Shore Forest Collaborative (NSFC). Member groups and individuals are engaged in such activities as tree planting, fencing to protect from deer browsing, control of invasive plants, and educational forums for local communities. While not the focus of these restoration activities, SNAs play an important role in this effort, says NSFC Coordinator Duane Lula: "SNAs in the vicinity serve as reference points for undisturbed conditions, especially those containing old-growth, including the maple, yellow birch and conifers at Spring Beauty Northern Hardwoods SNA and the white pine and white spruce at nearby Hovland Woods SNA. These give an indication of not only canopy species that were here prior to early 20th century logging and subsequent fires, but also of the understory species and functioning of ecosystems."

It's an important role of SNAs that is sometimes overlooked: they provide a reference point for undisturbed conditions, setting an ecological standard useful in understanding and managing other lands. To fully appreciate the value of Spring Beauty Northern Hardwoods SNA, one has to look far beyond its boundaries.

* The fire tower, now gone, and a communications tower (still present) are located on state forest land between the two parcels of this SNA.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within Grand Portage State Forest.

parking.directions: In Red Wing off US Hwy 61 0.3 mile S on Tyler Rd, then 350 feet W on Koseck Dr, then 0.3 mile S on Old Tyler Rd, then 0.5 mile S on Red Fox Dr, then 0.2 mile W on Wild Turkey Ln. Continue on gravel access lane, past cul-de-sac. Park at wood-routed sign.

name: Spring Creek Prairie SNA
description:
Spring Creek Prairie SNA lies within the Blufflands subsection, an area characterized by steep bluffs, broad floodplains and deep valleys eroded by rivers and streams. In this heavily dissected part of the Paleozoic Plateau, topography is largely controlled by bedrock, capped with loess (wind-blown silt) and exposed in outcroppings on ridge tops and sheer cliff faces.

Ranked by the Minnesota County Biological Survey as having "outstanding biological diversity," this 146-acre site features broad, southwest-facing bluffs that rise to a narrow ridge top then slope down to the north. Two native plant communities predominate, with roughly 36 acres of dry, bedrock bluff prairie on the southwest-facing slopes and 65 acres of oak-shagbark hickory woodland on north-facing slopes.

The SNA is especially noteworthy for having one of the state's largest populations of bladderpod, a state-listed endangered plant recognized by its yellow flowers and narrow leaves, rising on slender stems from a central, basal rosette. Minnesota's few populations—all in Goodhue County —are considered outliers, since they are separated by over 300 miles from the species' main range in the dry prairies of the western United States. Within the SNA, it finds its preferred habitat in the sandy draws between bedrock outcroppings on southwest-facing bluffs.

Varying moisture levels in the soil are reflected here in the assembly of native grasses: little bluestem and side-oats grama on the bedrock bluff prairie; hairy grama and plains muhly on dry slopes and ledges; and in the moister areas, big bluestem, Indian grass, and prairie dropseed. Like the small burrowing mammals, skinks and snakes that also share this landscape, they find what they need here to sustain their existence.

Past grazing, cultivation of lowlands, and absence of fire have made their mark on the native plant communities here, with invasive species such as buckthorn in the oak woodland and encroachment of woody vegetation in prairie areas. Ongoing management works to address these issues with regular prescribed burns and removal of eastern red cedar.

Just as the heights of these bluffs were once literally islands in historically higher levels of the Mississippi River, they are now islands in a sea of agricultural fields and residential developments. So much has changed in this community of Red Wing since environmental writer/philosopher Henry David Thoreau visited the area in June of 1861, on what has been called "the last and longest journey of his life." But here at Spring Creek Prairie one can still find many of the same native prairie plants that Thoreau jotted down in his journal from his walk on nearby Barn Bluff: pale-spiked lobelia, zigzag spiderwort, porcupine grass, black-eyed susan, hoary puccoon. One day they may inspire the next young would-be naturalist/philosopher who will find their own Walden here in Minnesota: this one, not woods but prairie.

Information from Thoreau's journals provided by Chris Burawa of the Anderson Center, Red Wing.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Bayport about 0.5 mile S on MN Hwy 95. Park on W road shoulder near guard rail.
From Bayport, 0.7 mile W on Co Hwy 14, then 0.8 mile S on Co Hwy 21, then 0.25 mile E on Inspiration Pkwy, then 0.25 mile SE on Prairie Way, then about 0.15 mile E and S to dead end. Park at gate.

name: St. Croix Savanna SNA
description:
Look south and east from the top of the bluff here, and see the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway, bound for the Mississippi. Look west, and the land drops 130 feet to the floor of an inland valley, at its base the bed of an intermittent stream.

This SNA with its dramatic topography site protects one of the best remaining examples of hill prairie in the Lower St. Croix National Scenic Riverway. Dry gravel prairie blankets the slopes and crest of the bluff, transitioning to savanna with widely-spaced burr and pin oaks on the flat terrace, then to oak woodland.

This is a very special place, in that kittentails and James' Polanisia (respectively threatened and endangered plants in Minnesota) have both been documented here. These species have extremely limited ranges in the state. They are largely restricted to river valley bluffs and terraces—in particular, sandy, gravelly soils of dry prairie and oak savanna—which are themselves rare.

The southern exposure makes this one of the best places to find the first pasque flowers blooming in early spring. Throughout the summer, find a changing array of prairie wildflowers. In late autumn, the golden native grasses on the slopes together with the wine-red oaks of the savanna are nothing short of spectacular. Find big and little bluestem, prairie dropseed, sideoats grama, prairie sandreed, porcupine grass and Junegrass. Later still, into November, watch for swans and eagles migrating down the river.

Watch for poison ivy in the savanna (which can make for a more memorable visit than you might wish) and please take care not to disturb the soil of the highly erodible slopes. Don't be surprised to see signs of tree removal here. Management focuses on maintaining openness, preventing the savanna and slopes from being overtaken by woody vegetation.

Note: A northern and southern access are available, the later requiring a somewhat steep climb up the face of the bluff. Parking at the northern access is recommended, since there is no dedicated parking at the southern access along busy Highway 95.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from Anne McManus and the estate of Hattie Miller.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From St. Joseph 4.3 mile NE on Co Hwy 2, then 3.2 miles W then N on Co Rd 4. Park in pull off on S. Hike SE into site.

name: St. Wendel Tamarack Bog  SNA
description:
Surrounded by cropland, this site is a harbor of biodiversity which—despite its name—is technically not a bog. A plant ecologist would define the dominant plant community here as tamarack swamp (80%), along with smaller areas of black ash (red maple) seepage swamp, willow-dogwood shrub swamp and sedge meadow.

This 650-acre SNA is roughly a quarter of the larger wetland complex that exists here. It is especially notable for its 10-acre calcareous fen, a globally rare plant community that relies on mineral-rich groundwater. This particular fen is unique in Central Minnesota, having more in common with so-called "spring fens" found in peatlands 150 miles or more to the north, with species such as twig rush, pitcher plant and Hudson's Bay bulrush. The plants are fed by nutrients carried in water that moves slowly, almost imperceptibly, in a sheet-like flow across the land.

Longtime MBS botanist Mike Lee has noted with concern some die-off of tamarack trees in recent decades. "When tamaracks go, light levels increase, water levels rise, you can see a transition to more alder, coarse sedges, horsetails. Once I would have found tens of thousands of showy lady's-slippers and other orchids here. More recently, I have found a few dozen. That could change for the better, but it's something to pay attention to, given the ecological significance of this site."

Visitors should expect an up-close-and-personal kind of experience. Hummocky terrain, boot-topping wetlands, the absence of trails and a shrub layer of willow and dogwood present challenges for hikers spring through fall. Winter offers easier going, but the growing season has its rewards. Glimpse Sedge Wrens, Willow and Alder Flycatchers, Nashville and Mourning Warblers, blooming orchids, and the starry flower heads of state-threatened sterile sedge. Watch for a brush-tipped emerald dragonfly, a species not recorded in Stearns County until it was discovered here in 2016.

There is much to appreciate here, even from the vantage of adjacent Stearns County roads. In autumn, enjoy long views over open sedge meadows, with the tamaracks turning to gold. And any time of year, one can be grateful for the swamp's function as a carbon sink, helping to mitigate the effects of global climate change. Really, it's just another kind of beauty.

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was acquired with funding provided by the Minnesota Environment and Natural Resources Trust Fund as recommended by the Legislative-Citizen Commission on Minnesota Resources (LCCMR).
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Little Marais 8 miles NE on MN Hwy 61. Park in lot on E. Hike trails E to site.

name: Sugarloaf Point SNA
description:
Step out of the woods to find this protected cove on Lake Superior's north shore, with its curve of cobble beach and forested point ending in a rocky prominence. Yet the quiet here is deceiving. This SNA reflects a dramatic history—geological, cultural, ecological—beginning over a billion years ago.

Dr. John Green, Professor Emeritus, UMD Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, has studied the site's deep history and championed its preservation as a site of great geologic significance. He notes:

The bedrock here is an excellent example of basalt lava flows from the Precambrian age, when the Midcontinent Rift almost split North America apart about 1.1 billion years ago. These lavas, which make up the most of the Minnesota shore, are known as the North Shore Volcanic Group. On the point, wave action on the tilted lavas has produced excellent exposures of the surface and internal lava features of each successive flow. Structures such as pipe amygdules (mineral fillings formed in gas tubes in the base of flows), and ropy-surfaced, thin-bedded pahoehoe flows (flows with smooth, flat or gently undulating surfaces) can be clearly seen. Although ancient, these features formed by fiery hot volcanic activity are very well preserved.

The multi-colored cobbles and pebbles on the beach represent a jumble of geologic eras and origins. Dark basalt and red rhyolite from the more local 1.1 billion-year-old lava flows are intermingled with even older rock that was carried here from the north and northeast in glacial ice during the Great Ice Age (Pleistocene Epoch), including whitish granite and gneiss about 2.7 billion years old from Canada.

Evolving in concert with the landforms and lake-influenced climate is a diverse botanical community, including 87 species of lichen documented on the point alone – and 102 moss taxa, including the first Cook County records of 16 bryophyte species. Also present are arctic/alpine disjunct species, Hudson Bay eyebright and a species of liverwort, Barbilophozia atlantica. Now separated from their primary range to the north, these plants are relics of the glacial era, persisting here because of the cool micro-climate and natural disturbance regime created by the lake.

Large, leaning cedars are anchored in the shallow soils of the point. This point was once an island, connected to the land over time when beach sediment accumulated to bridge the gap (a feature known as a "tombolo"). This created conditions for formation behind the beach of a peat-based wetland community rarely found on Superior's coasts.

The 10.3-acre SNA encompasses the shoreline and point, while the surrounding 24-acre Sugarloaf Cove Nature Center is owned by the nonprofit Sugarloaf: The Northshore Stewardship Association. The SNA benefits from the ongoing activities of the adjacent Sugarloaf Cove Nature Center, which include education, uplands restoration of white pine and cedar, monitoring and management assistance. An active bird-banding program here has contributed to the understanding of the North Shore as a critical habitat for migratory birds.

While adapted to extreme weather and storm waves, the plant communities on the cliff faces and rocky slopes of this site are vulnerable to foot traffic. Please step carefully and do not remove geological features.
notes: An interpretive trail passes through site, see detail map. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Sacred Heart 7 miles S on Co Rd 9, then 1.5 miles W on Twp Rd 1 (440th St). Park in pull-off on S.

name: Swedes Forest SNA
description:
Bedrock outcrops are a defining feature of this Minnesota River Valley SNA, which straddles the border between Yellow Medicine and Redwood Counties. Pink, medium-grained quartz known as Sacred Heart granite—roughly 2,650 million years old—lies at or near the surface across much of the site. The outcroppings create a unique environment for rare, state-listed species such as Wolf's spike-rush and water-hyssop, both associated with shallow pools in the rock where rainwater gathers, and the common five-lined skink, which hibernate in rock crevices.

Native vegetation on these bedrock outcroppings must be able to tolerate exposed, often droughty conditions and temperature extremes. Lichen colonizes the bare rock, while species such as brittle prickly pear cacti, rock spikemoss, and rusty woodsia survive in cracks and shallow soils along with scattered, open-grown bur oak. Lowland areas of the SNA are dotted by ponds and wetlands, including an area mapped by the Minnesota Biological Survey as prairie meadow/carr.

Writing in the Spring 2015 issue of SNA Nature Notes, Management Specialist Brad Bolduan describes the intensive effort to remove woody invasives—in particular, red cedar and buckthorn—to restore the open character of the site evident in historic aerial photos. Far from a “one and done,” the investment of time and resources in clearing will need to continue in the years ahead, with selective use of mechanical and chemical controls as well as prescribed burns.

In the meantime, there are abundant reminders of why it's all worthwhile. Lark sparrows and blue buntings have been seen in greater numbers since the removal of red cedars began, and a bioblitz held on the site in 2017 offered a glimpse of the site’s diversity, with twenty-four species of sedge identified in the SNA's small wetlands and four species of fish in the ponds and streams. Other surveyors have documented twenty-six species of spider, five species of reptile, and four species of bat. And now more open to view, the beautiful Sacred Heart Granite, some of the oldest rock in the Canadian Shield.

Mining is the top threat to bedrock outcroppings in the Minnesota River Valley. Recent years have brought greater public awareness of their value and vulnerability, along with conservation action. One 2009 initiative, for example, utilized funding approved by the Legislative Commission on Minnesota Resources to secure easements on private lands in an effort to protect some of “the best of the best” outcroppings in Chippewa, Lac qui Parle, Redwood, Renville and Yellow Medicine counties. But landowner interest outpaced funding, and important sites featuring this nonrenewable resource remain at risk.

Those who visit Swede’s Forest SNA will see for themselves the unique community of life supported by these rare exposures of ancient bedrock, protected here as part of state’s natural heritage.
notes:
A bioblitz on June 17, 2017 documented plants and animals found at Swedes Forest SNA; see the results!

This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is an Audubon Important Bird Area.

Rock climbing for sport, including bouldering, is not allowed on Scientific and Natural Areas. Bouldering promoted at Swedes Forest and Blue Devil Valley Scientific and Natural Areas on various websites and guidebooks is in violation of state law, please do not boulder at these sites.

parking.directions: From Morristown 0.75 mile W on MN Hwy 60, then 3.6 miles NW Co Rd 99, then 0.5 mile N on LeSueur Ave. Park in lot on E. Hike corridor 0.5 mile E, N, then E to site.

name: Townsend Woods SNA
description:
Townsend Woods was designated an SNA to preserve a high quality remnant of Big Woods sugar maple forest, a native plant community ranked as imperiled in Minnesota.

This small but important site is associated with the Emmons-Faribault moraine: an area of rolling topography formed beneath and at the margins of stagnant glacial ice. Irregular knobs and ridges, dotted by lakes and wetlands, offered a barrier to fire that allowed the forest to develop and persist here. Through the years, the old-growth stand within the SNA also managed to escape the impacts of gravel mining, clear-cut logging and conversion to cropland. Aside from small-scale maple sugaring and some selective cutting of elm, it is essentially undisturbed.

The forest has an open aspect, with young maples in the understory but few shrubs. Large red oak and sugar maple dominate in the canopy, joined by basswood, elm and ironwood. Hollows among the hills host a small pond as well as ephemeral pools found in spring and during periods of above average rainfall. A steep ridge with north/northeast-facing slopes bi-sects the site, below which a small creek runs through a cattail marsh.

Management here has included planting of oak seedlings—now well established—in clearings at the perimeter of the site and, more recently, some buckthorn control. The SNA benefits from two dedicated volunteer site stewards—Denise Friesen and Steve Gahm— who assist with these efforts and provide ongoing monitoring.

It's been about 20 years that we've been stewards here, says Friesen. Still, it's different every time. In spring, it comes alive with wildflowers: hepatica, bloodroot and wild ginger, the marsh marigolds by the pond. We've seen warblers moving through, heard frogs singing from the pools, and have sometimes seen Sandhill Cranes. This forest is continually renewing itself— you'll come upon a massive tree that has fallen and is slowly returning to the soil. Visiting this SNA over many years has allowed us to see a place mostly unchanged from its native state, to be where it is quiet except for the wind, animals and birdsong.

If you venture here, be aware that reaching the woods requires a half-mile long trek in from the parking lot, and the site has no maintained trails. It's really best for one or two people at a time says Friesen, who enjoy the opportunity to be still for long periods. When you're quiet, you'll hear and see more.

Ownership & Origins: The Nature Conservancy assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Stacy 3.75 miles N on I-35, then 2.75 miles W on Co Rd 17 (becomes Co Rd 9). Park on N road shoulder.

name: Twin Lakes SNA
description:
Despite its name, the 48 acres of this SNA wrap around a bay of Horseshoe Lake, protecting an estimated 1,550 feet of shoreline. The origin of the name is the site’s association with a larger, 3400-acre complex of outstanding biodiversity significance documented by the Minnesota Biological Survey in the Anoka Sand Plain of Isanti County, which includes nearby Twin Lakes to the southwest. In the words of plant ecologist Barbara Delaney, this complex of upland and wetland areas—mostly in private ownership—has “quietly escaped serious disturbance.” It was exciting when the SNA Program had the opportunity to protect a site within this ecologically important area.

The SNA is an upland site, dominated by white pine-hardwood forest on nearly level terrain. A supercanopy of mature white pine rise above the closed canopy of red oak, aspen, red maple and birch. The understory across much of the SNA is very open, with relatively few invasive species in evidence. In spring, with the wind in the tall pines, the deep layer of pine duff on the forest floor, blooming starflowers and blueberries, trailing colonies of delicate clubmosses, even the distant call of a loon, it calls to mind the forests of the north. A student of native ferns could compare and contrast at least six species here, including lady, wood, sensitive, interrupted, cinnamon and royal ferns.

Come up quietly upon the lake's shore, and a visitor might be lucky to spot an otter, blue-winged teal, or a pair of tundra swans. In spring, Northern blue flag irises bloom at the water's edge in a narrow band of wet meadow/emergent marsh. Clubtail and Skimmer dragonflies make their exodus from the lake as wingless nymphs and undergo metamorphosis to adults, leaving their empty exoskeletons behind on near-shore vegetation and animating the forest with their darting flights.

White pine-hardwood forest was uncommon in the Anoka Sand Plain even at the time of the Public Land Survey in 1890. Today, it provides important habitat for state-listed species such as the red-shouldered hawk (special concern) and Blanding's turtle (threatened).

Management here is focused on restoration of old field to dry prairie along the SNA's eastern boundary, and control of buckthorn on the west.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Twin Valley 5 miles S on MN Hwy 32, then 4.5 miles W on Co Hwy 39, then 0.5 mile N on Co Rd 28. Park in pull-off on E.

name: Twin Valley Prairie SNA
description:
This 250-acre SNA is owned by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) and is part of a larger, 741-acre Twin Valley Preserve. As described by TNC, the Twin Valley Prairie SNA contains a prominent beach ridge of Glacial Lake Agassiz that supports plant communities ranging from wet to mesic to dry prairie. Sedge meadow and marsh communities occupy the poorly drained swales alongside the beach ridge.

The site was acquired by TNC and later designated an SNA because of its high-quality prairie and location within a larger complex of private and state-owned land that forms a major hotspot for biodiversity within the Agassiz Beach Ridges landscape. Here in the eastern third of Norman County, this beach ridge complex runs north/south. While a subtle feature on the landscape, these former shorelines of Glacial Lake Agassiz are associated with a remarkable number of the state's rare plant and animal species. They included, but are not limited to Wilson's Phalarope, Greater Prairie Chicken, regal fritillary, Marbled Godwit, blanketflower and small white lady's-slipper. The Dakota skipper butterfly, (listed as threatened on a federal level and endangered in Minnesota), has also historically been documented here, but populations of this prairie-dependent species have sadly plummeted in recent years.

Sometimes lost in the spectacle of species like the prairie chicken with its dramatic spring courtship displays and the Sandhill Cranes that stage here during migration are the more diminutive inhabitants of this SNA. Among these is the grizzled, gray-brown prairie vole, that has steadily declined in the state along with its grassland habitat. Their presence here is yet another signal of the value of preserving this prairie ecosystem. Research here has included studies comparing populations of small mammals on restored and remnant prairies, led by Professor Joseph Whittaker of Concordia College in conjunction with the Itasca Biological Station.

Management efforts in the SNA and the larger Twin Valley Prairie Preserve have included reclamation of a former gravel pit, restoration of former agricultural areas with native seed, and removal of woody vegetation in the interest of promoting habitat for grassland birds.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. Neal WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Karlstad 10.6 miles NE on MN Hwy 11, then 0.25 mile N on minimum maintenance road, just after Pauli Cemetery. Park on W road shoulder.

name: Two Rivers Aspen Parkland SNA
description:
"Two Rivers" is a reference to the Two Rivers River, a tributary of the Red River which—despite its name—has not two but three branches. This vast, 1400-acre SNA lies within a bend of the river's South Branch in Roseau County.

This SNA protects a landscape-sized aspen parkland remnant, with extensive areas of wet and wet-mesic brush prairie, shrubby wet meadow and aspen woodland. Subtle "swell and swale" topography runs north-northwest across the area from a prominent Lake Agassiz beach ridge located near the southern margin of the site along Minnesota Highway 11.

Brush prairie is the standout feature here. Major grasses are big bluestem, Indian grass, prairie dropseed, mat muhly, prairie cordgrass, northern reed grass, and bluejoint grass. Willows, bog birch, and shrubby cinquefoil dot the wet and wet-mesic brush prairie, while better drained areas support hazel, chokecherry, and serviceberry, along with scattered bur oak. Quaking aspen increases in density toward the southwest, where it forms an aspen woodland.

This SNA offers habitat for numerous rare plant and wildlife species, including Nelson's Sparrow, Yellow Rail, northern gentian and the Powesheik skipperling butterfly (listed as an endangered species at both state and federal levels).

As SNA specialist Tyler Janke describes in an article written for SNA Nature Notes management has focused on increasing the acreage of open grassland and brush relative to aspen woodlands, using aerial photos from the 1940s and 1950s as a guide. Prescribed burns, aspen girdling and brush mowing have all been employed toward this end. The goals, notes Janke, are: 1) to reduce encroaching woody cover by 25% by the year 2024, 2) re-establish a fire and disturbance regime, and 3) maintain a diverse parkland community. Partners in this ambitious effort have included The Nature Conservancy and Conservation Corps. Says Janke, "So far, the response has been very good, with prairie species recolonizing the girdled areas."

The rare Powesheik skipper butterfly presents unique management challenges. This species of the northern tallgrass prairie is very vulnerable to loss of habitat due to woodland encroachment. But the Powesheik is also sensitive to fire and mowing, which are primary tools used by managers to prevent invasion by woody vegetation. What to do? In this case, what is most efficient may not be what's needed for the survival of the species: a combination of smaller, patchy prescribed burns done in rotation and careful seasonal timing are considered key.

This SNA lies along the route of the Waters of the Dancing Sky Scenic Byway.

Read more about the Minnesota's Aspen Parklands in an article written by Nancy Sather and Robert Dana in the Minnesota Conservation Volunteer magazine.
notes: This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Zimmerman 5.4 miles W on Co Hwy 4, then 0.45 mile S on 168th St, then 1.25 miles W and S on forest road into Sand Dunes State Forest. Park in campground and hike S to site.
From Zimmerman 4.5 miles W on Co Hwy 4, then 2 miles S on Co Hwy 15 (164th St), then 0.8 mile W (pavement ends) on 245th Ave. Park in pull-off on N. Hike N and W into site.
From Zimmerman 4.5 miles W on Co Hwy 4, then 3.5 miles S on Co Hwy 15 (164th St), then 0.5 mile E on 233rd Ave. Park in pull-off on N and hike corridor N to site.

name: Uncas Dunes SNA
description:
This SNA is located within Sand Dunes State Forest in Sherburne County. It takes its name from the Uncas skipper, a member of the "banded skippers" (subfamily Hesperiinae) listed as an endangered species in Minnesota. Small and fast, this butterfly has a shape that's been compared to a fighter jet.

According to MBS ecologist Robert Dana, the only resident population of the Uncas Skipper known to have existed in Minnesota inhabited several dune areas in the Anoka Sand Plain, one of which is within this SNA. Numerous surveys documented the species' occurrence in this area from the 1960s through the late 80s, but it has not been reported in the state since that time.

The main range of this species reaches from the Dakotas westward, so Minnesota's population has always been thought of as outlier. Here, it demonstrated a close association with the sparsely vegetated environment of the dunes and—in particular—reliance on a grass called hairy grama (Bouteloua hirsuta), on which the females exclusively laid their eggs and the hatching larvae depended. Decline of this required dry grassland habitat may be a factor in the species apparent disappearance from the state in recent decades.

Also among this site's most ecologically significant natural features is a 223-acre dry barrens oak savanna, a native plant community with a state conservation ranking of imperiled to critically imperiled or (S1 to S2). This is a relatively open community, with total tree cover typically only 25-50%, and a sparse to patchy shrub layer. It is characterized by widely scattered bur and northern pin oak, with an understory of prairie grasses and wildflowers. Accordingly, management has focused on restoring and maintaining the open character of this community through prescribed burns and removal of encroaching woody vegetation, including planted pines not naturally occurring on the site.

The mosaic of native plant communities here also includes Southern dry mesic oak (maple) woodland, alder and tamarack swamps, sedge meadow, and a small (5-acre) fen.

This is one of Minnesota's most compelling natural landscapes, with stories of the past and present expressed in rolling dunes, rare butterflies and gnarled, open-grown oaks. Come in summer to see the classic plants of the dry barrens oak savanna in bloom: hairy puccoon and golden aster, Virginia ground cherry and silky prairie clover. Walk carefully near the dunes, which offer fragile habitat for seaside three-awn grass, annual skeleton-weed and creeping juniper. Consider, as you do, how the landscape might appear through the eyes of an Uncas Skipper.
notes: This site has hiking trails, see detail map. This site is in a Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area. Recreational facilities available in Sand Dunes State Forest.

parking.directions: From Donnelly 3.75 miles N on Co Hwy 9. Site on NE at Co Rd 76. Park on N road shoulder of Co Rd 76.

name: Verlyn Marth Memorial Prairie SNA
description:
"You could call it a 'postage stamp' prairie," notes SNA Program Regional Specialist Shelley Hedtke, "It's the last little remnant for miles in Stevens County."

Located in the gently rolling hills of the Fergus Falls till plain, this SNA was named after Verlyn Marth, a citizen known locally for his interest in botany and his advocacy for prairie protection. He had observed this site, with its two dry-mesic prairie knolls and its cattail marsh/sedge meadow, as it was used for pasture land during the 1930s and 40s. When he saw it being plowed and planted, he purchased the land to prevent further destruction. From then on, he worked to manage it as a prairie in an effort to restore it to its original condition.

One can appreciate what endures here as a result of his efforts. The side slopes bordering the ravine support the best prairie communities, with grasses little bluestem, Indian grass, switch grass, needle and thread and side oats grama. Characteristic flowering plants of the southern dry prairie here include hoary puccoon, narrow-leaved purple coneflower, stiff goldenrod, bird's foot coreopsis, bearded birdfoot violet and devil's tongue cacti (also called plains prickly pear cacti)—a special concern species in Minnesota.

Grassland bird species of particular interest documented on the SNA include the Upland Sandpiper, Short-eared Owl, Bobolink, Marbled Godwit, and a "grassland suite" of sparrow species: Le Conte's and Grasshopper and Nelson's Sparrow. By their presence, these birds are demonstrating what Verlyn Marth knew: that this piece of earth with its native prairie warranted protection.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Grand Rapids 12.75 miles N on MN Hwy 38, then 0.75 mile W on Co Hwy 19, then 0.5 mile S on Co Hwy 62. Park in lot on W.
From Grand Rapids 12.75 miles N on MN Hwy 38, then 1 mile W on Co Hwy 19. Park on N road shoulder near wood-routed sign.

name: Wabu Woods SNA
description:
Wabu Woods SNA is located in the lake-dotted landscape north of Grand Rapids, Minnesota . This land was donated to the DNR by The Nature Conservancy, which in turn had been gifted the property by its former owner, Abby Weed Grey.

The SNA consists of two main parcels on the northeast corner of Deer Lake, separated by less than half a mile as the crow flies. Generally hummocky terrain is punctuated by knolls and depressional wetlands. It is most remarkable for its mature, relatively undisturbed northern hardwood forest, with the highest quality forest concentrated in the more northerly of the two parcels.

The northern parcel hosts 32 acres mapped by the Minnesota Biological Survey as red oak – sugar maple – basswood forest, its diverse canopy interspersed with large white pines and an occasional yellow birch. Low-lying areas host pockets of alder swamp, ash swamp, and lowland white cedar forest.

The southern parcel is split by Highway 62 into two sections. The more westerly of these protects shoreline in a quiet bay of Deer Lake, bordered by lowland white cedar forest and sedge meadow. Numerous springs emerge from steep slopes, and large red and white pines occupy a ridge overlooking the lake. East of the highway is a somewhat richer hardwood forest, with 34 acres mapped as sugar maple – basswood forest, along with a small fen and conifer (tamarack/black spruce) swamp.

"The mix of forest communities at Wabu Woods is very representative of the area," says Regional SNA Specialist AmberBeth VanNingen, "which is actually a good thing to be able to say. That's an important role of SNAs, preserving quality examples of what's characteristic of a place, so that what you'd expect to be there is still there."

This Wabu Woods landscape is very familiar to Abby Marier and her husband, Don. Abby is the niece and namesake of Abby Weed Grey, who donated the land to The Nature Conservancy. As a child, she spent summers at her Aunt Abby's cabin, where she remembers blueberry picking, reading, and exploring Deer Lake by rowboat. Following her aunt's death in 1983, she and Don inherited a 5-acre property here, which they also chose to donate to the Conservancy to ensure its long term preservation. Abby and Don continue to visit the SNA, especially in summer, to enjoy the still-peaceful Deer Lake, pitcher plants in the bogs, the lush forest and opportunity to look for orchids, a particular interest of Don's.

This site was named Wabu Woods by Abby Grey, for reasons unknown. It may be a variation on waabooz, a word in the Ojibwe language that translates in English to snowshoe hare or rabbit, "but we don't know whether that was what she had in mind," says Don. "She was extremely well travelled, a poet, very creative, a person of many interests," says Abby of her aunt. In her lifetime, Abby Weed Grey became well known as a collector of international art and patron of cross-cultural programs for artists. She appreciated art that demanded, in her words, that she "perceive and understand reality in a deeper way." Here at Wabu Woods SNA, her preservation of this wild landscape allows us all to do just that.

Ownership & Origins: This site was a gift from The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: In Loman, from State Hwy 11, park in water access on N. Site is about 0.5 mile N on Black River, then 1 mile E on Rainy River. Accessible by boat.

name: Watrous Island SNA
description:
This site protects a pair of islands in the Rainy River on Minnesota's border with Canada. On the river's journey flowing west/northwest from International Falls, the SNA lies between two major tributaries: the Big Fork and the Black.

A standout feature of the site is its 44-acre Black Ash-Silver Maple Terrace forest, a community limited to islands and narrow bands along medium to large rivers. The terrace forest here is among the best documented to date in the ongoing survey of Koochiching County by the Minnesota Biological Survey (MBS). The SNA also hosts 5 acres of high quality sedge meadow and 16 acres of second-growth but maturing northern hardwood forest, with patchy aspen, black ash, bur oak, paper birch and balsam fir.

The islands take their name from early homesteader Charles Bouton (C.B.) Watrous, who first traveled here from Pennsylvania in 1895 seeking a site suitable for a saw mill. Acquiring land near the confluence of the Rainy and the Black River, he returned two years later to establish the mill.

It was a time of transition, when railroad expansion lessened the Rainy's use for navigational purposes and heightened its importance to the timber industry.
