In 1913, permits were approved for a boom operation in the river to transport downed trees for processing into lumber, wood, pulp and paper. This led to alterations such as dredging, straightening of channels, and closing of sloughs in the Rainy and its tributaries.

But in C.B. Watrous' first years here, the railroad reached only as far as Bemidji. He called upon a fellow Pennsylvanian, Philip Dewey, to assist with a 1902 log drive down the Big Fork River to the mill. Dewey's account of the experience offers a glimpse of the largely roadless landscape and the forest he would have a hand in changing: “To one who has never walked through an unbroken forest, there can be no adequate conception of its beauty and attractiveness. The great stillness, the impressiveness of such an enormous living commodity, the richness and perfection of it all, makes one stand in awe of its strength and gentleness.”

Today, visitors traveling to the SNA by boat will appreciate the mature terrace forest with its continuous canopy of silver maple, black and green ash. One can watch for bald eagles, listen for the cascading, ethereal call of the veery, and find a kingfisher perched near the water's edge. With its 10,000 feet of undeveloped shoreline, this site will only become more important over time in this popular waterway, helping to maintain water quality and habitat for wildlife ranging from wood ducks and nesting sandpipers to the Rainy's famous sturgeon.

From a conservation perspective, Watrous Island SNA is also notable for being the sole non-peatland SNA in this landscape, making it an important acquisition that helps fulfill the program's aim of protecting sites that reflect regional biodiversity.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The western end of the island is DNR Forestry administered land, and is open to the public.

parking.directions: From Floodwood 7 miles NW on US Hwy 2. Park in pull-off on N. Trek 1 mile NE along ditch into site. GPS recommended.

name: Wawina Peatland SNA
description:
The Wawina Peatland SNA lies in the shallow basin once occupied by Glacial Lake Upham. Ecologists call this area the Tamarack Lowlands: a region characterized by flat to gently rolling terrain, large rivers and abundant wetlands. While the SNA is not visible from the road, motorists who travel Highway 2 between Floodwood and Warba will be able to see the larger peatland complex of which it is a part.

The state owns no land here.* This SNA was created by statute in 1991 in recognition of its conservation value as Minnesota's southernmost example of a large patterned peatland. It contains a raised bog, featureless water track and well-developed ovoid (egg-shaped) islands.

Aerial views of this landscape tell a story. Roads, railways and ditching have all influenced the flow of water here, fragmenting what was once an integrated system. In a 2013 report on the Wawina peatlands, plant ecologist Scott Zager relates how ditching, in particular, degrades peatlands by lowering the water table. Woody vegetation invades and populations of sensitive, often rare, species may decline, replaced by species better able to tolerate the altered conditions.

The mapped peatland at Wawina is 4,070 acres, so it would seem to be sheltered from such impacts by virtue of its size. But peatlands are vulnerable to even small changes in water level and chemistry, so its future will continue to rely as much on what happens beyond its boundaries as within them.

Once viewed as wastelands, peatlands are now better recognized for their conservation value. Sharp-tailed Grouse are among the species that benefit from peatland protection here in the Tamarack Lowlands, utilizing habitat in open grass-brushland as well as bogs. In early spring, the males gather on a sparsely vegetated patch of ground known as a 'lek' to perform their foot-stamping, tail-vibrating courtship dance. With wings outspread and purple neck sacks inflated, they produce a resonant, cooing sound that echoes across Glacial Lake Upham's ancient bed. Clearly, the word 'wasteland' does not apply.

* Approximately 3420 acres of this 4070-acre site is public land, owned by St. Louis County. The remainder is privately owned.
notes: This site is owned mostly by St. Louis County, with some private ownership. While the state recognizes this as an ecologically significant site, it owns no land here. A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.
Snowmobiling on designated trail (Snowmobile Trail 305: Haggerman Voyager Lowman).

parking.directions: From International Falls 4 miles E on Co Hwy 24. Park at dead end and hike 0.1 mile E and S on logging trail, then trek 0.1 mile SE into site. GPS recommended.

name: West Rat Root River Peatland SNA
description:
This is one of two peatland SNAs on either side of the Rat Root River ("rat" referring to muskrat) that together encompass over 4300 acres. This wetland complex formed in the bed of Glacial Lake Agassiz which departed this part of its basin roughly 9,900 years ago. Primary peatland landforms here include a raised bog and featureless water track.

"Of the peatland SNAs, West Rat Root River Peatland is one of the easier sites to access," says AmberBeth VanNingen, SNA program Northeast Regional Specialist. "It's possible for someone to drive to the site and walk down into the peatland. What I appreciate here is that it feels like a classic peatland. You can see all the gradations, from upland forest with aspen birch and balsam fir; to wet forest with white cedar and ash, where the ground gets hummocky with persistent pools; then to forested rich peatland with scattered black spruce and tamarack, and sphagnum moss with ericaceous shrubs (leatherleaf, bog rosemary, Labrador tea). Finally, there is the open peatland with no trees, where large areas are dominated by sedges."

Getting to the boundary of this SNA is relatively easy, VanNingen cautions, but travel within the SNA presents the usual challenges that just come with peatland environments. Unless you go in winter, it's high waterproof boots or wet feet. Despite best efforts, the reality is often high boots with wet feet. "You might try in August when tends to be a little drier. A cloudy day helps with the heat, and a 20-30 mph wind keeps mosquitoes at bay. "Peatlands and mosquitoes," VanNingen says with a smile, "go together."

While impacted by ditching and fires, this site was protected in part for its potential value in comparative studies of peatland development.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is adjacent to Kabetogama State Forest.

parking.directions: From Rothsay 7 miles W on Co Hwy 26, then 2.5 miles N on Co Rd 165. Park in pull-off on E.

name: Western Prairie SNA
description:
If one wasn't already aware, the giant road-art figure in Rothsay makes it clear: this part of Minnesota is important to Greater Prairie Chickens. Native grasslands of the Glacial Lake Agassiz beach ridges and their intervening plains form the backbone of the species' primary range in the half dozen or so western counties (in particular, Norman, Clay, Polk and Wilkin) where the state's largest remnant populations still persist. Western Prairie SNA is one of two sites (the other being Richard M. & Mathilde Rice Elliot SNA). in Wilkin County acquired by The Nature Conservancy in the early 70s as part of a larger, regional effort to maintain appropriate habitat for the species.

One can still hear the resonant "boom" of male prairie chickens from their spring breeding grounds, called leks, in western and north-central Minnesota where appropriate grassland habitat remains. But, as noted on the webpage of the Minnesota Prairie Chicken Society, the birds face an uncertain future: "Much remains to be done to preserve critical lands in the present range to ensure the future of prairie chickens and other prairie life." Looking ahead, SNAs, wildlife management areas, state and federal conservation incentive programs, and land-use decisions by local private landowners will all play a necessary role.

This site is situated between two of Glacial Lake Agassiz' prominent beach ridges: the Lower Tintah and the Campbell. Minnesota Biological Survey plant ecologists have mapped its 320 acres as Saline Wet Prairie Complex, which is characterized by a combination of wet prairie (saline subtype), wet prairie, marsh, wet meadow and mesic prairie. An impressive diversity of native species has been documented here through the years, including many rare, state-listed species. These include Marbled godwit, Wilson's Phalarope, Nelson's Sparrow, regal fritillary butterfly, Northern gentian and small white lady's-slipper.

Western Prairie is part of a more than 8700-acre area known as the Salt Spring Lands or simply "the brines," which was given by the U.S. government to the state of Minnesota under the Land Grant Act of 1867 and sold shortly thereafter to raise funds for the University of Minnesota.

The saline nature of the soil is the result of the leaching of soluble ions (such as calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium, sulfate and chloride) by water into lower soil horizons and poorly drained areas. As described in a resource inventory completed for the SNA, some of these ions later precipitate out as salts, particularly calcium carbonate. These are especially concentrated along the southern part of the SNA, where one can see a whitish cast on the surface and an assembly of halophytic (salt-tolerant) plants such as salt grass, foxtail barley and Nuttall's alkali grass. The rare red saltwort (Salicornia rubra), was also reported to have been observed here in 1980, though its occurrence has not been confirmed by subsequent surveys or collection.

Visitors hoping to climb a tree to get their bearings here will be hard pressed. Cottonwoods grow along the larger, roadside ditches and willow thickets may be seen lining the smaller, interior ditches that cross the interior of the SNA. But for the most part, woody vegetation tends towards shrubs like the prairie rose, which don't offer much of a change in view. What you will find is a place of contrasts: look up to see the immensity of the sky and long views across the Lake Agassiz plains, look down for the many subtleties of the native prairie and the white blush of the brines. You are walking in a landscape where the male prairie chickens stamp and boom—each one larger, in its way, than the one in Rothsay.

Ownership & Origins: This site is owned by The Nature Conservancy.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area.

parking.directions: From Faribault 1.25 miles NW on Co Hwy 11, then 5.5 miles W on Co Hwy 38. Park in water access on S. Site is 0.5 mile S in Cedar Lake. Accessible by boat.

name: Whitney Island SNA
description:
Whitney Island SNA is a 42-acre island located in Cedar Lake, west of the city of Faribault. The Minnesota County Biological Survey mapped this site as part of its 1990-92 inventory of Rice County, documenting mature maple-basswood forest with large diameter trees, some over 160 years old. Loamy, moist soil and protection from fire has fostered the growth of this remnant "Big Woods" forest, a native plant community that once comprised 30% of the county's native vegetation.

Those who wander here will find a complex of knolls and shallow depressions associated with the Emmons-Faribault Moraine. Interior lowlands contain emergent marsh communities, while the fluctuating water levels along the shore favor the black willow, cottonwood, green ash, silver maple, and box elder of a floodplain forest. Areas of gravel cobble beach with naturally vegetated, undeveloped shoreline benefit the fishery in the lake and provide feeding areas for herons, egrets, spotted sandpiper and waterfowl.

Woody invasive species, including buckthorn, present a stewardship challenge here. The island is now uninhabited, but there remain signs of past land use, including the rocks of an old cabin foundation atop a knoll, and locals report that cows were once brought out by barge for grazing.

Still, the island is largely undisturbed, a rare and lovely refuge that on any given spring morning is filled with birdsong. Listen for the chatter-rattle of a kingfisher near the lakeshore and the trills of cedar waxwings feeding high in the branches of massive hackberry trees; check the skies for circling osprey, or find a quiet spot to wait and watch for the blue flash of an indigo bunting.

Ownership & Origins: Whitney Island SNA is named to honor the donor family's long involvement with the site.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

parking.directions: From Brownsdale 2 miles E on Co Hwy 2, then 0.35 mile S on Co Hwy 19 (610th Ave). Park in lot on W.
In Dexter 0.25 mile W from corner of Main St (Co Hwy 7) and Front St. Park in lot on S as road turns N.
From Brownsdale 2.25 miles W on Co Hwy 2, then 1.4 miles S on Co Hwy 16 (570th Ave). Park in lot on W.

name: Wild Indigo SNA
description:
Nature and culture meet in this 12.5-mile long SNA aligned along an abandoned railroad corridor in the Oak Savanna ecological subsection. One of the finest examples of mesic tallgrass prairie left in southeastern Minnesota persists here because a railroad right of way prevented its cultivation. Management associated with the active railroad—namely, cutting of woody vegetation and prescribed burning—also served to sustain the prairie for more than 100 years, as did the unintentional wildfires caused by trains.

This segment of railway was built in 1870 by the Milwaukee Railroad,* one of the earliest to operate in the state. When the railroad was finally abandoned in 1979, the state was able to purchase the strip of land. By 1980 it was officially designated an SNA.

The high preservation value of this land is due to its nearly 100 acres of Southern Mesic Prairie: a native plant community ranked as S2, or imperiled, in Minnesota. Over 340 native plant species occur here, including rare/listed species protected within only a few managed areas of the state. This is an important site for wild quinine and Indian plantain, (both endangered in Minnesota) as well as Sullivant's milkweed and valerian (both threatened in Minnesota). The SNA is named for two state-listed special concern species in the Baptisia genus: plains wild indigo and white wild indigo. Watch for the cream to yellow flowers of the shrub-like plains wild indigo blooming as early as May and into June. Peak bloom time for the white wild indigo is a little later, in June/July, when its tall stalk laden with showy white flowers can be seen rising as high as 6 feet. Both are pollenated by bumble bees.

The configuration of this SNA presents interesting challenges for management, with a high ratio of boundary to interior space, road crossings and many adjacent landowners. For planning purposes, the site is divided into separate management units with strategies tailored to the unique needs and conditions of each unit. Prescribed burns are a primary management tool, along with restoration of the disturbed shoulders on either side of the former rail bed. Volunteer Site Steward Trevor Bordelon has actively participated in restoration efforts by collecting seed from within the SNA's native prairie remnants for reseeding of degraded areas.

As photographer Dale Bohlke's stunning images displayed on this web page show, Wild Indigo SNA offers a wonderful opportunity to discover a diversity of prairie wildflowers. If you visit, please consider helping to minimize spread of invasive species at this important site by brushing shoe/boot treads clean prior to setting out for your walk. Use your own brush, or note the boot brushes installed on entry signs at the two more westerly parking areas for this SNA.

* Later, the Chicago Milwaukee St. Paul and Pacific Railroad
notes: A primitive hiking trail follows the former railroad grade though site. Ramsey Mill Pond WMA is adjacent to this site.

restrictions: All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Roosevelt 1.8 miles W on Co Rd 2 (280th St), then 7.6 miles S on Roosevelt-Norris Forest Rd. Park on W road shoulder at ditch crossing. Hike N on road, then W into site. GPS recommended.

name: Winter Road Lake Peatland SNA
description:
Narrow and long, the Winter Road Lake Peatland snakes west to east across Lake of the Woods County for over eleven miles. As aerial photos beautifully convey, this site displays water tracks with well-developed ribbed fen patterns. Note the "strings" (peat ridges) and "flarks" (pools) oriented perpendicular to the water flow. The SNA also contains a raised bog.

Part of the internationally significant Glacial Lake Agassiz Peatlands, this site offers important habitat to species such as the Short-eared Owl, Nelson's Sparrow , Yellow Rail (all Minnesota-special concern). Several peatland specialist butterflies are found here, including the dorcas copper, frigga fritillary and red-disked alpine.

The well-maintained Roosevelt-Norris State Forest Road crosses part of the SNA, providing a level of access uncommon in the state's peatland SNAs. WMA area manager Gretchen Mehmel suggests paying careful attention even if just passing through: "When young Short-eared Owls have fledged, we'll often see them out on the road."

Due in part to its relative accessibility, Winter Road Lake Peatland has been widely studied. DNR Hydrogeologist Michele Walker is manager of a long term research project here investigating the impact of drainage ditches on peatland hydrology and habitat. As part of the study, researchers have established vegetation plots at various distances from ditches and are documenting changes over time.

According to Walker, the monitoring is already offering insights. "I was surprised to find that the ditches were still effective at draining the peatland. They were constructed in the early 1900's and, to my knowledge, never maintained. I thought they would have filled in over time and by now would be minimally impacting the peatland. However, my research shows that in spite of the lack of maintenance and the large number of beaver dams, the ditches are still draining the peatland."

She makes clear that this monitoring is just a first step. "The study was constructed to understand the baseline conditions in the peatland and SNA; how the hydrology and vegetation function right now. Ultimately, the goal is to restore the peatland and improve the habitat there. Knowing where we started and where we end in any restoration efforts will tell us how successful the restoration is." Long term, it is hoped that strategies developed here will be applicable to restoration of the state's other ecologically-significant peatlands.
notes: A GPS and detailed topographical maps are advised to visit this site. This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. This site is in an Audubon Important Bird Area. This site is within Beltrami Island State Forest.

parking.directions: From Long Lake 0.5 mile N on Brown Rd to Co Hwy 6. Cross 6 and park in the NE corner of Trinity Lutheran Church parking lot.

name: Wolsfeld Woods SNA
description:
Designated in 1978, Wolsfeld Woods was among the first of Minnesota's Scientific and Natural Areas. It was acquired to protect one the best remaining examples of the Big Woods forest community in the state. The site's hilly topography can be credited at least in part with the survival of the forest here. Early homesteaders found it impractical to till for farming, opting instead to establish a maple syruping operation that continued from the 1880s into the 1940s.

Mature maple-basswood forest dominates the SNA, with some of the state's largest individual sugar maple trees. The site also hosts areas of oak forest and emergent marsh. Permanent and intermittent streams have carved meandering valleys through the rolling terrain.

All but the northwest corner of 35-acre Wolsfeld Lake lies within the SNA. Researchers have used lakebed sediments (including pollen) to reconstruct the area's environmental history. Studies by U of MN researcher Eric Grimm and colleagues indicates that 12,000 years ago this site was characterized by spruce forest. As the climate grew warmer and drier, conifers were gradually replaced by deciduous forest and then by prairie. Prairie persisted until about 5000 years ago, when a return to cooler/wetter climate fostered a transition to oak savanna and oak forest. This, in turn, was replaced by maple-basswood forest within in the last 500 years.

This is a much-loved, much visited SNA located in a growing metropolitan community. Local residents organized as "Friends of Wolsfeld Woods" host regular guided events for all ages focused on birding, bats, wildflowers, mushrooms and other natural features of the site. The group also engages the community in periodic buckthorn pulls, providing the muscle to help control this invasive species.

Liz Weir is an active member of this Friends group and invites others to enjoy the site and participate in its stewardship. Notes Weir, "I believe what people most love about the site is its relatively unspoiled beauty and, for me, its ancient tug to the conscience of how this part of Minnesota once looked, before our pioneer ancestors arrived to clear the forest cover for farming."

Ownership & Origins: The Nature Conservancy assisted in the protection of this site.
notes: This site has hiking trails, see detail map (dogs are not permitted). This site is in a Watchable Wildlife Viewing Area.

restrictions: Biking on designated trail (Luce Line State Trail).

parking.directions: From downtown Long Lake 1.25 miles E on Wayzata Blvd, then continue 0.25 mile E on Old Long Lake Rd. Park in lot on S. Hike E along road to trails.

name: Wood-Rill SNA
description:
Wood-Rill SNA preserves an outstanding example of Sugar Maple "Big Woods" forest. This forest type is ranked S2, or imperiled, in the state and is increasingly rare in the developing metro-area.

According to University of Minnesota Forest Ecologist Lee Frelich, individual trees in Wood-Rill range from seedlings to 350 years old, with many trees between 120-180 years old. The oldest trees that Frelich has core-dated are sugar maples. "But none of the trees are as old as the forest," he notes. "Analysis of data from pond sediment indicates that the big woods forest community replaced oak savanna at this site about the year 1300 AD. That tells us that the big woods forest here is roughly 700 years old."

Uplands host a closed-canopy forest of trees over 90 feet tall, the largest with diameters of nearly 3 feet at breast height. Dominant canopy trees included red oak, basswood, sugar maple and white oak. In the more poorly drained lowlands, the dominant trees are red maple, black ash, hackberry, basswood and green ash. Large, downed trees are scattered on the forest floor in various stages of decay. The occasional gap created in the canopy by one of these fallen giants is soon filled by young maples that reach for the light.

The steep hills here reflect the topography of the St. Croix moraine, legacy of the glacial era that also left behind small ice-block depressions now filled with a pond, sedge meadows, and a black ash swamp* on the site's western perimeter. A tiny tamarack swamp (1.27 acres) is like a jewel, carpeted in sphagnum moss and hosting cranberries and wintergreen. Rare species documented here have included butternut (endangered in Minnesota) and Red-shouldered Hawk (special concern in Minnesota).

In the Winter 2015 issue of SNA Nature Notes, retired SNA Program Supervisor Bob Djupstrom tells the story of the gifting of this site to the state by Bruce and Ruth Dayton. After acquiring the land bit by bit over decades, the Dayton's secured the last remaining inholdings and removed any structures on the land. Later, they helped support reforestation of the resulting clearings, as well as exclosures used to study effects of deer and earthworms on ground-layer species.

As Djupstrom relates, the name given to this natural area by the Daytons—Wood-Rill—originates in a line of poetry by Wordsworth, a rill being a brook or small stream: "His daily teachers had been woods and rills/ The silence that is in the starry sky/The sleep that is among the lonely hills."

Thanks to the Daytons, we can all be students of these woods and rills. Walk here in early spring to find wildflowers including bloodroot, nodding trillium, Virginia waterleaf, jack-in-the-pulpit and rue anemone. In summer, as the big woods forest drops into shade, find the forest floor blanketed in ferns, with northern lady fern and maidenhair ferns, spinulose wood fern and ostrich fern. In any season, there is something to be learned here from the old trees and from the forest, older still.

* Black ash - Yellow Birch – Red Maple – Alder Swamp.

Ownership & Origins: The majority of the site was a gift from Bruce and Ruth Dayton.
notes: This site has hiking trails, see detail map.

parking.directions: From Spring Valley 5 miles NE on Co Hwy 8, then about 0.8 mile SE on Good Earth Village entrance road. Please ask permission at the office to park, then hike S into site. Restricted entry, see details above.

name: Wykoff Balsam Fir SNA
description:
Wykoff Balsam Fir SNA is located in southeastern Minnesota's Driftless Area, a region of high topographic relief that escaped the scouring effects of the most recent (Wisconsin) glaciation and its overburden of till. Limestone or dolomite bedrock tends to be at or near the surface, often deeply dissected by streams. Surface water and groundwater interact relatively freely through sinkholes and fissures in the bedrock. This has a down side, in that groundwater is highly sensitive to surface contaminants. Yet it also has an upside: these hydro-geologic conditions support rare and fascinating assemblies of plant and animal life.

The boundaries of this SNA seem curious, until one realizes that they follow the meandering route of Spring Valley Creek. It is here, in the creek's narrow, shade-filled valley, that globally-imperiled algific talus communities have been documented.

Algific, from the Latin, means "to make cold." Typically associated with steep, north-facing slopes, algific talus communities are characterized by a kind of natural air conditioning. Air flows through deep fissures in the bedrock, cooled by winter ice that can persist long into the growing season. Temperatures in the vicinity of an algific talus slope may remain at 40-60 degrees Fahrenheit through the hottest days of summer.

This cool, moist micro-habitat provides a refuge for plant species typically found much farther north, surviving here as relic populations from historically colder periods. Long gone from the surrounding landscape, stands of balsam fir rise here from shady slopes. This is one of Minnesota's only documented refugia for Iowa golden saxifrage, generally considered an arctic/alpine species.

At 151 acres, this is among the larger SNAs in this part of the state, and one of the few characterized by continuous forest cover. White pines crown the ridge tops. The rolling hills are covered in red and white oak, sugar maple, even a few shagbark hickory. This block of hardwood forest with its diverse understory adds to the ecological significance of the site.

Recommended access to this SNA is via the privately-owned Good Earth Village near Wykoff, with permission required from the office to park. The Good Earth Village property abuts the SNA land on its northern perimeter and offers winding trails with views of the landscape and Spring Valley Creek below. In planning your visit, please familiarize yourself with the parts of this SNA that are designated and marked as Sanctuary areas. These are closed to visitors except by research permit because they contain sensitive natural features vulnerable to erosion. Thank you for helping to protect these areas.
notes:
Sanctuary (posted sanctuary portions closed). This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

Parking to access Wykoff Balsam Fir SNA at Good Earth Village is very limited mid-June to mid-August due to summer programming.

restrictions: Dogs (only when used for hunting, must be under control).
All hunting allowed, see the regulations handbook for hunting details.

parking.directions: From Nassau 1 mile E on Co Hwy 24, then 0.35 mile S on Co Hwy 7. Park in gated pull-off on W.

name: Yellow Bank Hills SNA
description:
It's true the hills here are yellow-gold with prairie grasses for much of the year. But like the township in which it is located, this SNA takes its name from the Yellow Bank River, which flows nearby, bound for Big Stone Lake. According to an 1882 report by then state geologist N.H. Winchell, “yellow bank” refers to the yellowish glacial drift exposed by the river along newly eroded bluffs. Geologist Carrie Jennings, who has done extensive work in this region, notes that the till exposed in the river (like the surface till of the Des Moines lobe and older tills in the area) is typically dark gray initially but oxidizes to a yellowish brown over time.

Jennings describes this prominence as part of “a linear string of sand and gravel hills representing the former course of a glacial stream that was once supported by ice, most likely at or near the ice margin.” When the ice melted, material in the streambed was left deposited on the land, its steep sides showing the angle of repose.

This site was acquired for SNA designation to protect the high quality remnant of dry sand-gravel prairie on its upper slopes. It hosts four state-listed rare species that occur in Minnesota at the extreme eastern edge of their range: Missouri milkvetch, yellow prairie violet, cut-leaf ironplant, and soft goldenrod. The prairie vole also makes its home here. This grizzled little gray mammal is a state-listed special concern species, having been generally replaced by the meadow vole in areas where land has been converted from prairie to agricultural use.

A short climb brings one to the hilltop ridge, roughly (50+) feet in local relief. The native plants of the dry prairie here are well-adapted to the exposed conditions and droughty, excessively drained soils on the steep slopes. Find little bluestem, Wilcoxian's panic grass, blue grama grass, dotted blazing star, and needle-and-thread grass with its barbed, twisted awn that disperses seeds by hitching a ride on whatever (or whomever) passes by. Below is Pegg Lake. A small stretch of its shoreline lies within the SNA.

While it may appear deceptively simple, even impoverished, this landscape is rich in many ways, from the finely structured native plants of the dry prairie, to its variety of insect life (13 species of dragonflies and damselflies were documented in a one-day survey in 2019, seven of which were first records in the county), to grassland bird species such as the Western meadowlark, dickcissel and bobolink. Peg Lake adds another dimension for birds and thus, birders, offering a good vantage point to see yellow-headed blackbirds, sedge wrens and the migrating waterfowl that pass through in spring and fall.

One of the most ever-present, dominant natural features here is tough to fully convey in words or in a photograph: wind gusting strong and steady from the west across the plains. Like the dry hills, it was instrumental in the region's fire history, part of the dynamic that sustained and continues to sustain the prairie.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities.

restrictions: Deer hunting only allowed (only anlerless by permit), see the regulations handbook for hunting details. Varies year to year, check current regulations handbook for information.

parking.directions: From Zumbro Falls 1.75 miles S on US Hwy 63, then 1 mile E on 605th St to dead end. Continue through farm yard. Park in lot E of home and hike E into site.
From Zumbro Falls 0.5 mile E on MN Hwy 60, then 1 mile S on 371st Ave. Park in lot on E. Hike corridor 0.35 mile E and S into woods of site.

name: Zumbro Falls Woods SNA
description:
This SNA straddles the Lower Zumbro River between the communities of Zumbro Falls and Hammond in Wabasha County. The river here is in its final stretch: its three forks—which drain a watershed of 1,422 square miles—have joined into a single main stem that meanders its way toward confluence with the Mississippi near Kellogg.

The Zumbro's watershed is characterized by Paleozoic-era bedrock, and exposures of Cambrian-age sandstones, shale and dolomites may be seen along the eastern part of the river valley in Wabasha County. Within the SNA, canoeists and kayakers will encounter the landmark of Wall Rock, a sheer cliff that towers 200 feet above the water at a bend in the river.

Southern mesic hardwood forest dominates the SNA, with its canopy of oak, basswood and maple. Along the river is a terrace forest—periodically subject to flooding—with silver maple, green ash, cottonwood and elm. Higher and drier areas host comparatively more open, fire-dependent communities, including oak-shagbark hickory woodland and sand-gravel prairie, while the vertical faces of bedrock exposures provide habitat for a unique community of plants and wildlife.

Spring brings spectacular displays of bluebells under the basswood stands along the river. Wild ginger, trilliums, and hepatica bloom in the woodlands, and jeweled shooting star—a species confined to cliffs and rocky woods in Minnesota's Paleozoic Plateau—is seen here in abundance.

The forest and riverine habitats protected here in their natural, undisturbed condition make an important contribution to the biodiversity of the region as a whole. If visiting, please take care not to disturb riparian forest, stream banks and sandbars, which are both fragile and especially important to wildlife such as nesting turtles and feeding sandpipers.

Management attention has focused on reconstructing prairie and savanna in areas converted to old field and pine plantation, using native seed collected from local sources. Other activities have included cutting of invasive species (buckthorn and honeysuckle), and use of prescribed burns to prevent/reduce woody encroachment.

Those who would like to better understand the context of this site will find a wealth of information (including oral history interviews) in "The Environmental History of the Zumbro River Watershed: An Annotated Bibliography," by Greg Gaut, Janet Timmerman and Kevin Strauss, a product of the Zumbro Watershed Partnership and Olmstead County. Timmerman lived for a time on the Zumbro and kayaked its branches. "Environmental histories offer the modern world a base line for making decisions about a place." she writes. "Whether those decisions are political, economic, social or cultural, knowing the dynamics of the environment is critical. We shape, and are shaped by, the particular environment we inhabit. Though the Zumbro is in places an artificial channel, it still retains a wild nature."

Ownership & Origins: A portion of this site was a gift from Robert and Kathe Yoss.
notes: This site has no maintained trails or other recreational facilities. The Zumbro River Water Trail passes through this site.
